Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: FDJ, LLC v. Determan
Court: Supreme Court of South Dakota.
Headnote: There are six factors to consider when determining whether equity demands a disregard of the corporate entity: (1) undercapitalization; (2) failure to observe corporate formalities; (3) absence of corporate records; (4) payment by the corporation of individual obligations; (5) fraudulent misrepresentation by corporate directors; and (6) use of the corporation to promote fraud, injustice or illegality.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Limited Liability Companies. Individual members of LLC were not jointly and severally liable for LLC's breach of purchase agreement with business owner.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: In re Kwok
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, D. Connecticut.
Headnote: Under Delaware law, several factors are considered when considering whether alleged alter ego asserts dominion and control over corporate entity, including (1) whether company was adequately capitalized for undertaking, (2) whether company was solvent, (3) whether corporate formalities were observed, (4) whether dominant shareholder siphoned company funds, and (5) whether, in general, company simply functioned as facade for dominant shareholder; none of these factors is dispositive in determining dominion and control.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY  Bankruptcy Estate. Chapter 11 bankruptcy trustee had standing to bring turnover claim on behalf of creditors at large.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: In re Kwok
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, D. Connecticut.
Headnote: In considering whether to reverse pierce corporate veil, courts consider traditional factors Delaware courts consider when reviewing traditional veil-piercing claim, as well as additional factors reflecting concern that creditors and other stakeholders of entity might have their legitimate expectations thwarted.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY  Bankruptcy Estate. Chapter 11 bankruptcy trustee had standing to bring turnover claim on behalf of creditors at large.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: Louis Monteleone Fibres, Ltd. v. Hudson Baylor Brookhaven, LLC
Court: Supreme Court, Appellate Division, Second Department, New York.
Headnote: Factors to be considered in determining whether individual has abused privilege of doing business in corporate or limited liability company (LLC) form to pierce the corporate veil include failure to adhere to corporate or LLC formalities, inadequate capitalization, commingling of assets, and personal use of corporate or LLC funds.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Piercing Corporate Veil. Waste-paper broker sufficiently alleged facts to support claim to pierce corporate veil of LLCs to hold its members personally liable.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: Wells Fargo Bank, N.A. v. Stewart Homes, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, C.D. California.
Headnote: Under California law, no single factor is determinative in determining whether a party is the alter ego of a corporation, and instead a court must examine all the circumstances to determine whether to apply the alter ego doctrine.
Document Preview: FINANCE AND BANKING  Attachment and Garnishment. Bank demonstrated probable validity of fraudulent transfer claim under California law, as required to issue writ of attachment.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: Brightstar LLC v. Jordan
Court: Colorado Court of Appeals, Division I.
Headnote: The alter ego element of a piercing-the-corporate-veil analysis entails consideration of several factors, including whether (1) the entity is operated as a distinct business entity; (2) funds and assets are commingled; (3) adequate business records are maintained; (4) the nature and form of the entity's ownership and control facilitate misuse by an insider; (5) the entity is used as a "mere shell"; (6) the entity is thinly capitalized; (7) legal formalities are disregarded; and (8) the entity's funds or assets are used for non-business purposes.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Arbitration. Arbitrator did not exhibit partiality against defendants by rolling his eyes or shaking his head in response to a witness evading questions.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: Ene v. Graham
Court: Supreme Court of Nevada.
Headnote: The following factors, though not conclusive, may indicate the existence of an alter ego relationship: (1) commingling of funds; (2) under-capitalization; (3) unauthorized diversion of funds; (4) treatment of corporate assets as the individual's own; and (5) failure to observe corporate formalities.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Limited Liability Companies. Evidence that LLC's single member occasionally used LLC's property for personal enjoyment did not support alter ego determination.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: New Hackensack Realty, LLC v. Lawrence Development Realty, LLC
Court: Supreme Court, Appellate Division, Second Department, New York.
Headnote: Factors which a court considers in determining whether the owner of a corporation has abused the privilege of doing business in the corporate form, as required to pierce the corporate veil, include whether there was a failure to adhere to corporate formalities, inadequate capitalization, commingling of assets, and use of corporate funds for personal use.
Document Preview: REAL PROPERTY  Fraudulent Conveyances. Purchasers of commercial property could not maintain claim against seller for unjust enrichment where there was valid contract between parties covering dispute.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: Sikousis Legacy, Inc. v. B-Gas Limited
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Ninth Circuit.
Headnote: To pierce corporate veil, party must show that (1) controlling corporate entity exercises total domination of subservient corporation, to extent that subservient corporation manifests no separate corporate interests of its own, (2) injustice will result from recognizing subservient entity as separate entity, and (3) controlling entity had fraudulent intent or intent to circumvent statutory or contractual obligations.
Document Preview: MARITIME LAW  Attachment. Probable cause to believe that plaintiff would prevail on merits of its attachment claim applied to determine whether to continue attachment.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: Sikousis Legacy, Inc. v. B-Gas Limited
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Ninth Circuit.
Headnote: In determining whether to pierce corporate veil, courts must look to totality of record and circumstances to determine whether domination, injustice, and ill intent are satisfied.
Document Preview: MARITIME LAW  Attachment. Probable cause to believe that plaintiff would prevail on merits of its attachment claim applied to determine whether to continue attachment.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: Boulder Falcon, LLC v. Brown
Court: United States District Court, D. Utah.
Headnote: Under Utah law, nonexhaustive factors to be considered in determining whether to pierce the corporate veil are: (1) undercapitalization of a one-man corporation; (2) failure to observe corporate formalities; (3) nonpayment of dividends; (4) siphoning of corporate funds by the dominant stockholder; (5) nonfunctioning of other officers or directors; (6) absence of corporate records; (7) the use of the corporation as a facade for operations of the dominant stockholder or stockholders; and (8) the use of the corporate entity in promoting injustice or fraud.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW  Contracts. Genuine disputes of material fact precluded summary judgment in favor of defendants on LLC's claim for breach of contract under Georgia law.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: SonicSolutions Algae Control, LLC v. Diversified Power International, LLC
Court: United States District Court, D. Massachusetts.
Headnote: Under Tennessee law, courts consider the following factors in determining whether to disregard a corporation's separate legal identity: (1) whether there was a failure to collect paid in capital; (2) whether the corporation was grossly undercapitalized; (3) the non-issuance of stock certificates; (4) the sole ownership of stock by one individual; (5) the use of the same office or business location; (6) the employment of the same employees or attorneys; (7) the use of the corporation as an instrumentality or business conduit for an individual or another corporation; (8) the diversion of corporate assets by or to a stockholder or other entity to the detriment of creditors, or the manipulation of assets and liabilities in another; (9) the use of the corporation as a subterfuge in illegal transactions; (10) the formation and use of the corporation to transfer to it the existing liability of another person or entity; and (11) the failure to maintain arms length relationships among related entities.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW  Implied Contracts. Genuine issues of material fact existed as to whether implied-in-fact contract existed between distributor and manufacturer under Massachusetts law.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: SonicSolutions Algae Control, LLC v. Diversified Power International, LLC
Court: United States District Court, D. Massachusetts.
Headnote: Under Tennessee law, no single factor among those for determining whether to disregard a corporation's separate legal identity is conclusive, nor is it required that all such factors support piercing the corporate veil; typically, courts will rely on a combination of the factors in deciding the issue.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW  Implied Contracts. Genuine issues of material fact existed as to whether implied-in-fact contract existed between distributor and manufacturer under Massachusetts law.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: Wurtzebach v. Flooring Depot FTL, Inc.
Court: District Court of Appeal of Florida, Fourth District.
Headnote: To pierce a corporate veil, a plaintiff must prove each of the following three factors: (1) the shareholder dominated the corporation to such an extent that the corporation had no independent existence and the shareholder was the alter ego of the corporation; (2) the corporate form was used fraudulently or for an improper purpose; and (3) the claimant was injured as a result.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW  Fraudulent Transfers. Res judicata did not bar creditors' fraudulent transfer claim in supplemental proceedings against debtor corporation's principal and his daughter.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: Societe Financial, LLC v. MJ Corporation
Court: Supreme Court of Alaska.
Headnote: Factors for evaluating whether to impose personal liability on a shareholder under the alter ego/mere instrumentality standard include (1) whether the shareholder sought to be charged owns all or most of the stock of the corporation, (2) whether the shareholder has subscribed to all of the capital stock of the corporation or otherwise caused its incorporation, (3) whether the corporation has grossly inadequate capital, (4) whether the shareholder uses the property of the corporation as his own, (5) whether the directors or executives of the corporation act independently in the interest of the corporation or simply take their orders from the shareholder in the latter's interest, and (6) whether the formal legal requirements of the corporation are observed; it is not necessary for all six factors to be satisfied before instrumentality can be found.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW  Contracts. Alleged self-serving affidavit was sufficient to create a genuine issue of material fact that precluded summary judgment on breach of contract claim.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: Mohawk Construction and Supply Company, Inc. v. Walsh/Consigli JV
Court: Supreme Court, Appellate Division, Second Department, New York.
Headnote: In determining whether an individual or another corporation constitutes an alter ego, as required to pierce the corporate veil, a reviewing court must look for overlap in ownership, officers, directors, and personnel, inadequate capitalization, a commingling of assets, or an absence of separate paraphernalia that are part of the corporate form, such that one of the corporations is a mere instrumentality, agent, and alter ego of the other.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW  Contracts. Limited liability company and company related to joint venture were not liable for breach of subcontract between joint venture and subcontractor.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: In re Dravo LLC
Court: Superior Court of Pennsylvania.
Headnote: Although all factors involving undercapitalization, failure to adhere to corporate formalities, substantial intermingling of corporate and personal affairs, and use of the corporate form to perpetrate a fraud may not be needed or relevant in each veil piercing case, courts may still look to those factors, and the cases that apply them, for guidance when determining whether to pierce corporate veil based on showing that separate personalities of corporation and the individual no longer exist due to unity of interest and ownership and that adherence to corporate fiction under the circumstances would sanction fraud or promote injustice.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Piercing Corporate Veil. Factual questions precluded summary judgment for parent corporation of dissolved asbestos products company.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: Kalkey v. Euromodas, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, D. Puerto Rico.
Headnote: Indicia of misuse of corporate form, supporting piercing of corporate veil to impose liability on shareholders, include: (1) shareholders' failure to observe corporate formalities; (2) absence of corporate records; (3) non-functioning officers or directors; (4) inadequate capitalization in light of the purposes for which the corporation was organized; (5) intermingling of the corporation's properties or accounts with those of the owner; and (6) siphoning of funds from the corporation; no one of these factors is either necessary or sufficient to disregard corporate structure.
Document Preview: LABOR AND EMPLOYMENT  Hours and Wages. Employee sufficiently alleged that defendants exerted extensive or pervasive control over entities, for purposes of individual liability under FLSA.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: Brummett v. Bailey
Court: Court of Appeals of Indiana.
Headnote: When determining whether a shareholder is liable for corporate acts through piercing the corporate veil, a court's considerations may include: (1) undercapitalization of the corporation, (2) the absence of corporate records, (3) fraudulent representations by corporation shareholders or directors, (4) use of the corporation to promote fraud, injustice, or illegal activities, (5) payment by the corporation of individual obligations, (6) commingling of assets and affairs, (7) failure to observe required corporate formalities, and (8) other shareholder acts or conduct ignoring, controlling, or manipulating the corporate form.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Piercing Corporate Veil. Piercing corporate veil was not warranted to find bar's owner and former owner personally liable for alleged assault on patron.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: Barsoum v. Kinderhook Industries, LLC
Court: United States District Court, D. Massachusetts.
Headnote: In applying corporate veil-piercing analysis, Massachusetts courts endorse a 12-factor approach, the relevant factors including: (1) common ownership; (2) pervasive control; (3) confused intermingling of business assets; (4) thin capitalization; (5) nonobservance of corporate formalities; (6) absence of corporate records; (7) no payment of dividends; (8) insolvency at the time of the litigated transaction; (9) siphoning away of corporation's funds by dominant shareholder; (10) nonfunctioning of officers and directors; (11) use of the corporation for transactions of the dominant shareholders; and (12) use of the corporation in promoting fraud.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Piercing Corporate Veil. Employee failed to adequately allege principal-agent relationship between subsidiary and parent company or former parent under Massachusetts law.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: Groth v. Ferrante
Court: Supreme Court, Appellate Division, Second Department, New York.
Headnote: Factors to consider in determining whether an individual has abused the corporate form, as an element for piercing the corporate veil, include failure to adhere to corporate formalities, inadequate capitalization, commingling of assets, and personal use of corporate funds.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Piercing Corporate Veil. Piercing corporate veil of judgment debtor to reach shareholders was not warranted in judgment creditors' action seeking to enforce default judgment.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: Paul v. Bathurst
Court: Supreme Court of South Dakota.
Headnote: There are six factors to consider when determining whether equity demands a disregard of the corporate entity: (1) undercapitalization; (2) failure to observe corporate formalities; (3) absence of corporate records; (4) payment by the corporation of individual obligations; (5) fraudulent misrepresentation by corporate directors; and (6) use of the corporation to promote fraud, injustice or illegality.
Document Preview: LABOR AND EMPLOYMENT  Independent Contractors. Whether ranch manager was an employee or independent contractor, for statute of limitation purposes, could not be resolved on motion to dismiss.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: Paul v. Bathurst
Court: Supreme Court of South Dakota.
Headnote: The six factors to consider when determining whether to pierce the corporate veil can be grouped into two separate prongs: the "separate corporate identity" prong and the "fraud or inequitable consequences" prong; if the four factors under the "separate corporate identity" prong are present in sufficient number and/or degree, then the court will consider the two factors under the "fraud or inequitable consequences" prong.
Document Preview: LABOR AND EMPLOYMENT  Independent Contractors. Whether ranch manager was an employee or independent contractor, for statute of limitation purposes, could not be resolved on motion to dismiss.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: Archival, Inc. v. 177 Realty Corp.
Court: Supreme Court, Appellate Division, Second Department, New York.
Headnote: Factors to be considered in determining whether individual against whom doctrine of piercing corporate veil is asserted has abused privilege of doing business in corporate or limited liability company (LLC) form, as necessary for party seeking to pierce corporate veil to survive motion to dismiss complaint, include failure to adhere to corporate or LLC formalities, inadequate capitalization, commingling of assets, and personal use of corporate or LLC funds.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Piercing Corporate Veil. Property purchaser, which sought to pierce corporate veil, adequately pleaded seller's members, owners, and/or shareholders dominated purchaser.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: Kaplan Group Investments LLC v. A.S.A.P. Logistics Ltd.
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: To satisfy the domination prong, for purposes of veil piercing under New York law, courts look to factors such as the absence of the formalities and paraphernalia that are part and parcel of the corporate existence, i.e., issuance of stock, election of directors, keeping of corporate records and the like; inadequate capitalization; whether funds are put in and taken out of the corporation for personal rather than corporate purposes; and the amount of business discretion displayed by the allegedly dominated corporation.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW  Sales. Buyers sufficiently alleged existence of contract for purchase of medical grade nitrile gloves.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: Equal Employment Opportunity Commission v. 'Murica, LLC
Court: United States District Court, D. Colorado.
Headnote: To determine alter ego status in the context of piercing the corporate veil under Colorado law, courts consider various factors, including whether the entity operates as a distinct business entity, assets or funds are commingled, proper corporate records are maintained, the nature and form of the entity's ownership and control facilitate insider misuse, the business is thinly capitalized, the entity is used as a mere shell, legal formalities are disregarded, and entity funds or assets are used for non-entity purposes.
Document Preview: LABOR AND EMPLOYMENT  Discrimination. District court had jurisdiction over EEOC's Title VII claims against employer that employees asserted as counterclaims in settled state-court action.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: City of Chicago v. Equte LLC
Court: United States District Court, N.D. Illinois, Eastern Division.
Headnote: Minnesota veil-piercing doctrine considers insolvency as a relatively minor element in its overall analysis.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Piercing Corporate Veil. Corporations' principal could not be held personally liable for online e-cigarette sales that allegedly violated municipal code.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: Top Brand LLC v. Cozy Comfort Company LLC
Court: United States District Court, D. Arizona.
Headnote: Under Arizona law, factors considered in determining the alter-ego status of a corporation include, but are not limited to, failure to maintain formalities of separate corporate existence, plaintiff's lack of knowledge of separate corporate existence, owners' making of interest-free loans to corporation, maintaining of corporate financial records, commingling of personal and corporate funds, diversion of corporate property for shareholders' personal use, observance of formalities of corporate meetings, and filing of corporate income tax returns.
Document Preview: PATENTS  Design. Design patents for wearable blankets were invalid as anticipated by patentee's own products.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: Presidio, Inc. v. People Driven Technology, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, S.D. Ohio, Eastern Division.
Headnote: Courts typically look to a variety of factors to determine if the corporate form should be disregarded by piercing the corporate veil, including the intermingling of corporate and personal funds, undercapitalization of the corporation, failure to observe corporate formalities such as the maintenance of separate books and records, failure to pay dividends, insolvency at the time of a transaction, siphoning off of funds by the dominant shareholder, and the inactivity of other officers and directors.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW  Contracts. Affiliate of purchaser of family business lacked valid and enforceable contract with affiliate's former employees based on assigned agreements.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: Motul S.A. v. USA Wholesale Lubricant, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, N.D. California.
Headnote: Court may consider the following factors to determine if a plaintiff alleges sufficient facts to make a prima facie showing of unity of interest, as a prong of the alter ego test under California law, although no single factor is dispositive: commingling of funds and other assets of the two entities, the holding out by one entity that is liable for the debts of the other, identical equitable ownership in the two entities, use of the same offices and employees, use of one as a mere shell or conduit for the affairs of the other, inadequate capitalization, disregard of corporate formalities, lack of segregation of corporate records, and identical directors and officers.
Document Preview: TRADEMARKS  Dilution. Motor oil manufacturer's MOTUL mark was not famous, as required for dilution claim against distributors that allegedly sold counterfeit product.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: 407 N 117 Street, LLC v. Harper
Court: Supreme Court of Nebraska.
Headnote: In determining whether to disregard the corporate entity on the basis of fraud, a court considers the following factors: (1) grossly inadequate capitalization, (2) insolvency of the debtor corporation at the time the debt is incurred, (3) diversion by the shareholder or shareholders of corporate funds or assets to their own or other improper uses, and (4) the fact that the corporation is a mere facade for the personal dealings of the shareholder and that the operations of the corporation are carried on by the shareholder in disregard of the corporate entity.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Piercing Corporate Veil. Veil piercing sought by judgment creditor, a landlord, against officer and former director of defunct corporate tenant was not warranted.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: 407 N 117 Street, LLC v. Harper
Court: Supreme Court of Nebraska.
Headnote: A corporation is "insolvent" at the time a debt is incurred, as a factor in determining whether to pierce the corporate veil, if the corporation is unable to pay its debts as they become due in the usual course of its business, or if it has an excess of liabilities of the corporation over its assets at a fair valuation.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Piercing Corporate Veil. Veil piercing sought by judgment creditor, a landlord, against officer and former director of defunct corporate tenant was not warranted.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: Tabchouri v. Hard Eight Restaurant Company, LLC
Court: Supreme Court, Appellate Division, Second Department, New York.
Headnote: Factors to be considered in determining whether an owner has abused the privilege of doing business in the corporate form, as would support piercing the corporate veil, include whether there was a failure to adhere to corporate formalities, inadequate capitalization, commingling of assets, or use of corporate funds for personal use.
Document Preview: TORTS  Dram Shop. Piercing corporate veil to hold owners of LLC restaurant operator liable for violation of Dram Shop Act was unwarranted, absent fraud or wrongdoing.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: Franklin Capital Funding, LLC v. Austin Business Finance, LLC
Court: United States District Court, E.D. Michigan, Southern Division.
Headnote: Under Michigan law, when determining whether to disregard the separate existence of an artificial entity, court should examine the totality of the evidence surrounding the owner's use of artificial entity and, in particular, the manner in which the entity was employed in the matter at issue.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW  Contracts. Assignee of automobile dealer's factoring debt plausibly stated claim for breach of assignment agreement against assignor and its alleged alter ego.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: In re Kwok
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, D. Connecticut.
Headnote: The traditional factors to support a finding of alter ego and/or piercing the corporate veil under Delaware law, which are relevant towards the element of dominion and control, are: (1) whether the company was adequately capitalized for the undertaking; (2) whether the company was solvent; (3) whether corporate formalities were observed; (4) whether the dominant shareholder siphoned company funds; and (5) whether, in general, the company simply functioned as a facade for the dominant shareholder.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY  Avoidance. LLC's corporate form worked injustice and therefore reverse veil-piercing would be in public interest.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: In re Kwok
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, D. Connecticut.
Headnote: While traditional factors to support finding of alter ego and/or piercing corporate veil under Delaware law are useful, any single one of them is not determinative; ultimate decision regarding veil-piercing is largely based on some combination of these factors, in addition to overall element of injustice or unfairness.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY  Avoidance. LLC's corporate form worked injustice and therefore reverse veil-piercing would be in public interest.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: In re Kwok
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, D. Connecticut.
Headnote: Additional factors to be considered under Delaware law in determining whether to pierce corporate veil are: (1) the degree to which allowing a reverse pierce would impair the legitimate expectations of any adversely affected shareholders who are not responsible for the conduct of the insider that gave rise to the reverse pierce claim, and the degree to which allowing a reverse pierce would establish a precedent troubling to shareholders generally; (2) the degree to which the corporate entity whose disregard is sought has exercised dominion and control over the insider who is subject to the claim by the party seeking a reverse pierce; (3) the degree to which the injury alleged by the person seeking a reverse pierce is related to the corporate entity's dominion and control of the insider, or to that person's reasonable reliance upon a lack of separate entity status between the insider and the corporate entity; (4) the degree to which the public convenience, as articulated by the Delaware General Corporation Law and Delaware's common law, would be served by allowing a reverse pierce; (5) the extent and severity of the wrongful conduct, if any, engaged in by the corporate entity whose disregard is sought by the insider; (6) the possibility that the person seeking the reverse pierce is himself guilty of wrongful conduct sufficient to bar him from obtaining equitable relief; (7) the extent to which the reverse pierce will harm innocent third-party creditors of the entity the plaintiff seeks to reach; and (8) the extent to which other claims or remedies are practically available to the creditor at law or in equity to recover the debt.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY  Avoidance. LLC's corporate form worked injustice and therefore reverse veil-piercing would be in public interest.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: In re Kwok
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, D. Connecticut.
Headnote: Alter ego determination under Delaware law does not rely on presence of all enumerated factors.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY  Avoidance. LLC's corporate form worked injustice and therefore reverse veil-piercing would be in public interest.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: In re Palmieri
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, N.D. Illinois, Eastern Division.
Headnote: Under Delaware law, the so-called "alter ego" factors for corporate veil piercing include insolvency, undercapitalization, commingling of corporate and personal funds, the absence of corporate formalities, and whether the subsidiary is simply a façade for the owner; the court should then ask whether the owner is utilizing the corporate form to perpetuate fraud or an injustice.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY  Limitations. Trustee could step into shoes of IRS under strong-arm statute and use ten-year limitations window available to IRS for collection of assessed taxes.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: Michigan GeoSearch, Inc. v. TC Energy Corporation
Court: United States District Court, E.D. Michigan, Southern Division.
Headnote: Under Michigan law, factors used by courts to determine the propriety of piercing the corporate veil include: (1) whether the corporation is undercapitalized, (2) whether separate books are kept, (3) whether there are separate finances for the corporation, (4) whether the corporation is used for fraud or illegality, (5) whether corporate formalities have been followed, and (6) whether the corporation is a sham.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Piercing Corporate Veil. Piercing corporate veil was not warranted under Michigan law to allow owner of natural gas well to seek recovery from parent company.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: In re Childers
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, N.D. Ohio, Western Division, WESTERN DIVISION.
Headnote: Under Ohio law, courts consider list of nonexclusive factors in deciding whether to disregard the corporate form, including: (1) grossly inadequate capitalization, (2) failure to observe corporate formalities, (3) insolvency of the debtor corporation at the time the debt is incurred, (4) shareholders holding themselves out as personally liable for certain corporate obligations, (5) diversion of funds or other property of the company property for personal use, (6) absence of corporate records, and (7) the fact that the corporation was a mere facade for the operations of the dominant shareholders.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY  Discharge. Creditor's failed to prove by a preponderance of the evidence that Chapter 7 debtor's certification that siding was complete was false.

Title: Concepts NREC, LLC v. Qiu

Headnote: A court is required to consider the totality of the facts in evaluating whether a corporation is an alter-ego of another entity.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Piercing Corporate Veil. Magistrate judge did not commit clear error in determining that corporate dealings were not at arms' length, for purposes of alter-ego analysis.

Title: McCallan v. Wilkins
Court: United States District Court, M.D. Alabama, Northern Division.
Headnote: Under Alabama law, corporate entity may be shareholder's alter ego where corporation is set up as subterfuge, where shareholders do not observe corporate form, where legal requirements of corporate law are not complied with, where corporation maintains no corporate records, where corporation maintains no corporate bank account, where corporation has no employees, where corporate and personal funds are intermingled and corporate funds are used for personal purposes, or where individual drains funds from corporation.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY  Professionals. Bankruptcy Court did not abuse its discretion in denying recusal motion that was based in part on objectionable email sent by party's former counsel.

Headnote: Presence of all of the Coala factors, 182 B.R. 887, is not necessary to find that an entity was a shareholder's alter ego under Alabama law.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY  Professionals. Bankruptcy Court did not abuse its discretion in denying recusal motion that was based in part on objectionable email sent by party's former counsel.

Title: Bristow First Assembly of God v. BP p.l.c.

Headnote: Under Delaware law, factors to be considered in determining whether piercing the corporate veil is appropriate include: (1) whether the company was adequately capitalized for the undertaking; (2) whether the company was solvent; (3) whether corporate formalities were observed; (4) whether the dominant shareholder siphoned company funds; and (5) whether, in general, the company simply functioned as a façade for the dominant shareholder.

Headnote: Under Delaware law, the ultimate decision regarding corporate veil-piercing is largely based on some combination of relevant factors, in addition to an overall element of injustice or unfairness.

Title: Goodwill Toys MFG, Ltd. v. I–Star Entertainment, LLC
Court: Supreme Court, Appellate Division, Second Department, New York.
Headnote: In determining whether to disregard the corporate form and pierce the corporate veil under Delaware law, courts consider factors including: (1) whether the company was adequately capitalized for the undertaking, (2) whether the company was solvent, (3) whether corporate formalities were observed, (4) whether the dominant shareholder siphoned company funds, and (5) whether, in general, the company simply functioned as a facade for the dominant shareholder.

Title: Goodwill Toys MFG, Ltd. v. I–Star Entertainment, LLC
Court: Supreme Court, Appellate Division, Second Department, New York.
Headnote: While the factors used by courts in determining whether to disregard the corporate form and pierce the corporate veil under Delaware law are useful, any single one of them is not determinative; an ultimate decision regarding veil-piercing is largely based on some combination of the factors, in addition to an overall element of injustice or unfairness.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Piercing Corporate Veil. Manufacturer's allegations and submission were sufficient to support inference that company was alter ego of LLC, warranting jurisdictional discovery.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: Stark v. State
Court: Court of Appeals of Indiana.
Headnote: To determine whether the party seeking to pierce the corporate veil has met the burden of proving that the corporate form was so ignored, controlled or manipulated that it was merely the instrumentality of another and that the misuse of the corporate form would constitute a fraud or promote injustice, courts consider whether the party has presented evidence demonstrating: (1) under capitalization; (2) absence of corporate records; (3) fraudulent representation by corporation shareholders or directors; (4) use of the corporation to promote fraud, injustice, or illegal activities; (5) payment by the corporation of individual obligations; (6) commingling of assets and affairs; (7) failure to observe corporate form; or (8) conduct.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Piercing Corporate Veil. Trial court's conclusion that piercing corporate veil to impose personal liability against president of wildlife nonprofit was not clearly erroneous.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: Tropical Paradise Resorts, LLC v. JBSHBM, LLC
Court: United States District Court, S.D. Florida.
Headnote: As to the first element of a veil-piercing claim under Florida law-the defendants' dominion and control over the company-the plaintiff must allege a blurring of corporate lines, such as ignoring corporate formalities or commingling corporate funds with personal funds.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW  Default. Attorney willfully defaulted in supplemental proceeding by failing to respond to complaint against him even though he filed documents for client.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: JPV I L.P. v. Koetting
Court: Court of Appeal, First District, Division 3, California.
Headnote: Factors relevant in applying the alter ego doctrine include one individual's ownership of all stock in a corporation, use of the same office or business location, commingling of funds and other assets of the individual and the corporation, an individual holding out that he is personally liable for debts of the corporation, identical directors and officers, failure to maintain minutes or adequate corporate records, disregard of corporate formalities, absence of corporate assets and inadequate capitalization, the use of a corporation as a mere shell, instrumentality or conduit for the business of an individual, the use of the corporate entity to procure labor, services or merchandise for another person or entity, and the diversion of assets from a corporation by or to a stockholder or other person or entity, to the detriment of creditors.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Limited Liability Companies. Insufficient evidence supported finding that managing members made no personal use of any LLC assets, for purposes of alter ego doctrine.

Title: Rosenshein v. Kushner
Court: Supreme Court, Appellate Division, Second Department, New York.
Headnote: Factors to be considered in determining whether an individual has abused the privilege of doing business in the corporate or limited liability company (LLC) form, as a factor in piercing the corporate veil, include the failure to adhere to corporate or LLC formalities, inadequate capitalization, commingling of assets, and the personal use of corporate or LLC funds.

Title: Christian v. Loyakk, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, D. Wyoming.
Headnote: Under Wyoming law, if a corporation is not a viable one and the individuals are in fact conducting personal activities and using the corporate form as a shield, a court may feel compelled to pierce the corporate veil and permit assertion of personal jurisdiction over the individuals.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: Christian v. Loyakk, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, D. Wyoming.
Headnote: Under Wyoming law, factors pertinent to determination of whether to pierce the corporate veil include, unauthorized diversion of corporate funds or assets to other than corporate uses, the treatment by an individual of the assets of the corporation as his own, the identification of the equitable owners thereof with the domination and control of the entities, and the diversion of assets from a corporation by or to a stockholder or other person or entity, to the detriment of creditors.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Piercing Corporate Veil. Court could exercise personal jurisdiction over dissolved company officers under alter ego theory because they diverted company's assets to themselves.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: Arnold v. LME, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, D. Minnesota.
Headnote: In determining whether shareholders and corporation have failed to maintain their separate identities, as required to pierce corporate veil, the court may consider following non-exhaustive list of factors: (1) whether the corporation is operated as a separate entity; (2) the commingling of funds and other assets; (3) the failure to maintain adequate corporate records; (4) the nature of the corporation's ownership and control; (5) the availability and use of corporate assets, the absence of same, or under capitalization; (6) the use of the corporate form as a mere shell, instrumentality or conduit of an individual or another corporation; (7) disregard of corporate legal formalities and the failure to maintain an arm's-length relationship among related entities; (8) diversion of the corporate funds or assets to noncorporate purposes; and (9) transfer or disposal of corporate assets without fair consideration; no one factor is dispositive, and not all factors must be present for the veil to be pierced.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Piercing Corporate Veil. Nature and control of owner-operated corporation weighed against piercing the corporate veil, in former employees' action against corporate owners.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: Arnold v. LME, Inc.

Headnote: It is irrelevant to whether the owner of an owner-operated corporation is liable under common-law doctrine, such as piercing the corporate veil, that the owner made decisions on behalf of the corporation and that there was a unity of management and ownership in the businesses.

Title: UMB Bank, N.A. v. Eagle Crest Apartments, LLC

Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Piercing Corporate Veil. Court appropriately pierced the corporate veil to find individual's numerous separate entities liable for deficiency judgment.

Title: Hamilton v. Young Management, LLC

Headnote: In determining whether to disregard the corporate form, Massachusetts courts analyze 12 factors: (1) common ownership, (2) pervasive control, (3) confused intermingling of business activity assets or management, (4) thin capitalization, (5) nonobservance of corporate formalities, (6) absence of corporate records, (7) no payment of dividends, (8) insolvency at the time of the litigated transaction, (9) siphoning away corporate assets by the dominant shareholders, (10) nonfunctioning of officers and directors, (11) use of the corporation for transactions of the dominant shareholders, and (12) use of the corporation in promoting fraud.

Title: Pike Cnty. Fiscal Ct. v. RCC Big Shoal, LLC
Court: United States District Court, E.D. Kentucky, Southern Division., Pikeville.
Headnote: Within list of eleven factors that guide court's analysis on loss of corporate separateness element of a corporate veil-piercing claim under Kentucky law, the three factors that carry greater weight than the companion eight are: grossly inadequate capitalization; egregious failure to observe corporate formalities; and a high degree of control over the corporation's day-to-day operations and decisions.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Piercing Corporate Veil. Judgment creditors could pierce debtor LLC's corporate shield to hold its owners liable for the debt since injustice would otherwise be promoted.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: In re Shakir
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, N.D. Illinois, Eastern Division.
Headnote: Illinois courts consider the following factors when determining whether there is sufficient "unity of interest" to justify disregarding corporate form: (1) inadequate capitalization; (2) failure to observe corporate formalities; (3) insolvency of debtor corporation; (4) nonfunctioning of other officers or directors; (5) absence of corporate records; (6) commingling of funds; (7) diversion of assets from corporation by or to shareholder; (8) failure to maintain arm's length relationships among related entities; and (9) whether corporation is mere facade for operation of dominant shareholders.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY  Avoidance. Chapter 7 trustee had standing to prosecute alter ego claims in adversary proceeding.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: In re Maxus Energy Corporation
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, D. Delaware.
Headnote: On a claim to pierce the corporate veil under the alter ego theory, a court considers several factors to evaluate dominion and control: (1) whether the company was adequately capitalized for the undertaking; (2) whether the company was solvent; (3) whether corporate formalities were observed; (4) whether the dominant shareholder siphoned company funds; and (5) whether, in general, the company simply functioned as a façade for the dominant shareholder.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY  Avoidance. Parent corporation ultimately could be held liable for alleged asset stripping strategy upon which liquidating trust based its alter ego claim.

Title: Lopez v. Escamilla

Headnote: For purposes of alter ego doctrine, courts look to the totality of circumstances to determine who actually owns or controls the corporate entity and who is using it as a mere shell or conduit for his or her own personal interests.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Shareholders. Fact issue regarding whether sole shareholder of judgment debtor corporation was liable as alter ego precluded summary judgment.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: West Dakota Oil, Inc. v. Kathrein Trucking, LLC
Court: Supreme Court of North Dakota.
Headnote: Factors considered in determining whether to pierce the corporate veil include insufficient capitalization for the purposes of the corporate undertaking, failure to observe corporate formalities, nonpayment of dividends, insolvency of the debtor corporation at the time of the transaction in question, siphoning of funds by the dominant shareholder, nonfunctioning of other officers and directors, absence of corporate records, and the existence of the corporation as merely a facade for individual dealings.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: Pizana v. SanMedica International LLC
Court: United States District Court, E.D. California.
Headnote: Under Utah law, in evaluating whether entity's form may be disregarded under the alter ego doctrine, courts look to the following seven factors that bear on the unity of interest and ownership analysis: (1) undercapitalization of a one-man corporation; (2) failure to observe corporate formalities; (3) nonpayment of dividends; (4) siphoning of corporate funds by the dominant stockholder; (5) nonfunctioning of other officers or directors; (6) absence of corporate records; (7) the use of the corporation as a facade for operations of the dominant stockholder or stockholders.
Document Preview: TORTS  RICO. Consumer sufficiently stated Racketeer Influenced and Corrupt Organizations Act (RICO) claim against growth hormone supplement manufacturer.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: In re Daniels
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, S.D. Ohio, Western Division.
Headnote: A court analyzing an alter ego claim under Ohio law considers: (1) grossly inadequate capitalization, (2) failure to observe corporate formalities, (3) insolvency of the debtor corporation at the time the debt is incurred, (4) shareholders holding themselves out as personally liable for certain corporate obligations, (5) diversion of funds or other property of the company property for personal use, (6) absence of corporate records, and (7) the fact that the corporation was a mere facade for the operations of the dominant shareholder(s).
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY  Discharge. Debtor failed to maintain records from which his financial condition could be ascertained, and therefore discharge exception applied.

Title: Cyprus Amax Minerals Company v. TCI Pacific Communications, LLC

Title: In re Flint Water Cases

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: In re Flint Water Cases
Court: United States District Court, E.D. Michigan, Southern Division.
Headnote: Under Michigan law, in order to pierce the corporate veil, a court must first examine the totality of the evidence surrounding the owner's use of an artificial entity and, in particular, the manner in which the entity was employed in the manner at issue; from this evidence, the trial court must determine whether the evidence establishes that the owner operated the entity as his or her alter ego, that is, as a sham or mere agent or instrumentality of his or her will.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Piercing Corporate Veil. Alter ego liability could not be imposed against parent by piercing corporate veil based on parent-subsidiary relationship in negligence action.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: In re Flint Water Cases
Court: United States District Court, E.D. Michigan, Southern Division.
Headnote: Under Michigan law, in considering whether an entity is a mere instrumentality of another, in order to pierce the corporate veil, factors to be evaluated include: (1) whether the corporation is undercapitalized, (2) whether separate books are kept, (3) whether there are separate finances for the corporation, (4) whether the corporation is used for fraud or illegality, (5) whether the corporate formalities have been followed, and (6) whether the corporation is a sham.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Piercing Corporate Veil. Alter ego liability could not be imposed against parent by piercing corporate veil based on parent-subsidiary relationship in negligence action.

Title: Chaleplis v. Karloutsos

Headnote: Under Pennsylvania law, factors considered in deciding whether to pierce corporate veil are undercapitalization, failure to adhere to corporate formalities, substantial intermingling of corporate and personal affairs, and use of corporate form to perpetrate fraud.

Title: U.S. Bank National Association v. MMCO, L.L.C.

Roark, 617 N.E.2d 1075, to determine whether to pierce the corporate veil, courts may consider factors including, (1) whether corporate formalities were observed, (2) whether corporate records were kept, (3) whether corporate funds were commingled with personal funds, and (4) whether corporate property was used for a personal purpose.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: Martin v. Top Quality Professional Construction, LLC
Court: Court of Appeals of Indiana.
Headnote: To determine whether party seeking to pierce corporate veil has met its burden, courts consider whether party has presented evidence demonstrating: (1) under capitalization; (2) absence of corporate records; (3) fraudulent representation by corporation shareholders or directors; (4) use of corporation to promote fraud, injustice, or illegal activities; (5) payment by corporation of individual obligations; (6) commingling of assets and affairs; (7) failure to observe required corporate formalities; or (8) other shareholder acts or conduct ignoring, controlling, or manipulating corporate form.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Limited Liability Companies. Homeowner failed to meet burden to pierce corporate veil in breach of contract claim against limited liability company (LLC).

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: Jinks v. Credico (USA) LLC
Court: Supreme Judicial Court of Massachusetts, Suffolk.
Headnote: To trigger veil-piercing liability, a plaintiff must show the following factors: (1) common ownership; (2) pervasive control; (3) confused intermingling of business assets; (4) thin capitalization; (5) nonobservance of corporate formalities; (6) absence of corporate records; (7) no payment of dividends; (8) insolvency at the time of the litigated transaction; (9) siphoning away of corporation's funds by dominant shareholder; (10) nonfunctioning of officers and directors; (11) use of the corporation for transactions of the dominant shareholders; and (12) use of the corporation in promoting fraud.

Title: Butler Motors, Inc. v. Benosky

Headnote: Factors that courts consider when determining whether to pierce the corporate veil include: (1) undercapitalization, (2) absence of corporate records, (3) fraudulent representation by corporation shareholders or directors, (4) use of the corporation to promote fraud, injustice, or illegal activities, (5) payment by the corporation of individual obligations, (6) commingling of assets and affairs, (7) failure to observe required corporate formalities, and (8) other shareholder acts or conduct ignoring, controlling, or manipulating the corporate form.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: Blizzard Energy, Inc. v. Schaefers
Court: Court of Appeal, Second District, Division 6, California.
Headnote: Factors for determining unity of interest and ownership, as a condition for invoking the alter ego doctrine, include: (1) commingling of funds and other assets, failure to segregate funds of the separate entities, and the unauthorized diversion of corporate funds or assets to other than corporate uses; (2) treatment by an individual of the assets of the corporation as his own; and (3) the disregard of legal formalities and the failure to maintain arm's length relationships among related entities.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Piercing Corporate Veil. Evidence was sufficient to support a finding that LLC was judgment debtor's alter ego.

Title: Blizzard Energy, Inc. v. Schaefers

Title: In re Stone Pine Investment Banking, LLC

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: In re VanHuss
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, C.D. Illinois.
Headnote: Under Illinois law, courts consider a number factors when determining whether a unity of interest and ownership exists, as required to pierce the corporate veil: (1) inadequate capitalization; (2) failing to issue stock; (3) failing to observe corporate formalities; (4) failing to pay dividends; (5) corporate insolvency; (6) nonfunctioning corporate officers; (7) missing corporate records; (8) commingling funds; (9) diverting assets to an owner or other entity to creditor detriment; (10) failing to maintain an arm's-length relationship among related entities; and (11) whether the corporation is a mere façade for a dominant owner.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: In re Financial Oversight and Management Board for Puerto Rico
Court: United States District Court, D. Puerto Rico.
Headnote: Under Delaware law, factors considered in determining whether a corporation is the alter ego of its shareholders are: (1) undercapitalization; (2) failure to observe corporate formalities; (3) nonpayment of dividends; (4) the insolvency of the debtor corporation at the time; (5) siphoning of the corporation's funds by the dominant stockholder; and (6) whether there is a genuine dispute as to whether there is a genuine dispute as to whether there is a genuine dispute as to the corporation's operations.
Document Preview: GOVERNMENT CONTRACTS  Rescission and Termination. Conviction for grand larceny in New York law was not equivalent to aggravated misappropriation under statute prohibiting future award of contracts.

Title: Mohegan Lake Motors, Inc. v. Maoli

Title: Childs v. Pommer
Court: Supreme Court of Alabama.
Headnote: The corporate veil may be pierced where a corporation is set up as a subterfuge, where shareholders do not observe the corporate form, where the legal requirements of corporate law are not complied with, where the corporation maintains no corporate records, where the corporation maintains no corporate bank account, where the corporation has no employees, where corporate and personal funds are intermingled and corporate funds are used for personal purposes, or where an individual drains funds from the corporation.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Piercing Corporate Veil. Piercing construction company's corporate veil as a limited-liability company (LLC) was not warranted.

Title: Mortimer v. McCool
Court: Supreme Court of Pennsylvania.
Headnote: The following factors are relevant to the inquiry whether to pierce the corporate veil: undercapitalization, failure to adhere to corporate formalities, substantial intermingling of corporate and personal affairs, and use of the corporate form to perpetrate a fraud.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Piercing Corporate Veil. Enterprise liability doctrine did not apply to permit judgment creditor to pierce veil of judgment debtor LLC's affiliated corporate entity.

Title: Blackwell v. Superior Safe Rooms LLC

Title: Manichaean Capital, LLC v. Exela Technologies, Inc.
Court: Court of Chancery of Delaware.
Headnote: Delaware courts consider a number of factors in determining whether to disregard the corporate form and pierce the corporate veil, including: (1) whether the company was adequately capitalized for the undertaking; (2) whether the company was solvent; (3) whether corporate formalities were observed; (4) whether the dominant shareholder siphoned company funds; and (5) whether, in general, the company simply functioned as a facade for the dominant shareholder.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: Manichaean Capital, LLC v. Exela Technologies, Inc.
Court: Court of Chancery of Delaware.
Headnote: An ultimate decision regarding veil-piercing is largely based on some combination of relevant factors, in addition to an overall element of injustice or unfairness.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Piercing Corporate Veil. Reverse piercing of corporate veil was appropriate to hold subsidiaries liable for payments to company's shareholders under appraisal judgment.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: Manichaean Capital, LLC v. Exela Technologies, Inc.
Court: Court of Chancery of Delaware.
Headnote: When reviewing a claim for reverse veil-piercing, the court consider the traditional "alter ego" factors for a veil-piercing claim, and then focus on additional factors including: (1) degree to which allowing a reverse pierce would impair legitimate expectations of any adversely affected shareholders who are not responsible for conduct of insider that gave rise to reverse pierce claim, and degree to which allowing a reverse pierce would establish a precedent troubling to shareholders generally; (2) degree to which corporate entity whose disregard is sought has exercised dominion and control over insider subject to claim by party seeking a reverse pierce; (3) degree to which injury alleged by person seeking reverse pierce is related to corporate entity's dominion and control of insider or to person's reasonable reliance upon lack of separate entity status between insider and corporate entity; (4) degree to which public convenience would be served by allowing reverse pierce; (5) extent and severity of wrongful conduct, if any, engaged in by corporate entity whose disregard is sought by insider; (6) possibility the person seeking reverse pierce is guilty of wrongful conduct sufficient to bar him or her from obtaining equitable relief; (7) extent to which reverse pierce will harm innocent third-party creditors of entity the party seeks to reach; and (8) extent to which other claims or remedies are practically available to the creditor at law or in equity to recover the debt.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Piercing Corporate Veil. Reverse piercing of corporate veil was appropriate to hold subsidiaries liable for payments to company's shareholders under appraisal judgment.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: BIC Corporation v. Chicago Import, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, N.D. Illinois, Eastern Division.
Headnote: Factors to be considered in determining whether to pierce corporate veil include gross undercapitalization, failure to observe corporate formalities, nonpayment of dividends, insolvency of debtor corporation at time, siphoning of funds of corporation by dominant stock holder, nonfunctioning of other officers or directors, absence of corporate records, and fact that corporation is merely façade of operations of dominant stockholder or stockholders.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Jurisdiction. Buyer plausibly alleged that seller's current limited liability company (LLC) was a continuation of prior LLC dissolved during pendency of litigation.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: Pado, Inc. v. SG Trademark Holding Co. LLC
Court: United States District Court, E.D. New York.
Headnote: On claim to pierce corporate veil under New York law, in analyzing whether individual exercised domination over corporation, a court considers: (1) whether corporate formalities are observed; (2) whether corporation is adequately capitalized; (3) whether funds are put in and taken out of corporation for personal rather than corporate purposes; (4) whether there is overlap in ownership, officers, directors, and personnel; (5) whether corporate entities share common office space, address and telephone numbers; (6) amount of business discretion displayed by allegedly dominated corporation; (7) whether alleged dominator deals with dominated corporation at arm's length; (8) whether corporation is treated as independent profit center; (9) whether others pay or guarantee debts of corporation; and (10) whether corporation had property that was used by alleged dominator as if it were his own.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Piercing Corporate Veil. Patent owner failed to adequately plead facts justifying piercing corporate veil under New York law to hold competitor's owner directly liable for patent infringement.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: JNM Express, LLC v. Lozano
Court: Court of Appeals of Texas, Corpus Christi-Edinburg.
Headnote: Alter ego is shown from the total dealings of the corporation and the individual, including the degree to which corporate and individual property have been kept separately, the amount of financial interest, ownership, and control the individual maintains over the corporation, and whether the corporation has been used for personal purposes.
Document Preview: TRANSPORTATION  Carriers. Trucking companies that disregarded federal regulations concerning amount of rest driver was required to receive between trips were grossly negligent.
