Title: Peterson v. Colony American Finance Lender LLC
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, N.D. Illinois, Eastern Division.
Headnote: Under Delaware law, court considers the following factors in determining whether to pierce the corporate veil: (1) whether the company was adequately capitalized for the undertaking; (2) whether the company was solvent; (3) whether corporate formalities were observed; (4) whether the controlling shareholder siphoned company funds; or (5) whether, in general, the company simply functioned as a facade for the controlling shareholder.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY  Avoidance. Lender that entered revolving loan agreement with transferee was neither initial transferee nor entity for whose benefit the transfers were made.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: Peterson v. Colony American Finance Lender LLC
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, N.D. Illinois, Eastern Division.
Headnote: Insolvency alone is insufficient to pierce the corporate veil under Delaware law.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY  Avoidance. Lender that entered revolving loan agreement with transferee was neither initial transferee nor entity for whose benefit the transfers were made.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: Stellar Restoration Services, LLC v. James Christopher Courtney
Court: United States District Court, E.D. Texas, Sherman Division.
Headnote: Under Texas law, the types of evidence a court will consider as proof of an alter ego include: (1) the payment of alleged corporate debts with personal checks or other commingling of funds, (2) representations that the individual will financially back the corporation, (3) the diversion of company profits to the individual for his persona use, (4) inadequate capitalization, and (5) other failure to keep corporate and personal assets separate.
Document Preview: LITIGATION  Venue. Contract was ambiguous was to who it bound, thus, defendants were bound by contract's forum selection clause at motion to dismiss stage.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: Bick v. Legacy Building Maintenance Company LLC
Court: Missouri Court of Appeals, Eastern District, DIVISION ONE.
Headnote: A court can pierce the corporate veil when actual fraud is shown, when a corporation is undercapitalized, or when the corporation's assets are stripped to avoid creditors.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Piercing Corporate Veil. Piercing corporate veil theory applied to claim asserting corporation's president controlled corporation and undercapitalized it for unlawful purpose.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: Lyngaas v. Curaden Ag
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Sixth Circuit.
Headnote: Under Michigan law, whether corporate entity is mere instrumentality of another, thus warranting piercing corporate veil, is determined by analyzing (1) whether corporation is undercapitalized, (2) whether separate books are kept, (3) whether there are separate finances for corporation, (4) whether corporation is used for fraud or illegality, (5) whether corporate formalities have been followed, and (6) whether corporation is sham.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW  Consumer Protection. Swiss toothbrush manufacturer was not liable for its distributor's Telephone Consumer Protection Act (TCPA) violations.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: Steadfast Insurance Company v. T.F. Nugent Inc.
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: Under New York law, for purposes of piercing the corporate veil under an alter ego theory, to satisfy prong requiring that a corporation be dominated, courts look to factors including: (1) the absence of the formalities and paraphernalia that are part and parcel of the corporate existence, such as the issuance of stock, election of directors, keeping of corporate records and the like, (2) inadequate capitalization, (3) whether funds are put in and taken out of the corporation for personal rather than corporate purposes, and (4) the amount of business discretion displayed by the allegedly dominated corporation.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Successor Liability. Insurer plausibly alleged painting company's successor was incorporated and created solely to hide business assets of company.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: In re Udelhoven
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, N.D. Illinois, Eastern Division.
Headnote: In determining whether the "unity of interest and ownership" prong of the piercing-the-corporate-veil test is met, Illinois courts generally will not rest a decision on a single factor, but will examine many factors, including: (1) inadequate capitalization; (2) failure to issue stock; (3) failure to observe corporate formalities; (4) nonpayment of dividends; (5) insolvency of the corporation; (6) nonfunctioning of the other officers or directors; (7) absence of corporate records; (8) commingling of funds; (9) diversion of assets from the corporation by or to a stockholder or other person or entity to the detriment of corporate creditors; (10) failure to maintain arm's-length relationships among related entities; and (11) whether, in fact, the corporation is a mere facade for the operation of the dominant stockholders.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY  Discharge. Debt arising out of unperformed contract to construct home could not be excepted from discharge on fraud theory.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: Ming-Hsiang Kao v. Holiday
Court: Court of Appeal, First District, Division 3, California.
Headnote: Factors trial court may consider when deciding unity of interest and whether the fiction of a separate existence would promote fraud and injustice, as required to invoke alter ego liability to disregard corporate entity, include the following: (1) commingling of funds and other assets; (2) treatment by an individual of the assets of the corporation as his own; (3) failure to maintain adequate corporate records; (4) sole ownership of all of the stock in a corporation by the members of a family; (5) the use of a corporation as a mere shell, instrumentality or conduit for a single venture or the business of an individual; (6) the concealment of personal business activities; (7) the use of the corporate entity to procure labor, services, or merchandise for another person or entity; and (8) the use of a corporation as a subterfuge of illegal transactions.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Piercing Corporate Veil. CEO and president of travel tour company were alter egos of their closely-held corporation, and thus personally liable for unpaid wages.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: In re Energy Conversion Devices, Inc.
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, E.D. Michigan, Southern Division.
Headnote: Michigan courts, in deciding whether a corporate entity was used as mere instrumentality and whether corporate veil may be pierced, may consider such factors as undercapitalization of corporation, maintenance of separate books, the separation of the corporate and individual finances, use of corporation to support fraud or illegality, the honoring of corporate formalities, and whether corporation is merely a sham.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY  Avoidance. Trust established under confirmed plan stated actual fraudulent transfer claim based on confluence of fraud badges.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: Qun Lin v. Cruz
Court: Court of Special Appeals of Maryland.
Headnote: The factors used in analyzing whether a paramount equity should be enforced to allow a plaintiff to pierce the corporate veil include, inter alia, whether the corporation was grossly undercapitalized, the dominant stockholder's siphoning of corporate funds, the absence of corporate records, and the corporation's status as a facade for the stockholders' operations.
Document Preview: LABOR AND EMPLOYMENT  Hours and Wages. Remand was warranted for court to determine whether purported owner was owner of restaurant either by piercing corporate veil or economic reality test under FLSA.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: In re AuditHead, LLC
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, D. South Carolina.
Headnote: South Carolina courts apply a two-pronged test in deciding whether to pierce corporate veil, under which they first decide whether corporate formalities have been observed based on such factors as (1) undercapitalization, (2) a failure to pay dividends, (3) insolvency, (4) lack of corporate records, (5) a siphoning off of corporate funds by dominant shareholders, (6) use of the corporation as a mere facade for operations of its dominant shareholders, (7) the non-functioning of other officers or directors, and (8) other such failures; some combination of these factors is required to meet the first prong of the test, and no single factor alone will suffice.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY  Case Administration. Substantive consolidation could not be applied in order to bring assets of alleged non-debtor successor into debtor-LLC's estate.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: In re AuditHead, LLC
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, D. South Carolina.
Headnote: Under South Carolina law, defendant does not need to have actual knowledge of plaintiff's claim against corporation in order to be "aware" thereof for veil-piercing purposes; it is enough that defendant has notice of facts which, if pursued with due diligence, would lead to knowledge of the claim.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY  Case Administration. Substantive consolidation could not be applied in order to bring assets of alleged non-debtor successor into debtor-LLC's estate.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: Moss v. Associated Underwriters, Inc.
Court: Court of Appeals of Nebraska.
Headnote: Some of the relevant factors in determining whether to disregard the corporate entity on the basis of fraud are (1) grossly inadequate capitalization, (2) insolvency of the debtor corporation at the time the debt is incurred, (3) diversion by the shareholder or shareholders of corporate funds or assets to their own or other improper uses, and (4) the fact that the corporation is a mere facade for the personal dealings of the shareholder and that the operations of the corporation are carried on by the shareholder in disregard of the corporate entity.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Piercing Corporate Veil. Evidence warranted piercing corporate veil of insurance corporation to hold corporation's sole shareholder liable for unpaid judgment.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: Moss v. Associated Underwriters, Inc.
Court: Court of Appeals of Nebraska.
Headnote: A corporation is "insolvent," for the purposes of determining whether to disregard the corporate entity, or pierce the corporate veil, on the basis of fraud, if it is unable to pay its debts as they become due in the usual course of its business, or if it has an excess of liabilities of the corporation over its assets at a fair valuation.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Piercing Corporate Veil. Evidence warranted piercing corporate veil of insurance corporation to hold corporation's sole shareholder liable for unpaid judgment.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: Roley v. National Professional Exchange, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, D. Maryland.
Headnote: Under Maryland law, in assessing whether the requirements for application of the alter ego doctrine for piercing the corporate veil are met, courts consider a set of factors that includes: (1) whether the corporation is inadequately capitalized, fails to observe corporate formalities, fails to issue stock or pay dividends, or operates without a profit, (2) whether there is commingling of corporate and personal assets, (3) whether there are non-functioning officers or directors, (4) whether the corporation is insolvent at the time of the transaction, and (5) the absence of corporate records.
Document Preview: LABOR AND EMPLOYMENT  Hours and Wages. Former employee's travel expense reimbursements constituted wages under Maryland Wage Payment and Collection Law.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: United States v. Kindred Healthcare, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, E.D. Pennsylvania.
Headnote: Courts examine the following factors in deciding whether to pierce the corporate veil: gross undercapitalization, failure to observe corporate formalities, nonpayment of dividends, insolvency of debtor corporation, siphoning of funds from the debtor corporation by the dominant stockholder, nonfunctioning of officers and directors, absence of corporate records, and whether the corporation is merely a facade for the operations of the dominant stockholder.
Document Preview: GOVERNMENT  False Claims. Relator sufficiently alleged that nursing home operators knew staffing levels they mandated made it impossible to provide for their residents' needs.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: In re Horizon Group Management, LLC
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, N.D. Illinois, Eastern Division.
Headnote: Factors bearing on whether there is such unity of interest and ownership that the separate personalities of corporation and individual no longer exist, as required for a reverse veil pierce, include common or shared ownership, commingling of assets, failure to observe corporate formalities, and undercapitalization.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY  Avoidance. Tax payments on third part debt were received by the IRS in good faith.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: Munsell v. Colgate-Palmolive Co.
Court: United States District Court, D. Massachusetts.
Headnote: Under Massachusetts law, courts employ twelve factors to guide their veil-piercing analysis, including: (1) common ownership, (2) pervasive control, (3) confused intermingling of business assets, (4) thin capitalization, (5) nonobservance of corporate formalities, (6) absence of corporate records, (7) no payment of dividends, (8) insolvency at the time of the litigated transaction, (9) siphoning away of corporation's funds by dominant shareholder, (10) nonfunctioning of officers and directors, (11) use of the corporation for transactions of the dominant shareholders, and (12) use of the corporation in promoting fraud.
Document Preview: PRODUCTS LIABILITY  Industry Regulation. Buyer of personal care products plausibly alleged product labels had capacity to mislead.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: Dill v. Rembrandt Group, Inc.
Court: Colorado Court of Appeals, Division VI.
Headnote: In establishing whether such unity of interest exists as to disregard the corporate fiction and treat the corporation and shareholder as alter egos, courts consider a variety of factors, including whether (1) the corporation is operated as a distinct business entity, (2) funds and assets are commingled, (3) adequate corporate records are maintained, (4) the nature and form of the entity's ownership and control facilitate misuse by an insider, (5) the business is thinly capitalized, (6) the corporation is used as a "mere shell," (7) shareholders disregard legal formalities, and (8) corporate funds or assets are used for noncorporate purposes.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Piercing Corporate Veil. Horizontal veil piercing was not supported where no evidence supported finding that sister corporations were alter egos of common owners.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: Dill v. Rembrandt Group, Inc.
Court: Colorado Court of Appeals, Division VI.
Headnote: In establishing whether such unity of interest exists as to disregard the corporate fiction and treat the corporation and shareholder as alter egos, courts examine the specific facts of the case and need not find the existence of every relevant factor to find an alter ego.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Piercing Corporate Veil. Horizontal veil piercing was not supported where no evidence supported finding that sister corporations were alter egos of common owners.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: In re L. Scott Apparel, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, C.D. California.
Headnote: California courts consider many factors concerning unity of interest and ownership for alter ego analysis, including inadequate capitalization; commingling of funds and other assets; use of the corporation as a mere conduit for the affairs of the owner; disregard of corporate formalities; sole ownership of all the stock in a corporation by one individual; lack of segregation of corporate records; the use of the same office or business location; and the manipulation of assets and liabilities between entities so as to concentrate the assets in one and the liabilities in another.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY  Claims. Bankruptcy Court's recharacterization of $350,000 loan from claimant to debtor as equity and not debt under Delaware law was not clearly erroneous.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: In re L. Scott Apparel, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, C.D. California.
Headnote: No factor concerning unity of interest and ownership is determinative in alter ego analysis under California law.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY  Claims. Bankruptcy Court's recharacterization of $350,000 loan from claimant to debtor as equity and not debt under Delaware law was not clearly erroneous.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: Angell v. Santefort Family Holdings LLC
Court: Appellate Court of Illinois, Third District.
Headnote: To determine if there is a unity of ownership and interest, as requirement to pierce corporate veil, courts consider: (1) inadequate capitalization; (2) failure to issue stock; (3) failure to observe corporate formalities; (4) nonpayment of dividends; (5) insolvency of the debtor corporation; (6) nonfunctioning of the other officers or directors; (7) absence of corporate records; (8) commingling of funds; (9) diversion of assets from the corporation by or to a stockholder or other person or entity to the detriment of creditors; (10) failure to maintain arm's-length relationships among related entities; and (11) whether, in fact, the corporation is a mere façade for the operation of the dominant stockholders.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Piercing Corporate Veil. Owner of mobile home park and owner of mobile home were subject to the doctrine of piercing the corporate veil.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: In re Jaques
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, D. Idaho.
Headnote: Factors relevant to establishing a unity of interest, of kind required under Idaho law to pierce the corporate veil, include evidence that individual deposited his or her own money into the company's financial accounts for purposes other than meeting capital obligations, that individual used company funds to pay his or her own obligations, and that the individual failed to maintain the separate identity of the company.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY  Discharge. Debtor's misuse of trust funds supported fiduciary fraud or defalcation claim.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: In re Jaques
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, D. Idaho.
Headnote: Idaho court may consider a variety of factors when ruling on veil-piercing claims and are not required to meet any set number of factors before piercing the veil.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY  Discharge. Debtor's misuse of trust funds supported fiduciary fraud or defalcation claim.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: Best Choice Roofing & Home Improvement, Inc. v. Best Choice Roofing Savannah, LLC
Court: United States District Court, M.D. Tennessee, Nashville Division.
Headnote: Under Tennessee law, factors to be considered in determining whether to disregard the corporate veil include not only whether the entity has been used to work a fraud or injustice in contravention of public policy, but also: (1) whether there was a failure to collect paid in capital; (2) whether the corporation was grossly undercapitalized; (3) the nonissuance of stock certificates; (4) the sole ownership of stock by one individual; (5) the use of the same office or business location; (6) the employment of the same employees or attorneys; (7) the use of the corporation as an instrumentality or business conduit for an individual or another corporation; (8) the diversion of corporate assets by or to a stockholder or other entity to the detriment of creditors, or the manipulation of assets and liabilities in another; (9) the use of the corporation as a subterfuge in illegal transactions; (10) the formation and use of the corporation to transfer to it the existing liability of another person or entity; and (11) the failure to maintain arms-length relationships among related entities.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW  Contracts. Fact issue existed whether licensees suffered damages from licensor's alleged breach of contract for failure to provide notice and cure period, precluding summary judgment.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: Best Choice Roofing & Home Improvement, Inc. v. Best Choice Roofing Savannah, LLC
Court: United States District Court, M.D. Tennessee, Nashville Division.
Headnote: No single factor is conclusive in determining whether to disregard the corporate veil under Tennessee law; courts will typically rely on a combination of the factors in deciding the issue.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW  Contracts. Fact issue existed whether licensees suffered damages from licensor's alleged breach of contract for failure to provide notice and cure period, precluding summary judgment.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: Zhang v. Chu
Court: Court of Appeal, Second District, Division 8, California.
Headnote: A variety of factors informs the equitable analysis about when to pierce the corporate veil, including whether ownership of the corporation's stock is concentrated in one individual or family, whether there is use of the same office or business location, whether there is employment of the same employees, and whether there is employment of the same attorney.
Document Preview: TORTS  Malicious Prosecution. Company owner failed to establish that attorney added him as defendant in underlying wage-and-hour action maliciously.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: In re Thornton
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, C.D. Illinois.
Headnote: Under Illinois law, courts consider a variety of factors in determining whether a unity of interest or ownership exists, as required for corporate veil-piercing, including undercapitalization, insolvency, disregard of formalities, absence of records, diversion of assets from the entity to the individual, commingling of funds, and whether the entity is merely a facade for the individual.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY  Claims. Creditor failed to establish a unity of interest or alter ego as required to support veil-piercing of limited liability company owned by debtor.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: In re Thornton
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, C.D. Illinois.
Headnote: Under Illinois law, although insolvency is a factor to be considered, the failure of a business, in and of itself, is not determinative of whether the veil of a corporation or limited liability company (LLC) should be pierced.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY  Claims. Creditor failed to establish a unity of interest or alter ego as required to support veil-piercing of limited liability company owned by debtor.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: Ferrante v. Westin St. John Hotel Co.
Court: United States District Court, E.D. North Carolina, Eastern Division.
Headnote: North Carolina courts consider the elements of piercing the corporate veil, including control, breach of duty, and proximate cause, in light of several factors: (1) inadequate capitalization, i.e. "thin corporation," (2) non-compliance with corporate formalities, (3) complete domination and control of the corporation so that it has no independent identity, and (4) excessive fragmentation of a single enterprise into separate corporations.
Document Preview: REAL PROPERTY  Condominiums. Condominium developer's refusal to allow time share owners to use time share was not a breach of contract under the law of the U.S. Virgin Islands.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: Bonanni v. Horizons Investors Corp.
Court: Supreme Court, Appellate Division, Second Department, New York.
Headnote: Factors to be considered in determining whether the owner has abused the privilege of doing business in the corporate form as would support piercing the corporate veil include whether there was a failure to adhere to corporate formalities, inadequate capitalization, commingling of assets, and use of corporate funds for personal use.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Mergers and Acquisition. Excluded member was entitled to accounting based upon de facto merger between LLC and PLLC.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: In re Digirolamo
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, M.D. Louisiana.
Headnote: Under Louisiana law, the factors that indicate that a shareholder or director is the alter ego of the corporation include: (1) commingling of corporate and shareholder funds, (2) failure to follow statutory formalities for incorporating and transacting corporate affairs, (3) undercapitalization, (4) failure to provide separate bank accounts and bookkeeping records, and (5) failure to hold regular shareholder and director meetings.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY  Business Relationships. Debtor did not defraud homeowner by failing to disclose that his company was not a licensed contractor, as required to pierce corporate veil.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: TrueNorth Companies, L.C. v. TruNorth Warranty Plans of North America, LLC
Court: United States District Court, N.D. Iowa, Cedar Rapids Division.
Headnote: In determining whether the corporate veil should be pierced under Iowa law, the court should consider whether: (1) the corporation is undercapitalized, (2) without separate books, (3) its finances are not kept separate from individual finances, individual obligations are paid by the corporation, (4) the corporation is used to promote fraud or illegality, (5) corporate formalities are not followed or (6) the corporation is merely a sham.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Jurisdiction. Corporation formed by alleged infringer's founder was not the alter ego of alleged infringer.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: Durham v. Accardi
Court: Court of Appeals of Texas, Houston (14th Dist.).
Headnote: Alter ego corporate veil piercing is shown from the total dealings of the corporation and the individual, including the degree to which corporate formalities have been followed and corporate and individual property have been kept separately, the amount of financial interest, ownership, and control the individual maintains over the corporation, and whether the corporation has been used for personal purposes.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Piercing Corporate Veil. Evidence was insufficient that corporation's representatives were corporation's alter ego and thus employee could not pierce corporate veil.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: Durham v. Accardi
Court: Court of Appeals of Texas, Houston (14th Dist.).
Headnote: Evidence that will support an alter ego finding, as basis for piercing the corporate veil, includes (1) the payment of alleged corporate debts with personal checks or other commingling of funds, (2) representations that the individual will financially back the corporation, (3) the diversion of company profits to the individual for the individual's personal use, (4) inadequate capitalization, and (5) any other failure to keep corporate and personal assets separate.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Piercing Corporate Veil. Evidence was insufficient that corporation's representatives were corporation's alter ego and thus employee could not pierce corporate veil.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: Durham v. Accardi
Court: Court of Appeals of Texas, Houston (14th Dist.).
Headnote: An individual's role as an officer, director, or majority shareholder of an entity alone is not sufficient to support a finding of alter ego, for purposes of piercing the corporate veil.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Piercing Corporate Veil. Evidence was insufficient that corporation's representatives were corporation's alter ego and thus employee could not pierce corporate veil.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: Sweeney v. Waitz
Court: Supreme Court, Suffolk County, New York.
Headnote: Factors to be considered in determining whether a corporation's owner has abused the privilege of doing business in the corporate form include whether there was a failure to adhere to corporate formalities, inadequate capitalization, commingling of assets, and use of corporate funds for personal use.
Document Preview: REAL PROPERTY  Contractors and Developers. Allegations that contractor improperly installed air handler and removed load-bearing support beam sounded in breach of contract, not negligence.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: Aaron Carlson Corporation v. Cohen
Court: Supreme Court of Minnesota.
Headnote: A judicial decision on whether an individual has used a corporation to defraud creditors, as could allow piercing of veil, is based on function over form; the factors relevant to this decision include insufficient capitalization for purposes of corporate undertaking, failure to observe corporate formalities, nonpayment of dividends, insolvency of debtor corporation at time of transaction in question, siphoning of funds by dominant shareholder, nonfunctioning of other officers and directors, absence of corporate records, and existence of corporation as merely facade for individual dealings.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Piercing Corporate Veil. Veil-piercing claim against shareholders of judgment debtor, which was controlled by receiver, could be brought by judgment creditor.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: Takeda Pharmaceuticals U.S.A., Inc. v. Spireas
Court: United States District Court, E.D. Pennsylvania.
Headnote: In general, a court analyzing a corporate veil piercing claim under Pennsylvania law considers several factors, including, undercapitalization, failure to adhere to corporate formalities, the insolvency of the entity, substantial intermingling of corporate and personal affairs, use of the corporate form to perpetrate a fraud, and circumstances that present an element of injustice or unfairness.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Piercing Corporate Veil. Breach of contract claim premised on principal's own conduct did not require piercing corporate veil of licensing company to permit recovery.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: Russell Barnett Ford of Tullahoma, Inc. v. H & S Bakery, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, E.D. Tennessee, Winchester Division.
Headnote: Under Tennessee law, when considering whether to pierce the corporate veil, courts will consider whether the corporation was used to commit fraud or wrongdoing, but must also consider the following factors: (1) whether there was a failure to collect paid in capital, (2) whether the corporation was grossly undercapitalized, (3) the non-issuance of stock certificates, (4) the sole ownership of stock by one individual, (5) the use of the same office or business location, (6) the employment of the same employees or attorneys, (7) the use of the corporation as an instrumentality or business conduit for an individual or another corporation, (8) the diversion of corporate assets by or to a stockholder or other entity to the detriment of creditors, or the manipulation of assets and liabilities in another, (9) the use of the corporation as a subterfuge in illegal transactions, (10) the formation and use of the corporation to transfer to it the existing liability of another person or entity, and (11) the failure to maintain arms length relationships among related entities; not every factor needs to be met, nor will any single factor be dispositive in determining whether to pierce the corporate veil.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW  Contracts. Bakery business was not a party to contract for sale of commercial vehicles, and thus, could not be held liable for breach of that contract.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: Estate of Bogue v. Adams
Court: United States District Court, D. Colorado.
Headnote: Under Colorado law, in establishing whether such unity of interest exists as to disregard the corporate fiction and treat a corporation and shareholder as alter egos, courts consider a variety of factors, including whether (1) the corporation is operated as a distinct business entity, (2) funds and assets are commingled, (3) adequate corporate records are maintained, (4) the nature and form of the entity's ownership and control facilitate misuse by an insider, (5) the business is thinly capitalized, (6) the corporation is used as a mere shell, (7) shareholders disregard legal formalities, and (8) corporate funds or assets are used for noncorporate purposes.
Document Preview: TORTS  Fraud. Estate of decedent adequately alleged timeliness of its Colorado-law breach of fiduciary duty claim against investment industry professionals.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: Watamar Holding S.A. v. SFM Holdings, S.A.
Court: Court of Appeals of Texas, Houston (14th Dist.).
Headnote: For purposes of alter ego status, courts consider: payment of alleged corporate debt with personal checks or other commingling of funds, representations that individual will back corporation financially, diversion of corporate profits for personal use, and inadequate capitalization; an individual's status as an officer, director, or shareholder of an entity is not enough to support an alter ego finding.
Document Preview: LITIGATION  Jurisdiction. Trial court lacked personal jurisdiction over nonresident defendants and Swiss holding corporation.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: In re Garza
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, S.D. Texas, McAllen Division.
Headnote: Under Texas law, alter ego claim may be established from total dealings of corporation and the individual, including the degree to which corporate formalities have been followed, the degree of which corporate and individual property has been kept separate, the amount of financial interest, ownership and control that the individual maintains over the corporation, and whether the corporation has been used for personal purposes.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY  Debtor Protections. No emotional distress damages could be awarded for secured creditor's stay violation in repossessing vehicle.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: McKay v. Longman
Court: Supreme Court of Connecticut.
Headnote: In determining whether a corporation is dominated or controlled by the defendant, as element of instrumentality rule for piercing the corporate veil, courts consider a number of factors, including: (1) the absence of corporate formalities; (2) inadequate capitalization; (3) whether funds are put in and taken out of the corporation for personal rather than corporate purposes; (4) overlapping ownership, officers, directors, personnel; (5) common office space, address, phones; (6) the amount of business discretion by the allegedly dominated corporation; (7) whether the corporations dealt with each other at arm's length; (8) whether the corporations are treated as independent profit centers; (9) payment or guarantee of debts of the dominated corporation; and (10) whether the corporation in question had property that was used by other of the corporations as if it were its own.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Piercing Corporate Veil. Outsider reverse veil piercing is recognized despite prospective legislative prohibition.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: In re Trujillo
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, S.D. Florida.
Headnote: Under Florida law, notwithstanding the common reference to "shareholder" in alter ego cases, the focus is on who holds the equitable ownership and benefit of the corporate entity, rather than on formal share ownership, and accordingly that formal shareholder status is not a prerequisite to imposition of alter ego liability.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY  Bankruptcy Estate. Debtor was equitable owner of Panamanian foundation, such that assets of foundation were property of the bankruptcy estate subject to turnover.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: In re Brugnara Properties VI
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, N.D. California.
Headnote: Among factors which California courts consider in deciding whether requisite unity of interest exists, of a kind required for veil-piercing, are the following: (1) commingling of funds and other assets; (2) failure to segregate and the unauthorized diversion of funds or assets; (3) treatment by individual of assets of corporation as his own; (4) failure to obtain authority to issue stock; (5) holding out by individual that he is personally liable for debts of corporation; (6) failure to maintain minutes or adequate corporate records; (7) closely held nature of corporation; (8) use of same office or business location; (9) undercapitalized nature of corporation; (10) use of corporation as mere shell, instrumentality or conduit for single venture; (11) concealment and misrepresentation of identity of the responsible ownership; (12) disregard of corporate formalities; and (13) formation and use of corporation to transfer to it the existing liability of another person or entity.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Piercing Corporate Veil. Taxing authorities could pierce veil separating taxpayers from wholly owned corporation.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: Sedgwick Properties Development Corporation v. Hinds
Court: Colorado Court of Appeals, Division V.
Headnote: In determining whether a corporate entity is the alter ego of the person or entity in issue, courts consider a variety of factors, including whether (1) the corporation is operated as a distinct business entity, (2) funds and assets are commingled, (3) adequate corporate records are maintained, (4) the nature and form of the entity's ownership and control facilitate misuse by an insider, (5) the business is thinly capitalized, (6) the corporation is used as a mere shell, (7) legal formalities are disregarded, and (8) corporate funds or assets are used for noncorporate purposes.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Piercing Corporate Veil. Alleged undercapitalization of limited liability company (LLC) did not support piercing LLC's corporate veil in garnishment action.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: Sedgwick Properties Development Corporation v. Hinds
Court: Colorado Court of Appeals, Division V.
Headnote: Inquiry into whether a corporate entity is the alter ego of the person or entity in issue looks to the specific facts of each case, and not all of the factors that a court may consider need to be shown in order to establish alter ego status.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Piercing Corporate Veil. Alleged undercapitalization of limited liability company (LLC) did not support piercing LLC's corporate veil in garnishment action.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: Taszarek v. Lakeview Excavating, Inc.
Court: Supreme Court of North Dakota.
Headnote: Factors considered significant in determining whether or not to disregard the corporate entity include: insufficient capitalization for the purposes of the corporate undertaking, failure to observe corporate formalities, nonpayment of dividends, insolvency of the debtor corporation at the time of the transaction in question, siphoning of funds by the dominant shareholder, nonfunctioning of other officers and directors, absence of corporate records, and the existence of the corporation as merely a facade for individual dealings.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Piercing Corporate Veil. Judgment piercing the corporate veil contained insufficient findings to permit appellate review, and thus remand for further findings was required.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: Global Force Entertainment, Inc. v. Anthem Sports & Entertainment Corp.
Court: United States District Court, M.D. Tennessee, Nashville Division.
Headnote: Under Tennessee law, courts consider a number of factors in determining whether an alter ego relationship exists, including (1) whether there was a failure to collect paid in capital; (2) whether the corporation was grossly undercapitalized; (3) the nonissuance of stock certificates; (4) the sole ownership of stock by one individual; (5) the use of the same office or business location; (6) the employment of the same employees or attorneys; (7) the use of the corporation as an instrumentality or business conduit for an individual or another corporation; (8) the diversion of corporate assets by or to a stockholder or other entity to the detriment of creditors, or the manipulation of assets and liabilities in another; (9) the use of the corporation as a subterfuge in illegal transactions; (10) the formation and use of the corporation to transfer to it the existing liability of another person or entity; and (11) the failure to maintain arms length relationships among related entities.
Document Preview: COPYRIGHTS  Jurisdiction. General personal jurisdiction did not exist over nonresident parent company of wrestling events promoter, in copyright infringement action.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: In re Draw Another Circle.
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, D. Delaware.
Headnote: Under Delaware law, specific facts a court may consider when being asked to disregard the corporate form include: (1) whether the company was adequately capitalized for the undertaking, (2) whether the company was solvent, (3) whether corporate formalities were observed, (4) whether the dominant shareholder siphoned company funds, and (5) whether, in general, the company simply functioned as a façade of the dominant shareholder.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY  Business Relationships. Liquidating trustee stated claim against debtor's board chair for breach of fiduciary duty.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: Wade v. Touchdown Realty Group, LLC
Court: United States District Court, D. Massachusetts.
Headnote: Under Massachusetts law, courts consider multiple factors in determining whether to pierce the corporate veil, including (1) common ownership; (2) pervasive control; (3) confused intermingling of business assets; (4) thin capitalization; (5) nonobservance of corporate formalities; (6) absence of corporate records; (7) no payment of dividends; (8) insolvency at the time of the litigated transaction; (9) siphoning away of corporation's funds by dominant shareholder; (10) nonfunctioning of officers and directors; (11) use of the corporation for transactions of the dominant shareholders; and (12) use of the corporation in promoting fraud.
Document Preview: TORTS  Fraud. Purchasers' reliance on vendor's representation that home could be used as a three bedroom because it was grandfathered in was not unreasonable.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: Wade v. Touchdown Realty Group, LLC
Court: United States District Court, D. Massachusetts.
Headnote: Under Massachusetts law, factors to consider in determining whether to pierce the corporate veil are not simply added up, but rather are considered in an integrated manner based on all of the facts presented.
Document Preview: TORTS  Fraud. Purchasers' reliance on vendor's representation that home could be used as a three bedroom because it was grandfathered in was not unreasonable.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: Hickey v. Angelo
Court: Court of Appeal of Louisiana, Fourth Circuit.
Headnote: When a party seeks to pierce the corporate veil, the totality of the circumstances is determinative.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Piercing Corporate Veil. Finding of no exceptional circumstance warranting piercing corporate veil to hold owner of medical corporation personally liable was not clearly wrong.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: Denny v. Breawick, LLC
Court: Court of Appeals of Ohio, Third District, Hancock County.
Headnote: Some of the factors used to determine if a corporation is an individual's alter ego include (1) whether corporate formalities were observed, (2) whether corporate records were kept, (3) whether corporate funds were commingled with personal funds, and (4) whether corporate property was used for a personal purpose.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Piercing Corporate Veil. Contractor had such complete control over his companies that they had no separate mind of their own, as necessary to pierce corporate veil.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: In re Blast Fitness Group, LLC
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, D. Massachusetts, Eastern Division.
Headnote: In deciding whether to apply doctrine of corporate disregard in order to treat corporation as alter ego of its dominant shareholder or shareholders, Massachusetts courts consider the following relevant factors: (1) common ownership; (2) pervasive control; (3) confused intermingling of business assets; (4) thin capitalization; (5) nonobservance of corporate formalities; (6) absence of corporate records; (7) no payment of dividends; (8) insolvency at time of the litigated transaction; (9) siphoning away of corporation's funds by dominant shareholder; (10) nonfunctioning of officers and directors; (11) use of the corporation for transactions of the dominant shareholders; and (12) use of corporation in promoting fraud.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY  Claims. Chapter 7 trustee stated plausible claim for veil piercing and/or alter ego determination against affiliated entities under Massachusetts law.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: Martin Hilti Family Trust v. Knoedler Gallery, LLC
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: Courts consider the following factors in determining whether a corporation and its dominant shareholder operate as a single economic entity, such that it may pierce corporate veil and impose liability on shareholder: (1) whether the corporation was adequately capitalized for the corporate undertaking; (2) whether the corporation was solvent; (3) whether dividends were paid, corporate records kept, officers and directors functioned properly, and other corporate formalities were observed; (4) whether the dominant shareholder siphoned corporate funds; and (5) whether, in general, the corporation simply functioned as a facade for the dominant shareholder.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW  Fraudulent Transfers. Art gallery's owner was not liable to foreign trust for Racketeer Influenced and Corrupt Organizations Act claims.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: In re Blast Fitness Group, LLC
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, D. Massachusetts, Eastern Division.
Headnote: In deciding whether to apply doctrine of corporate disregard in order to treat corporation as alter ego of its dominant shareholder or shareholders, Massachusetts courts consider the following relevant factors: (1) common ownership; (2) pervasive control; (3) confused intermingling of business assets; (4) thin capitalization; (5) nonobservance of corporate formalities; (6) absence of corporate records; (7) no payment of dividends; (8) insolvency at time of the litigated transaction; (9) siphoning away of corporation's funds by dominant shareholder; (10) nonfunctioning of officers and directors; (11) use of the corporation for transactions of the dominant shareholders; and (12) use of corporation in promoting fraud.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY  Avoidance. Trustee stated plausible strong-arm claim to avoid transfer of right to acquire real estate.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: In re Blast Fitness Group, LLC
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, D. Massachusetts, Eastern Division.
Headnote: Relevant factors that Massachusetts courts consider when deciding whether to apply the doctrine of corporate disregard in order to treat corporation as alter ego of its dominant shareholder or shareholders are the following: (1) common ownership; (2) pervasive control; (3) confused intermingling of business assets; (4) thin capitalization; (5) nonobservance of corporate formalities; (6) absence of corporate records; (7) no payment of dividends; (8) insolvency at time of the litigated transaction; (9) siphoning away of corporation's funds by dominant shareholder; (10) nonfunctioning of officers and directors; (11) use of the corporation for transactions of the dominant shareholders; and (12) use of corporation in promoting fraud.

Title: Calipjo v. Purdy
Court: Supreme Court of Hawai‘i.
Headnote: No single factor is dispositive in determining whether a corporate entity is the alter ego of another.

Title: Hebert v. Vantage Travel Service, Inc.

Headnote: To determine whether to pierce the corporate veil under Massachusetts law, courts consider: (1) common ownership; (2) pervasive control; (3) confused intermingling of business assets; (4) thin capitalization; (5) nonobservance of corporate formalities; (6) absence of corporate records; (7) no payment of dividends; (8) insolvency at the time of the litigated transaction; (9) siphoning away of corporation's funds by dominant shareholder; (10) nonfunctioning of officers and directors; (11) use of the corporation for transactions of the dominant shareholders; and (12) use of the corporation in promoting fraud.

Title: Hebert v. Vantage Travel Service, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, D. Massachusetts.
Headnote: The factors for determining whether to pierce the corporate veil under Massachusetts law are weighed, not counted.
Document Preview: LITIGATION  Class Actions. Class certification was warranted with respect to proposed class of passengers on malfunctioning tour boat.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: Innerimages, Inc. v. Newman
Court: Court of Appeals of Tennessee, AT KNOXVILLE.
Headnote: Factors to be considered in determining whether to disregard the corporate veil include not only whether the entity has been used to work a fraud or injustice in contravention of public policy, but also: (1) whether there was a failure to collect paid in capital; (2) whether the corporation was grossly undercapitalized; (3) the non issuance of stock certificates; (4) the sole ownership of stock by one individual; (5) the use of the same office or business location; (6) the employment of the same employees or attorneys; (7) the use of the corporation as an instrumentality or business conduit for an individual or another corporation; (8) the diversion of corporate assets by or to a stockholder or other entity to the detriment of creditors, or the manipulation of assets and liabilities in another; (9) the use of the corporation as a subterfuge in illegal transactions; (10) the formation and use of the corporation to transfer to it the existing liability of another person or entity; and (11) the failure to maintain arms length relationships among related entities.
Document Preview: REAL PROPERTY  Homeowners Associations. Developer of gated community breached fiduciary duty to homeowners and was required to create homeowner's association and relinquish property control.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: Tisch v. Tisch
Court: Colorado Court of Appeals, Division III.
Headnote: To determine whether sufficient unity of interest exists between a corporation and a shareholder to establish alter ego, as would permit piercing the corporate veil, courts consider several factors, including whether (1) the corporation is operated as a distinct business entity, (2) funds and assets are commingled, (3) adequate corporate records are maintained, (4) the nature and form of the entity's ownership and control facilitate misuse by an insider, (5) the business is thinly capitalized, (6) the corporation is used as a "mere shell," (7) shareholders disregard legal formalities, and (8) corporate funds or assets are used for noncorporate purposes.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Derivative Actions. Minority shareholders of closely-held corporation sufficiently alleged claim that controlling shareholder engaged in civil theft with regard to profits not formally declared as distributions.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: Tisch v. Tisch
Court: Colorado Court of Appeals, Division III.
Headnote: A court may reverse pierce the corporate veil only upon a clear showing by the requesting party of all the following factors: (1) the controlling insider and the corporation are alter egos of each other; (2) justice requires recognizing the substance of the relationship over the corporate form because the corporate form is used to perpetuate a fraud or to defeat a rightful claim; and (3) an equitable result is achieved by piercing.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Derivative Actions. Minority shareholders of closely-held corporation sufficiently alleged claim that controlling shareholder engaged in civil theft with regard to profits not formally declared as distributions.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: In re Shapow
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, C.D. California, San Fernando Valley Division.
Headnote: Factors that California courts consider in deciding whether to pierce corporate veil, as suggesting an absence of separate personalities of individual and corporation, include the following: (1) a commingling of funds and other assets and a failure to segregate the funds of the separate entities; (2) treatment by individual of the assets of corporation as his own; (3) disregard of legal formalities and failure to maintain arm's length relationships among related entities; and (4) diversion of assets from corporation by or to a stockholder or another person or entity to detriment of creditors, or the manipulation of assets between entities so as to concentrate the assets in one and the liabilities in another.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY  Discharge. Creditor failed to demonstrate any false oath in failing to schedules assets owned by debtor individually.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: In re Shapow
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, C.D. California, San Fernando Valley Division.
Headnote: Under California law, no one factor governs whether there is an absence of separate personalities between individual and corporation, as required to pierce corporate veil; instead, courts must look at all the circumstances to determine whether veil-piercing doctrine should be applied.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY  Discharge. Creditor failed to demonstrate any false oath in failing to schedules assets owned by debtor individually.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: In re Shapow
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, C.D. California, San Fernando Valley Division.
Headnote: To pierce corporate veil under California law, there must be evidence of such critical facts as inadequate capitalization, commingling of assets, disregard of corporate formalities, or other facts which demonstrate the critical element, that an inequitable result would have followed if the corporate separateness had been respected.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY  Discharge. Creditor failed to demonstrate any false oath in failing to schedules assets owned by debtor individually.

Title: d'Amico Dry d.a.c. v. Nikka Finance, Inc.

Headnote: No uniform standard exists on whether corporate veil should be pierced; instead, courts should look to the totality of the circumstances.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: Wichita Destination Developers, Inc. v. Focus Hospitality Services, LLC
Court: United States District Court, D. Kansas.
Headnote: Under Kansas law, in determining whether to disregard the corporate entity, court looks to the following eight factors: (1) undercapitalization of a one-man corporation; (2) failure to observe corporate formalities; (3) nonpayment of dividends; (4) siphoning of corporate funds by the dominant stockholder; (5) nonfunctioning of other officers or directors; (6) absence of corporate records; (7) the use of the corporation as a facade for operations of the dominant stockholder or stockholders; and (8) the use of the corporate entity in promoting injustice or fraud.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Piercing Corporate Veil. Complaint stated claim for piercing corporate veil to collect judgment.
