Title: Eskelsen v. Theta Investment Company
Court: Court of Appeals of Utah.
Headnote: A non-exclusive list of factors courts consider in determining whether the "formalities requirement" has been met to a corporate entity and hold an individual liable as a debtor include: (1) undercapitalization of a one-person corporation; (2) failure to observe corporate formalities; (3) nonpayment of dividends; (4) siphoning of corporate funds by the dominant stockholder; (5) nonfunctioning of other officers or directors; (6) absence of corporate records; and (7) the use of the corporation as a facade for operations of the dominant stockholder or stockholders.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Limited Liability Companies. Record did not establish that LLC formed by debtors was the alter ego of debtors, so as to hold LLC liable for debt following debtors' default.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: D'Amico Dry D.A.C. v. Primera Maritime (Hellas) Limited
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: There is no rule about how many factors must be met to warrant piercing the corporate veil; rather, the general principle guiding courts in determining whether to pierce the corporate veil is that liability is imposed when doing so would achieve an equitable result.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Successor Liability. Ship management company was liable as a successor-in-interest for judgment incurred by predecessor in English court.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: Sky–Track Technology Company Limited v. HSS Development, Inc.
Court: Supreme Court, Appellate Division, Second Department, New York.
Headnote: Factors to be considered in determining whether an owner of a corporation has abused the privilege of doing business in the corporate form, as a plaintiff seeking to pierce the corporate veil must demonstrate, include whether there was a failure to adhere to corporate formalities, inadequate capitalization, commingling of assets, and use of corporate funds for personal use.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Piercing Corporate Veil. Plaintiff's conclusory, unsubstantiated claims were insufficient to allege abuse of privilege as would give rise to defendant's individual liability.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: Bartels v. Saber Healthcare Group, LLC
Court: United States District Court, E.D. North Carolina, Western Division.
Headnote: Under North Carolina law, the presence or absence of a particular factor is not determinative of whether to pierce the veil of a foreign corporation, and the alter ego or instrumentality theory of liability is an equitable one which aims to place the burden of loss on the party who should be held responsible.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Piercing Corporate Veil. Court would pierce corporate veil of assisted living care centers and affiliated corporations and apply forum selection clause to all defendants.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: In re Stage Presence, Inc.
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: Under New York law, non-exclusive factors that may be considered in deciding whether a corporation has been completely dominated by its owner to the point where the corporation has no separate identity, as required in order to pierce the corporate veil, include: the absence of the formalities that are part of corporate existence, for example, the issuance of stock, election of directors, and keeping of corporate records; inadequate capitalization; whether funds are put in and taken out of the corporation for personal rather than corporate purposes; overlaps in ownership, officers, directors and personnel; common office space, address and telephone numbers; the amount of business discretion displayed by the allegedly dominated corporation; whether the related corporation dealt with its owner or other related corporations at arm's-length; whether the corporation was treated as an independent profit center; the payment or guarantee of debts by the dominated corporation in favor of its owner or other related corporations; and whether the corporation in question had property that was used by the owner just as though it belonged to the owner.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY  Claims. Creditors failed to establish that corporate debtor was completely dominated by its sole owner, as required to pierce the corporate veil.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: Bazarian International Financial Associates, LLC v. Desarrollos Hotelco, C.A.
Court: United States District Court, District of Columbia.
Headnote: There is neither a precise formula by which to predict when courts will pierce the corporate veil and assign liability upon individual shareholder, since each case is sui generis, nor a uniform standard to determine whether the evidence has sufficiently demonstrated unity of interest and ownership; the factor which predominates will vary in each case, influenced by considerations of who should bear the risk of loss and what degree of legitimacy exists for those claiming the limited liability protection of a corporation.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW  Contracts. Under written agreement, investment banking company was entitled to recover unpaid debt fee, as damages, from developer and related entities.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: Tavadia v. Mitchell
Court: Court of Appeals of Kentucky.
Headnote: To assess whether domination of a corporation results in a loss of corporate separateness as an element of piercing the corporate veil, courts should analyze the following factors: (1) inadequate capitalization; (2) failure to issue stock; (3) failure to observe corporate formalities; (4) nonpayment of dividends; (5) insolvency of the debtor corporation; (6) nonfunctioning of the other officers or directors; (7) absence of corporate records; (8) commingling of funds; (9) diversion of assets from the corporation by or to a stockholder or other person or entity to the detriment of creditors; (10) failure to maintain arm's-length relationships among related entities; and (11) whether, in fact, the corporation is a mere façade for the operation of the dominant stockholders.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Piercing Corporate Veil. Acting CEO's use of company funds for personal expenses, while not respecting corporate formalities, resulted in a loss of corporate separateness.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: Tavadia v. Mitchell
Court: Court of Appeals of Kentucky.
Headnote: Factors for determining whether domination of a corporation resulted in a loss of corporate separateness are not simply a checklist to determine if element for doctrine of piercing the corporate veil is met; rather, a trial court should place more emphasis on the factors of grossly inadequate capitalization, egregious failure to observe corporate formalities, and a high degree of control over the corporation's day-to-day operations and decisions.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Piercing Corporate Veil. Acting CEO's use of company funds for personal expenses, while not respecting corporate formalities, resulted in a loss of corporate separateness.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: Lloyd's Syndicate 457 v. American Global Maritime Inc.
Court: United States District Court, S.D. Texas, Houston Division.
Headnote: In determining whether to pierce the veil, Louisiana courts examine the totality of circumstances, taking into consideration any commingling of funds, failure to follow corporate formalities, undercapitalization, failure to keep separate accounts and records, and failure to hold regular shareholder and director meetings.
Document Preview: TORTS  Negligence. Maritime warranty surveyor owed duty to insurers of all-risk commercial liability insurance policy to use reasonable care and competence.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: Rice v. First Energy Corp.
Court: United States District Court, W.D. Pennsylvania, Pittsburgh.
Headnote: Under Pennsylvania law, the factors to be considered in determining whether to pierce the corporate veil include, among other things, undercapitalization, failure to adhere to corporate formalities, substantial intermingling of corporate and personal affairs and use of the corporate form to perpetrate a fraud; courts may also consider whether the company is not paying dividends, the dominant shareholder has siphoned funds from the company, other officers or directors are not functioning, there is an absence of corporate records, and the corporation is merely a façade for the operations of the dominant stockholder or stockholders.
Document Preview: ENERGY AND UTILITIES  Electricity. Energy corporations were not liable for coal ash contamination stemming from power plants owned by subsidiaries.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: E.I. du Pont de Nemours and Company v. Agfa-Gavaert NV
Court: United States District Court, D. Delaware.
Headnote: Under Delaware law, courts consider the following factors when deciding whether to pierce corporate veil and disregard the corporate entity: (1) whether the company was adequately capitalized for the undertaking; (2) whether the company was solvent; (3) whether corporate formalities were observed; (4) whether the dominant shareholder siphoned company funds; and (5) whether, in general, the company simply functioned as a facade for the dominant shareholder.
Document Preview: LITIGATION  Jurisdiction. Subsidiary did not control other subsidiary of same parent, as could allow jurisdiction over subsidiary based on actions of other subsidiary.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: E.I. du Pont de Nemours and Company v. Agfa-Gavaert NV
Court: United States District Court, D. Delaware.
Headnote: Under Delaware law, in deciding whether to pierce corporate veil, no single factor is dispositive, and generally there must be some combination of them, and there must be an overall element of injustice or unfairness present.
Document Preview: LITIGATION  Jurisdiction. Subsidiary did not control other subsidiary of same parent, as could allow jurisdiction over subsidiary based on actions of other subsidiary.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: KDN Management, Inc. v. WinCo Foods, LLC
Court: Supreme Court of Idaho, Rexburg, May 2018 Term.
Headnote: Under Utah law, factors to consider in determining whether to pierce the corporate veil include: (1) undercapitalization of a one-man corporation; (2) failure to observe corporate formalities; (3) nonpayment of dividends; (4) siphoning of corporate funds by the dominant stockholder; (5) nonfunctioning of other officers or directors; (6) absence of corporate records; (7) the use of the corporation as a facade for operations of the dominant stockholder or stockholders; and (8) the use of the corporate entity in promoting injustice or fraud; these factors are helpful guidelines and not required elements.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Shareholders. Sole shareholder of company that breached concrete maintenance contract with grocery store chain was jointly and severally liable.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: In re Wyly
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, N.D. Texas, Dallas Division.
Headnote: Under Texas law, a court must consider the totality of the circumstances to determine whether the alter ego doctrine applies.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY  Claims. Debtor's transfer of partnership interest at time when he had unpaid tax liabilities was fraudulent within meaning of Texas fraudulent transfer law.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: Lunneborg v. My Fun Life
Court: Supreme Court of Idaho, Lewiston, April 2018 Term.
Headnote: Stock ownership, while important, is not a necessary prerequisite to pierce the corporate veil-it is merely one factor to consider.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Piercing Corporate Veil. Court could pierce corporate veil to hold sole shareholder's non-shareholder wife liable for damages award to former corporate employee.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: Lunneborg v. My Fun Life
Court: Supreme Court of Idaho, Lewiston, April 2018 Term.
Headnote: When a claimant seeks to hold a non-shareholder liable for corporate debts, the court may look to a range of evidence to consider whether fairness dictates allowing recovery against a non-shareholder-officer, with the primary consideration being the element of control or influence exercised by that person in the affairs of the corporation.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Piercing Corporate Veil. Court could pierce corporate veil to hold sole shareholder's non-shareholder wife liable for damages award to former corporate employee.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: CBF Industria de Gusa S/A v. AMCI Holdings, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: There is no set rule regarding how many factors must weigh in favor of piercing the corporate veil for control to be found; instead, the general principle followed by the courts has been that liability is imposed when doing so would achieve an equitable result.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW  Arbitration. Companies and individuals interrelated with buyer of pig iron were not deprived of full and fair opportunity to be heard.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: U.S. KingKing, LLC v. Precision Energy Services, Inc.
Court: Court of Appeals of Texas, Houston (1st Dist.).
Headnote: Alter ego, in the context of piercing the corporate veil, is determined from the total dealings of the corporation and the individual owner, including the degree to which corporate and individual property have been kept separate, the amount of financial interest, ownership, and control the individual maintains over the corporation, and whether the corporation has been used for personal purposes.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Piercing Corporate Veil. Factual issues as to if member of oil equipment supplier's customer, a limited-liability company, was customer's alter ego precluded summary judgment.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: U.S. KingKing, LLC v. Precision Energy Services, Inc.
Court: Court of Appeals of Texas, Houston (1st Dist.).
Headnote: As proof that a company and its owner are alter egos, as partially required to pierce the corporate veil, courts may consider: (1) the payment of alleged corporate debts with personal checks or other commingling of funds, (2) representations that the individual will financially back the corporation, (3) the diversion of company profits to the individual for his personal use, (4) inadequate capitalization, and (5) other failures to keep corporate and personal assets separate. Tex. Bus. Org. Code § 21.223(b).
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Piercing Corporate Veil. Factual issues as to if member of oil equipment supplier's customer, a limited-liability company, was customer's alter ego precluded summary judgment.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: Prompt Staffing, Inc. v. United States
Court: United States District Court, C.D. California.
Headnote: To determine whether a unity of interest exists under the alter ego doctrine, California courts consider the following list of non-exhaustive factors: (1) the commingling of funds and other assets; (2) the failure to segregate funds of the individual and the corporation; (3) the unauthorized diversion of corporate fluids to other than corporate purposes; (4) the treatment by an individual of corporate assets as his own; (5) the failure to seek authority to issue stock or issue stock under existing authorization; (6) the representation by an individual that he is personally liable for corporate debts; (7) the failure to maintain adequate corporate minutes or records; (8) the intermingling of the individual and corporate records; (9) the ownership of all the stock by a single individual or family; (10) the domination or control of the corporation by the stockholders; (11) the use of a single address for the individual and the corporation; (12) the inadequacy of the corporation's capitalization; (13) the use of the corporation as a mere conduit for an individual's business; (14) the concealment of the ownership of the corporation; (15) the disregard of formalities and the failure to maintain arm's-length transactions with the corporation; and (16) the attempts to segregate liabilities to the corporation.
Document Preview: TAXATION  Liens. In wrongful levy action, unity of interest existed between corporations' founder and corporations, as required under alter ego doctrine.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: Prompt Staffing, Inc. v. United States
Court: United States District Court, C.D. California.
Headnote: No single factor is determinative, in determining whether a unity of interest exists under the alter ego doctrine under California law, and courts must consider all the circumstances in deciding whether there is a unity of interest.
Document Preview: TAXATION  Liens. In wrongful levy action, unity of interest existed between corporations' founder and corporations, as required under alter ego doctrine.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: In re Bernard L. Madoff Investment Securities LLC
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: In deciding whether individual exercised such control over corporation that it had become a mere instrumentality, New York courts consider the following: (1) absence of formalities and paraphernalia which are part and parcel of corporate existence, such as issuance of stock and election of directors; (2) adequacy of capitalization; (3) whether funds were put in and taken out of corporation for personal rather than corporate purposes; (4) overlap in ownership; (5) common office space, address and telephone numbers; (6) amount of business discretion displayed by the allegedly dominated corporation; (7) whether related entities dealt with the dominated corporation at arm's length; (8) whether corporation was treated as independent profit center; (9) payment or guarantee of debts of dominated corporation; and (10) whether corporation had property used by others as if it were their own.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY  Avoidance. SIPA trustee stated basis for inferring that investors in Madoff Ponzi scheme knew of the fraud.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: Johnson v. New Destiny Christian Center Church, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, M.D. Florida, Orlando Division.
Headnote: Evidence demonstrating an absence of corporate formalities, lack of equity capital, proof of domination and control, and that a corporation was used as vehicle for personal interests, is not the correct standard to pierce the corporate veil under Florida law.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Piercing Corporate Veil. Piercing title holding company's corporate veil was not warranted in website operator's malicious prosecution action under Florida law.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: Hurricane Deck Holding Company v. Spanburg Investments, LLC
Court: Missouri Court of Appeals, Southern District, Division Two.
Headnote: The court will disregard a legal entity when the entity is operated while undercapitalized or if its assets are stripped to avoid the demands of creditors.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW  Fraudulent Transfers. Vendor failed to meet its burden to show that purchasers violated Uniform Fraudulent Trust Act (UFTA).

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: Shantou Real Lingerie Manufacturing Co., Ltd. v. Native Group International, Ltd.
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: Under New York law, courts are not required to find that every piercing the veil factor is present, and no one factor is dispositive.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Piercing Corporate Veil. Corporate debtor's principal dominated and controlled corporation, such that piercing the corporate veil was appropriate.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: Richard Nugent and CAO, Inc. v. Estate of Ellickson
Court: Court of Appeals of Texas, Houston (14th Dist.).
Headnote: In determining whether a corporation is organized and operated as a mere tool or business conduit of another, as required to pierce the corporate veil, the court considers the total dealings of the corporation and the individual, including the degree to which corporate formalities have been followed and corporate and individual property have been kept separately, the amount of financial interest, ownership and control the individual maintains over the corporation, and whether the corporation has been used for personal purposes.
Document Preview: REAL PROPERTY  Limitations. Four-year limitations period governing claims for breach of fiduciary duty arising out of negotiations of terms of sale began to run on date of closing.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: Richard Nugent and CAO, Inc. v. Estate of Ellickson
Court: Court of Appeals of Texas, Houston (14th Dist.).
Headnote: An individual's role as an officer, director, or majority shareholder of an entity alone is not sufficient to support a finding of alter ego liability, and the corporate structure will not be disregarded merely because of centralized control, mutual purposes, and shared finances.
Document Preview: REAL PROPERTY  Limitations. Four-year limitations period governing claims for breach of fiduciary duty arising out of negotiations of terms of sale began to run on date of closing.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: UIRC–GSA Holdings Inc. v. William Blair & Company, L.L.C.
Court: United States District Court, N.D. Illinois, Eastern Division.
Headnote: When determining whether a unity of interest and ownership exists to justify disregarding separate corporate identities under Illinois law, courts look to the following factors: inadequate capitalization; failing to issue stock; failing to observe corporate formalities; failing to pay dividends; corporate insolvency; nonfunctioning corporate officers; missing corporate records; commingling funds; diverting assets to an owner or other entity to creditor detriment; failing to maintain an arm's-length relationship among related entities; and whether the corporation is a mere façade for a dominant owner.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Piercing Corporate Veil. Investment bank stated a claim for piercing the corporate veil of bond issuer.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: UIRC–GSA Holdings Inc. v. William Blair & Company, L.L.C.
Court: United States District Court, N.D. Illinois, Eastern Division.
Headnote: No single factor is determinative of alter ego liability under Illinois law, and the court's inquiry invariably involves factual questions to be determined by the circumstances of each case.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Piercing Corporate Veil. Investment bank stated a claim for piercing the corporate veil of bond issuer.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: Malden Transportation, Inc. v. Uber Technologies, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, D. Massachusetts.
Headnote: Under Massachusetts law, courts consider a multitude of factors when deciding whether to pierce a corporate veil: (1) common ownership; (2) pervasive control; (3) confused intermingling of business assets; (4) thin capitalization; (5) nonobservance of corporate formalities; (6) absence of corporate records; (7) no payment of dividends; (8) insolvency at the time of the litigated transaction; (9) siphoning away of corporation's funds by dominant shareholder; (10) nonfunctioning of officers and directors; (11) use of the corporation for transactions of the dominant shareholders; and (12) use of the corporation in promoting fraud.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW  Jurisdiction. Specific personal jurisdiction did not exist over founders of passenger transportation service, in action by taxi drivers for unfair competition.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: Partridge v. American Hospital Management Company, LLC
Court: United States District Court, District of Columbia.
Headnote: Under District of Columbia law, in deciding whether to pierce the corporate veil in order to hold individual owners and officers of the corporation liable, courts consider such factors as, (1) whether corporate formalities have been disregarded, (2) whether corporate funds and assets have been extensively intermingled with personal assets, (3) inadequate initial capitalization, and (4) fraudulent use of the corporation to protect personal business from the claims of creditors.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Piercing Corporate Veil. Employee's allegations were sufficient to permit piercing corporate veil in order to assert breach of contract claims directly against CEO.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: Summer Haven Lake Association, Inc. v. Vlach
Court: Court of Appeals of Nebraska.
Headnote: Among the factors which are relevant in determining to disregard the corporate entity are diversion by the shareholder or shareholders of corporate funds or assets to their own or improper uses and the fact that the corporation is a mere facade for the personal dealings of the shareholder and that the operations of the corporation are carried on by the shareholder in disregard of the corporate entity.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW  Contracts. Purported shareholder in nonpublic lake association was bound individually by association's shareholder agreement.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: Allen v. American Capital Limited
Court: United States District Court, D. Arizona.
Headnote: Factors that bear on the analysis for piercing the corporate veil under Delaware law include: (1) whether the company was adequately capitalized for the undertaking; (2) whether the company was solvent; (3) whether corporate formalities were observed; (4) whether the dominant shareholder siphoned company funds; and (5) whether, in general, the company simply functioned as a façade for the dominant shareholder.
Document Preview: PRODUCTS LIABILITY  Defects. Methodology of product identification expert regarding vials of pharmaceutical product was not reliable.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: Stockdale v. Ellsworth
Court: Supreme Court of Colorado.
Headnote: To determine whether a corporation is an alter ego of its shareholder, a court should consider a number of factors, including whether: (1) the corporation is operated as a distinct business entity; (2) funds and assets are commingled; (3) adequate corporate records are maintained; (4) the nature and form of the entity's ownership and control facilitate misuse by an insider; (5) the business is thinly capitalized; (6) the corporation is used as a mere shell; (7) shareholders disregard legal formalities; and (8) corporate funds or assets are used for noncorporate purposes.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Piercing Corporate Veil. LLC was mere alter ego of shareholder, such that piercing of corporate veil was warranted.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: Daewoo Electronics America Inc. v. Opta Corporation
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Ninth Circuit.
Headnote: Under California law, in considering whether there is sufficient unity of interest and ownership, as an element of alter ego liability, relevant factors include whether there is inadequate capitalization, commingling of funds and other assets, holding out by one entity that it is liable for the debts of the other, identical equitable ownership, use of the same offices and employees, use of one as a mere conduit for the affairs of the other, disregard of corporate formalities, lack of segregation of corporate records, and identical directors and officers.
Document Preview: LITIGATION  Judgment. Judgment creditor's alter ego and successor liability claims against affiliated companies of judgment debtor were not barred by res judicata.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: Thomas v. Khrawesh
Court: United States District Court, E.D. Michigan, Southern Division.
Headnote: When analyzing the three factors considered by Michigan courts in determining whether to hold corporate officers personally liable, courts also consider the undercapitalization of the corporation, the maintenance of separate books, the separation of corporate and individual finances, the use of the corporation to support fraud or illegality, the honoring of corporate formalities, and whether the corporation is merely a sham.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Piercing Corporate Veil. Former employee of dissolved corporation could pierce corporate veil to collect, from corporation's owner, default judgment previously awarded against corporation.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: Mark Hershey Farms, Inc. v. Robinson
Court: Superior Court of Pennsylvania.
Headnote: In deciding whether to pierce the corporate veil, the Superior Court inquires, among other things, whether corporate formalities have been observed and corporate records kept, whether officers and directors other than the dominant shareholder himself actually function, and whether the dominant shareholder has used the assets of the corporation as if they were his own.
Document Preview: ESTATE PLANNING AND PROBATE  Beneficiaries. Theory of piercing the corporate veil could not be applied to hold estate beneficiary liable for debts of the estate.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: Chapco, Inc. v. Woodway USA, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, D. Connecticut.
Headnote: Courts, in assessing whether an entity is dominated or controlled, for purposes of piercing the corporate veil, consider a number of factors, including: (1) the absence of corporate formalities; (2) inadequate capitalization; (3) whether funds are put in and taken out of the corporation for personal rather than corporate purposes; (4) overlapping ownership, officers, directors, personnel; (5) common office space, address, phones; (6) the amount of business discretion by the allegedly dominated corporation; (7) whether the corporations dealt with each other at arm's length; (8) whether the corporations are treated as independent profit centers; (9) payment or guarantee of debts of the dominated corporation; and (10) whether the corporation in question had property that was used by other of the corporations as if it were its own.
Document Preview: PATENTS  Consumer Goods. Alleged infringer's treadmill products infringed on patentee's patent.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: City of Almaty v. Ablyazov
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: Under New York law, factors to be considered in determining whether corporation's owner has abused privilege of doing business in corporate form, thus warranting piercing of corporate veil, include whether there was failure to adhere to corporate formalities, inadequate capitalization, commingling of assets, and use of corporate funds for personal use.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW  Fraudulent Transfers. Kazakh city sufficiently pled plausible veil-piercing theory of liability to preclude dismissal of fraudulent conveyance claims against former mayor.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: In re Madeoy
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, D. Maryland, at Greenbelt.
Headnote: Among factors commonly considered by Maryland courts in deciding whether to apply alter ego doctrine are the following: (1) whether corporation is inadequately capitalized, fails to observe corporate formalities, fails to issue stock or pay dividends, or operates without profit; (2) whether there is commingling of corporate and personal assets; (3) whether there are non-functioning officers or directors; (4) whether corporation is insolvent at time of transaction; and (5) absence of corporate records.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY  Avoidance. No recovery for conspiring to commit fraudulent transfer by nontransferees and nonbeneficiaries.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: Kelleher v. Dream Catcher, L.L.C.
Court: United States District Court, District of Columbia.
Headnote: In determining whether to pierce the corporate veil, courts generally inquire as to whether corporate formalities have been observed, whether there has been commingling of corporate and shareholder funds, staff and property, whether a single shareholder dominates the corporation, whether the corporation is adequately capitalized, and, especially, whether the corporate form has been used to effectuate a fraud.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Limited Liability Companies. Homeowner plausibly alleged that owners of construction LLC were alter egos of LLC, and thus, could be held individually liable on homeowner's claims.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: Howard Town Center Developer, LLC v. Howard University
Court: United States District Court, District of Columbia.
Headnote: In determining whether to pierce the corporate veil to hold a corporate officer personally liable for corporation's obligations under District of Columbia law, courts generally consider, inter alia, (1) whether corporate formalities have been observed; (2) whether there has been commingling of corporate and shareholder funds, staff and property; (3) whether a single shareholder dominates the corporation; (4) whether the corporation is adequately capitalized; and, especially, (5) whether the corporate form has been used to effectuate a fraud.
Document Preview: EDUCATION  Property and Contracts. Under District of Columbia law, university landowner provided proper notice to developer prior to terminating ground lease and development agreement.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: Smith v. Carolina Medical Center
Court: United States District Court, E.D. Pennsylvania.
Headnote: In evaluating whether veil-piercing is appropriate, a court should consider whether the company failed to observe corporate formalities, had functioning officers and directors, or kept corporate records, and whether the owner and the corporation comingled funds so that the corporation is merely a facade for the operations of the owner.
Document Preview: GOVERNMENT  False Claims. Defendants' false certifications in enrollment documents supported False Claims Act liability.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: LaMusga v. Summit Square Rehab, LLC
Court: Court of Appeals of Ohio, Second District, Montgomery County.
Headnote: In determining whether a corporation is an individual's alter ego, Ohio appellate courts consider various factors, such as (1) whether corporate formalities were observed, (2) whether corporate records were kept, (3) whether corporate funds were commingled with personal funds, (4) whether corporate property was used for a personal purpose, and (5) gross undercapitalization; these factors are non-exclusive.
Document Preview: LABOR AND EMPLOYMENT  Employer's Liability. Security officer training company was not liable for death allegedly caused by actions of guards trained by company.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: United States v. TDC Management Corp.
Court: United States District Court, District of Columbia.
Headnote: Under District of Columbia law, to determine whether there is a sufficient unity of interest to warrant piercing the corporate veil, courts consider various factors, including: (1) whether a single shareholder dominates the corporation, (2) whether corporate formalities have been disregarded, (3) whether the corporation has maintained minutes or adequate corporate records, (4) whether corporate funds and assets have been extensively intermingled with personal assets, and (5) fraudulent use of the corporation to protect personal business from the claims of creditors.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Piercing Corporate Veil. Under alter ego theory, assets of corporation owned by judgment debtor were subject to garnishment by federal government as judgment creditor.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: United States v. TDC Management Corp.
Court: United States District Court, District of Columbia.
Headnote: Under District of Columbia law, no single factor for determining whether there is a sufficient unity of interest to warrant piercing the corporate veil predominates, and it is clearly not necessary that all of the factors be present in a given case to justify piercing the veil.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Piercing Corporate Veil. Under alter ego theory, assets of corporation owned by judgment debtor were subject to garnishment by federal government as judgment creditor.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: In re Sherrick
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, M.D. Tennessee.
Headnote: Under Tennessee law, factors to consider when deciding whether to remove the corporate protection include: (1) whether there was a failure to collect paid-in capital, (2) whether the corporation was grossly undercapitalized, (3) nonissuance of stock certificates, (4) sole ownership of stock by one individual, (5) use of the same office or business location, (6) employment of the same employees or attorneys, (7) use of the corporation as an instrumentality or business conduit for an individual or another corporation, (8) diversion of corporate assets by or to a stockholder or other entity to the detriment of creditors, or the manipulation of assets and liabilities in another, (9) use of the corporation as a subterfuge in illegal transactions, (10) formation and use of the corporation to transfer to it the existing liability of another person or entity, and (11) failure to maintain arms-length relationships among related entities.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY  Discharge. Debt owed creditor for work done on federal contract project fell within embezzlement discharge exception.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: In re Sherrick
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, M.D. Tennessee.
Headnote: In determining whether to pierce the corporate veil under Tennessee law, no single factor is conclusive, nor is it required that all relevant factors support piercing the corporate veil; typically, courts will rely on a combination of factors in deciding the issue.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY  Discharge. Debt owed creditor for work done on federal contract project fell within embezzlement discharge exception.

Title: All Finish Concrete, Inc. v. Erickson
Court: Court of Appeals of Minnesota.
Headnote: When determining whether to pierce the corporate veil a court may consider whether the corporate entity (1) is insufficiently capitalized; (2) fails to observe corporate formalities; (3) is insolvent; (4) fails to maintain corporate records; or (5) exists as a mere facade for individual dealings.

Title: All Finish Concrete, Inc. v. Erickson
Court: Court of Appeals of Minnesota.
Headnote: In determining whether the corporate entity should be disregarded, courts apply a two-prong test; the first prong requires the application of eight factors to determine the shareholder's relationship to the corporation, and the second prong of the test requires a showing that piercing the corporate veil is necessary to avoid injustice or fundamental unfairness.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Estoppel. Offensive collateral estoppel precluded sole shareholder of judgment debtor from relitigating issue of whether the corporate veil could be pierced.

Title: Cluck-U Chicken, Inc. v. Cluck-U Corp.

Headnote: Under Maryland law, ownership of a corporation by a single individual is not sufficient on its own to pierce the corporate veil.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >

Title: Benzakry v. Patel
Court: Appellate Court of Illinois, Third District.
Headnote: Courts look at various factors in determining whether to pierce the corporate veil, including inadequate capitalization, failure to issue stock, failure to observe corporate formalities, nonpayment of dividends, insolvency of the debtor corporation, nonfunctioning of the other officers or directors, absence of corporate records, commingling of funds, diversion of assets from the corporation by or to a shareholder, failure to maintain arm's length relationships among related entities, and whether the corporation is a mere facade for the operation of the dominant shareholders.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: Cohen v. Schroeder
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: In determining whether to impose personal liability on a corporation's owner based on operation as a single economic entity under Delaware law, district courts examine factors which reveal how the corporation operates and the particular defendant's relationship to that operation including: (1) whether the corporation was adequately capitalized for the corporate undertaking, (2) whether the corporation was solvent, (3) whether dividends were paid, corporate records kept, officers and directors functioned properly, and other corporate formalities were observed, (4) whether the dominant shareholder siphoned corporate funds, and (5) whether, in general, the corporation simply functioned as a facade for the dominant shareholder.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Piercing Corporate Veil. Piercing the corporate veil to impose personal liability on majority owner in small, privately-held Delaware corporation was unwarranted.

Headnote: While no single factor can justify a decision to disregard the corporate entity, some combination of them is required under Delaware law.

Title: Commonwealth v. Golden Gate National Senior Care LLC

Title: Landress v. Tier One Solar LLC
Court: United States District Court, M.D. North Carolina.
Headnote: Under North Carolina law, in determining whether corporate veil should be pierced, courts should consider following non-exhaustive factors: (1) inadequate capitalization; (2) non-compliance with corporate formalities; (3) complete domination and control; (4) excessive fragmentation; (5) non-payment of dividends; (6) debtor corporation's insolvency; (7) siphoning of funds by dominant shareholder; (8) non-functioning of other officers or directors; and (9) absence of corporate records.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: In re Packaged Seafood Products Antitrust Litigation
Court: United States District Court, S.D. California.
Headnote: Under California law, nonexclusive factors that can be used to support the first element to impose alter ego liability, unity of interest, include commingling of funds, failure to maintain minutes or adequate corporate records, identification of the equitable owners with the domination and control of the two entities, the use of the same office or business locations, the identical equitable ownership of the two entities, the use of a corporation as a mere shell, instrumentality or conduit for a single venture or the business of an individual, and the failure to adequately capitalize a corporation.
Document Preview: ANTITRUST  Conspiracy. Allegations of communications regarding collusive price increases were sufficient to allege parent companies' direct participation in conspiracy.

Title: In re Packaged Seafood Products Antitrust Litigation

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: Medici v. Lifespan Corp.
Court: United States District Court, D. Massachusetts.
Headnote: Massachusetts courts considering whether to allow the piercing of the corporate veil consider 12 factors, which are not formulaically added together, but rather, are considered in their totality based on the facts presented: (1) common ownership; (2) pervasive control; (3) confused intermingling of business assets; (4) thin capitalization; (5) nonobservance of corporate formalities; (6) absence of corporate records; (7) no payment of dividends; (8) insolvency at the time of the litigated transaction; (9) siphoning away of corporation's funds by dominant shareholder; (10) nonfunctioning of officers and directors; (11) use of the corporation for transactions of the dominant shareholders; and (12) use of the corporation in promoting fraud.
Document Preview: HEALTH  Discipline. Scientist had to exhaust his administrative remedies before Department of Health and Human Services' Office of Research Integrity before bringing suit challenging termination for research misconduct.

Title: TransFirst Group, Inc. v. Magliarditi

Headnote: Under Nevada law, courts consider the following factors as indicative of the existence of an alter-ego relationship: (1) commingling of funds; (2) undercapitalization; (3) unauthorized diversion of funds; (4) treatment of corporate assets as the individual's own; and (5) failure to observe corporate formalities.

Title: Fausse Riviere, L.L.C. v. Snyder
Court: Court of Appeal of Louisiana, First Circuit.
Headnote: Some of the circumstances that may point to veil piercing and disregarding the corporate identity are: (1) commingling of corporate and shareholder funds; (2) failure to follow statutory formalities for incorporating and transacting corporate activities; (3) under-capitalization; (4) failure to provide separate bank accounts and bookkeeping records; and (5) failure to hold regular shareholder and director meetings.

Title: In re Rouette
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, D. Connecticut, New Haven Division.
Headnote: Connecticut courts consider multiple factors in determining whether corporation was so controlled or dominated by the individual sought to be held liable for corporation's actions that corporate form should be disregarded, including the following: (1) failure to observe corporate formalities; (2) inadequate capitalization; (3) fact that funds are put in and taken out of the corporation for personal rather than corporate purposes; (4) overlapping ownership, officers, directors, and personnel; (5) common office space, address, and phones; and (6) amount of business discretion possessed by the allegedly dominated corporation.

Title: Gust, Inc. v. AlphaCap Ventures, LLC

Headnote: Under California law, factors suggesting an alter ego relationship include: (1) commingling of funds and other assets and failure to segregate funds of the separate entities; (2) the treatment by an individual of the assets of the corporation as his own; (3) the disregard of legal formalities and the failure to maintain arm's length relationships among related entities; and (4) the diversion of assets from a corporation by or to a stockholder or other person or entity, to the detriment of creditors, or the manipulation of assets between entities so as to concentrate the assets in one and the liabilities in another.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: United States v. Dynamic Visions, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, District of Columbia.
Headnote: To determine whether there is a sufficient unity of interest to warrant piercing the corporate veil, district courts consider the following factors: (1) the nature of the corporate ownership and control, (2) whether the corporation has maintained minutes or adequate corporate records, (3) whether the corporation has maintained corporate formalities necessary for issuance or subscription to stock, such as an independent board of directors' formal approval of the stock issue, (4) whether there is a commingling of funds and other assets of the corporation, (5) whether there is a diversion of the corporation's funds or assets to non-corporate uses such as the personal uses of the corporation's shareholders, and (6) whether the corporation and its individual shareholders use the same office or business location.
