Title: Premier Therapy, LLC v. Childs
Court: Court of Appeals of Ohio, Seventh District, Columbiana County.
Headnote: In the corporate context, a non-exhaustive list of factors which can be considered to determine whether the alter ego doctrine for piercing the corporate veil applies includes (1) inadequate capitalization, (2) insolvency at the time of the disputed act, (3) the individual held himself out as personally liable for certain corporate obligations, (4) siphoning of funds or assets of the entity for personal expenditures or use, (5) the entity's inability to pay debts due to high salaries or loans to shareholders, (6) commingling of individual and entity funds; (7) disregard of corporate roles; (8) disregard of corporate formalities, (9) lack of corporate records, especially regarding claimed loans to or from the entity to be pierced, (10) common office space, (11) personnel, and (12) the degree of domination by the person to be held liable, e.g., where the corporation was a mere facade for the operations of the dominant shareholders.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Issue of whether guarantor of loan for purchasers of nursing home was alter ego for home such that corporate veil could be pierced was question for jury.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: Tatung Company, Ltd. v. Shu Tze Hsu
Court: United States District Court, C.D. California, Southern Division.
Headnote: No single factor is determinative in determining whether a party is the alter ego of a corporation, and instead a court must examine all the circumstances to determine whether to apply the alter ego doctrine under California law.
Document Preview: TORTS  RICO. Creditor suffered domestic injury to business or property, as required to recover for civil RICO violation against foreign debtor.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: Olivieri Const. Corp. v. WN Weaver Street, LLC
Court: Supreme Court, Appellate Division, Second Department, New York.
Headnote: Factors to be considered in determining whether an individual has abused the privilege of doing business in the corporate or limited liability company (LLC) form, as required to pierce the corporate veil, include the failure to adhere to corporate or LLC formalities, inadequate capitalization, commingling of assets, and the personal use of corporate or LLC funds.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Subcontractor alleged that shareholder engaged in acts amounting to abuse of corporate form, as required to pierce corporate veil.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: United States ex. rel. Scollick v. Narula
Court: United States District Court, District of Columbia.
Headnote: In determining whether there is sufficient unity of interest and ownership to warrant piercing corporate veil, courts may consider nature of corporate ownership and control, i.e., whether corporation is alter ego of individual who controls it; failure to maintain corporate records; failure to maintain corporate formalities necessary for issuance or subscription to stock; commingling of funds or assets; diversion of corporate funds or assets for personal use; and use of same office by corporation and by individuals.
Document Preview: GOVERNMENT  False Claims. Relator stated plausible false presentment and false statement claims against contractor's officers under False Claims Act.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: Jefferson v. Collins
Court: United States District Court, District of Columbia.
Headnote: In determining whether the corporation is the alter ego of its shareholders, as basis for piercing the corporate veil under District of Columbia law, the court will consider various factors, such as: (1) whether corporate formalities have been disregarded; (2) whether corporate funds and assets have been extensively intermingled with personal assets; (3) inadequate initial capitalization; and (4) fraudulent use of the corporation to protect personal business from the claims of creditors.
Document Preview: REAL PROPERTY  Vendor and Purchaser. Water bill did not allow inference that vendor had actual knowledge of water leak.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: In re Stillwater Asset Backed Offshore Fund Ltd.
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: Under Delaware law, in determining whether to disregard corporate form to assert alter ego liability, factors that court may consider include: whether company to be disregarded was adequately capitalized; whether company to be disregarded was solvent; whether dividends were paid, corporate records kept, officers and directors functioned properly, and other corporate formalities were observed; whether dominant shareholder siphoned corporate funds; and whether, in general, corporation simply functioned as facade for dominant shareholder.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY  Real Property. Debtor that had owned participation interests in mortgage loans made by third party had no property interest in mortgaged properties.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: Monster Heavy Haulers, LLC v. Goliath Energy Services, LLC
Court: Supreme Court of North Dakota.
Headnote: Factors considered significant in determining whether or not to disregard the corporate entity include insufficient capitalization for the purposes of the corporate undertaking, failure to observe corporate formalities, nonpayment of dividends, insolvency of the debtor corporation at the time of the transaction in question, siphoning of funds by the dominant shareholder, nonfunctioning of other officers and directors, absence of corporate records, and the existence of the corporation as merely a facade for individual dealings.
Document Preview: LITIGATION - Process. Signed return receipts for service by certified mail raised rebuttable presumption of valid service of process.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: Taszarek v. Lakeview Excavating, Inc.
Court: Supreme Court of North Dakota.
Headnote: In deciding whether an alter ego claim has been established to pierce the corporate veil, courts examine various factors which reveal how the corporation operates and the particular defendant's relationship to that operation; these factors are similar to the factors considered in determining whether to disregard a corporate entity, which include (1) insufficient capitalization for the purposes of the corporate undertaking, (2) failure to observe corporate formalities, nonpayment of dividends, (3) insolvency of the debtor corporation at the time of the transaction in question, (4) siphoning of funds by the dominant shareholder, (5) nonfunctioning of other officers and directors, (6) absence of corporate records, and (7) the existence of the corporation as merely a facade for individual dealings.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Failure to object to alter ego instruction constituted consent to allow jury to consider whether contractor was alter ego of its president.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: Commonwealth Department of Environmental Protection v. Trainer Custom Chemical LLC
Court: United States District Court, E.D. Pennsylvania.
Headnote: Under Pennsylvania law, in determining whether to pierce the corporate veil, courts consider, among other things, whether: (1) the company is undercapitalized; (2) there has been a failure to observe corporate formalities; (3) the dominant shareholder has siphoned funds from the company; (4) other officers or directors are not functioning; (5) there is an absence of corporate records; and (6) the corporation is merely a facade for the operations of the dominant stockholder or stockholders.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Piercing Corporate Veil. Evidence that LLC was undercapitalized and did not comply with corporate formalities was insufficient to pierce corporate veil under alter ego theory.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: In re Crabtree
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, D. Minnesota.
Headnote: Minnesota courts employ two-step analysis when determining whether corporate entity is alter ego of individual, under which they first consider the relationship between the corporation and the individual, focusing on factors such as a failure to observe corporate formalities, siphoning of corporate funds by the individual, absence of corporate records, and existence of corporation merely as a facade for the individual, and then consider nature of relationship between corporation and party seeking to pierce corporate veil and whether corporation has operated in a fraudulent or unjust manner toward that party.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY  Bankruptcy Estate. Conversion of nonexempt assets to homestead triggers limitation on exemption rights.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: United States v. Executive Health Resources, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, E.D. Pennsylvania.
Headnote: When deciding whether to pierce the corporate veil under the federal common law test, a court must examine the following factors : gross undercapitalization, failure to observe corporate formalities, nonpayment of dividends, insolvency of debtor corporation, siphoning of funds from the debtor corporation by the dominant stockholder, nonfunctioning of officers and directors, absence of corporate records, and whether the corporation is merely a facade for the operations of the dominant stockholder.
Document Preview: GOVERNMENT  False Claims. Relator alleged nationwide scope of scheme with sufficient particularity in FCA action against physician advisor company.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: United States v. Executive Health Resources, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, E.D. Pennsylvania.
Headnote: The factors to be considered under the federal common law test for piercing the corporate veil do not constitute elements of a rigid test; instead, the key inquiry is into whether the debtor corporation is little more than a legal fiction.
Document Preview: GOVERNMENT  False Claims. Relator alleged nationwide scope of scheme with sufficient particularity in FCA action against physician advisor company.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: Egan v. Tenet Health Care
Court: United States District Court, D. Massachusetts.
Headnote: Under Massachusetts law, in determining whether circumstances warrant the operation of the doctrine of corporate disregard, a court considers: (1) common ownership; (2) pervasive control; (3) confused intermingling of business assets; (4) thin capitalization; (5) nonobservance of corporate formalities; (6) absence of corporate records; (7) no payment of dividends; (8) insolvency at the time of the litigated transaction; (9) siphoning away of corporation's funds by dominant shareholder; (10) non-functioning of officers and directors; (11) use of the corporation for transactions of the dominant shareholders; and (12) use of the corporation in promoting fraud.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Parent and Subsidiary. Application of doctrine of corporate disregard was not warranted in employment action, and thus service on manager at subsidiary was insufficient.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: Motir Services, Inc. v. Ekwuno
Court: United States District Court, District of Columbia.
Headnote: In determining whether to pierce the corporate veil to hold a corporate officer personally liable for corporation's obligations under District of Columbia law, courts generally consider various factors, including: (1) whether corporate formalities have been observed; (2) whether there has been commingling of corporate and shareholder funds, staff and property; (3) whether a single shareholder dominates the corporation; (4) whether the corporation is adequately capitalized; and, especially, (5) whether the corporate form has been used to effectuate a fraud.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Piercing Corporate Veil. Contractor's substandard work and untimeliness did not show disregard of corporate formalities or use of corporation as alter ego for fraud.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: Gourdine v. Karl Storz Endoscopy–America, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, D. South Carolina, Charleston Division.
Headnote: Under California alter ego law, conditions under which the corporate entity may be disregarded or the corporation be regarded as the alter ego of the stockholders vary according to the circumstances in each case inasmuch as the doctrine is essentially an equitable one.
Document Preview: PRODUCTS LIABILITY  Jurisdiction. District court could exercise personal jurisdiction over German medical device manufacturer in products liability action.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: Albuquerque Facility, LLC v. Danielson
Court: United States District Court, D. New Mexico.
Headnote: Under the alter ego doctrine, a corporation may be found to be a mere instrumentality of an individual if: (1) the corporation is undercapitalized, (2) without separate books, (3) its finances are not kept separate from individual finances, individual obligations are paid by the corporation or vice versa, (4) corporate formalities are not followed, or (5) the corporation is merely a sham.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Piercing Corporate Veil. Managing member of limited liability company lacked minimum contacts required for exercise of personal jurisdiction for alter ego claim.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: Selfridge v. Jama
Court: United States District Court, D. Massachusetts.
Headnote: To pierce the corporate veil in Massachusetts and hold individual officers of corporation liable for corporation's acts, court must consider numerous factors, including: (1) common ownership; (2) pervasive control; (3) confused intermingling of business activity assets, or management; (4) thin capitalization; (5) nonobservance of corporate formalities; (6) absence of corporate records; (7) no payment of dividends; (8) insolvency at the time of the litigated transaction; (9) siphoning away of corporate assets by the dominant shareholders; (10) nonfunctioning of officers and directors; (11) use of the corporation for transactions of the dominant shareholders; (12) use of the corporations in promoting fraud.
Document Preview: LABOR AND EMPLOYMENT  Wrongful Discharge. Employer's conduct in terminating employee was not extreme or outrageous.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: Continental Cas. Co. v. Symons
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Seventh Circuit.
Headnote: Alter-ego analysis under Indiana law proceeds along the so-called Aronson factors including (1) undercapitalization; (2) absence of corporate records; (3) fraudulent representation by corporation shareholders or directors; (4) use of corporation to promote fraud, injustice, or illegal activities; (5) payment by corporation of individual obligations; (6) commingling of assets and affairs; (7) failure to observe required corporate formalities; or (8) other shareholder acts or conduct ignoring, controlling, or manipulating the corporate form.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Court could pierce veil and hold shareholders liable for crop insurance business buyers' fraudulent transfer of resale proceeds to related corporations.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: McBeth v. Porges
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: The fact intensive alter ego inquiry under Delaware law for piercing the corporate veil requires a court to determine whether the relevant parties operated as a "single entity" by considering factors such as: (1) whether the company was adequately capitalized for the undertaking; (2) whether the company was solvent; (3) whether corporate formalities were observed; (4) whether the controlling shareholder siphoned company funds; and (5) whether, in general, the company simply functioned as a facade for the controlling shareholder.
Document Preview: TORTS  Fraud. Sophisticated investor's reliance on any statements made by defendants prior to execution of offering papers was unreasonable.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: Aldmyr Systems, Inc. v. Friedman
Court: United States District Court, D. Maryland.
Headnote: To determine whether an entity is the alter ego of an individual, warranting piercing of the corporate veil, courts consider such factors as gross undercapitalization, insolvency, siphoning of funds, failure to observe corporate formalities and maintain proper corporate records, non-functioning of officers, control by a dominant stockholder, and injustice or fundamental unfairness, but these factors do not create a firm rule.
Document Preview: LITIGATION  Jurisdiction. Under domestic relations exception, federal court did not have jurisdiction over corporations' claims against attorney who represented CEO's wife.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: Accurso v. Infra-Red Services, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, E.D. Pennsylvania.
Headnote: The courts in Pennsylvania look at the following factors to determine whether a corporation is being operated as an alter ego of an individual defendant: (1) undercapitalization; (2) failure to adhere to corporate formalities; (3) substantial intermingling of corporate and personal affairs, and (4) use of the corporate form to perpetrate a fraud.
Document Preview: LITIGATION  Sanctions. Spoliation sanctions would not be imposed on employee after he apparently deleted all of his personal e-mails.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: Steiner Elec. Co. v. Maniscalco
Court: Appellate Court of Illinois, First District, Third Division.
Headnote: In determining whether the "unity of interest and ownership" prong of the piercing-the-corporate-veil test is met, a court generally will not rest its decision on a single factor, but will examine many factors, including: (1) inadequate capitalization; (2) failure to issue stock; (3) failure to observe corporate formalities; (4) nonpayment of dividends; (5) insolvency of the debtor corporation; (6) nonfunctioning of the other officers or directors; (7) absence of corporate records; (8) commingling of funds; (9) diversion of assets from the corporation by or to a stockholder or other person or entity to the detriment of creditors; (10) failure to maintain arm's-length relationships among related entities; and (11) whether, in fact, the corporation is a mere façade for the operation of the dominant stockholders.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Costs. Judgment creditor was entitled to attorney fees incurred in piercing corporate veil and collecting judgment.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: U.S. v. Vernon
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Tenth Circuit.
Headnote: Where a non-owner of a corporation is allowed by the nominal owner to dominate and control the corporation at issue, the corporation can be treated as the non-owner's alter ego.
Document Preview: CRIMINAL JUSTICE - Taxes. Evidence was sufficient to establish that defendant exercised complete control over corporation, rendering it a sham corporation to evade tax laws.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: Walnut Housing Associates 2003 L.P. v. MCAP Walnut Housing LLC
Court: Supreme Court, Appellate Division, First Department, New York.
Headnote: Delaware courts apply the alter ego theory rather strictly and, in determining the sufficiency of a piercing-the-corporate-veil claim, will often consider a combination of factors including whether a company was adequately capitalized or solvent, whether corporate formalities were observed, whether the dominant shareholder siphoned company funds and whether, in general the company simply functioned as a facade for the dominant shareholder.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW - Guaranty. Dismissing breach of guaranty agreement claim was unwarranted, as it was premature to determine that damages were speculative.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: In re Tronox Incorporated
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: Delaware courts look to several factors to determine whether to pierce the corporate veil, including whether: (1) the corporation was adequately capitalized for the corporate undertaking, (2) the corporation was solvent, (3) dividends were paid, corporate records kept, officers and directors functioned properly, and other corporate formalities were observed, (4) the dominant shareholder siphoned corporate funds, and (5) in general, the corporation simply functioned as a facade for the dominant shareholder.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY  Injunction. Injunction in settlement agreement barred tort claimants' claims against Chapter 11 debtors' former ultimate parent.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: Norfolk Southern Railway Company v. Pittsburgh & West Virginia Railroad
Court: United States District Court, W.D. Pennsylvania.
Headnote: Under Pennsylvania laws, a court must consider several factors in deciding whether to disregard the corporate form by veil piercing: (1) the failure to observe corporate formalities, (2) non-payment of dividends, (3) insolvency of debtor corporation, (4) siphoning funds from corporation by dominant shareholders, (5) non-functioning of other officers and directors, (6) absence of corporate records, (7) whether the corporation is a mere facade for the operations of a common shareholder or shareholders, and (8) gross under-capitalization.
Document Preview: TRANSPORTATION  Railroads. Lessor's fraud against lessee of railroad line did not justify award of punitive damages.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: In re ES2 Sports & Leisure, LLC
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, M.D. North Carolina, Greensboro Division.
Headnote: Under North Carolina law, factors that are considered with respect to the element of control under the instrumentality rule to pierce the corporate veil include: (1) inadequate capitalization, (2) non-compliance with corporate formalities, (3) complete domination and control of the corporation so that it has no independent identity, and (4) excessive fragmentation of a single enterprise into separate corporations.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY  Claims. Debtor's parent company and its majority owner were liable for unjust enrichment for retaining security deposit rightfully payable to debtor.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: Clientron Corp. v. Devon IT, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, E.D. Pennsylvania.
Headnote: Under Pennsylvania law, factors court considers with respect to alter ego theory and piercing the corporate veil include: (1) failure to observe corporate formalities; (2) non-payment of dividends; (3) insolvency of debtor corporation; (4) siphoning the funds from corporation by dominant shareholders; (5) non-functioning of other officers and directors; (6) absence of corporate records; (7) whether the corporation is a mere facade for the operations of a common shareholder or shareholders; and (8) gross undercapitalization.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW  Contracts. Multimillion dollar business transactions were required to be in writing.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: People v. Abrams
Court: Appellate Court of Illinois, First District, Second Division.
Headnote: In the context of piercing the corporate veil, an alter ego analysis starts with examining the factors which reveal how the corporation operates and the particular party's relationship to that operation.
Document Preview: CRIMINAL JUSTICE - Sentencing. Trial court did not abuse its discretion in sentencing 68-year-old defendant, convicted of theft of more than $1.8 million, to 12-year term.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: Lomas v. Kravitz
Court: Superior Court of Pennsylvania.
Headnote: Courts consider the following factors when determining whether to pierce the corporate veil: (1) undercapitalization; (2) failure to adhere to corporate formalities; (3) substantial intermingling of corporate and personal affairs, and (4) use of the corporate form to perpetrate a fraud.
Document Preview: LITIGATION - Judges. Recusal of court of common pleas judge who presided over action by contractor against developer was not warranted.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: Securities and Exchange Commission v. Cooper
Court: United States District Court, D. New Jersey, Camden Vicinage.
Headnote: In determining whether to pierce the corporate veil, courts consider the following factors: failure to observe corporate formalities, siphoning of funds from the debtor corporation by the dominant stockholder, nonfunctioning of officers and directors, absence of corporate records, and whether the corporation is merely a facade for the operations of the dominant stockholder.
Document Preview: SECURITIES REGULATION  Fraud. Seller of fictitious investments acted with scienter while employing fraudulent scheme, as required to establish securities fraud violation.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: Securities and Exchange Commission v. Cooper
Court: United States District Court, D. New Jersey, Camden Vicinage.
Headnote: The factors used to determine whether to pierce the corporate veil are not a rigid test; the essential inquiry is whether the corporation is little more than a legal fiction.
Document Preview: SECURITIES REGULATION  Fraud. Seller of fictitious investments acted with scienter while employing fraudulent scheme, as required to establish securities fraud violation.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: Johnson v. Serenity Transportation, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, N.D. California.
Headnote: Under California law, when assessing whether there is unity of interest between a corporation and an individual for the purposes of piercing the corporate veil under alter ego liability, courts consider, among other factors, the commingling of funds and other assets, the failure to segregate funds of the individual and the corporation, the unauthorized diversion of corporate funds to other than corporate purposes, the treatment by an individual of corporate assets as his own, the failure to seek authority to issue stock or issue stock under existing authorization, the representation by an individual that he is personally liable for corporate debts, the failure to maintain adequate corporate minutes or records, the intermingling of the individual and corporate records, the ownership of all the stock by a single individual or family, the domination or control of the corporation by the stockholders, the use of a single address for the individual and the corporation, the inadequacy of the corporation's capitalization, the use of the corporation as a mere conduit for an individual's business, the concealment of the ownership of the corporation, the disregard of formalities and the failure to maintain arm's-length transactions with the corporation, and the attempts to segregate liabilities to the corporation.
Document Preview: LABOR AND EMPLOYMENT  Hours and Wages. Employer's customers were not joint employers of workers, who were mortuary drivers, and thus customers could not be liable under FLSA.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: Equitas Disability Advocates, LLC v. Bryant
Court: United States District Court, District of Columbia.
Headnote: In determining whether to pierce the corporate veil under District of Columbia law, courts look to the following factors: (1) whether corporate formalities have been disregarded; (2) whether corporate funds and assets have been extensively intermingled with personal assets; (3) inadequate initial capitalization; and (4) fraudulent use of the corporation to protect personal business from the claims of creditors.
Document Preview: LEGAL SERVICES  Law Firms. Shareholders in professional corporation were not liable under partnership by estoppel.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: Morrissey v. Krystopowicz
Court: Court of Appeals of New Mexico.
Headnote: Under certain circumstances, courts may exercise their equitable power to pierce the corporate veil, thereby requiring shareholders to answer for the corporation's liability; to do so, a court must find that (1) the corporation was operated not in a legitimate fashion to serve the valid goals and purposes of the corporation, but instead under the domination and control and for the purposes of some dominant party, (2) there is some form of moral culpability attributable to the shareholder, such as use of the corporation to perpetrate a fraud, and (3) there is some reasonable relationship between the injury suffered by the plaintiff and the actions of the defendant.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Causal connection existed between shareholder's abuse of corporate form and nursing home resident's death.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: Situ v. O'Neill
Court: United States District Court, D. Puerto Rico.
Headnote: Federal common law factors used to determine whether to disregard the corporate entity include: (1) undercapitalization; (2) nonpayment of dividends; (3) extensive or pervasive control by the shareholder or shareholders; (4) intermingling of the corporation's funds, properties or accounts; (5) a failure to observe corporate formalities; (6) siphoning of funds from the corporation; (7) an absence of corporate records; and (8) non-functioning officers or directors.
Document Preview: TORTS - Premises Liability. Fact issues precluded summary judgment on negligence claims brought by relatives of guest who died from gas explosion.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: Situ v. O'Neill
Court: United States District Court, D. Puerto Rico.
Headnote: Under Puerto Rico law, the non-issuance of stock by a corporation is a factor supporting piercing the corporate veil.
Document Preview: TORTS - Premises Liability. Fact issues precluded summary judgment on negligence claims brought by relatives of guest who died from gas explosion.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: Gajda v. Steel Solutions Firm, Inc.
Court: Appellate Court of Illinois, First District, Fourth Division.
Headnote: In determining whether to pierce the corporate veil, the court considers several factors to determine if there is a unity of ownership and interest, including (1) inadequate capitalization; (2) failure to issue stock; (3) failure to observe corporate formalities; (4) nonpayment of dividends; (5) insolvency of the debtor corporation; (6) nonfunctioning of the other officers or directors; (7) absence of corporate records; (8) commingling of funds; (9) diversion of assets from the corporation by or to a stockholder or other person or entity to the detriment of creditors; (10) failure to maintain arm's-length relationships among related entities; and (11) whether, in fact, the corporation is a mere façade for the operation of the dominant stockholders.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Pleading. Dismissal of complaint was not warranted even though plaintiffs improperly pleaded piercing of corporate veil.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: Sentry Ins. v. Brand Management Inc.
Court: United States District Court, E.D. New York.
Headnote: Under New York law, every single factor need not weigh in favor of piercing the corporate veil; a court only needs to find that the balance of the relevant factors weighs in favor of either party on proven facts not contradicted by other admissible proof.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Principal of related professional employment organizations was liable for debt of those organizations under alter ego theory.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: Hawkeye Land Co. v. ITC Midwest LLC
Court: United States District Court, N.D. Iowa, Central Division.
Headnote: Under Iowa law, there are exceptional circumstances when court will decide to pierce the veil of limited liability company and hold members or managers individually liable; e.g., six factors support court's decision to pierce corporate veil, including (1) it is undercapitalized, (2) it is without separate books, (3) its finances are not separated from individual finances, (4) it pays an individual's obligations, (5) it is used to promote fraud or illegality, or (6) it is merely a sham.
Document Preview: REAL PROPERTY - Nuisance. Property owner stated plausible claim for unreasonable interference with private property based on construction of transmission lines on its property.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: Simons v. Park City RV Resort, LLC
Court: Court of Appeals of Utah.
Headnote: The significant, but not conclusive, factors for determining whether the formalities requirement of the test for piercing the corporate veil has been met include: (1) undercapitalization of a one-man corporation, (2) failure to observe corporate formalities, (3) nonpayment of dividends, (4) siphoning of corporate funds by the dominant stockholder, (5) nonfunctioning of other officers or directors, (6) absence of corporate records, and (7) the use of the corporation as a facade for operations of the dominant stockholder or stockholders.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Homeowner failed to show unity of interest and ownership between construction company and its president to pierce corporate veil.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: Kain Development, LLC v. Krause Properties, LLC
Court: Supreme Court, Appellate Division, Third Department, New York.
Headnote: Absent fraud, the corporate veil may be pierced in order to achieve equity when a corporation has been so dominated by individuals or other entities that it primarily transacts the dominators' business instead of its own; this inquiry includes consideration of factors such as the overlap in ownership, officers, directors and personnel, the capitalization of the corporation, any commingling of assets and the presence, or absence, of the formalities that attend the corporate form.
Document Preview: REAL PROPERTY - Vendor and Purchaser. Purchaser repudiated, rather than terminated, contract for sale of real property.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: Cioffi v. S.M. Foods, Inc.
Court: Supreme Court, Appellate Division, Second Department, New York.
Headnote: The concept of piercing the corporate veil is equitable in nature, and the decision whether to pierce in a given instance will depend on the facts and circumstances.
Document Preview: TRANSPORTATION - Motor Vehicles. Criminal wrongdoing exception to statute shielding motor vehicle owners from vicarious liability only applied to wrongdoing proximately causing injuries.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: Gerritsen v. Warner Bros. Entertainment Inc.
Court: United States District Court, C.D. California.
Headnote: Plaintiff can plead a number of different factors to show "unity of interest," and among factors to be considered in applying this prong of alter ego doctrine are commingling of funds and other assets of the two entities, the holding out by one entity that it is liable for the debts of the other, identical equitable ownership in the two entities, use of the same offices and employees, and use of one as a mere shell or conduit for the affairs of the other; this list is non-exclusive, and California courts have relied on host of other factors.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Successor Liability. Author's amended complaint failed to allege plausible claims against entertainment corporation on successor-in-interest theory.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: EV Scarsdale Corp. v. Engel & Voelkers North East LLC
Court: Supreme Court, New York County, New York.
Headnote: While there are no definitive rules governing the varying circumstances when veil piercing power may be exercised, courts consider various factors, such as lack of corporate formalities, to evaluate whether the alleged alter egos should be treated as an independent entities for liability purposes.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Franchises and Dealerships. Franchisees' fraudulent inducement claim under New York Franchise Sales Act was not barred by agreements' merger clause.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: In re MBM Entertainment, LLC
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: Under New York law, the corporate veil may be pierced where there has been, inter alia, a failure to adhere to corporate formalities, inadequate capitalization, use of corporate funds for a personal purpose, overlap in ownership and directorship, or common use of office space and equipment.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY  Case Administration. Cases of LLCs would not be dismissed as bad faith filings.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: Bank of America v. WS Management, Inc.
Court: Appellate Court of Illinois, First District, First Division.
Headnote: A claim that seeks to pierce the corporate veil based on an alter ego theory examines whether a person or entity uses a corporation merely as an instrumentality to conduct that person's or entity's business; this inquiry considers numerous operating practices and the relative involvement of the allegedly dominant individuals.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW - Debt Collection. Finding of a Fraudulent Transfer Act violation was not against the manifest weight of the evidence.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: Bank of America v. WS Management, Inc.
Court: Appellate Court of Illinois, First District, First Division.
Headnote: In determining whether there is such unity of interest and ownership that the separate personalities of the corporation and individual no longer exist, as would support decision to pierce the corporate veil, a court generally will not rest its decision on a single factor, but will examine many factors, including: (1) inadequate capitalization; (2) failure to issue stock; (3) failure to observe corporate formalities; (4) nonpayment of dividends; (5) insolvency of the debtor corporation; (6) nonfunctioning of the other officers or directors; (7) absence of corporate records; (8) commingling of funds; (9) diversion of assets from the corporation by or to a stockholder or other person or entity to the detriment of creditors; (10) failure to maintain arm's-length relationships among related entities; and (11) whether the corporation is a mere façade for the operation of the dominant stockholders.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW - Debt Collection. Finding of a Fraudulent Transfer Act violation was not against the manifest weight of the evidence.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: Commonwealth Land Title Insurance Company v. Miceli
Court: Missouri Court of Appeals, Eastern District, DIVISION ONE.
Headnote: A court will disregard the corporate form and hold the corporate owners or officers liable if three elements are met: (1) control, not mere majority or complete stock control, but complete domination, not only of finances, but of policy and business practice in respect to the transaction attacked so that the corporate entity as to this transaction had at the time no separate mind, will or existence of its own; (2) such control must have been used by the corporation to commit fraud or wrong, to perpetrate the violation of statutory or other positive legal duty, or dishonest and unjust act in contravention of plaintiff's legal rights; and (3) the control and breach of duty must proximately cause the injury or unjust loss complained of.
Document Preview: INSURANCE  Title. Res judicata barred title insurer's fraud and negligence claims against home builder that misrepresented that subcontractors had been paid.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: Commonwealth Land Title Insurance Company v. Miceli
Court: Missouri Court of Appeals, Eastern District, DIVISION ONE.
Headnote: There is no hard and fast rule for when a court will pierce the corporate veil; the inquiry is highly fact-specific and depends on the equities of the situation at hand.
Document Preview: INSURANCE  Title. Res judicata barred title insurer's fraud and negligence claims against home builder that misrepresented that subcontractors had been paid.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: Commonwealth Land Title Insurance Company v. Miceli
Court: Missouri Court of Appeals, Eastern District, DIVISION ONE.
Headnote: While shareholder status is a factor to be considered in assessing the degree of control an individual or entity might have over a corporation, a lack of ownership interest by itself does not defeat a claim for piercing the corporate veil.
Document Preview: INSURANCE  Title. Res judicata barred title insurer's fraud and negligence claims against home builder that misrepresented that subcontractors had been paid.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: Commonwealth Land Title Insurance Company v. Miceli
Court: Missouri Court of Appeals, Eastern District, DIVISION ONE.
Headnote: In some situations, the corporate veil may be pierced when a corporation is undercapitalized, or when its assets are stripped to avoid creditors.
Document Preview: INSURANCE  Title. Res judicata barred title insurer's fraud and negligence claims against home builder that misrepresented that subcontractors had been paid.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: In re Carrano
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, D. Connecticut.
Headnote: Under Connecticut law, the corporate veil is pierced only under exceptional circumstances where the corporation is a mere shell, serving no legitimate purpose, and used primarily as an intermediary to perpetuate fraud or promote injustice.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY  Discharge. Debt for overpayment of rent fell within the discharge exception for debts obtained through embezzlement.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: Sebago v. Boston Cab Dispatch, Inc.
Court: Supreme Judicial Court of Massachusetts, Suffolk.
Headnote: Disregard of the corporate form requires an analysis of the following factors: (1) common ownership; (2) pervasive control; (3) confused intermingling of business assets; (4) thin capitalization; (5) nonobservance of corporate formalities; (6) absence of corporate records; (7) no payment of dividends; (8) insolvency at the time of the litigated transaction; (9) siphoning away of corporation's funds by dominant shareholder; (10) nonfunctioning of officers and directors; (11) use of the corporation for transactions of the dominant shareholders; and (12) use of the corporation in promoting fraud.
Document Preview: LABOR AND EMPLOYMENT - Independent Contractors. Taxicab drivers did not provide services to cab companies, as required for independent contractor statute to apply.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: CADC/RADC Venture 2011-1 LLC v. Bradley
Court: Court of Appeal, First District, Division 1, California.
Headnote: Alter ego liability conditions under which the corporate entity may be disregarded vary by circumstance, but courts often consider commingling of funds, personal use of corporate assets, inadequate corporate records, lack of employees, offices, or operating funds, and inadequate capitalization.
Document Preview: REAL PROPERTY  Mortgages and Deeds of Trust. Guaranties for loan secured by deed of trust were not sham guaranties which precluded any post-foreclosure action to recover deficiency.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: CADC/RADC Venture 2011-1 LLC v. Bradley
Court: Court of Appeal, First District, Division 1, California.
Headnote: In some situations, a corporation's failure to allocate ownership or stock may support an alter ego finding.
Document Preview: REAL PROPERTY  Mortgages and Deeds of Trust. Guaranties for loan secured by deed of trust were not sham guaranties which precluded any post-foreclosure action to recover deficiency.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: TradeWinds Airlines, Inc. v. Soros
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: Under Delaware law, relevant considerations as to whether a corporation and its alleged alter ego acted as a single economic entity, as would support piercing the corporate veil, include: whether the corporation was adequately capitalized for the corporate undertaking; whether the corporation was solvent; whether dividends were paid, corporate records kept, officers and directors functioned properly, and other corporate formalities were observed; whether the dominant shareholder siphoned corporate funds; and whether, in general, the corporation simply functioned as for the dominant shareholder.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Creditors could not pierce veil to hold purported controllers of aircraft leasing corporation liable for default judgment.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: TradeWinds Airlines, Inc. v. Soros
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: Under Delaware law, some combination of the factors supporting a finding that an entity and its owner operated as a single economic entity is required to piece the corporate veil because none alone is sufficient to disregard the corporate form; multi-factor analysis is used to determine whether there has been a mingling of the operators of the entity and its owner.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Creditors could not pierce veil to hold purported controllers of aircraft leasing corporation liable for default judgment.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: Lothrop v. North American Air Charter, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, D. Massachusetts.
Headnote: Under Massachusetts law, courts considering whether to set aside corporate formalities consider twelve factors: (1) common ownership; (2) pervasive control; (3) confused intermingling of business assets; (4) thin capitalization; (5) nonobservance of corporate formalities; (6) absence of corporate records; (7) no payment of dividends; (8) insolvency at the time of the litigated transaction; (9) siphoning away of corporation's funds by dominant shareholder; (10) nonfunctioning of officers and directors; (11) use of the corporation for transactions of the dominant shareholders; and (12) use of the corporation in promoting fraud.
Document Preview: LITIGATION - Jurisdiction. District court could not exercise personal jurisdiction over defendant under alter-ego theory.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: A.G. Cullen Const., Inc. v. Burnham Partners, LLC
Court: Appellate Court of Illinois, First District, Third Division.
Headnote: Under Delaware law, an alter ego analysis must start with an examination of factors which reveal how the corporation operates and the particular defendant's relationship to that operation, and these factors include: (1) whether the corporation was adequately capitalized for the corporate undertaking; (2) whether the corporation was solvent; (3) whether dividends were paid, corporate records kept, officers and directors functioned properly, and other corporate formalities were observed; (4) whether the dominant shareholder siphoned corporate funds; and (5) whether, in general, the corporation simply functioned as a facade for the dominant shareholder.
Document Preview: LITIGATION - Fraudulent Conveyances. LLC and member violated by Uniform Fraudulent Transfer Act (UFTA) by winding down LLC and transferring assets.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: Hodge v. Strong Built Intern., LLC
Court: Court of Appeal of Louisiana, Third Circuit.
Headnote: In determining whether a company is its members' alter ego, for purposes of determining whether it should pierce the corporate veil, a court should consider such factors as commingling of corporate and member funds; failing to follow statutory formalities in incorporating and transacting corporate affairs; undercapitalization; failing to maintain separate bank accounts and bookkeeping records; and failing to hold regular shareholder and director meetings.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Limited Liability Companies. Member of limited liability corporation who did not participate in design and manufacturing of deer stand was not personally liable for alleged defect.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: Meridian North Investments LP v. Sondhi
Court: Court of Appeals of Indiana.
Headnote: When determining whether a shareholder is liable for corporate acts, considerations may include: (1) undercapitalization of the corporation, (2) the absence of corporate records, (3) fraudulent representations by corporation shareholders or directors, (4) use of the corporation to promote fraud, injustice, or illegal activities, (5) payment by the corporation of individual obligations, (6) commingling of assets and affairs, (7) failure to observe required corporate formalities, and (8) other shareholder acts or conduct ignoring, controlling, or manipulating the corporate form.
Document Preview: REAL PROPERTY - Landlord and Tenant. Provision of lease for office building that president signed purporting to absolve lessor from liability for injuries to tenants did not apply to president.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: Meridian North Investments LP v. Sondhi
Court: Court of Appeals of Indiana.
Headnote: When determining whether a shareholder is liable for corporate acts, considerations may include whether corporate assets were treated as personal assets by a shareholder and whether there has been an attempt to deceive third parties.
Document Preview: REAL PROPERTY - Landlord and Tenant. Provision of lease for office building that president signed purporting to absolve lessor from liability for injuries to tenants did not apply to president.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: Powertrain, Inc. v. Ma
Court: United States District Court, N.D. Mississippi, Aberdeen Division.
Headnote: Under Mississippi law, the court will not disregard the corporate entity unless the plaintiff presents proof on three elements: (1) some frustration of contractual expectations regarding the party to whom he looked for performance; (2) the flagrant disregard of corporate formalities by the defendant corporation and its principals; and (3) a demonstration of fraud or other equivalent misfeasance on the part of the corporate shareholder.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Defendant's sole employee did not engage in fraud, precluding piercing of corporate veil on alter ego theory.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: Digby Adler Group LLC v. Image Rent a Car, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, N.D. California.
Headnote: Under California law, courts consider a non-exhaustive list of factors when deciding whether it is proper to pierce the corporate veil, including: the commingling of funds and other assets; the failure to segregate funds of the individual and the corporation; the unauthorized diversion of corporate funds to other than corporate purposes; the treatment by an individual of corporate assets as his own; the failure to seek authority to issue stock or issue stock under existing authorization; the representation by an individual that he is personally liable for corporate debts; the failure to maintain adequate corporate minutes or records; the intermingling of the individual and corporate records; the ownership of all the stock by a single individual or family; the domination or control of the corporation by the stockholders; the use of a single address for the individual and the corporation; the inadequacy of the corporation's capitalization; the use of the corporation as a mere conduit for an individual's business; the concealment of the ownership of the corporation; the disregard of formalities and the failure to maintain arm's-length transactions with the corporation; and the attempts to segregate liabilities to the corporation.
Document Preview: TRADEMARKS  Internet. Award of $25,000 in statutory damages was appropriate in van rental service's cybersquatting suit against two competing companies.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: Gerritsen v. Warner Bros. Entertainment Inc.
Court: United States District Court, C.D. California.
Headnote: Under California law, no single factor is determinative of whether there is a unity of interest between a corporation and its equitable owner, for purposes of establishing alter ego liability, and instead a court must examine all the circumstances to determine whether to apply the doctrine.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW - Contracts. Author failed to allege that there was a contract between her and entertainment company that produced film allegedly based on her novel.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: Bell Helicopter Textron Inc. v. Airbus Helicopters
Court: United States District Court, District of Columbia.
Headnote: Mere ownership of stock is not enough to pierce the corporate veil.
Document Preview: PATENTS  Injunction. Permanent injunction was appropriate in patent infringement action brought by commercial helicopter distributor holding patent covering landing gear.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: Zarichny v. Complete Payment Recovery Services, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, E.D. Pennsylvania.
Headnote: Under federal common law, the District Court may pierce the corporate veil to hold a parent accountable under a limited set of circumstances that requires the court to look at the following factors: gross undercapitalization, failure to observe corporate formalities, nonpayment of dividends, insolvency of debtor corporation, siphoning of funds from the debtor corporation by the dominant stockholder, nonfunctioning of officers and directors, absence of corporate records, and whether the corporation is merely a facade for the operations of the dominant stockholder.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW - Debt Collection. Proposed class of alleged debtors was not readily ascertainable as required for class certification in FDCPA claim.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: Bash v. Textron Financial Corp.
Court: United States District Court, N.D. Ohio, Eastern Division.
Headnote: In Ohio, courts may consider a number of nonexclusive factors in deciding whether to disregard the corporate fiction under the alter ego theory, including: (1) grossly inadequate capitalization, (2) failure to observe corporate formalities, (3) insolvency of the debtor corporation at the time the debt is incurred, (4) shareholders holding themselves out as personally liable for certain corporate obligations, (5) diversion of funds or other property of the company property for personal use, (6) absence of corporate records, and (7) the fact that the corporation was a mere facade for the operations of the dominant shareholder(s); although these are the factors generally considered, because of the equitable nature of the veil-piercing doctrine, no list of factors can be exclusive or exhaustive.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Avoidance. Debtor was operated as Ponzi scheme, as required for Ponzi scheme presumption of fraudulent intent to arise in trustee's action to avoid and recover transfers.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: Lodges at Bear Hollow Condominium Homeowners Ass'n, Inc. v. Bear Hollow Restoration, LLC
Court: Court of Appeals of Utah.
Headnote: Under the two-part Norman test to determine whether a party in a breach of contract action against a corporation may pierce the corporate veil, the second prong of the test, the fairness requirement, is addressed to the conscience of the court, but the first prong of the test, the formalities requirement, is determined by examining seven factors, called the Colman factors: (1) undercapitalization of a one-person corporation; (2) failure to observe corporate formalities; (3) nonpayment of dividends; (4) siphoning of corporate funds by the dominant stockholder; (5) nonfunctioning of other officers or directors; (6) absence of corporate records; and (7) the use of the corporation as a facade for operations of the dominant stockholder or stockholders.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Homeowners association failed to demonstrate that developer and general contractor were alter egos.
