Title: Lodges at Bear Hollow Condominium Homeowners Ass'n, Inc. v. Bear Hollow Restoration, LLC
Court: Court of Appeals of Utah.
Headnote: The seven Colman factors are useful considerations to aid courts in determining whether to pierce the corporate veil, but they are merely helpful tools and not required elements.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Homeowners association failed to demonstrate that developer and general contractor were alter egos.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: Lodges at Bear Hollow Condominium Homeowners Ass'n, Inc. v. Bear Hollow Restoration, LLC
Court: Court of Appeals of Utah.
Headnote: Courts should evaluate the entire relationship between a corporation and its officers in determining whether to pierce the corporate veil.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Homeowners association failed to demonstrate that developer and general contractor were alter egos.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: Eagle Air Transport, Inc. v. National Aerotech Aviation Delaware, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, N.D. Illinois, Eastern Division.
Headnote: Under Delaware law, court considers the following factors in determining whether to pierce the corporate veil: (1) whether the company was adequately capitalized for the undertaking; (2) whether the company was solvent; (3) whether corporate formalities were observed; (4) whether the controlling shareholder siphoned company funds; or (5) whether, in general, the company simply functioned as a facade for the controlling shareholder.
Document Preview: LITIGATION  Jurisdiction. Court had jurisdiction over non-resident defendant accused of breaching an agreement for the sale of an aircraft.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: Cleary v. American Capital, Ltd.
Court: United States District Court, D. Massachusetts.
Headnote: Massachusetts corporate veil-piercing theory focuses on common ownership, pervasive control, intermingling of business assets, thin capitalization, nonobservance of corporate formalities, absence of corporate records, non-payment of dividends, insolvency at the time of the litigated transaction, the siphoning of corporation funds by dominant shareholders, nonfunctioning officers and directors, the use of the corporation for unilateral transactions benefitting dominant shareholders, and the use of the corporation as a vehicle for fraud.
Document Preview: LABOR AND EMPLOYMENT - Layoffs. Private equity fund was not liable for employer's failure to provide WARN Act notices to employees.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: Rutherlan Enterprises, Inc. v. Zettler Hardware
Court: United States District Court, S.D. Ohio, Eastern Division.
Headnote: Pursuant to Ohio law, there are several nonexhaustive, nonexclusive factors courts should consider when determining whether a company is an alter ego of an individual, including: (1) grossly inadequate capitalization, (2) failure to observe corporate formalities, (3) insolvency of the debtor corporation at the time the debt is incurred, (4) shareholders holding themselves out as personally liable for certain corporate obligations, (5) diversion of funds or other property of the company property for personal use, (6) absence of corporate records, and (7) the fact that the corporation was a mere facade for the operations of the dominant shareholders.
Document Preview: LITIGATION - Limitations. Savings clause in Ohio's four-year statute of limitations for fraud claims did not operate to toll limitations period.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: In re Geer
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, N.D. Georgia, Atlanta Division.
Headnote: Under Georgia law, courts determining whether to disregard a corporate entity typically look at whether the principals commingled the assets of the company with their personal assets or otherwise confused the assets, records, and liabilities of the individual and the corporation.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Discharge. Debtor's transfer of interest in house to QRPT did not warrant denial of his discharge.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: Queens West Development Corp. v. Nixbot Realty Associates
Court: Supreme Court, Appellate Division, Second Department, New York.
Headnote: In determining whether an owner has abused the privilege of doing business in the corporate form, as required to pierce the corporate veil, a court may consider, inter alia, whether there was a failure to adhere to corporate formalities, inadequate capitalization, commingling of assets, and use of corporate funds for personal use.
Document Preview: REAL PROPERTY - Eminent Domain. In condemnation proceeding, just compensation for taking trade fixtures was warranted, separate from award for taking of fee.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: Toumazou v. Turkish Republic of Northern Cyprus
Court: United States District Court, District of Columbia.
Headnote: Under test for determining whether corporate entity is alter ego of person or corporation in control, as required to pierce the corporate veil, courts in the District of Columbia generally inquire as to whether corporate formalities have been observed, whether there has been commingling of corporate and shareholder funds, staff, and property, whether a single shareholder dominates the corporation, whether the corporation is adequately capitalized, and, especially, whether the corporate form has been used to effectuate a fraud.
Document Preview: E-COMMERCE  Internet. Accessibility of website in District of Columbia was insufficient to establish minimum contracts for purposes of specific personal jurisdiction.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: Parr v. Ebrahimian
Court: United States District Court, District of Columbia.
Headnote: In determining whether a corporation is the alter ego of its shareholders, as would support piercing the corporate veil, under District of Columbia law, court will consider various factors, such as (1) whether corporate formalities have been disregarded, (2) whether corporate funds and assets have been extensively intermingled with personal assets, (3) inadequate initial capitalization, and (4) fraudulent use of the corporation to protect personal business from the claims of creditors.
Document Preview: REAL PROPERTY  Condominiums. Vendor's alleged misrepresentations to condominium unit purchaser did not violate District of Columbia Condominium Act.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: In re Joseph Walker & Company, Inc.
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, D. South Carolina.
Headnote: Under South Carolina law, two-prong DeWitt test is used in analyzing whether to pierce an entity's corporate veil and impose personal liability on its directors: the first part of the test looks to observance of corporate formalities by dominant shareholders, considering eight factors, including whether (1) there is evidence that corporation was grossly undercapitalized, (2) corporate formalities were not observed, (3) dividends were not paid, (4) corporation was insolvent, (5) corporate funds were siphoned off by controlling shareholders, (6) corporate records were not maintained, (7) corporation was a facade for the operations of controlling shareholders, and (8) there are non-functioning or "frozen out" shareholders or directors, while second part of test requires that there be an element of injustice or fundamental unfairness if the acts of the corporation are not regarded as the acts of the individuals.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY  Claims. Representations made by debtor's dual director concerning debtor's ability to perform contract did not rise to level of actionable fraud.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: Ng v. Adler
Court: United States District Court, E.D. New York.
Headnote: In determining owners' domination of corporation, for purposes of piercing the corporate veil under New York law, courts consider, inter alia, the following factors: (1) whether corporate formalities are observed, (2) whether the capitalization is adequate, (3) whether funds are put in and taken out of the corporation for personal rather than corporate purposes, (4) whether there is overlap in ownership, officers, directors, and personnel, (5) whether the corporation is treated as an independent profit center, and (6) whether others pay or guarantee debts of the dominated corporation; there is no set rule as to how many factors must be present in order to pierce the corporate veil.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Avoidance. Bankruptcy Court did not err in piercing corporate veil and holding debtor liable for debts of corporations.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: Claybar v. Huffman
Court: United States District Court, S.D. Alabama, Southern Division.
Headnote: Under Alabama law, courts will pierce the corporate veil where a corporation is set up as a subterfuge, where shareholders do not observe the corporate form, where the legal requirements of corporate law are not complied with, where the corporation maintains no corporate records, where the corporation maintains no corporate bank account, where the corporation has no employees, where corporate and personal funds are intermingled and corporate funds are used for personal purposes, or where an individual drains funds from the corporation.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Subcontractor's allegations were sufficient to state a claim for piercing the corporate veil against contractor and its owner.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: Takiguchi v. MRI Intern., Inc.
Court: United States District Court, D. Nevada.
Headnote: Under Nevada law, several factors, none conclusive, may indicate alter ego: (1) commingling of funds; (2) undercapitalization; (3) unauthorized diversion of funds; (4) treatment of corporate assets as the individual's own; and (5) failure to observe corporate formalities.
Document Preview: SECURITIES REGULATION - Fraud. Investors sufficiently pled that they made domestic transactions in securities not listed on a domestic exchange.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: Blanks v. Fluor Corp.
Court: Missouri Court of Appeals, Eastern District, Division Four.
Headnote: There is no hard and fast rule for when a court will pierce the corporate veil; the inquiry is highly fact-specific and depends on the equities of the situation at hand.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Parent and Subsidiary. Parent company's domination of and control of subsidiaries were insufficient to establish principal-agent relationship.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: Kutty v. U.S. Dept. of Labor
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Sixth Circuit.
Headnote: Under Tennessee law, when determining whether to pierce corporate veil, court should consider not only whether entity has been used to work fraud or injustice in contravention of public policy, but also (1) whether there was failure to collect paid in capital; (2) whether corporation was grossly undercapitalized; (3) nonissuance of stock certificates; (4) sole ownership of stock by one individual; (5) use of same office or business location; (6) employment of same employees or attorneys; (7) corporation's use as instrumentality or business conduit for individual or another corporation; (8) diversion of corporate assets by or to stockholder or other entity to detriment of creditors, or manipulation of assets and liabilities in another; (9) corporation's use as subterfuge in illegal transactions; (10) formation and use of corporation to transfer to it existing liability of another person or entity; and (11) failure to maintain arms length relationships among related entities.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Piercing of corporate veil was warranted to hold medical clinic operator personally liable for immigration violations.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: Black v. Gigliotti
Court: United States District Court, E.D. Pennsylvania.
Headnote: Factors to determine whether a corporate entity is merely an alter ego of the controlling shareholder are: gross undercapitalization, failure to observe corporate formalities, nonpayment of dividends, insolvency of debtor corporation, siphoning of funds from the debtor corporation by the dominant stockholder, nonfunctioning of officers and directors, absence of corporate records, and whether the corporation is merely a facade for the operations of the dominant stockholder; the test is demonstrably an inquiry into whether the debtor corporation is little more than a legal fiction.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Discharge. Creditors failed to establish debt to except from discharge on veil-piercing theory.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: Ferrara v. Smithtown Trucking Co., Inc.
Court: United States District Court, E.D. New York.
Headnote: In determining alter ego status, courts typically look to the following factors: (1) absence of formalities which are part and parcel of normal corporate existence, i.e., issuance of stock, election of directors, keeping of corporate records, etc., (2) inadequate capitalization, (3) personal use of corporate funds, and (4) perpetration of fraud by means of corporate vehicle.
Document Preview: LITIGATION - Pleading. Trustees of multiemployer plan could amend pleading to join defendants to hold them liable under ERISA.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: Glenn v. TPI Petroleum, Inc.
Court: Court of Appeals of Michigan.
Headnote: Factors used by courts to determine the propriety of piercing the corporate veil include: (1) whether the corporation is undercapitalized; (2) whether separate books are kept; (3) whether there are separate finances for the corporation; (4) whether the corporation is used for fraud or illegality; (5) whether corporate formalities have been followed; and (6) whether the corporation is a sham.
Document Preview: TORTS - Jurisdiction. Trial court lacked limited personal jurisdiction over non-resident petroleum company in negligence action.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: United States ex rel. Landis v. Tailwind Sports Corporation
Court: United States District Court, District of Columbia.
Headnote: With respect to the formalities prong, i.e., the unity of interest and ownership prong, of the two-pronged test for determining whether to pierce the corporate veil, the court will consider several factors, although it is not necessary that all of these factors be present in a given case to justify piercing the corporate veil, including: the nature of the corporate ownership and control; failure to maintain corporate minutes or adequate corporate records; failure to maintain the corporate formalities for issuance or subscription to stock; commingling of funds and other assets of the corporation; and diversion of the corporation's funds or assets to non-corporate uses such as the personal uses of the corporation's shareholders.
Document Preview: GOVERNMENT  False Claims. Relator and government stated claim against former lead rider of professional cycling team under reverse false claims provision of False Claims Act.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: Wandering Trails, LLC v. Big Bite Excavation, Inc.
Court: Supreme Court of Idaho, Boise, February 2014 Term.
Headnote: Under the theory of piercing the corporate veil, factors to consider include the level of control that the shareholder exercises over the corporation, the lack of corporate formalities, the failure to operate corporations separately, keeping separate books, and the decision-making process of the entity.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Issues of alter ego and veil-piercing claims are equitable questions.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: Wandering Trails, LLC v. Big Bite Excavation, Inc.
Court: Supreme Court of Idaho, Boise, February 2014 Term.
Headnote: The factors considered for veil-piercing claims generally revolve around shareholders, members, or owners of a business entity exploiting the company without regard to its legal separateness.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Issues of alter ego and veil-piercing claims are equitable questions.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: Accurso v. Infra-Red Services, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, E.D. Pennsylvania.
Headnote: Under Pennsylvania law, factors relevant to whether the corporate veil should be pierced include undercapitalization, failure to adhere to corporate formalities, substantial intermingling of corporate and personal affairs, and use of the corporate form to perpetrate a fraud.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW - Contracts. Term Company in independent contractor agreement referred only to corporation, and did not personally bind corporation's president.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: Llewellyn-Jones v. Metro Property Group, LLC
Court: United States District Court, E.D. Michigan, Southern Division.
Headnote: In considering whether an entity is used as a mere instrumentality as required under Michigan law to pierce the corporate veil, a court may consider factors such as undercapitalization of corporation, maintenance of separate books, separation of corporate and individual finances, use of corporation to support fraud or illegality, honoring of corporate formalities, and whether corporation is merely a sham.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW - Contracts. Economic-loss doctrine did not apply to bar investors' fraudulent inducement claim against sellers of sham investments.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: Flame S.A. v. Industrial Carriers, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, E.D. Virginia, Norfolk Division.
Headnote: The conclusion to disregard the corporate entity may not rest on a single factor, whether undercapitalization, disregard of a corporation's formalities, or what-not, but must involve a number of such factors, which must present an element of injustice or fundamental unfairness.
Document Preview: MARITIME LAW - Attachment. Equitable vacatur of maritime attachments applies only domestically.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: VFS Financing, Inc. v. Falcon Fifty LLC
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: Several factors are relevant to determining whether there was a mingling of the operations of an entity and its owner, as required to support piercing the corporate veil under Delaware law, including whether the corporation was adequately capitalized for the corporate undertaking; whether the corporation was solvent; whether dividends were paid, corporate records kept, officers and directors functioned properly, and other corporate formalities were observed; whether the dominant shareholder siphoned corporate funds; and whether, in general, the corporation simply functioned as a facade for the dominant shareholder.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW - Contracts. Purchaser of aircraft sufficiently alleged that its alleged breaches of security agreement governing loan were not material.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: Buckley v. Abuzir
Court: Appellate Court of Illinois, First District, Fourth Division.
Headnote: In determining whether there is such a unity of interest and ownership that the separate personalities of the corporation and the parties who compose it no longer exist, courts considering piercing the corporate veil will examine many factors, including (1) inadequate capitalization, (2) failure to issue stock, (3) failure to observe corporate formalities, (4) nonpayment of dividends, (5) insolvency of the debtor corporation, (6) nonfunctioning of the other officers or directors, (7) absence of corporate records, (8) commingling of funds, (9) diversion of assets from the corporation by or to a stockholder or other person or entity to the detriment of creditors, (10) failure to maintain arm's-length relationships among related entities, and (11) whether, in fact, the corporation is a mere facade for the operation of the dominant stockholders.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Creditors were not required to show that controller was a shareholder in order to pierce the corporate veil.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: Tianbo Huang v. iTV Media, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, E.D. New York.
Headnote: To warrant piercing the corporate veil under English law, the wrongdoer must have placed the corporation between himself and his victim after incurring liability.
Document Preview: LITIGATION - Jurisdiction. Nonresident defendants had sufficient minimum contacts with New York to support exercise of personal jurisdiction over them.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: A&M Global Management Corp. v. Northtown Urology Associates, P.C.
Court: Supreme Court, Appellate Division, Fourth Department, New York.
Headnote: Factors to be considered in determining whether a corporation has abused the privilege of doing business in the corporate form, as would warrant veil piercing, include whether there was a failure to adhere to corporate formalities, inadequate capitalization, commingling of assets, and use of corporate funds for personal use.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Director and shareholder of professional corporation that ceased doing business was personally liable for corporate lease obligations.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: A&M Global Management Corp. v. Northtown Urology Associates, P.C.
Court: Supreme Court, Appellate Division, Fourth Department, New York.
Headnote: A decision to pierce the corporate veil is a fact-laden determination and no one factor is dispositive.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Director and shareholder of professional corporation that ceased doing business was personally liable for corporate lease obligations.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: USHA Holdings, LLC v. Franchise India Holdings Ltd.
Court: United States District Court, E.D. New York.
Headnote: To determine if a corporation is being used as a shell, as would warrant piercing the corporate veil to impute jurisdiction, under New York law, courts examine factors such as the failure to observe corporate formalities, inadequate capitalization, intermingling of personal and corporate funds, shared office space and phone numbers, or an overlap of ownership, directors, officers, and personnel.
Document Preview: LITIGATION - Process. Plaintiffs properly served defendants, without resorting to fraud or deceit to lure them into forum state.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: In re Gigliotti
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, E.D. Pennsylvania.
Headnote: Factors to which courts look in deciding whether to pierce the corporate veil are: gross undercapitalization, failure to observe corporate formalities, nonpayment of dividends, corporate insolvency, siphoning of funds from corporation by the dominant stockholder, nonfunctioning of officers and directors, absence of corporate records, and whether corporation is merely a facade for operations of dominant stockholder.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Discharge. Creditors failed to establish debt to except from discharge on veil-piercing theory.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: Trinity Industries Leasing Company v. Midwest Gas Storage, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, N.D. Illinois, Eastern Division.
Headnote: Under Delaware law, in determining whether corporate veil may be pierced under alter ego theory, court considers: (1) whether the company was adequately capitalized for the undertaking; (2) whether the company was solvent; (3) whether corporate formalities were observed; (4) whether the dominant shareholder siphoned company funds; and (5) whether, in general, the company simply functioned as a facade for the dominant shareholder.
Document Preview: TORTS  Fraud. lessor alleged with sufficient particularity affirmative misrepresentations by the lessee's chief executive officer (CEO).

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: Webmediabrands, Inc. v. Latinvision, Inc.
Court: Supreme Court, New York County, New York.
Headnote: Under New York law, factors to be considered in determining whether the corporate veil can be pierced include whether there was a failure to adhere to corporate formalities, inadequate capitalization, commingling of assets, and use of corporate funds for personal use; additional factors include overlap in ownership and directorship, or common use of office space and equipment.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Corporation and its principal were liable as alter egos of related corporation for judgment against related corporation.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: Lopes v. JetsetDC, LLC
Court: United States District Court, District of Columbia.
Headnote: Under District of Columbia's veil-piercing test, court generally inquires as to whether corporate formalities have been observed, whether there has been commingling of corporate and shareholder funds, staff and property, whether a single shareholder dominates the corporation, whether the corporation is adequately capitalized, and, especially, whether the corporate form has been used to effectuate a fraud; but the inquiry ultimately rests on whether the corporation is, in reality, an alter ego or business conduit of the person in control.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Limited Liability Companies. Complaint stated claim for piercing the corporate veil.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: Country Contractors, Inc. v. A Westside Storage of Indianapolis, Inc.
Court: Court of Appeals of Indiana.
Headnote: In determining whether a plaintiff seeking to pierce the corporate veil has met its burden, the trial court considers whether the plaintiff has presented evidence showing: (1) undercapitalization; (2) absence of corporate records; (3) fraudulent representation by corporation shareholders or directors; (4) use of the corporation to promote fraud, injustice or illegal activities; (5) payment by the corporation of individual obligations; (6) commingling of assets and affairs; (7) failure to observe required corporate formalities; or (8) other shareholder acts or conduct ignoring, controlling, or manipulating the corporate form; the list of factors is not exhaustive, and the plaintiff need not prove all eight in order to pierce the corporate veil. West's A.I.C. 23–1–26–3(b).
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Evidence did not support finding that contractor corporation was undercapitalized, as would support piercing corporate veil.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: Dog House Investments, LLC v. Teal Properties, Inc.
Court: Court of Appeals of Tennessee, Western Section, at Nashville.
Headnote: When determining whether piercing the corporate veil is appropriate, the court must consider whether the corporate entity has been used to work a fraud or injustice in contravention of public policy and also: (1) whether there was a failure to collect paid in capital; (2) whether the corporation was grossly undercapitalized; (3) the nonissuance of stock certificates; (4) the sole ownership of stock by one individual; (5) the use of the same office or business location; (6) the employment of the same employees or attorneys; (7) the use of the corporation as an instrumentality or business conduit for an individual or another corporation; (8) the diversion of corporate assets by or to a stockholder or other entity to the detriment of creditors, or the manipulation of assets and liabilities in another; (9) the use of the corporation as a subterfuge in illegal transactions; (10) the formation and use of the corporation to transfer to it the existing liability of another person or entity; and (11) the failure to maintain arms length relationships among related entities.
Document Preview: REAL PROPERTY - Landlord and Tenant. Lease provision delineating landlord's obligations for damage to premises from fire or other cause encompassed flood damage.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: Dog House Investments, LLC v. Teal Properties, Inc.
Court: Court of Appeals of Tennessee, Western Section, at Nashville.
Headnote: In determining whether to pierce the corporate veil, no single factor in the analysis is conclusive, and not every factor must exist; rather, the question depends on the specific facts and circumstances of the case.
Document Preview: REAL PROPERTY - Landlord and Tenant. Lease provision delineating landlord's obligations for damage to premises from fire or other cause encompassed flood damage.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: Rock Ivy Holding, LLC v. RC Properties, LLC
Court: Court of Appeals of Tennessee.
Headnote: When applicable, factors to be considered in determining whether to disregard the corporate veil include not only whether the entity has been used to work a fraud or injustice in contravention of public policy, but also: (1) whether there was a failure to collect paid in capital; (2) whether the corporation was grossly undercapitalized; (3) the nonissuance of stock certificates; (4) the sole ownership of stock by one individual; (5) the use of the same office or business location; (6) the employment of the same employees or attorneys; (7) the use of the corporation as an instrumentality or business conduit for an individual or another corporation; (8) the diversion of corporate assets by or to a stockholder or other entity to the detriment of creditors, or the manipulation of assets and liabilities in another; (9) the use of the corporation as a subterfuge in illegal transactions; (10) the formation and use of the corporation to transfer to it the existing liability of another person or entity; and (11) the failure to maintain arms length relationships among related entities.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Limited Liability Companies. President of LLC did not violate his duty of loyalty in seeking to sell LLC's property.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: Snapp v. Castlebrook Builders, Inc.
Court: Court of Appeals of Ohio, Third District, Shelby County.
Headnote: In considering whether to pierce the corporate veil, courts look at the following nonexclusive list of factors to determine whether an individual's complete control over the corporation warrants treating the corporation as the individual's alter ego: (1) whether corporate formalities were observed, (2) whether corporate records were kept, (3) whether corporate funds were commingled with personal funds, and (4) whether corporate property was used for a personal purpose.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Evidence supported piercing of corporate veil in action against construction company and its owner.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: Freilich v. Green Energy Resources, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, W.D. Texas, San Antonio Division.
Headnote: Factors to be considered in determining whether to hold individual liable for corporation's debts pursuant to alter ego theory include degree to which corporate formalities have been followed and corporate and individual property have been kept separately, amount of financial interest, ownership and control individual maintains over corporation, and whether corporation has been used for personal purposes.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Officers and Directors. Corporation's principal's answer was ineffective with regard to corporation, but effective with regard to him.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: Dodd v. Savino
Court: Court of Appeals of Texas, Houston (14th Dist.).
Headnote: Evidence as proof of an alter ego, or piercing the corporate veil, includes (1) the payment of alleged corporate debts with personal checks or other commingling of funds, (2) representations that the individual will financially back the corporation, (3) the diversion of company profits to the individual for the individual's personal use, (4) inadequate capitalization, and (5) any other failure to keep corporate and personal assets separate. V.T.C.A., Business Organizations Code § 21.223.

Title: Glassell Producing Co., Inc. v. Jared Resources, Ltd.
Court: Court of Appeals of Texas, Texarkana.
Headnote: In determining whether a corporation is an alter ego, as would warrant piercing the corporate veil, a court may consider evidence of (1) the payment of alleged corporate debts with personal checks or other commingling of funds, (2) representations that the individual will financially back the corporation, (3) the diversion of company profits to the individual for his personal use, (4) inadequate capitalization, and (5) other failure to keep corporate and personal assets separate.
Document Preview: ENERGY AND UTILITIES - Alternative Dispute Resolution. Fraud-related tort claims against operator of oil and gas interests fell within scope of arbitration clause.

Title: Dry Handy Investments, Ltd. v. Corvina Shipping Co. S.A.
Court: United States District Court, E.D. Virginia, Norfolk Division.
Headnote: The conclusion to disregard the corporate entity, and pierce the corporate veil, may not rest on a single factor, whether undercapitalization, disregard of corporate formalities, or what-not, but must involve a number of such factors, and in addition, it must present an element of injustice or fundamental unfairness.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: Nieto-Vicenty v. Valledor
Court: United States District Court, D. Puerto Rico.
Headnote: Factors to be considered in determining whether to pierce the corporate veil include (1) inadequate capitalization, (2) extensive control by shareholders, (3) intermingling of the corporation's properties with those of its owner, (4) failure to observe corporate formalities and separateness, (5) siphoning of funds from the corporation, (6) absence of corporate records, and (7) non-functioning officers or directors.

Title: Bridge Street Automotive, Inc. v. Green Valley Oil, LLC
Court: United States District Court, D. Massachusetts.
Headnote: Under Massachusetts law, factors relevant to deciding whether circumstances permit piercing of the corporate veil include: (1) common ownership; (2) pervasive control; (3) confused intermingling of business assets; (4) thin capitalization; (5) nonobservance of corporate formalities; (6) absence of corporate records; (7) no payment of dividends; (8) insolvency at the time of the litigated transaction; (9) siphoning away of corporation's funds by dominant shareholder; (10) nonfunctioning of officers and directors; (11) use of the corporation for transactions of the dominant shareholders; and (12) use of the corporation in promoting fraud.
Document Preview: LITIGATION - Jurisdiction. Gas station owner did not establish relatedness prong of test for specific jurisdiction over lessor's alleged alter ego.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: Abbott v. Crown Mill Restoration Development, LLC
Court: Supreme Court, Appellate Division, Fourth Department, New York.
Headnote: Factors to be considered in determining whether a corporation has abused the privilege of doing business in the corporate form include whether there was a failure to adhere to corporate formalities, inadequate capitalization, commingling of assets, and use of corporate funds for personal use.
Document Preview: LITIGATION - Judgment. Absent a reasonable excuse for the default, vacating default judgment was not warranted.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: Tommy Lee Handbags Mfg. Ltd. v. 1948 Corp.
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: Under Delaware law, in determining whether to pierce corporate veil under alter ego theory, court should consider: whether corporation was adequately capitalized for corporate undertaking; whether corporation was solvent; whether dividends were paid, corporate records kept, officers and directors functioned properly, and other corporate formalities were observed; whether dominant shareholder siphoned corporate funds; and whether, in general, corporation simply functioned as facade for dominant shareholder.
Document Preview: ANTITRUST - Bid-Rigging. Unsecured creditor lacked antitrust standing to pursue bid rigging claims.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: Solid Comfort, Inc. v. Hatchett Hospitality Inc.
Court: Supreme Court of North Dakota.
Headnote: Factors considered significant in determining whether or not to disregard the corporate entity include insufficient capitalization for the purposes of the corporate undertaking, failure to observe corporate formalities, nonpayment of dividends, insolvency of the debtor corporation at the time of the transaction in question, siphoning of funds by the dominant shareholder, nonfunctioning of other officers and directors, absence of corporate records, and the existence of the corporation as merely a facade for individual dealings.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW - Jurisdiction. Creditor made prima facie case for piercing debtor's corporate veil, as basis for exercising personal jurisdiction over debtor's nonresident owner and affiliates.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: Lipsitt v. Plaud
Court: Supreme Judicial Court of Massachusetts, Worcester.
Headnote: Factors which should be considered in deciding whether to penetrate the corporate form and hold one personally liable for the corporation's liabilities are as follows: (1) common ownership; (2) pervasive control; (3) confused intermingling of business assets; (4) thin capitalization; (5) nonobservance of corporate formalities; (6) absence of corporate records; (7) no payment of dividends; (8) insolvency at the time of the litigated transaction; (9) siphoning away of corporation's funds by dominant shareholders; (10) nonfunctioning of officers and directors; (11) use of the corporation for transactions of the dominant shareholders; and (12) use of the corporation in promoting fraud.
Document Preview: LABOR AND EMPLOYMENT - Hours and Wages. The Wage Act does not preempt common-law claims for breach of contract and related quasi-contract claims in actions to recover unpaid wages.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: Estate of Hurst ex rel. Cherry v. Moorehead I, LLC
Court: Court of Appeals of North Carolina.
Headnote: Factors that have been expressly or impliedly considered by courts in piercing the corporate veil include: (1) inadequate capitalization; (2) non-compliance with corporate formalities; (3) complete domination and control of the corporation so that it has no independent identity; and (4) excessive fragmentation of a single enterprise into separate corporations.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. A showing of actual fraud on member's part was not a necessary element for the court to pierce the corporate veil.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: Estate of Hurst ex rel. Cherry v. Moorehead I, LLC
Court: Court of Appeals of North Carolina.
Headnote: Other factors that may be considered in determining whether corporate form should be disregarded, include non-payment of dividends, insolvency of the debtor corporation, siphoning of funds by the dominant shareholder, nonfunctioning of other officers or directors, and absence of corporate records.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. A showing of actual fraud on member's part was not a necessary element for the court to pierce the corporate veil.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: Estate of Hurst ex rel. Cherry v. Moorehead I, LLC
Court: Court of Appeals of North Carolina.
Headnote: Focus of the instrumentality rule is upon reality, not form, upon the operation of the corporation, and upon the defendant's relationship to that operation; it is not the presence or absence of any particular factor that is determinative, but rather, it is a combination of factors which, when taken together with an element of injustice or abuse of corporate privilege, suggest that the corporate entity attacked had no separate mind, will or existence of its own and was therefore the mere instrumentality or tool of the dominant corporation or shareholder.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. A showing of actual fraud on member's part was not a necessary element for the court to pierce the corporate veil.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: H.G. Hill Realty Co., L.L.C. v. Re/Max Carriage House, Inc.
Court: Court of Appeals of Tennessee.
Headnote: Factors to be considered in determining whether to disregard the corporate veil include not only whether the entity has been used to work a fraud or injustice in contravention of public policy, but also: (1) whether there was a failure to collect paid in capital; (2) whether the corporation was grossly undercapitalized; (3) the nonissuance of stock certificates; (4) the sole ownership of stock by one individual; (5) the use of the same office or business location; (6) the employment of the same employees or attorneys; (7) the use of the corporation as an instrumentality or business conduit for an individual or another corporation; (8) the diversion of corporate assets by or to a stockholder or other entity to the detriment of creditors, or the manipulation of assets and liabilities in another; (9) the use of the corporation as a subterfuge in illegal transactions; (10) the formation and use of the corporation to transfer to it the existing liability of another person or entity; and (11) the failure to maintain arms length relationships among related entities.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. The amended complaint and the amendment thereto averred facts sufficient to form a basis to pierce the corporate veil.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: H.G. Hill Realty Co., L.L.C. v. Re/Max Carriage House, Inc.
Court: Court of Appeals of Tennessee.
Headnote: Generally, no one factor is conclusive in determining whether to pierce the corporate veil; rather, courts will rely upon a combination of factors in deciding the issue.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. The amended complaint and the amendment thereto averred facts sufficient to form a basis to pierce the corporate veil.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: JAS Enterprises, Inc. v. BBS Enterprises, Inc.
Court: Supreme Court of South Dakota.
Headnote: There are a number of factors that may justify piercing the corporate veil, including: (1) fraudulent misrepresentation by corporation directors, (2) undercapitalization, (3) failure to observe corporate formalities, (4) absence of corporate records, (5) payment by the corporation of individual obligations, and (6) use of the corporation to promote fraud, injustice, or illegality.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW - Evidence. Character evidence regarding reputation for untruthfulness of seller's principal was admissible in breach of contract action.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: Tap Holdings, LLC v. Orix Finance Corp.
Court: Supreme Court, Appellate Division, First Department, New York.
Headnote: Under Delaware law, no single factor could justify a decision to pierce the corporate veil and disregard the corporate entity; rather, some combination of them is required, and an overall element of injustice or unfairness must always be present, as well.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Promissory note holders stated a claim against maker's lenders based on piercing the corporate veil theory.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: Toho–Towa Co., Ltd. v. Morgan Creek Productions, Inc.
Court: Court of Appeal, Second District, Division 5, California.
Headnote: No one characteristic governs in determining whether to pierce the corporate veil, but the courts must look at all the circumstances to determine whether the alter ego doctrine should be applied.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Piercing Corporate Veil. Movie studio was properly added to judgment against affiliates as alter ego.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: Phillips v. Reed Group, Ltd.
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: Under Colorado law, for purposes of piercing the corporate veil, unity of interest consideration requires court to consider whether: (1) the corporation is operated as a distinct business entity; (2) funds and assets are commingled; (3) adequate corporate records are maintained; (4) the nature and form of the entity's ownership and control facilitate misuse by an insider; (5) the business is thinly capitalized; (6) the corporation is used as a mere shell; (7) shareholders disregard legal formalities; and (8) corporate funds or assets are used for noncorporate purposes.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Jurisdiction. Activities of LLC's predecessor could be used to establish personal jurisdiction over LLC.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: Phillips v. Reed Group, Ltd.
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: In determining whether a corporate entity is the alter ego of a shareholder under Colorado law, court considers a variety of factors, including whether: (1) the corporation is operated as a distinct business entity; (2) funds and assets are commingled; (3) adequate corporate records are maintained; (4) the nature and form of the entity's ownership and control facilitate misuse by an insider; (5) the business is thinly capitalized; (6) the corporation is used as a mere shell; (7) shareholders disregard legal formalities; and (8) corporate funds or assets are used for noncorporate purposes.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Jurisdiction. Activities of LLC's predecessor could be used to establish personal jurisdiction over LLC.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: Kasper Global Collection & Brokers, Inc. v. Global Cabinets & Furniture Mfrs. Inc.
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: Some factors that tend to show owners' domination of corporation, as would support piercing the corporate veil under New York law, are intermingling of corporate and personal funds, undercapitalization of corporation, failure to observe corporate formalities such as maintenance of separate books and records, failure to pay dividends, insolvency at time of a transaction, siphoning off of funds by dominant shareholder, and inactivity of other officers and directors.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW - Jurisdiction. Mandatory forum-selection clause encompassed seller's breach of contract claims against retailer.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: Kasper Global Collection & Brokers, Inc. v. Global Cabinets & Furniture Mfrs. Inc.
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: Under New York law, fact that corporation may have been created to engage in certain business does not warrant stripping its owners of protection from liability, and mere fact that individual is sole member, shareholder, or controlling person in entity does not, by itself, justify piercing corporate veil.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW - Jurisdiction. Mandatory forum-selection clause encompassed seller's breach of contract claims against retailer.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: Thomas v. Bridges
Court: Court of Appeal of Louisiana, First Circuit.
Headnote: Some of the factors courts consider when determining whether to apply the alter ego doctrine include, but are not limited to: (1) commingling of corporate and shareholder funds; (2) failure to follow statutory formalities for incorporating and transacting corporate affairs; (3) undercapitalization; (4) failure to provide separate bank accounts and bookkeeping records; and (5) failure to hold regular shareholder and director meetings.
Document Preview: TAXATION - Business. Taxpayer's creation of limited liability company to reduce tax liability did not amount to fraud.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: Springfield v. Palco Invest. Co., Inc.
Court: Court of Appeals of Ohio, Second District, Clark County.
Headnote: In determining whether a corporation is an individual's alter ego, the court considers various factors, such as (1) whether corporate formalities were observed, (2) whether corporate records were kept, (3) whether corporate funds were commingled with personal funds, (4) whether corporate property was used for a personal purpose, and (5) gross undercapitalization.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. City, which had judgment against corporation, could pierce corporate veil to hold liable its sole shareholder.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: Allred v. Exceptional Landscapes, Inc.
Court: Court of Appeals of North Carolina.
Headnote: Factors to consider in piercing the corporate veil include: inadequate capitalization, non-compliance with corporate formalities, complete domination and control of the corporation so that it had no independent identity, and excessive fragmentation of a single enterprise into separate corporations.
Document Preview: LABOR AND EMPLOYMENT - Workers' Compensation. Industrial Commission had jurisdiction over work-related injury claim against uninsured employer.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: W & W Steel, LLC v. BSC Steel, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, D. Kansas.
Headnote: Under Kansas law, no single factor is conclusive in determining whether to apply the alter ego doctrine.
Document Preview: TORTS - Fraud. Subcontractor stated a negligent misrepresentation claim against contractor and intermediary through which it was hired.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: Rottner v. AVG Technologies USA, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, D. Massachusetts.
Headnote: Under Delaware law, as under Massachusetts law, it is only the exceptional case where a court will disregard the corporate form; some specific facts a court may consider when being asked to disregard the corporate form include: (1) whether the company was adequately capitalized for the undertaking; (2) whether the company was solvent; (3) whether corporate formalities were observed; (4) whether the dominant shareholder siphoned company funds; and (5) whether, in general, the company simply functioned as a facade for the dominant shareholder.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW - Warranties. Sale of software was predominately like sale of a good.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: In re Appalachian Fuels, LLC
Court: United States Bankruptcy Appellate Panel of the Sixth Circuit.
Headnote: West Virginia courts utilize two-step test in determining whether corporate veil should be pierced, under which they first examine a number of factors, including adequacy of capital structures, whether personal and corporate funds have been commingled without regard to corporate form by sole shareholder, whether corporations have commingled their funds so that their accounts are interchangeable, whether they have failed to follow corporate formalities, whether funds have been siphoned from one corporation to another without regard to the harm caused either entity, and whether corporations failed to keep separate records, and then analyzes these factors in conjunction with evidence that corporation attempted to use its corporate structure to perpetrate a fraud or do grave injustice to the innocent third party seeking to pierce corporate veil.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Case Administration. Joint administration of Chapter 11 cases did not alter any substantive rights.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: In re Henkel
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, S.D. Ohio, Western Division.
Headnote: Among factors that Ohio courts consider in deciding, for veil-piercing purposes, whether corporation had no separate mind, will, or existence of its own are: (1) grossly inadequate capitalization, (2) failure to observe corporate formalities, (3) insolvency of corporation at time debt is incurred, (4) shareholders holding themselves as personally liable for certain corporate obligations, (5) the diversion of funds or other property of corporation for personal use, (6) absence of corporate records, and (7) fact that corporation was mere facade for operations of dominant shareholder(s); however, because of equitable nature of veil-piercing doctrine, no list of factors can be exclusive or exhaustive.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Discharge. State court's findings were not sufficiently detailed for its judgment to have issue preclusive effect.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: JMB Mfg., Inc. v. Child Craft, LLC
Court: United States District Court, S.D. Indiana, New Albany Division.
Headnote: Under Indiana law, there are eight practices that most often result in a court deciding to disregard the corporate form: (1) undercapitalization; (2) absence of corporate records; (3) fraudulent representation by corporation shareholders or directors; (4) use of the corporation to promote fraud, injustice or illegal activities; (5) payment by the corporation of individual obligations; (6) commingling of assets and affairs; (7) failure to observe required corporate formalities; or (8) other shareholder acts or conduct ignoring, controlling, or manipulating the corporate form.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW - Contracts. A fact issue existed as to whether a manufacturer waived its contractual remedies under the perfect tender rule.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: Jurista v. Amerinox Processing, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, D. New Jersey.
Headnote: In ascertaining whether the veil shrouding corporate individuals from liability should be pulled back, courts in the Third Circuit are to consider the "Pearson factors," namely: (1) gross undercapitalization of the corporation, (2) failure to observe corporate formalities, (3) nonpayment of dividends, (4) insolvency of a debtor corporation, (5) siphoning of funds from the debtor corporation by the dominant stockholder, (6) nonfunctioning of corporate officers and directors, (7) absence of corporate funds, and (8) whether the corporation is merely a facade for the operations of the dominant stockholder.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Avoidance. Disbursing agent stated claim for actual fraudulent transfers against debtor's officers and directors.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: D'Mel & Associates v. Athco, Inc.
Court: Supreme Court, Appellate Division, First Department, New York.
Headnote: Factors to be considered in determining whether owner of corporation has abused privilege of doing business in corporate form, as would support piercing corporate veil, include whether there was failure to adhere to corporate formalities, inadequate capitalization, commingling of assets, and use of corporate funds for personal use.
Document Preview: TORTS - Fraud. Corporate officers were not liable for fraudulent conveyances.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: National Integrated Group Pension Plan v. Dunhill Food Equipment Corp.
Court: United States District Court, E.D. New York.
Headnote: Under New York law, in determining whether owners exercised complete domination of corporation, such that piercing corporate veil is warranted, court should consider: (1) absence of formalities and paraphernalia that are part and parcel of corporate existence, such as issuance of stock, election of directors, keeping of corporate records, and the like, (2) inadequate capitalization, (3) whether funds are put in and taken out of corporation for personal rather than corporate purposes, (4) overlap in ownership, officers, directors, and personnel, (5) common office space, address and telephone numbers of corporate entities, (6) amount of business discretion displayed by allegedly dominated corporation, (7) whether related corporations deal with dominated corporation at arms length, (8) whether corporations are treated as independent profit centers, (9) payment or guarantee of debts of dominated corporation by other corporations in group, and (10) whether corporation had property that was used by other corporations as if it were their own.
Document Preview: LABOR AND EMPLOYMENT - Benefit Plans. Employer's owner was jointly and severally liable for its withdrawal liability to multiemployer pension plan.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: In re Gulf Fleet Holdings, Inc.
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, W.D. Louisiana, Lafayette Division.
Headnote: Under Louisiana law, factors considered in applying the alter ego doctrine include (1) commingling of corporate and shareholder funds, (2) failure to follow statutory formalities for incorporating and transacting corporate affairs, (3) undercapitalization, (4) failure to provide separate bank accounts and bookkeeping records, and (5) failure to hold regular shareholder and director meetings.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Avoidance. Trustee did not adequately allege claim to avoid repayment of insider's $4,000,000 loan as constructive fraudulent transfer.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: Damon v. Groteboer
Court: United States District Court, D. Minnesota.
Headnote: Courts consider following eight factors to determine whether corporation functioned as "mere instrumentality" of individuals sought to be held personally liable, as would support piercing corporate veil under Minnesota law: insufficient capitalization for purposes of corporate undertaking, failure to observe corporate formalities, nonpayment of dividends, insolvency of debtor corporation at time of transaction in question, siphoning of funds by dominant shareholder, nonfunctioning of other officers and directors, absence of corporate records, and existence of corporation as merely facade for individual dealings.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Corporate veil would not be pierced to subject corporation's members to liability for fraud and misrepresentation.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: Ness v. Gurstel Chargo, P.A.
Court: United States District Court, D. Minnesota.
Headnote: Under Minnesota law, the first prong of the alter ego doctrine focuses on the shareholder's relationship to the corporation; factors that are significant to the assessment of this relationship include whether there is insufficient capitalization for purposes of corporate undertaking, a failure to observe corporate formalities, nonpayment of dividends, insolvency of debtor corporation at time of transaction in question, siphoning of funds by dominant shareholder, nonfunctioning of other officers and directors, absence of corporate records, and existence of the corporation as merely a facade for individual dealings.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW - Jurisdiction. Rooker-Feldman doctrine divested trial court of jurisdiction over consumers' unjust enrichment claim against debt collector.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: Ridgerunner, LLC v. Meisinger
Court: Supreme Court of Wyoming.
Headnote: Among possible factors pertinent to determination of whether to disregard a corporate entity and pierce the corporate veil are commingling of funds and other assets, failure to segregate funds of separate entities, unauthorized diversion of corporate funds or assets to other than corporate uses, treatment by individual of assets of corporation as his own, failure to obtain authority to issue or subscribe to stock, holding out by an individual that he is personally liable for debts of corporation, failure to maintain minutes or adequate corporate records, confusion of records of separate entities, and identical equitable ownership in two entities.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Allegations in breach of contract complaint were insufficient to support piercing corporate veil to hold shareholder personally liable.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: Ridgerunner, LLC v. Meisinger
Court: Supreme Court of Wyoming.
Headnote: Among possible factors pertinent to determination of whether to disregard a corporate entity and pierce the corporate veil are identification of equitable owners thereof with domination and control of two entities, failure to adequately capitalize corporation, absence of corporate assets, undercapitalization, use of corporation as mere shell, instrumentality or conduit for single venture or business of individual or another corporation, concealment and misrepresentation of identity of responsible ownership, concealment of personal business activities, and disregard of legal formalities and failure to maintain arm's length relationships among related entities.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Allegations in breach of contract complaint were insufficient to support piercing corporate veil to hold shareholder personally liable.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: Ridgerunner, LLC v. Meisinger
Court: Supreme Court of Wyoming.
Headnote: Among possible factors pertinent to determination of whether to disregard a corporate entity and pierce the corporate veil are use of corporate entity to procure labor, services, or merchandise for another person or entity, diversion of assets from corporation by or to stockholder or other person or entity, to detriment of creditors, or manipulation of assets and liabilities between entities so as to concentrate assets in one and liabilities in another, contracting with another with intent to avoid performance by use of corporation as a subterfuge of illegal transactions and formation and use of a corporation to transfer to it existing liability of another person or entity.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Allegations in breach of contract complaint were insufficient to support piercing corporate veil to hold shareholder personally liable.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: U.S. v. Cohen
Court: United States District Court, C.D. Illinois.
Headnote: Although not conclusive, courts consider the following factors to determine the existence of an alter ego relationship under Nevada law: (1) commingling of funds; (2) undercapitalization; (3) unauthorized diversion of funds; (4) treatment of corporate assets as the individual's own; and (5) failure to observe corporate formalities.
Document Preview: TAXATION - Collection. Factors favored finding that corporation was taxpayer's nominee, for purposes of action to foreclose federal tax liens.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: GEBAM, Inc. v. Investment Realty Series I, LLC
Court: United States District Court, N.D. Georgia, Atlanta Division.
Headnote: Delaware courts consider several factors when assessing whether to allow piercing of the corporate veil, including: (1) the failure to keep standard corporate records; (2) the failure to observe corporate formalities; (3) undercapitalization at the corporation's formation; (4) insolvency; (5) exclusive domination and control over the company by the individual; and (6) whether the dominant shareholder siphoned corporate funds.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Limited Liability Companies. Genuine issue of fact whether member authorized loans precluded summary judgment on aiding and abetting breach of fiduciary duty claim.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: GEBAM, Inc. v. Investment Realty Series I, LLC
Court: United States District Court, N.D. Georgia, Atlanta Division.
Headnote: While no single factor justifies a decision to disregard the corporate entity, some combination of factors is required, and an overall element of injustice or unfairness must always be present.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Limited Liability Companies. Genuine issue of fact whether member authorized loans precluded summary judgment on aiding and abetting breach of fiduciary duty claim.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: Timber Integrated Investments, LLC v. Welch
Court: Court of Appeals of North Carolina.
Headnote: When evaluating whether the instrumentality rule elements are present in any one particular factual scenario, the court considering piercing the corporate veil considers the following factors: (1) inadequate capitalization, (2) non-compliance with corporate formalities, (3) complete domination and control of the corporation so that it has no independent identity, and (4) excessive fragmentation of a single enterprise into separate corporations.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Issues as to relationship between re-seller and principals precluded summary judgment on piercing the corporate veil theory.

Title: Timber Integrated Investments, LLC v. Welch
Court: Court of Appeals of North Carolina.
Headnote: Factors that may be considered when determining whether to pierce the corporate veil include non-payment of dividends, insolvency of the debtor corporation, siphoning of funds by the dominant shareholder, non-function of other officers or directors, and absence of corporate records; these are, however, merely factors to be considered to determine whether sufficient control and domination is present to satisfy the first prong of the three-pronged instrumentality rule.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Issues as to relationship between re-seller and principals precluded summary judgment on piercing the corporate veil theory.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: My Father's House No. 1 v. McCardle
Court: Court of Appeals of Ohio, Third District, Marion County.
Headnote: Factors used to determine if a corporation is alter ego of individual, as could support piercing corporate veil, include: (1) whether corporate formalities were observed; (2) whether corporate records were kept; (3) whether corporate funds were commingled with personal funds; and (4) whether corporate property was used for a personal purpose.
Document Preview: FAMILY LAW - Antenuptial Agreements. Antenuptial agreement precluded wife from challenging husband's transfer of property even though wife was will beneficiary.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: Vitol, S.A. v. Primerose Shipping Co. Ltd.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Fourth Circuit.
Headnote: In applying the factors used to answer the question of whether to pierce the corporate veil, a court must focus on reality and not form, on how the corporation operated and the individual defendant's relationship to that operation.
Document Preview: MARITIME LAW - Jurisdiction. Legal action in Commercial Court of English High Court of Justice did not divest resulting judgment of admiralty character.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: Serio v. Baystate Properties, LLC
Court: Court of Special Appeals of Maryland.
Headnote: Factors to be considered in determining whether to pierce the corporate veil under the alter ego theory include whether the corporation was adequately capitalized, the company's solvency when entering the transaction, the observance of corporate formalities, and evidence that the corporation had no separate mind, will, or existence of its own.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Limited Liability Companies. Piercing of LLC's veil was not warranted in absence of fraud.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: Tyson Fresh Meats, Inc. v. Lauer Ltd., L.L.C.
Court: United States District Court, N.D. Iowa, Western Division.
Headnote: When the fraud is not apparent, Nebraska courts look to the following factors to determine whether the inference of fraud is sufficiently strong for piercing the corporate: (1) grossly inadequate capitalization; (2) insolvency of the debtor corporation at the time the debt is incurred; (3) diversion by the shareholder or shareholders of corporate funds or assets to their own or other improper uses; and (4) the fact that the corporation is a mere facade for the personal dealings of the shareholder and that the operations of the corporation are carried on by the shareholder in disregard of the corporate entity.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Limited Liability Companies. Piercing LLC's corporate veil, so as to obtain personal jurisdiction over its members, was warranted.
