Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: On Command Video Corp. v. Roti
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Seventh Circuit.
Headnote: Illinois allows the corporate veil to be pierced, thereby exposing the corporation's owner to personal liability for the corporation's debts, if two conditions are satisfied: (1) the owner has failed to operate it as a corporation, neglecting such requisites of the corporate form as adequate capitalization, election of directors and officers, and separation of corporate from personal funds, and (2) refusing to pierce the veil would sanction a fraud or promote injustice.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Piercing corporate veil was unwarranted in suit seeking to enforce underlying statecourt default judgment.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: Gieseke ex rel. Diversified Water Diversion, Inc. v. IDCA, Inc.
Court: Court of Appeals of Minnesota.
Headnote: Courts apply a two-prong test to determine when the corporate entity should be disregarded: (1) the first prong of the test focuses on the shareholder's relationship to the corporation, and (2) the second prong examines the relationship of the plaintiff to the corporation.
Document Preview: TORTS - Tortious Interference. A claim of tortious interference with prospective advantage is a valid tort claim under Minnesota law.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: Gieseke ex rel. Diversified Water Diversion, Inc. v. IDCA, Inc.
Court: Court of Appeals of Minnesota.
Headnote: Eight factors are significant in making a determination on the first prong of test to disregard a corporate entity, which prong focuses on the shareholder's relationship to the corporation: (1) insufficient capitalization for purposes of corporate undertaking; (2) failure to observe corporate formalities; (3) nonpayment of dividends; (4) insolvency of debtor corporation at time of transaction in question; (5) siphoning of funds by dominant shareholder; (6) nonfunctioning of other officers and directors; (7) absence of corporate records; and (8) existence of corporation as merely facade for individual dealings.
Document Preview: TORTS - Tortious Interference. A claim of tortious interference with prospective advantage is a valid tort claim under Minnesota law.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: Gieseke ex rel. Diversified Water Diversion, Inc. v. IDCA, Inc.
Court: Court of Appeals of Minnesota.
Headnote: Disregard of the corporate entity requires not only that a number of the factors regarding a shareholder's relationship to the corporation be present, but also that there be an element of injustice or fundamental unfairness.
Document Preview: TORTS - Tortious Interference. A claim of tortious interference with prospective advantage is a valid tort claim under Minnesota law.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: Kraft Power Corp. v. Merrill
Court: Supreme Judicial Court of Massachusetts, Middlesex.
Headnote: Ultimately, decision to disregard settled expectations accompanying corporate form requires determination that shareholder directed and controlled corporation, and used it for improper purpose, based on evaluative consideration of twelve factors: (1) common ownership; (2) pervasive control; (3) confused intermingling of business assets; (4) thin capitalization; (5) nonobservance of corporate formalities; (6) absence of corporate records; (7) no payment of dividends; (8) insolvency at the time of the litigated transaction; (9) siphoning away of corporation's funds by dominant shareholder; (10) nonfunctioning of officers and directors; (11) use of the corporation for transactions of the dominant shareholders; and (12) use of corporation in promoting fraud.
Document Preview: ANTITRUST - Survival of Claim. Business's statutory unfair trade practices claim was contractual in nature and, therefore, survived death of sole shareholder.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: SMS Assist L.L.C. v. East Coast Lot & Pavement Maintenance Corp.
Court: United States District Court, N.D. Illinois, Eastern Division.
Headnote: Illinois courts weigh various factors when determining whether to disregard the separate existence of a corporation, including: failure to comply with corporate formalities or maintain adequate corporate records; commingling of funds or assets; undercapitalization; failure to maintain an arms-length relationship with related entities; non-functioning of the other officers or directors; diversion of assets from the corporation to the officer to the detriment of other creditors; and whether the corporation is a mere facade for dominant shareholders.
Document Preview: TORTS - Fraud. Snow removal contractor could not prevail on its fraud claim against subcontractor under Illinois law.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: In re Cabrini Medical Center
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: Factors considered in deciding whether to pierce the corporate veil in the context of an ERISA action are as follows: (1) the absence of the formalities which are part and parcel of normal corporate existence, i.e., the issuance of stock, the election of directors, the keeping of corporate records, etc., (2) inadequate capitalization, (3) personal use of corporate funds, and (4) the perpetration of fraud by means of the corporate vehicle; bankruptcy trustee may assert an ERISA claim seeking to pierce the corporate veil when the conditions are met. Employee Retirement Income Security Act of 1974, § 2 et seq., 29 U.S.C.A. § 1001 et seq.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Claims. Creditors' alter ego claims against debtor were property of the estate.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: Reed v. Reid
Court: Supreme Court of Indiana.
Headnote: When determining whether a shareholder is liable for corporate acts, court's considerations may include: (1) undercapitalization of the corporation; (2) the absence of corporate records; (3) fraudulent representations by corporation shareholders or directors; (4) use of the corporation to promote fraud, injustice, or illegal activities; (5) payment by the corporation of individual obligations; (6) commingling of assets and affairs; (7) failure to observe required corporate formalities; and (8) other shareholder acts or conduct ignoring, controlling, or manipulating the corporate form; however, these factors are not exclusive.
Document Preview: TORTS - Fraud. Representation that allegedly hazardous waste to be dumped on landowner's property was clean fill could support fraud claim.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: Edmunds v. Delta Partners, L.L.C.
Court: Court of Appeals of Tennessee, Middle Section, at Nashville.
Headnote: Generally, no one factor is conclusive in determining whether to pierce the corporate veil; rather, courts will rely upon a combination of factors in deciding the issue.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Evidence was insufficient to support piercing of corporate veil and holding of company president personally liable to employee for unpaid wages.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: Tatten v. Bank of America Corp.
Court: United States District Court, D. Colorado.
Headnote: A court generally will not allow the corporate veil to be pierced except in certain factual circumstances, and the court considers a variety of factors to determine whether the corporate form should be disregarded including: (1) whether the corporation is operated as a separate entity; (2) commingling of funds and other assets; (3) failure to maintain adequate corporate records; (4) the nature of the corporation's ownership and control; (5) absence of corporate assets and undercapitalization; (6) use of the corporation as a mere shell; (7) disregard of legal formalities; and (8) diversion of the corporation's funds or assets to noncorporate uses.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW - Consumer Credit. Tort claims brought against mortgage lender's president and chief executive officer (CEO) were precluded.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: AngioDynamics, Inc. v. Biolitec AG
Court: United States District Court, D. Massachusetts.
Headnote: Under Massachusetts law, the analysis of the 12 factors for courts to consider in determining whether to pierce the corporate veil does not involve merely counting the ones favoring veil-piercing and the ones against it; a court must examine the twelve factors to form an opinion whether the over-all structure and operation misleads.
Document Preview: TORTS - Fraud. Judgment creditor demonstrated substantial likelihood of success on its fraudulent conveyance claim.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: In re Archdiocese of Milwaukee
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, E.D. Wisconsin.
Headnote: Under Wisconsin law, courts will consider the following factors to determine if a corporation is a sham, for purposes of applying the alter ego doctrine: failure to observe corporate formalities, non-payment of dividends, siphoning of funds of the corporation by the dominant stockholder, non-functioning of other officers or directors, and the absence of corporate records.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Case Administration. Committee failed to state colorable claim for substantive consolidation.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: Jefferson v. Collins
Court: United States District Court, District of Columbia.
Headnote: Under District of Columbia law, for purposes of the veil-piercing analysis, no single factor for determining whether the corporate veil has been pierced is dispositive, and the factor which predominates will vary in each case.
Document Preview: REAL PROPERTY - Merger. Home purchasers' breach of contract claim against seller for faulty electrical system survived delivery of the deed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: Ferrara v. Oakfield Leasing Inc.
Court: United States District Court, E.D. New York.
Headnote: Test for piercing the corporate veil is flexible one, which allows courts to weigh the circumstances of the individual case, and courts typically look at the following factors: (1) absence of formalities which are part and parcel of normal corporate existence, i.e., issuance of stock, election of directors, keeping of corporate records, etc., (2) inadequate capitalization, (3) personal use of corporate funds, and (4) perpetration of fraud by means of corporate vehicle.
Document Preview: LABOR AND EMPLOYMENT - Attorney Fees. Time sheets in ERISA action for delinquent contributions were sufficiently detailed, but rates charged were not all reasonable.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: Bash v. Textron Financial Corp.
Court: United States District Court, N.D. Ohio, Eastern Division.
Headnote: Under Ohio law, courts may consider a number of nonexclusive factors in deciding whether to disregard the corporate fiction under the alter ego theory, including: (1) grossly inadequate capitalization, (2) failure to observe corporate formalities, (3) insolvency of the debtor corporation at the time the debt is incurred, (4) shareholders holding themselves out as personally liable for certain corporate obligations, (5) diversion of funds or other property of the company for personal use, (6) absence of corporate records, and (7) the fact that the corporation was a mere facade for the operations of the dominant shareholder(s).
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Avoidance. Trustee could use Ponzi scheme presumption to satisfy fraudulent intent requirement of fraudulent conveyance claim.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: Howell Contractors, Inc. v. Berling
Court: Court of Appeals of Kentucky.
Headnote: In order to pierce the corporate veil under Kentucky law, two elements must be met: (1) the loss of corporate or entity separateness, as established by analysis of the eleven factors listed in Inter–Tel Techs., Inc. v. Linn Station Props., LLC; and (2) the sanctioning of fraud or promoting injustice.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Limited Liability Companies. LLC's failure to pay an entity debt did not rise to the level of fraud, illegality, or unlawfulness necessary to pierce the entity veil.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: Board of Trustees of Auto. Mechanics' Local No. 701 Union and Industry Pension Fund v. Moroni
Court: United States District Court, N.D. Illinois, Eastern Division.
Headnote: For a claim of alter ego liability, unity of interest and ownership may be shown by evidence of several factors, with no single one being determinative, including misrepresentation, commingling of funds, assets, or identities, inadequate capitalization, failure to operate at arms' length, failure to comply with corporate formalities, failure to issue stock, non-payment of dividends, insolvency of the corporation, non-functioning of other officers or directors, absence of corporate records, diversion of assets by or to a shareholder to the detriment of creditors, failure to maintain arm's length relationships among related entities, and whether in fact the corporation is a mere facade for the operation of the dominant shareholders.
Document Preview: LABOR AND EMPLOYMENT - Benefit Plans. ERISA single employer liability claim was sufficiently alleged by board of trustees for ERISA pension fund.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: Board of Trustees of Auto. Mechanics' Local No. 701 Union and Industry Pension Fund v. Moroni
Court: United States District Court, N.D. Illinois, Eastern Division.
Headnote: Three general factors are analyzed in determining whether underlying objectives of the alter ego doctrine have been satisfied: (1) the amount of respect which the shareholders give to the separate entity, (2) the fraudulent intent involved, and (3) the amount of injustice which parties would suffer by respecting the corporate entity.
Document Preview: LABOR AND EMPLOYMENT - Benefit Plans. ERISA single employer liability claim was sufficiently alleged by board of trustees for ERISA pension fund.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: In re Opus East, L.L.C.
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, D. Delaware.
Headnote: In determining whether two entities are in fact a single economic entity under alter-ego theory of piercing the corporate veil under Delaware law, following factors must be sufficiently pleaded by plaintiff: (1) undercapitalization, (2) failure to observe corporate formalities, (3) nonpayment of dividends, (4) insolvency of debtor corporation at the time, (5) siphoning of corporation's funds by dominant stockholder, (6) absence of corporate records, and (7) fact that corporation is merely facade for operations of dominant stockholder or stockholders.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Claims. Complaint failed to adequately plead claims for fraud and conspiracy to commit fraud under fraud pleading rule.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: In re Opus East, L.L.C.
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, D. Delaware.
Headnote: While no single factor justifies a decision to disregard the corporate entity through piercing the corporate veil under Delaware law, some combination of relevant factors is required, and an overall element of injustice or unfairness must be present as well.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Claims. Complaint failed to adequately plead claims for fraud and conspiracy to commit fraud under fraud pleading rule.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: Twenty-Nine Palms Enterprises Corp. v. Bardos
Court: Court of Appeal, Fourth District, Division 2, California.
Headnote: A few of the factors that must be considered under the alter ego doctrine are (1) whether there was commingling of funds, (2) whether the individual treated corporate assets as his own, and (3) whether the individual held himself out as being personally liable for the debts of the corporation.
Document Preview: GOVERNMENT - Licensing. Contractor could not assert sovereign immunity as defense in tribal project owner's action under licensing statutes.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: Rowen Petroleum Properties, LLC v. Hollywood Tanning Systems, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, D. New Jersey.
Headnote: Under New Jersey law, factors to consider in determining whether to pierce corporate veil include: gross undercapitalization, failure to observe corporate formalities, non-payment of dividends, debtor corporation's insolvency at time, siphoning of corporate funds by dominant stockholder, non-functioning of other officers or directors, absence of corporate records, and fact that corporation is merely facade for operations of dominant stockholder or stockholders.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Landlord could not pierce corporate veil to hold tenant's principals liable for its breach of lease agreement.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: In re Juve
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, D. Minnesota.
Headnote: Under Minnesota law, several factors must exist to support finding that corporation is mere instrumentality or alter ego of its shareholder, among which are: insufficient capitalization, a failure to observe corporate formalities, nonpayment of dividends, insolvency of corporation, siphoning of funds, nonfunctioning of officers and directors, absence of corporate records, or existence of corporation as mere façade for individual dealings.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Discharge. Debtor's false representations and omissions rendered debt nondischargeable.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: Gold Dust Mines, Inc. v. Little Squaw Gold Min. Co.
Court: Supreme Court of Alaska.
Headnote: In applying the mere instrumentality test to help the factfinder to decide whether the evidence favors piercing the corporate veil, Supreme Court asks whether: (1) the shareholder sought to be charged owns all or most of the stock of the corporation, (2) the shareholder has subscribed to all of the capital stock of the corporation or otherwise caused its incorporation, (3) the corporation has grossly inadequate capital, (4) the shareholder uses the property of the corporation as his own, (5) the directors or executives of the corporation act independently in the interest of the corporation or simply take their orders from the shareholder in the latter's interest, and (6) the formal legal requirements of the corporation are observed; it is not necessary for all six factors to be satisfied before imposing personal liability.
Document Preview: ENERGY AND UTILITIES - Mining. Mining claims staked by former lessee's officer during lessee's holdover tenancy were held in constructive trust.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: Stanley v. Central Garden and Pet Corp.
Court: United States District Court, D. Maryland.
Headnote: Under Maryland law, factors that may be used in deciding whether the doctrine of paramount equity applies to pierce the corporate veil include whether the corporation was grossly undercapitalized, the dominant stockholder's siphoning of corporate funds, the absence of corporate records, and the corporation's status as a facade for the stockholders' operations.
Document Preview: PRODUCTS LIABILITY - Warnings. Under Maryland law, warnings adequately warned of dangers of dog chew toy.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: In re Osorno
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, D. Massachusetts.
Headnote: Under Massachusetts law, factors relevant to corporate veil-piercing analysis are (1) common ownership, (2) pervasive control, (3) confused intermingling of business assets, (4) thin capitalization, (5) nonobservance of corporate formalities, (6) absence of corporate records, (7) no payment of dividends, (8) insolvency at the time of litigated transaction, (9) siphoning away of corporation's funds by dominant shareholder, (10) nonfunctioning of officers and directors, (11) use of corporation for transactions of dominant shareholders, and (12) use of corporation in promoting fraud.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Discharge. Judgment creditors of two limited liability companies failed to establish that member was alter ego liable for LLC debts.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: Tryco Enterprises, Inc. v. Robinson
Court: Court of Appeals of Texas, Houston (1st Dist.).
Headnote: Alter ego theory for piercing the corporate veil applies when there is such unity between corporation and individual that the separateness of the corporation has ceased and holding only the corporation liable would result in injustice; it is shown from the total dealings of the corporation and the individual, including the degree to which corporate formalities have been followed and corporate and individual property have been kept separately, the amount of financial interest, ownership and control the individual maintains over the corporation, and whether the corporation has been used for personal purposes. V.T.C.A., Bus. & C. § 21.223(a)(2).
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Corporate forms of former employer and employer's successor were alter egos of owners, as grounds for piercing corporate veil to enforce judgment against employer.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: Gaddy v. Universal Cable Systems, Inc.
Court: Court of Appeal of Louisiana, Second Circuit.
Headnote: Piercing the corporate veil on the basis of the "alter ego" theory involves considering five factors: (1) commingling of corporate and shareholder funds, (2) failure to follow statutory formalities for incorporating and transacting corporate affairs, (3) undercapitalization, (4) failure to maintain separate bank accounts and bookkeeping records, and (5) failure to hold regular shareholder and director meetings.
Document Preview: LABOR AND EMPLOYMENT - Hours and Wages. Trial court's refusal to award penalty wages due to unreasonable delay in resolving pay dispute was manifest error.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: Green v. Freeman
Court: Court of Appeals of North Carolina.
Headnote: Factors to consider in piercing the corporate veil include: (1) inadequate capitalization; (2) non-compliance with corporate formalities; (3) complete domination and control of the corporation so that it has no independent identity; and (4) excessive fragmentation of a single enterprise into separate corporations.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Officers and Directors. Member's diversion of corporate funds for personal use constitute breach of fiduciary duty owed to minority shareholders.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: Konrad Motor and Welder Service, Inc. v. Magnetech Industrial Services, Inc.
Court: Court of Appeals of Indiana.
Headnote: In determining whether the burden of showing fraud or injustice stemming from misuse of the corporate form has been met, the court considering a request to pierce the corporate veil considers the following factors: (1) undercapitalization, (2) absence of corporate records, (3) fraudulent representation by corporation shareholders or directors, (4) use of the corporation to promote fraud, injustice, or illegal activities, (5) payment by the corporation of individual obligations, (6) commingling of assets and affairs, (7) failure to observe required corporate formalities, and (8) other shareholder acts or conduct ignoring, controlling, or manipulating the corporate form; these factors are not exhaustive in that not all factors must be shown to support a determination that the corporate veil should be pierced.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. New company was contractor's alter ego and thus was liable for judgment against contractor.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: In re Steffner
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, E.D. Tennessee.
Headnote: Under Tennessee law, factors to be considered in determining whether to disregard corporate veil include not only whether entity has been used to work a fraud or injustice in contravention of public policy, but also (1) whether there was failure to collect paid in capital, (2) whether corporation was grossly undercapitalized, (3) nonissuance of stock certificates, (4) sole ownership of stock by one individual, (5) use of same office or business location, (6) employment of same employees or attorneys, (7) use of corporation as instrumentality or business conduit for individual or another corporation, (8) diversion of corporate assets by or to stockholder or other entity to detriment of creditors, or manipulation of assets and liabilities in another, (9) use of corporation as subterfuge in illegal transactions, (10) formation and use of corporation to transfer to it existing liability of another person or entity, and (11) failure to maintain arms-length relationships among related entities.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Limited Liability Companies. Piercing of corporate veil of limited liability company was not warranted under Tennessee law

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: In re Steffner
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, E.D. Tennessee.
Headnote: Under Tennessee law, no one factor is conclusive as to whether court should grant remedy of piercing of the corporate veil, and it is not necessary that all factors weigh in favor of piercing the corporate veil, but it is necessary that the equities substantially favor the party requesting the court to disregard the corporate status.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Limited Liability Companies. Piercing of corporate veil of limited liability company was not warranted under Tennessee law

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: NuCal Foods, Inc. v. Quality Egg LLC
Court: United States District Court, E.D. California.
Headnote: When evaluating the degree of control wielded by the dominant corporation, courts consider the following factors: (1) substantial ownership of a corporation and dominance over its management; (2) inadequacy of the corporation's capitalization or its insolvency; (3) failure to observe corporate formalities; (4) absence of regular board meetings; (5) nonfunctioning of corporate directors; (6) commingling of corporate and noncorporate assets; (7) the diversion of assets from the corporation to the detriment of creditors; and (8) failure of an individual to maintain an arm's length relationship with the corporation.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW - Jurisdiction. Assertion of personal jurisdiction over other related entities would not have been consistent with due process.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: Joe Hand Promotions, Inc. v. Sharp
Court: United States District Court, D. Minnesota.
Headnote: A plaintiff attempting to impose individual liability under the Federal Communications Act (FCA) for cable piracy need not show a failure to observe corporate formalities or insufficient capitalization, traditional elements of a veil-piercing analysis, nor must a plaintiff necessarily establish that an individual defendant had a strong financial interest in the allegedly unlawful conduct, as in the benefit-and-control test; rather, to impose individual liability a plaintiff must show that there exists no distinction between the individual's actions and that of his corporation. Federal Communications Act of 1934, § 1 et seq., 47 U.S.C.A. § 151 et seq.
Document Preview: ENERGY AND UTILITIES - Telecommunications. Corporation's sole shareholder was not personally liable for corporation's alleged violations of Federal Communications Act.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: Bank of Montreal v. SK Foods, LLC
Court: United States District Court, N.D. California, San Jose Division.
Headnote: To determine whether there is sufficient unity of interest and ownership to support alter ego liability under California law, courts consider non-exhaustive list of factors: (1) commingling of funds and other assets, failure to segregate funds of separate entities, and unauthorized diversion of corporate funds or assets to other than corporate uses, (2) treatment by individual of corporate assets as his own, (3) failure to obtain authority to issue stock or to subscribe to or issue same, (4) holding out by individual that he is personally liable for debts of corporation, (5) failure to maintain minutes or adequate corporate records, and confusion of records of separate entities, (6) identical equitable ownership in two entities, (7) identification of equitable owners thereof with domination and control of two entities, (8) identification of directors and officers of two entities in responsible supervision and management, (9) sole ownership of all of stock in corporation by one individual or members of family, (10) use of same office or business location, (11) employment of same employees and/or attorney, (12) failure to adequately capitalize corporation, (13) total absence of corporate assets and undercapitalization, (14) use of corporation as mere shell, instrumentality, or conduit for single venture or business of individual or another corporation, (15) concealment and misrepresentation of identity of responsible ownership, management, and financial interest, or concealment of personal business activities, (16) disregard of legal formalities and failure to maintain arm's length relationships among related entities, (17) use of corporate entity to procure labor, services, or merchandise for another person or entity, (18) diversion of assets from corporation by or to stockholder or other person or entity, to detriment of creditors, or manipulation of assets and liabilities between entities so as to concentrate assets in one and liabilities in another, (19) contracting with another with intent to avoid performance by use of corporate entity as shield against personal liability, or use of corporation as subterfuge of illegal transactions, and (20) formation and use of corporation to transfer to it existing liability of another person or entity.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Jurisdiction. Transfer or dismissal of action related to substantive consolidation proceeding before bankruptcy court was not warranted.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: Canadian Nat. Ry. Co. v. Waltman
Court: Supreme Court of Mississippi.
Headnote: In both tort and contract claims, the corporate entity will not be disregarded unless the complaining party can demonstrate: (1) some frustration of expectations regarding the party to whom he looked for performance; (2) the flagrant disregard of corporate formalities by the defendant corporation and its principals; and (3) a demonstration of fraud or other equivalent misfeasance on the part of the corporate shareholder.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Jurisdiction. Plaintiffs' failed to justify disregarding railroad defendant's corporate structure as grounds for exercising personal jurisdiction over its Canadian parent.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: Allstate ATM Corp. v. E.S.A. Holding Corp.
Court: Supreme Court, Appellate Division, Second Department, New York.
Headnote: Factors to be considered in determining whether an individual has abused the privilege of doing business in the corporate form, so as to support piercing the corporate veil, include the failure to adhere to corporate formalities, inadequate capitalization, commingling of assets, and the personal use of corporate funds.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Amended complaint did not plead sufficient facts to hold shareholder personally liable in breach of contract action.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: Endsley Elec., Inc. v. Altech, Inc.
Court: Court of Appeals of Texas, Texarkana.
Headnote: Alter ego is shown from the total dealings of the corporation and the individual, including factors such as: (1) the payment of alleged corporate debts with personal checks or other commingling of funds, (2) representations that the individual will financially back the corporation, (3) the diversion of company profits to the individual for his or her personal use, (4) inadequate capitalization, (5) whether the corporation has been used for personal purposes, and (6) other failure to keep corporate and personal assets separate.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Subcontractor was not undercapitalized as would support the piercing of the corporate veil.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: Central Transport, LLC v. Atlas Towing, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, E.D. Pennsylvania.
Headnote: Under Pennsylvania law, the factors to be considered in determining whether to disregard the corporate form include undercapitalization, failure to adhere to corporate formalities, substantial intermingling of corporate and personal affairs, and use of the corporate form to perpetrate a fraud.
Document Preview: TORTS - Conversion. Tractor-trailer owner and lessee stated a conversion claim against tow truck operator.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: Jones v. Bowie Industries, Inc.
Court: Supreme Court of Alaska.
Headnote: A party seeking to pierce the corporate veil does not need to present evidence of all six applicable factors; the factors assist the trial court to determine whether the evidence favors piercing the veil.
Document Preview: TORTS - Evidence. Admitting evidence of injured worker's receipt of workers' compensation and social security benefits was abuse of discretion in negligence action.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: Jones & Trevor Marketing, Inc. v. Lowry
Court: Supreme Court of Utah.
Headnote: The following factors, while not required elements, are helpful tools to aid courts in determining whether to pierce the corporate veil, including whether there was (1) undercapitalization of a one-man corporation; (2) failure to observe corporate formalities; (3) nonpayment of dividends; (4) siphoning of corporate funds by the dominant stockholder; (5) nonfunctioning of other officers or directors; (6) absence of corporate records; (7) the use of the corporation as a facade for operations of the dominant stockholder or stockholders; and (8) the use of the corporate entity in promoting injustice or fraud.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Plaintiff was not required to produce evidence of more than one of the Coleman factors to survive motion for summary judgment on its alter ego case.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: Burchinal v. PJ Trailers-Seminole Management Co., LLC
Court: Court of Appeals of Texas, Texarkana.
Headnote: Alter ego, as basis for piercing the corporate veil, is shown from the total dealings of the corporation and the individual, including the degree to which corporate and individual property have been kept separately, the amount of financial interest, ownership, and control the individual maintains over the corporation, and whether the corporation has been used for personal purposes.
Document Preview: TORTS - Limitations. Limitations period for negligence claim was not tolled based on misidentification.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: Burchinal v. PJ Trailers-Seminole Management Co., LLC
Court: Court of Appeals of Texas, Texarkana.
Headnote: Evidence as proof of an alter ego, as basis for piercing the corporate veil, includes: (1) the payment of alleged corporate debts with personal checks or other commingling of funds; (2) representations that the individual will financially back the corporation; (3) the diversion of company profits to the individual for the individual's personal use; (4) inadequate capitalization; and (5) other failure to keep corporate and personal assets separate.
Document Preview: TORTS - Limitations. Limitations period for negligence claim was not tolled based on misidentification.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: In re Hoffmann
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, D. Minnesota.
Headnote: Several factors must exist to support finding, for veil-piercing purposes under Minnesota law, that corporation is the alter ego or mere instrumentality of shareholder, including: insufficient capitalization, failure to observe corporate formalities, nonpayment of dividends, insolvency of corporation, siphoning of funds, nonfunctioning of officers and directors, absence of corporate records, or existence of corporation as mere façade for individual dealings.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Discharge. Sellers justifiably relied on representations contradicted by close, lawyerly reading of closing documents.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: Battino v. Cornelia Fifth Ave., LLC
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: Under New York law, factors that courts consider when determining whether it is appropriate to pierce the corporate veil include: (1) the absence of the formalities and paraphernalia that are part and parcel of the corporate existence, i.e., issuance of stock, election of directors, keeping of corporate records and the like, (2) inadequate capitalization, (3) whether funds are put in and taken out of the corporation for personal rather than corporate purposes, (4) overlap in ownership, officers, directors, and personnel, (5) common office space, address and telephone numbers of corporate entities, (6) the amount of business discretion displayed by the allegedly dominated corporation, (7) whether the related corporations deal with the dominated corporation at arms length, (8) whether the corporations are treated as independent profit centers, (9) the payment or guarantee of debts of the dominated corporation by other corporations in the group, and (10) whether the corporation in question had property that was used by other of the corporations as if it were its own.
Document Preview: LABOR AND EMPLOYMENT - Judgment. Issues of material fact precluded summary judgment on issue of successor liability in FLSA unpaid wages action.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: In re Autobacs Strauss, Inc.
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, D. Delaware.
Headnote: Factors that Delaware courts consider in deciding, for purposes of alter ego claim, whether parent and subsidiary corporations were operated as single economic unit are: (1) whether subsidiary was undercapitalized; (2) whether subsidiary was insolvent at relevant time; (3) whether companies failed to observe corporate formalities; (4) whether subsidiary failed to pay dividends to parent; (5) whether there was a siphoning of subsidiary's funds; (6) absence of corporate records; and (7) whether the subsidiary was merely a façade.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Claims. Debtor stated plausible claim for recharacterization of debt.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: In re Autobacs Strauss, Inc.
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, D. Delaware.
Headnote: Under Delaware law, no single factor is dispositive in deciding, for purposes of alter ego claim, whether corporate parent and subsidiary were operated as single economic unit; some combination of factors is required.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Claims. Debtor stated plausible claim for recharacterization of debt.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: Bloxom v. City of Shreveport
Court: Court of Appeal of Louisiana, Second Circuit.
Headnote: Regardless of the basis for piercing the corporate veil to impose individual liability on a corporate officer, the situation must be viewed with regard to the totality of circumstances in each case.
Document Preview: TORTS - Negligence. President of corporation did not a personal duty to protect victim from sexual assault and murder at the hands of a cab driver.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: First Keystone Consultants, Inc. v. Schlesinger Elec. Contractors, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, E.D. New York.
Headnote: When determining whether a shareholder has exercised complete domination over a corporation, so as to support piercing the corporate veil under New York law, courts will consider, inter alia, the following factors: (1) the absence of the formalities and paraphernalia that are part and parcel of the corporate existence, i.e., issuance of stock, elections of directors, keeping of corporate records and the like; (2) inadequate capitalization; (3) whether funds are put in and taken out of the corporation for personal rather than corporate purposes; (4) common office space, address and telephone numbers of corporate entities; (5) the amount of business discretion displayed by the allegedly dominated corporation; (6) the payment or guarantee of debts of the corporation by other corporations in the group; and (7) whether the corporation in question had property that was used by another as if it were its own.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Officers and Directors. Contractor was entitled to money judgment against corporation and its officers on New York claims for fraudulent conveyances.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: In re P & J Resources, Inc.
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, E.D. Kentucky, Pikeville Division.
Headnote: Under Kentucky law, corporate veil should be pierced on equity formulation theory only with reluctance and caution, and then only in presence of some combination of the following factors, no one of which is dispositive: (1) undercapitalization; (2) failure to observe corporate formalities; (3) nonpayment or overpayment of dividends; (4) a siphoning off of funds by dominant shareholder(s); and (5) majority shareholders having guaranteed corporate liabilities in their individual capacities.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Claims. Defendants' status as Chapter 7 debtors and size of compensatory award counseled against punitive damages.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: Raytheon Co. v. Boccard USA Corp.
Court: Court of Appeals of Texas, Houston (1st Dist.).
Headnote: The factors that a court must consider when evaluating an alter-ego argument for veil piercing under Delaware law include whether the corporation was adequately capitalized for the corporate undertaking; whether the corporation was solvent; whether dividends were paid, corporate records kept, officers and directors functioned properly, and other corporate formalities were observed; whether the dominant shareholder siphoned corporate funds; and whether, in general, the corporation simply functioned as a facade for the dominant shareholder.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Creditor of bankrupt third-tier subsidiary did not have standing to assert alter ego claim against parent corporation.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: Doyle v. Kontemporary Builders, Inc.
Court: Court of Appeals of Texas, Dallas.
Headnote: As proof of alter ego, as a theory under which the corporate veil may be pierced, courts may consider (1) the payment of alleged corporate debts with personal checks or other commingling of funds; (2) representations that the individual will financially back the corporation; (3) the diversion of company profits to the individual for his personal use; (4) inadequate capitalization; and (5) other failure to keep corporate and personal assets separate. V.T.C.A., Business Organizations Code § 21.223.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Limited liability company (LLC) was not a sham corporation or alter ego of sole shareholder/officer.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: Doyle v. Kontemporary Builders, Inc.
Court: Court of Appeals of Texas, Dallas.
Headnote: An individual's standing as an officer, director, or majority shareholder of an entity is, in and of itself, insufficient to support a finding of alter ego, as a theory under which the corporate veil may be pierced. V.T.C.A., Business Organizations Code § 21.223.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Limited liability company (LLC) was not a sham corporation or alter ego of sole shareholder/officer.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: Carlone v. Lion & the Bull Films, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: To determine whether it is appropriate to pierce the corporation veil under New York law, and thus to hold an individual liable for corporate action, courts consider: the absence of formalities and paraphernalia that are part and parcel of corporate existence, i.e., issuance of stock, election of directors, keeping of corporate records and the like; inadequate capitalization; whether funds are put in and taken out of corporation for personal rather than corporate purposes; overlap in ownership, officers, directors, and personnel; whether related corporations deal with dominated corporation at arms length; and whether corporation in question had property that is used by other of the corporations as if it were its own.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Piercing corporate veil was appropriate to hold principal liable for film production company's actions related to loan.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: Rogers v. Louisville Land Co.
Court: Supreme Court of Tennessee, at Knoxville.
Headnote: Factors to be considered in determining whether to disregard the corporate veil include not only whether the entity has been used to work a fraud or injustice in contravention of public policy, but also: (1) whether there was a failure to collect paid in capital; (2) whether the corporation was grossly undercapitalized; (3) the nonissuance of stock certificates; (4) the sole ownership of stock by one individual; (5) the use of the same office or business location; (6) the employment of the same employees or attorneys; (7) the use of the corporation as an instrumentality or business conduit for an individual or another corporation; (8) the diversion of corporate assets by or to a stockholder or other entity to the detriment of creditors, or the manipulation of assets and liabilities in another; (9) the use of the corporation as a subterfuge in illegal transactions; (10) the formation and use of the corporation to transfer to it the existing liability of another person or entity; and (11) the failure to maintain arms length relationships among related entities.
Document Preview: TORTS - Emotional Distress. Mother failed to prove that company's failure to adequately maintain cemetery caused her to suffer serious mental injury.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: Rogers v. Louisville Land Co.
Court: Supreme Court of Tennessee, at Knoxville.
Headnote: No single factor is conclusive in determining whether to disregard the corporate veil, nor is it required that all of the applicable factors support piercing the corporate veil; typically, courts will rely on a combination of the factors in deciding the issue.
Document Preview: TORTS - Emotional Distress. Mother failed to prove that company's failure to adequately maintain cemetery caused her to suffer serious mental injury.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: Delta Development Corp. v. F. Fani Gulf Intern.
Court: Court of Appeals of Tennessee.
Headnote: It is unnecessary that all of the Allen factors weigh in favor of piercing the corporate veil; instead, it is only necessary that the equities substantially favor the party requesting the court to disregard the corporate status.
Document Preview: LITIGATION - Evidence. Trial court did not abuse its discretion in finding borrower's general ledger qualified as a business record excepted from the hearsay rule.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: A.P.I., Inc. Asbestos Settlement Trust v. Home Ins. Co.
Court: United States District Court, D. Minnesota.
Headnote: Under Minnesota law, relevant factors in considering whether corporation abused corporate form, thus warranting piercing of corporate veil, include: insufficient capitalization for purposes of corporate undertaking, failure to observe corporate formalities, nonpayment of dividends, insolvency of debtor corporation at time of transaction in question, siphoning of funds by dominant shareholder, nonfunctioning of other officers and directors, absence of corporate records, and existence of corporation as merely facade for individual dealings.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Parent corporation did not abuse corporate form by creating subsidiary to manage insurance company it had acquired.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: Mazza v. Verizon Washington DC, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, District of Columbia.
Headnote: To assess whether there is a unity of interest and ownership, for purposes of alter ego test, the court may consider the following factors: (1) the nature of the corporate ownership and control; (2) failure to maintain corporate minutes or records; (3) failure to maintain corporate formalities; (4) commingling of funds and assets; (5) diversion of one corporation's funds to the other's uses; and (6) use of the same office or business location.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW - Debt Collection. Allegations were sufficient to state a claim of a pattern of abusive collection strategies in violation of FDCPA.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: Ziese & Sons Excavating, Inc. v. Boyer Const. Corp.
Court: Court of Appeals of Indiana.
Headnote: In determining whether the party seeking to pierce the corporate veil has met its burden of proof, the court considers the following factors: (1) undercapitalization, (2) absence of corporate records, (3) fraudulent representation by corporation shareholders or directors, (4) use of the corporation to promote fraud, injustice, or illegal activities, (5) payment by the corporation of individual obligations, (6) commingling of assets and affairs, (7) failure to observe required corporate formalities, and (8) other shareholder acts or conduct ignoring, controlling, or manipulating the corporate form.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Whether construction group was corporation's alter ego precluded summary judgment on claim to pierce the corporate veil.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: Wachovia Securities, LLC v. Banco Panamericano, Inc.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Seventh Circuit.
Headnote: Under Illinois law, no single factor is determinative of whether a unity of interest and ownership exists, as required to pierce the corporate veil.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. District court did not clearly err in finding adherence to separate identities of corporation and insiders would sanction fraud.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: Best Cartage, Inc. v. Stonewall Packaging, LLC
Court: Court of Appeals of North Carolina.
Headnote: Some factors to consider under the instrumentality rule for piercing the corporate veil are inadequate capitalization, non-compliance with corporate formalities, complete domination and control of the corporation so no independent identity exists, and excessive fragmentation.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Partnerships. Trucking company sufficiently alleged partnership between paper company and cardboard manufacturer which signed contract.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: CBR Event Decorators, Inc. v. Gates
Court: Court of Appeals of Indiana.
Headnote: Indiana courts considering piercing the corporate veil consider whether the party seeking to pierce has presented evidence showing (1) undercapitalization, (2) absence of corporate records, (3) fraudulent representation by corporation shareholders or directors, (4) use of the corporation to promote fraud, injustice, or illegal activities, (5) payment by the corporation of individual obligations, (6) commingling of assets and affairs, (7) failure to observe required corporate formalities, or (8) other shareholder acts or conduct ignoring, controlling, or manipulating the corporate form; this list is not exhaustive in that not all factors must be shown to support a determination that the corporate veil should be pierced.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Lack of causal connection between misuse of corporate form and alleged fraud or injustice precluded shareholder liability.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: Restaurant of Hattiesburg, LLC v. Hotel & Restaurant Supply, Inc.
Court: Court of Appeals of Mississippi.
Headnote: For a court to disregard the corporate entity and expose shareholders to liability, the complaining party must show: (1) some frustration of contractual expectations regarding the party to whom he looked for performance, (2) the flagrant disregard of corporate formalities by the defendant corporation and its principals, and (3) a demonstration of fraud or other equivalent misfeasance on the part of the corporate shareholder.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Limited Liability Companies. Genuine issues of material fact precluded attempt to pierce LLC veil and hold members liable.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: Brennan's Inc. v. Colbert
Court: Court of Appeal of Louisiana, Fourth Circuit.
Headnote: Factors to be considered when determining whether to apply the "alter ego doctrine," where the court may ignore the corporate fiction and find the shareholders personally liable for the debts of a corporation based on fraud or deceit practiced by the shareholder through the corporation, include, but are not limited to: (1) commingling of corporate and shareholder funds; (2) failure to following statutory formalities for incorporating and transacting corporate affairs; (3) undercapitalization; (4) failure to provide separate bank accounts and bookkeeping records; and (5) failure to hold regular shareholder and director meetings.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Law firm could not pierce the corporate veil and hold shareholders personally liable for the debts of the corporation.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: Brennan's Inc. v. Colbert
Court: Court of Appeal of Louisiana, Fourth Circuit.
Headnote: When a party seeks to pierce the corporate veil to find a shareholder personally liable for the debts of the corporation, the totality of the circumstances is determinative.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Law firm could not pierce the corporate veil and hold shareholders personally liable for the debts of the corporation.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: Inter-Tel Technologies, Inc. v. Linn Station Properties, LLC
Court: Supreme Court of Kentucky.
Headnote: When assessing the first element of piercing a corporate veil, i.e., domination of the corporation resulting in a loss of corporate separateness, courts should look beyond the five factors enumerated in White v. Winchester Land Development Corp., to a more expansive lists of factors, which include: (1) inadequate capitalization; (2) failure to issue stock; (3) failure to observe corporate formalities; (4) nonpayment of dividends; (5) insolvency of the debtor corporation; (6) nonfunctioning of the other officers or directors; (7) absence of corporate records; (8) commingling of funds; (9) diversion of assets from the corporation by or to a stockholder or other person or entity to the detriment of creditors; (10) failure to maintain arm's-length relationships among related entities; and (11) whether, in fact, the corporation is a mere facade for the operation of the dominant stockholders. KRS 271B.6–220(2).
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Actual fraud not required in order to pierce veil of tenant which was retail branch for parent and grandparent corporations.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: Martin v. Freeman
Court: Colorado Court of Appeals, Div. VII.
Headnote: In deciding whether to pierce the corporate veil, courts consider a variety of factors in determining alter ego status, including whether: (1) the entity is operated as a distinct business entity; (2) funds and assets are commingled; (3) adequate corporate records are maintained; (4) the nature and form of the entity's ownership and control facilitate insider misuse; (5) the business is thinly capitalized; (6) the entity is used as a mere shell; (7) legal formalities are disregarded; and (8) entity funds or assets are used for non-entity purposes.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. LLC's sale of its sole asset was an attempt to defeat creditor's rightful claim for purposes of piercing corporate veil.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: In re Zhang
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, S.D. Ohio, Western Division,
Headnote: Among factors considered by Ohio courts in deciding whether to disregard corporate identity on alter ego theory are: (1) grossly inadequate capitalization, (2) failure to observe corporate formalities, (3) insolvency of corporation when debt is incurred, (4) shareholders' holding themselves out as personally liable for certain corporate obligations, (5) diversion of funds or other property of company for personal use, (6) absence of corporate records, and (7) fact that corporation was mere facade for operations of dominant shareholder(s).
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Discharge. Hiding of funds in undisclosed corporate account warranted denial of debtor's discharge.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: McCloud v. Bettcher Industries, Inc.
Court: Supreme Court, Appellate Division, Fourth Department, New York.
Headnote: Factors to be considered in determining whether a parent company has abused privilege of doing business in the corporate form, so as to allow corporate veil to be pierced in tort action, include whether there was a failure to adhere to corporate formalities, inadequate capitalization, commingling of assets, and use of corporate funds for personal use.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. There was no evidence of control or dominion as required to support piercing corporate veil.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: Union Ins. Co. v. Hull & Co., Inc.
Court: United States District Court, S.D. Iowa, Central Division.
Headnote: Under Iowa law, burden is on the party seeking to pierce the corporate veil to show the exceptional circumstances required; factors that would support such a finding include (1) the corporation is undercapitalized; (2) it lacks separate books; (3) its finances are not kept separate from individual finances, or individual obligations are paid by the corporation; (4) the corporation is used to promote fraud or illegality; (5) corporate formalities are not followed; and (6) the corporation is a mere sham.
Document Preview: INSURANCE - Arbitration and Appraisal. Dispute between insurer and insurance agency did not fall within the scope of an arbitration provision.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: Smith v. Fusion Medical Spa, S.C./Synergy Institute
Court: United States District Court, N.D. Illinois, Eastern Division.
Headnote: In Illinois, there is sufficient unity of interest, for purposes of piercing corporate veil, when corporations (1) fail to maintain adequate corporate records or to comply with corporate formalities, (2) commingle funds or assets, (3) are undercapitalized, or (4) treat the assets of another as their own.
Document Preview: LABOR AND EMPLOYMENT - Discrimination. Aggregation of employees of two separately incorporated entities was not warranted for purposes of satisfying ADA's 15-employee threshold.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: Pan-American Products & Holdings, LLC v. R.T.G. Furniture Corp.
Court: United States District Court, M.D. North Carolina.
Headnote: Under North Carolina law, factors to examine during a determination of whether a defendant qualifies as an alter ego of another defendant, so as to pierce the corporate veil to establish personal jurisdiction, include inadequate capitalization, non-compliance with corporate formalities, complete dominion and control so that it has no independent identity, and excessive fragmentation of a single enterprise into separate corporations.
Document Preview: COPYRIGHTS - Art and Architecture. Furniture designer's breach of contract claim against furniture retailers was not preempted by Copyright Act.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: In re ClassicStar Mare Lease Litigation
Court: United States District Court, E.D. Kentucky, Central Division, at Lexington.
Headnote: Under Utah law, the corporate veil should be pierced only reluctantly and cautiously and then only where some combination of the following factors is present: (1) undercapitalization; (2) failure to observe formalities of corporate existence; (3) nonpayment or overpayment of dividends; (4) siphoning off of funds by the dominant shareholders; (5) where majority shareholders have guaranteed corporate liabilities in their individual capacities, and (6) where commingling of personal and corporate funds has occurred.
Document Preview: TORTS - RICO. Investment program constituted racketeering activity under Racketeer Influenced and Corrupt Organizations (RICO) Act.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: Canal Ins. Co. v. Montello, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, N.D. Oklahoma.
Headnote: Indiana law delineates eight guideposts courts may consider when determining whether to pierce the corporate veil, including (1) undercapitalization, (2) absence of corporate records, (3) fraudulent representation by corporation shareholders or directors, (4) use of the corporation to promote fraud, injustice, or illegal activities, (5) payment by the corporation or individual obligations, (6) commingling of assets and affairs, (7) failure to observe required corporate formalities, or (8) other shareholder acts or conduct ignoring, controlling, or manipulating the corporate form.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Insured stated a claim against insurer's owner for alter-ego liability under Indiana law.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: In re Thompson
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, S.D. Ohio, Eastern Division.
Headnote: To determine whether a company is an alter ego of an individual, Ohio courts consider such factors as: (1) grossly inadequate capitalization, (2) failure to observe corporate formalities, (3) insolvency of the debtor corporation at the time the debt is incurred, (4) shareholders holding themselves out as personally liable for certain corporate obligations, (5) diversion of funds or other company property for personal use, (6) absence of corporate records, (7) the fact that the corporation was a mere facade for the operations of the dominant shareholder(s), (8) whether there was commingling of business and personal finances, (9) whether separate books and records were kept, (10) whether the company had issued stock, and (11) whether there was misappropriation of company funds or property.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Discharge. Debt arising from purchase of car by debtors' company was not obtained through false pretenses, false representation, or actual fraud.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: In re Thompson
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, S.D. Ohio, Eastern Division.
Headnote: To decide whether a company is an alter ego of an individual, Ohio courts consider such factors as: (1) grossly inadequate capitalization, (2) failure to observe corporate formalities, (3) insolvency of the debtor corporation at the time the debt is incurred, (4) shareholders holding themselves out as personally liable for certain corporate obligations, (5) diversion of funds or other company property for personal use, (6) absence of corporate records, (7) the fact that the corporation was a mere facade for the operations of the dominant shareholder(s), (8) whether there was commingling of business and personal finances, (9) whether separate books and records were kept, (10) whether the company had issued stock, and (11) whether there was misappropriation of company funds or property.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Business Relationships. Creditor of company was not entitled to pierce corporate veil to hold company's owners liable for debt.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: Oliver v. Black Knight Asset Management, LLC
Court: United States District Court, District of Columbia.
Headnote: Under District of Columbia law, to determine whether there is such unity of interest and ownership that separate personalities of a corporation and an individual no longer exist, for purposes of piercing the corporate veil, court considers the degree to which formalities have been followed to maintain a separate corporate identity; factors that weigh in this determination include: (1) nature of corporate ownership and control; (2) failure to maintain adequate corporate records; (3) failure to maintain corporate formalities; (4) commingling of funds and corporate assets; (5) diversion of corporation's funds or assets; and (6) use of same office or business location by corporation and individual shareholders.
Document Preview: LABOR AND EMPLOYMENT - Benefit Plans. Terminated employee stated ERISA claim against her employer.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: In re Juve
Court: United States Bankruptcy Appellate Panel of the Eighth Circuit.
Headnote: Factors that Minnesota courts consider in deciding whether relationship between individual and corporate entity is sufficiently close for corporate veil to be pierced include: insufficient capitalization for purposes of corporate undertaking, failure to observe corporate formalities, nonpayment of dividends, insolvency of corporation at time of transaction in question, siphoning of funds by dominant shareholder, nonfunctioning of other officers and directors, absence of corporate records, and existence of corporation as mere facade for individual dealings.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Discharge. Fact issues as to whether that was debt and what portion was for money obtained by fraud barred summary judgment.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: Pope v. Heritage Communities, Inc.
Court: Court of Appeals of South Carolina.
Headnote: South Carolina employs a two prong test for piercing the corporate veil; the first prong analyzes the shareholder's relationship to the corporation by evaluating eight factors, and the second prong requires the plaintiff to demonstrate that fundamental unfairness would result from recognition of the corporate entity.
Document Preview: LITIGATION - Jury. Property development companies were not prejudiced by trial court's misstatement of law on negligence in instructing jury.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: Marino v. Grupo Mundial Tenedora, S.A.
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: Under Delaware Law, being a shell corporation does not alone suffice to pierce a corporate veil.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Limited Liability Companies. Minority member did not breach a fiduciary duty owed to managing directors by selling LLC at less than fair value.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: TAC-Critical Systems, Inc. v. Integrated Facility Systems, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, District of Columbia.
Headnote: Under District of Columbia law, the corporate veil-piercing doctrine requires (1) unity of ownership and interest between the entities, and (2) either use of the corporate form to perpetrate fraud or wrong, or other considerations of justice and equity justify it; a commonly referenced, though not exhaustive, list of factors for determining when veil-piercing is appropriate includes (1) whether corporate formalities have been disregarded, (2) whether corporate funds and assets have been extensively intermingled, (3) whether there is inadequate initial capitalization, and (4) whether there is fraudulent use of the corporation to protect an entity from the claims of creditors.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Whether corporate veil could be pierced to hold contractor's principal individually liable presented triable fact issues.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: Misik v. D'Arco
Court: Court of Appeal, Second District, Division 3, California.
