Headnote: Among the many factors to be considered in determining whether there is sufficient unity of interest and ownership to apply the alter ego doctrine are one individual's ownership of all stock in a corporation; use of the same office or business location; commingling of funds and other assets of the individual and the corporation; an individual holding out that he is personally liable for debts of the corporation; identical directors and officers; failure to maintain minutes or adequate corporate records; disregard of corporate formalities; absence of corporate assets and inadequate capitalization; and the use of a corporation as a mere shell, instrumentality or conduit for the business of an individual.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Lack of alter ego allegation in lawsuit did not preclude amendment of judgment to add alter ego judgment debtor.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: Misik v. D'Arco
Court: Court of Appeal, Second District, Division 3, California.
Headnote: No single factor is determinative, and instead a court must examine all the circumstances to determine whether to apply the alter ego doctrine to disregard the corporate entity.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Lack of alter ego allegation in lawsuit did not preclude amendment of judgment to add alter ego judgment debtor.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: In re Digital Music Antitrust Litigation
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: In determining whether to pierce the corporate veil under either New York or Delaware law, courts consider allegations of disregarding corporate formalities, siphoning or intermingling of funds, inadequate capitalization, or that the corporation is a mere sham acting for the shareholder, among others.
Document Preview: ANTITRUST - Pricing. Purchasers of CDs failed to establish standing to bring Sherman Act claims alleging price fixing of online music.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: Doe v. U.S.
Court: United States District Court, District of Columbia.
Headnote: A commonly referenced, though not exhaustive, list of factors for determining when veil-piercing is appropriate under District of Columbia law includes: (1) whether corporate formalities have been disregarded, (2) whether corporate funds and assets have been extensively intermingled, (3) inadequate initial capitalization, and (4) fraudulent use of the corporation to protect an entity from the claims of creditors.
Document Preview: LABOR AND EMPLOYMENT - Workers' Compensation. Scientist's tort claims arising from exposure to mad-cow disease were barred by District of Columbia's Workers' Compensation Act.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: State ex rel. DeWine v. S & R Recycling, Inc.
Court: Court of Appeals of Ohio, Seventh District, Columbiana County.
Headnote: When determining whether a shareholder's control over a corporation is so complete that the corporation has no separate mind, will, or existence of its own, as required to pierce the corporate veil, court considers factors including (1) the failure to observe corporate formalities, (2) shareholders holding themselves out as personally liable for certain corporate obligations, (3) diversion of funds or other property of the company for personal use, (4) absence of corporate records, and (5) the fact that the corporation was a mere facade for the operations of the dominant shareholders.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Jurisdiction. Trial court lacked personal jurisdiction over corporation's principals under long-arm statute.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: American Nat. Property and Cas. Co. v. Campbell Ins., Inc.
Court: United States District Court, M.D. Tennessee, Nashville Division.
Headnote: When analyzing whether to pierce the corporate veil under Tennessee law, courts examine the following factors, although it is not necessary that all factors weigh in favor of piercing the corporate veil: (1) whether there was a failure to collect paid in capital; (2) whether the corporation was grossly undercapitalized; (3) the nonissuance of stock certificates; (4) the sole ownership of stock by one individual; (5) the use of the same office or business location; (6) the employment of the same employees or attorneys; (7) the use of the corporation as an instrumentality or business conduit for an individual or another corporation; (8) the diversion of corporate assets by or to a stockholder or other entity to the detriment of creditors, or the manipulation of assets and liabilities in another; (9) the use of the corporation as a subterfuge in illegal transactions; (10) the formation and use of the corporation to transfer to it the existing liability of another person or entity; and (11) the failure to maintain arms length relationships among related entities.
Document Preview: INSURANCE - Agents and Brokers. Stockholder who transferred her interest in insurance agency before she began competing against insurer did not breach agency contract.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: Martin v. Spring Break 83 Production, LLC
Court: United States District Court, E.D. Louisiana.
Headnote: Under Louisiana law, when a court considers whether one party functions as the alter ego of another, the court must consider the totality of the circumstances.
Document Preview: LABOR AND EMPLOYMENT - Hours and Wages. Nonsignatory film producer and its individual employees were not employers under the FLSA.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: In re American Remanufacturers, Inc.
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, D. Delaware.
Headnote: In deciding whether to disregard corporate distinctions, courts consider such factors as the corporation's failure to observe formalities, the non-functioning of officers and directors, an absence of corporate records, and whether the corporation is merely a facade for the shareholder's operations.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Claims. Corporate debtors had to be treated as single entity for purposes of retailers' defenses against common claim for payment.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: In re Arnette
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, N.D. Texas, Dallas Division.
Headnote: As proof of alter ego, court deciding claim to pierce the corporate veil under Texas law may consider (1) the payment of alleged corporate debts with personal checks or other commingling of funds, (2) representations that the individual will financially back the corporation, (3) the diversion of company profits to the individual for his personal use, (4) inadequate capitalization, and (5) other failure to keep corporate and personal assets separate.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Discharge. Debtor's personal liability for fraud committed against investor by his companies fell within fraud discharge exception.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: Crithfield v. Boothe
Court: Court of Appeals of Texas, Dallas.
Headnote: The types of evidence a court will consider as proof of alter ego, as would support a finding of personal jurisdiction over an individual director of a corporation, include: (1) the payment of alleged corporate debt with personal checks or other commingling of funds; (2) representations that the individual will financially back the corporation; (3) the diversion of company profits to the individual for his personal use; (4) inadequate capitalization; and (5) other failure to keep corporate and personal assets separate.
Document Preview: LITIGATION - Jurisdiction. Purported mineral interest owners pled jurisdictional facts to bring holding company director within Texas long-arm statute.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: In re Pace
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, W.D. Texas, San Antonio Division.
Headnote: In examining whether a corporation is merely the alter ego of its shareholder, courts look to the total dealings between the corporation and the shareholder, including the degree to which corporate formalities have been maintained, whether corporate and individual assets have been kept separately, the financial interests, ownership, and control the shareholder maintains over the corporation, and whether the corporation has been used for personal purposes.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Avoidance. Chapter 7 trustee could recover condominium unit, or its value, from both attorney and his LLC as initial transferees.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: In re Expert South Tulsa, LLC
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, D. Kansas.
Headnote: One who seeks to disregard the corporate veil under Oklahoma law must show that the corporate form was abused to the injury of a third party; however, fraud is not a necessary element.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY  Debtor Protections. Postpetition actions taken against debtor's principals in state court violated automatic stay, and were void.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: Leek v. Cooper
Court: Court of Appeal, Third District, California.
Headnote: No single factor is determinative when considering alter ego liability, and the result depends on the circumstances of each particular case.
Document Preview: LABOR AND EMPLOYMENT - Employer's Liability. Corporation's sole shareholder was not employees' employer for purposes of FEHA discrimination claims.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: In re Fields
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, D. Minnesota.
Headnote: Under Minnesota law, factors that would support a finding of identity between individual principal and corporation, so as to warrant piercing the corporate veil, include (1) insufficient capitalization, (2) failure to observe corporate formalities, (3) nonpayment of dividends, (4) insolvency of debtor corporation, and (5) siphoning of corporation as a mere facade for individual dealings; in addition, there must be an element of injustice or a fundamental unfairness that would result from honoring the nominal separateness of the corporation.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Claims. Debtor, as borrower's principal, was not directly liable for obligation to lender.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: Ruffin v. New Destination, LLC
Court: United States District Court, District of Columbia.
Headnote: Under District of Columbia law, when determining whether to pierce the corporate veil, although no single factor controls, courts generally inquire, inter alia, whether corporate formalities have been observed, whether there has been commingling of corporate and shareholder funds, staff and property, whether a single shareholder dominates the corporation, whether the corporation is adequately capitalized, and, especially, whether the corporate form has been used to effectuate a fraud.
Document Preview: LABOR AND EMPLOYMENT - Contracts. Under District of Columbia law, company that provided counseling services breached its contracts with social worker and counselor.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: Antkowiak v. TaxMasters
Court: United States District Court, E.D. Pennsylvania.
Headnote: To disregard the corporate form, Pennsylvania courts consider the following factors: (1) undercapitalization; (2) failure to adhere to corporate formalities; (3) substantial intermingling of corporate and personal affairs; and (4) use of the corporate form to perpetrate a fraud.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW - Debt Collection. Consumer sufficiently stated claims under provisions of Fair Debt Collection Practices Act (FDCPA).

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: Wilson v. Thorn Energy, LLC
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: Under Delaware law, court's analysis of a veil-piercing claim should begin with an examination of factors which reveal how the corporation operates and the particular defendant's relationship to that operation, including: (1) whether corporation was solvent; (2) whether dividends were paid, corporate records kept, officers and directors functioned properly, and other corporate formalities were observed; (3) whether dominant shareholder siphoned corporate funds; and (4) whether, in general, corporation simply functioned as a facade for dominant shareholder.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Fraud. Issues of material fact precluded summary judgment on fraud and veil piercing claims against energy company.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: In re Teleservices Group, Inc.
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, W.D. Michigan.
Headnote: In certain circumstances, corporation may be charged with knowledge possessed by its employees even though responsible decision-maker is not actually aware of all of the facts required to come to pertinent conclusion.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Avoidance. Subjective standard determined good faith of recipient of alleged fraudulent transfers.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: In re Teleservices Group, Inc.
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, W.D. Michigan.
Headnote: While it may not be fair to charge corporation with perfect knowledge of everything known by its constituent parts, neither can corporation feign ignorance when it has delegated responsibilities to group of individuals and an inexcusable breakdown of communication then occurs within that group.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Avoidance. Subjective standard determined good faith of recipient of alleged fraudulent transfers.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: In re Living Hope Southwest Medical SVCS, LLC
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, W.D. Arkansas, Texarkana Division.
Headnote: Among the factors tending to show domination and control required for piercing of the corporate veil under New York law are the absence of corporate formalities, inadequate capitalization, use of corporate funds for personal rather than corporate purpose, and the payment or guarantee of debts of the corporation by the owners or by another related corporation.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Avoidance. Retroactive approval of ad hoc bridge loans made by lender postpetition was not warranted.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: Alki Partners, L.P. v. Vatas Holding GmbH
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: Under New York law, factors court considers in determining whether to pierce corporate veil include: corporate organizational and structural factors such as the failure to adhere to corporate formalities, undercapitalization, intermingling of funds, overlap in ownership, staff and directorship, common use of office space, degree of discretion shown by wrongdoer, whether dealings between entities are at arms' length, and whether corporations are treated as independent profit centers.
Document Preview: SECURITIES REGULATION - Jurisdiction. Court had personal jurisdiction over Swiss broker.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: Salkin v. United Services Auto. Ass'n
Court: United States District Court, C.D. California.
Headnote: Under California law, to apply alter ego doctrine, there must be: (1) such unity of interest and ownership between corporation and its equitable owner that separate personalities do not in reality exist, and (2) there must be inequitable result if acts in question are treated as those of corporation alone.
Document Preview: LITIGATION - Removal. Life insurer's parent company was fraudulently joined to defeat removal based on diversity.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: Thorkelson v. Publishing House of Evangelical Lutheran Church in America
Court: United States District Court, D. Minnesota.
Headnote: Under Minnesota law, piercing the corporate veil requires (1) analyzing reality of how corporation functioned and the defendant's relationship to that operation, and (2) finding injustice or fundamental unfairness.
Document Preview: LABOR AND EMPLOYMENT - Benefit Plans. Single employer defined benefit pension plan was church plan exempt from Employee Retirement Income Security Act.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: Thorkelson v. Publishing House of Evangelical Lutheran Church in America
Court: United States District Court, D. Minnesota.
Headnote: Under Minnesota law, factors considered significant in determination of whether one corporation can be held liable for another entity's wrongdoing include insufficient capitalization for purposes of corporate undertaking, failure to observe corporate formalities, nonpayment of dividends, insolvency of debtor corporation at time of transaction in question, siphoning of funds by dominant shareholder, nonfunctioning of other officers and directors, absence of corporate records, and existence of corporation as merely facade for individual dealings; next, court must consider whether there is showing of injustice or fundamental unfairness.
Document Preview: LABOR AND EMPLOYMENT - Benefit Plans. Single employer defined benefit pension plan was church plan exempt from Employee Retirement Income Security Act.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: Bottom Line Equipment, L.L.C. v. BZ Equipment, L.L.C.
Court: Court of Appeal of Louisiana, Fifth Circuit.
Headnote: When a party seeks to pierce the corporate veil, the totality of the circumstances is determinative.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Limited Liability Companies. Evidence was insufficient to support lessor's claim that managing member of LLC engaged in fraud or deceit in an attempt to defraud creditors.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: In re Wolverine, Proctor & Schwartz, LLC
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, D. Massachusetts.
Headnote: Under Delaware law, numerous factors are important to alter ego analysis, including whether corporation was adequately capitalized for the corporate undertaking, whether corporation was solvent, whether dividends were paid, corporate records kept, officers and directors functioned properly, and other corporate formalities were observed, whether dominant shareholder siphoned corporate funds, and whether, in general, corporation simply functioned as a facade for dominant shareholder. 11 U.S.C.A. § 510(c).
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Claims. Secured creditor's $1.9 million loan would not be recharacterized as equity.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: Shaoxing County Huayue Import & Export v. Bhaumik
Court: Court of Appeal, Second District, Division 5, California.
Headnote: The circumstances of an individual case determine whether the court will pierce the corporate veil and regard the corporation as the alter ego of its shareholders.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Claims. Alter ego allegations did not become the property of the bankruptcy estate once corporate debtor filed for bankruptcy.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: Automotive Finance Corp. v. Joliet Motors, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, N.D. Illinois, Eastern Division.
Headnote: To determine whether a unity of interest exists, for purposes of piercing the corporate veil under Illinois law, court may consider numerous nondispositive factors, including: (1) inadequate capitalization; (2) failure to issue stock; (3) failure to observe corporate formalities; (4) nonpayment of dividends; (5) insolvency of the debtor corporation; (6) nonfunctioning of the other officers or directors; (7) absence of corporate records; (8) commingling of funds; (9) diversion of assets from the corporation by or to a stockholder or other person or entity to the detriment of creditors; (10) failure to maintain arm's-length relationships among related entities; and (11) whether, in fact, the corporation is a mere facade for the operation of the dominant stockholders.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Piercing of dealership's corporate veil to hold its sole owner personally liable for judgment obtained against dealership was warranted.

Headnote: There is no litmus test to determine when the corporate veil will be pierced; rather the result will depend on the circumstances of each particular case.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: Greenspan v. LADT, LLC
Court: Court of Appeal, Second District, Division 1, California.
Headnote: The alter ego test encompasses a host of factors, including: (1) commingling of funds and other assets, failure to segregate funds of the separate entities, and the unauthorized diversion of corporate funds or assets to other than corporate uses, (2) the treatment by an individual of the assets of the corporation as his own, (3) the failure to obtain authority to issue stock or to subscribe to or issue the same, (4) the holding out by an individual that he is personally liable for the debts of the corporation, the failure to maintain minutes or adequate corporate records, and the confusion of the records of the separate entities, (5) the identical equitable ownership in the two entities, the identification of the equitable owners thereof with the domination and control of the two entities, identification of the directors and officers of the two entities in the responsible supervision and management, sole ownership of all of the stock in a corporation by one individual or the members of a family, (6) the use of the same office or business location, the employment of the same employees and/or attorney, (7) the failure to adequately capitalize a corporation, the total absence of corporate assets, and undercapitalization, (8) the use of a corporation as a mere shell, instrumentality or conduit for a single venture or the business of an individual or another corporation, (9) the concealment and misrepresentation of the identity of the responsible ownership, management and financial interest, or concealment of personal business activities, (10) the disregard of legal formalities and the failure to maintain arm's length relationships among related entities, (11) the use of the corporate entity to procure labor, services or merchandise for another person or entity, (12) the diversion of assets from a corporation by or to a stockholder or other person or entity, to the detriment of creditors, or the manipulation of assets and liabilities between entities so as to concentrate the assets in one and the liabilities in another, (13) the contracting with another with intent to avoid performance by use of a corporate entity as a shield against personal liability, or the use of a corporation as a subterfuge of illegal transactions, and (14) and the formation and use of a corporation to transfer to it the existing liability of another person or entity.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Limited Liability Companies. Res judicata did not prohibit amendment of judgment to add debtor, under alter ego theory, who was successful in underlying arbitration.

Headnote: No single factor is determinative under the alter ego test, and instead a court must examine all the circumstances to determine whether to apply the doctrine.

Title: Sykes v. Mel Harris and Associates, LLC

Headnote: Under Delaware law, to pierce corporate veil, plaintiff must show: (1) that business entity and its owner operated as single economic entity, and (2) overall element of injustice or unfairness.
Document Preview: TORTS - RICO. Consumers alleged that debt-buying company, debt collection agency, and process service company engaged in RICO enterprise.

Title: Colon v. Blades
Court: United States District Court, D. Puerto Rico.
Headnote: Factors considered for piercing corporate veil under Puerto Rico law include under-capitalization, non-payment of dividends, non-functioning officers and directors, failure to observe corporate formalities, absence of corporate records, commingling of funds, and use of corporate funds for non-corporate purposes.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: CAO Holdings, Inc. v. Trost
Court: Supreme Court of Tennessee, at Nashville.
Headnote: In analyzing whether a corporation's separate legal identity should be ignored, it is not necessary that all factors weigh in favor of piercing the corporate veil; but, it is necessary that the equities substantially favor the party requesting the court to disregard the corporate status.
Document Preview: TAXATION - Judgment. Genuine issue of material fact as to whether corporate jet was used exclusively for renting or leasing precluded summary judgment.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: In re Jamuna Real Estate, LLC
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, E.D. Pennsylvania.
Headnote: Under Pennsylvania law, the factors considered when deciding whether to pierce the corporate veil are: (1) insufficient capitalization, (2) intermingling of funds, (3) non-functioning officers and directors, (4) absence of corporate formalities, (5) failure to pay dividends, and (6) outward representation of sole proprietorship as opposed to incorporation.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Business Relationships. Complaint failed to state veil-piercing claim against wife of debtors' principal.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: In re Schwarzkopf
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Ninth Circuit.
Headnote: Factors suggesting an alter ego relationship under California law include commingling of funds and other assets and failure to segregate funds of the separate entities; treatment by an individual of the assets of the corporation as his own; disregard of legal formalities and the failure to maintain arm's length relationships among related entities; and diversion of assets from a corporation by or to a stockholder or other person or entity, to the detriment of creditors, or the manipulation of assets between entities so as to concentrate the assets in one and the liabilities in another.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Bankruptcy Estate. Chapter 7 debtor was equitable owner of trust.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: Prasad v. Bullard
Court: Court of Appeal of Louisiana, Fifth Circuit.
Headnote: When a party seeks to pierce the corporate veil, the totality of the circumstances is determinative, and there are five non-exclusive factors to be used in determining whether to apply the alter ego doctrine: (1) commingling of corporate and shareholder funds; (2) failure to follow statutory formalities for incorporating and transacting corporate affairs; (3) undercapitalization; (4) failure to provide separate bank accounts and bookkeeping records; and, (5) failure to hold regular shareholder and director meetings.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW - Arbitration. Client's allegations were insufficient to pierce corporate veil and compel contractor's sole member to submit to arbitration under agreement between client and contractor.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Headnote: Evidence relevant to prove an alter ego theory includes: (1) payment of alleged business debts with personal funds or other commingling of funds; (2) representations that the individual will financially back the business entity; (3) diversion of profits for the individual's personal use; (4) inadequate capitalization; and (5) other failures to keep business and personal assets separate.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Headnote: A showing that an individual is an officer, director, or majority owner of the ownership interest is insufficient to support a finding of alter ego.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: Genssler v. Harris County
Court: Court of Appeals of Texas, Houston (1st Dist.).
Headnote: Evidence relevant to proving an alter ego theory, whereby an individual may be held liable for a business entity, includes: (1) payment of alleged business debts with personal funds or other commingling of funds, (2) representations that the individual will financially back the business entity, (3) diversion of profits for the individual's personal use, (4) inadequate capitalization, and (5) other failures to keep business and personal assets separate.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Officers and Directors. Evidence did not support holding director of individually liable as the alter ego of businesses.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: Genssler v. Harris County
Court: Court of Appeals of Texas, Houston (1st Dist.).
Headnote: A showing that an individual is an officer, director, or majority owner of the ownership interest is insufficient to support a finding of alter ego, an exception to the general rule that a business entity exists as a separate legal entity, whereby an individual may be held liable for the business entity.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Officers and Directors. Evidence did not support holding director of individually liable as the alter ego of businesses.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: In re Broadstripe, LLC
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, D. Delaware.
Headnote: Third Circuit uses the following multi-factor test for determining whether a "single economic entity" exists between entities: (1) undercapitalization, (2) failure to observe corporate formalities, (3) nonpayment of dividends, (4) the insolvency of the debtor corporation at the time, (5) siphoning of the corporation's funds by the dominant stockholder, (6) absence of corporate records, and (7) the fact that the corporation is merely a facade for the operations of the dominant stockholder or stockholders.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Claims. Summary judgment was not warranted in committee's action for equitable subordination.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: In re Broadstripe, LLC
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, D. Delaware.
Headnote: While no single factor justifies a decision to disregard the corporate entity, some combination of the pertinent factors is required, and an overall element of injustice or unfairness must always be present, as well.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Claims. Summary judgment was not warranted in committee's action for equitable subordination.

Title: In re Yellowstone Mountain Club, LLC
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, D. Montana.
Headnote: In Montana, no concrete formula exists under which a court will disregard the separate identity of the corporate entity.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: In re Yellowstone Mountain Club, LLC
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, D. Montana.
Headnote: Under Montana law, the factors relevant to a finding of alter ego include, but are not limited to, whether: (1) the individual is in a position of control or authority over the business entity, (2) the individual controls the entity's actions without need to consult others, (3) the individual uses the entity to shield himself from personal liability, (4) the individual uses the entity for his or her own financial benefit, (5) the individual mingles his own affairs in the affairs of the entity, and (6) the individual uses the entity to assume his own debts, or the debts of another, or uses his own funds to pay the entity's debts.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Claims. Co-founder's prepetition removal of $209 million from debtors was a distribution, not a loan.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: Zimmerman v. Puccio
Court: United States Court of Appeals, First Circuit.
Headnote: Under Massachusetts law, factors relevant to corporate veil-piercing analysis are: (1) common ownership; (2) pervasive control; (3) confused intermingling of business assets; (4) thin capitalization; (5) nonobservance of corporate formalities; (6) absence of corporate records; (7) no payment of dividends; (8) insolvency at the time of the litigated transaction; (9) siphoning away of corporation's funds by dominant shareholder; (10) nonfunctioning of officers and directors; (11) use of the corporation for transactions of the dominant shareholders; and (12) use of the corporation in promoting fraud.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW - Consumer Protection. Credit counseling agency was credit repair organizations within meaning of Credit Repair Organizations Act (CROA).

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: Macquarie Bank Ltd. v. Knickel
Court: United States District Court, D. North Dakota, Northwestern Division.
Headnote: Factors considered when determining whether to pierce the corporate veil under North Dakota law are: (1) insufficient capitalization for the purposes of the corporate undertaking, failure to observe corporate formalities, (2) nonpayment of dividends, insolvency of the debtor corporation at the time of the transaction in question, (3) siphoning of funds by the dominant shareholder, nonfunctioning of other officers and directors, (4) absence of corporate records, and (5) the existence of the corporation as merely a facade for individual dealings.
Document Preview: FINANCE AND BANKING - Loans. Bank had a duty to keep confidential trade secret information provided by borrowers.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: Macquarie Bank Ltd. v. Knickel
Court: United States District Court, D. North Dakota, Northwestern Division.
Headnote: Evidence was not sufficient under North Dakota law to pierce the corporate veils of borrowers and their affiliate; record was devoid of any evidence that companies were undercapitalized, that companies failed to observe corporate formalities, failed to pay dividends, or were insolvent, that principal owner siphoned funds from the companies, that the officers and directors of companies were nonfunctioning, of the absence of corporate records, and there was no evidence that it would be unjust, inequitable, or fundamentally unfair to not hold owner personally liable for the conduct of companies.
Document Preview: FINANCE AND BANKING - Loans. Bank had a duty to keep confidential trade secret information provided by borrowers.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: LDT Keller Farms, LLC v. Brigitte Holmes Livestock Co., Inc.
Court: United States District Court, N.D. Indiana, Fort Wayne Division.
Headnote: To determine if the party seeking to pierce the corporate veil has met its burden, Indiana courts consider whether the party has presented evidence showing: (1) undercapitalization; (2) absence of corporate records; (3) fraudulent representation by corporation shareholders or directors; (4) use of the corporation to promote fraud, injustice, or illegal activities; (5) payment by the corporation of individual obligations; (6) commingling of assets and affairs; (7) failure to observe required corporate formalities; or (8) other shareholder acts or conduct ignoring, controlling, or manipulating the corporate form.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW - Warranties. Livestock dealer did not disclaim implied warranty of fitness for particular purpose in contract for sale of certain calves.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: Greenspan v. LADT, LLC
Court: Court of Appeal, Second District, Division 1, California.
Headnote: What the alter ego formula comes down to, once shorn of verbiage about control, instrumentality, agency, and corporate entity, is that liability is imposed to reach an equitable result.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW - Arbitration. Investor's lawsuit against arbitrator did not disqualify arbitrator from presiding over breach of contract dispute.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: Zoran Corp. v. Chen
Court: Court of Appeal, Sixth District, California.
Headnote: The conditions under which the corporate entity may be disregarded, or the corporation be regarded as the alter ego of the stockholders, necessarily vary according to the circumstances in each case inasmuch as the doctrine is essentially an equitable one and for that reason is particularly within the province of the trial court.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Fact issues existed as to whether corporations were individual's alter egos.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: Zoran Corp. v. Chen
Court: Court of Appeal, Sixth District, California.
Headnote: The following factors, among others, are encompassed in the test to determine whether a corporation may be regarded as the alter ego of an individual: commingling of funds and other assets, failure to segregate funds of the separate entities, and the unauthorized diversion of corporate funds or assets to other than corporate uses; the treatment by an individual of the assets of the corporation as his own; the failure to obtain authority to issue stock or to subscribe to or issue the same; the holding out by an individual that he is personally liable for the debts of the corporation; the failure to maintain minutes or adequate corporate records, and the confusion of the records of the separate entities; the identical equitable ownership in the two entities; the identification of the equitable owners thereof with the domination and control of the two entities; identification of the directors and officers of the two entities in the responsible supervision and management; sole ownership of all of the stock in a corporation by one individual or the members of a family; the use of the same office or business location; the employment of the same employees and/or attorney; the failure to adequately capitalize a corporation; the total absence of corporate assets, and undercapitalization; the use of a corporation as a mere shell, instrumentality or conduit for a single venture or the business of an individual or another corporation; the concealment and misrepresentation of the identity of the responsible ownership, management and financial interest, or concealment of personal business activities; the disregard of legal formalities and the failure to maintain arm's length relationships among related entities; the use of the corporate entity to procure labor, services or merchandise for another person or entity; the diversion of assets from a corporation by or to a stockholder or other person or entity, to the detriment of creditors, or the manipulation of assets and liabilities between entities so as to concentrate the assets in one and the liabilities in another; the contracting with another with intent to avoid performance by use of a corporate entity as a shield against personal liability, or the use of a corporation as a subterfuge of illegal transactions; and the formation and use of a corporation to transfer to it the existing liability of another person or entity.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Fact issues existed as to whether corporations were individual's alter egos.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: Zoran Corp. v. Chen
Court: Court of Appeal, Sixth District, California.
Headnote: In determining whether a corporation may be regarded as the alter ego of an individual, no single factor is determinative, and instead a court must examine all the circumstances.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Fact issues existed as to whether corporations were individual's alter egos.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: New Orleans Jazz and Heritage Foundation, Inc. v. Kirksey
Court: Court of Appeal of Louisiana, Fourth Circuit.
Headnote: To pierce the corporate veil or find that a corporation is an alter ego of an individual, the courts traditionally look to five factors that, when considered with the totality of the evidence, indicate that the individual and the corporation were not separate entities: (1) commingling of corporate and shareholder funds; (2) failure to follow statutory formalities required for incorporation and for the transaction of corporate affairs; (3) undercapitalization; (4) failure to provide separate bank accounts and bookkeeping records; and, (5) failure to hold regular shareholder or director meetings.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW - Contracts. Music sponsor's agent had no fiduciary duty in failing to disclose his own company's contract with third party.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: Charter Services, Inc. v. DL Air, LLC
Court: United States District Court, S.D. Alabama, Southern Division.
Headnote: Under Delaware law, the alter ego analysis entails a fact intensive inquiry in which courts may consider the following factors, none of which are dominant: (1) whether the company was adequately capitalized for the undertaking; (2) whether the company was solvent; (3) whether corporate formalities were observed; (4) whether the controlling shareholder siphoned company funds; and (5) whether, in general, the company simply functioned as a facade for the controlling shareholder.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Evidence was insufficient, under Delaware law, to support piercing corporate veil.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: Jones & Trevor Marketing, Inc. v. Lowry
Court: Court of Appeals of Utah.
Headnote: Significant factors considered by court under the "formalities requirement" prong of alter ego claim are: (1) undercapitalization of a one-man corporation; (2) failure to observe corporate formalities; (3) nonpayment of dividends; (4) siphoning of corporate funds by the dominant stockholder; (5) nonfunctioning of other officers or directors; (6) absence of corporate records; (7) the use of the corporation as a facade for operations of the dominant stockholder or stockholders; and (8) the use of the corporate entity in promoting injustice or fraud.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Two sole shareholders and officers of corporation did not use corporation as facade.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: In re Jarvar
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, D. Montana.
Headnote: Under Montana law, factors relevant to a finding of alter ego include, but are not limited to, the following: (1) whether the individual is in a position of control or authority over the entity, (2) whether the individual controls the entity's actions without need to consult others, (3) whether the individual uses the entities to shield himself from personal liability, (4) whether the individual uses the business entity for his or her own financial benefit, (5) whether the individual mingles his own affairs in the affairs of the business entity, and (6) whether the individual uses the business entity to assume his own debts, or the debts of another, or whether the individual uses his own funds to pay the business entity's debts.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Judgment. Collateral estoppel did not apply under Montana law to preclude debtor's state-law consumer protection claims.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: A.P.I., Inc. v. Home Ins. Co.
Court: United States District Court, D. Minnesota.
Headnote: In determining whether, under Minnesota law, formalities of corporate existence should be disregarded by one seeking to use the corporate form, court considers various case-specific factors to determine whether the corporation maintains a sufficiently separate corporate identity and then evaluates whether there is an element or injustice of fundamental unfairness.
Document Preview: INSURANCE - Insolvent Insurers. Comity dictated declination of jurisdiction over insured's tortious interference claims against successor of insolvent insurer.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: In re Logistics Information Systems, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, D. Massachusetts.
Headnote: Twelve factors that Massachusetts courts consider in deciding whether to pierce the corporate veil are as follows: (1) common ownership; (2) pervasive control; (3) confused intermingling of business activity, assets or management; (4) thin capitalization; (5) nonobservance of corporate formalities; (6) absence of corporate records; (7) no payment of dividends; (8) insolvency at the time of the litigated transaction; (9) siphoning away of corporate assets by dominant shareholders; (10) nonfunctioning of officers and directors; (11) use of corporation for transactions of dominant shareholders; and (12) use of corporation in promoting fraud.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Avoidance. State law governed evidentiary issue in strong-arm avoidance proceeding.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: Naples v. Keystone Bldg. and Development Corp.
Court: Supreme Court of Connecticut.
Headnote: Courts, in assessing whether an entity is dominated or controlled, for purposes of piercing the corporate veil, consider a number of factors, including: (1) the absence of corporate formalities; (2) inadequate capitalization; (3) whether funds are put in and taken out of the corporation for personal rather than corporate purposes; (4) overlapping ownership, officers, directors, personnel; (5) common office space, address, phones; (6) the amount of business discretion by the allegedly dominated corporation; (7) whether the corporations dealt with each other at arm's length; (8) whether the corporations are treated as independent profit centers; (9) payment or guarantee of debts of the dominated corporation; and (10) whether the corporation in question had property that was used by other of the corporations as if it were its own.
Document Preview: REAL PROPERTY - Vendor and Purchaser. Amount of damages awarded to new home purchasers was clearly erroneous.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: Partners Coffee Co., LLC v. Oceana Services and Products Co.
Court: United States District Court, W.D. Pennsylvania.
Headnote: Under Pennsylvania law, when determining whether to pierce the corporate veil under the alter ego theory, the court considers: the failure to observe corporate formalities, non-payment of dividends, insolvency of the corporation, siphoning the funds from corporation by dominant shareholders, non-functioning of other officers and directors, absence of corporate records, whether the corporation is a mere facade for the operations of a common shareholder or shareholders, and gross undercapitalization.
Document Preview: TORTS - Fraud. Gist of the action doctrine did not bar fraud-in-the-inducement counterclaim.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: McWilliams Ballard, Inc. v. Level 2 Development
Court: United States District Court, District of Columbia.
Headnote: Factors for determining when to pierce the corporate veil under District of Columbia law include, inter alia, (1) whether corporate formalities have been disregarded, (2) whether corporate funds and assets have been extensively intermingled with personal assets, (3) inadequate initial capitalization, and (4) fraudulent use of the corporation to protect personal business from the claims of creditors.
Document Preview: REAL PROPERTY - Unjust Enrichment. Lender sufficiently alleged unjust enrichment claim arising from use of loan proceeds to purchase real property.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: Penhollow Custom Homes, LLC v. Kim
Court: Court of Appeals of Texas, El Paso.
Headnote: As proof of alter ego, a court considering piercing the corporate veil may consider: (1) the payment of alleged corporate debts with personal checks or other commingling of funds; (2) representations that the individual will financially back the corporation; (3) the diversion of company profits to the individual for his personal use; (4) inadequate capitalization; and (5) other failure to keep corporate and personal assets separate. V.T.C.A., Business Organizations Code § 21.223(a)(2).
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Evidence was not legally sufficient to find that owner of home building corporation was alter ego of corporation.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: Penhollow Custom Homes, LLC v. Kim
Court: Court of Appeals of Texas, El Paso.
Headnote: An individual's standing as an officer, director, or majority shareholder of an entity alone is insufficient to support a finding of alter ego necessary to pierce the corporate veil. V.T.C.A., Business Organizations Code § 21.223(a)(2).
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Evidence was not legally sufficient to find that owner of home building corporation was alter ego of corporation.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: In re Carlson
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, D. Idaho.
Headnote: Under Idaho law, among the factors that a court should consider when determining if a corporation and its individual owners have maintained separate personalities, for purposes of piercing the corporate veil, are whether: (1) the sole shareholder acted as president of the corporation, (2) there has been a lack of corporate formalities, such as directors' meetings, (3) the shareholder has failed to submit corporate contracts and inventory revisions to the board of directors, and (4) there have been transfers of funds, accrual and payment of accounts, and satisfaction of intercompany claims without approval by any director or officer of the corporation.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Discharge. Creditor did not justifiably rely on manager's misrepresentation concerning replacement of pick-up truck's converter.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: International Millennium Consultants, Inc. v. Taycom Business Solutions, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, E.D. Michigan, Southern Division.
Headnote: Under Michigan law, in determining whether to pierce the corporate veil, courts frequently consider specific factors such as undercapitalization of the corporation, the maintenance of separate books, the separation of corporate and individual finances, the use of the corporation to support fraud or illegality, the honoring of corporate formalities, and whether the corporation is merely a sham.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Company's corporate veil would be pierced on the ground that it was a mere instrumentality of its individual owners.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: Bona Fide Demolition and Recovery, LLC v. Crosby Const. Co. of Louisiana, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, E.D. Louisiana.
Headnote: Under Louisiana law, traditional veil piercing cases require consideration of four or five primary factors, and then an inquiry into the totality of the circumstances; single business enterprise (SBE) theory, on the other hand, uses an eighteen-factor test, in which no factor is dispositive, before considering the totality of the circumstances.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Parent and Subsidiary. Companies were single business enterprise (SBE) under Louisiana law for jurisdictional purposes.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: Bennett v. Itochu Intern., Inc.
Court: United States District Court, E.D. Pennsylvania.
Headnote: In determining whether to pierce corporate veil, Pennsylvania courts consider: (1) insufficient capitalization; (2) intermingling of funds; (3) other officers and directors not functioning; (4) failure to observe corporate formalities; and (5) failure to pay dividends.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW - Privileges. Privilege for communications pertinent to judicial proceedings under Pennsylvania law was applicable to defamation claim.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: Bear, Inc. v. Smith
Court: Court of Appeals of Kentucky.
Headnote: A party advocating that the corporate form be disregarded has the burden of establishing both an abuse of the form and a wrong; these elements must be assessed in light of the totality of circumstances, but generally the first element focuses on the relationship between the corporation and the owners or other corporate actors, while the second element concerns the relationship between the corporation and the plaintiff.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Dissolution and Survival. Company that operated fuel station had no affirmative duty to notify its creditors of dissolution.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: Bear, Inc. v. Smith
Court: Court of Appeals of Kentucky.
Headnote: Factors bearing on abuse of corporate form for purposes of piercing corporate veil include: (1) whether the corporation is inadequately capitalized; (2) whether the owners observe corporate formalities; (3) whether the corporation issues stock or pays dividends; (4) whether it operates without a profit; (5) whether there is a commingling of corporate and personal assets; (6) whether the owners use corporate assets as their own, or in general deal with the corporation at arms length; (7) whether there are non-functioning officers or directors; (8) whether the corporation is insolvent at the time of the transaction; (9) whether corporate records have been maintained; and (10) whether others pay or guarantee debts of the corporation.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Dissolution and Survival. Company that operated fuel station had no affirmative duty to notify its creditors of dissolution.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: Bear, Inc. v. Smith
Court: Court of Appeals of Kentucky.
Headnote: No single factor indicating abuse of corporate form for purposes of piercing corporate veil is dispositive.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Dissolution and Survival. Company that operated fuel station had no affirmative duty to notify its creditors of dissolution.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: MacDonald v. Summit Orthopedics, Ltd.
Court: United States District Court, D. Minnesota.
Headnote: Under the first prong of determining whether to pierce the corporate veil under Minnesota law, a court considers a number of factors in determining whether a corporation functioned as a mere instrumentality of the individuals sought to be held personally liable: (1) insufficient capitalization for purposes of corporate undertaking; (2) a failure to observe corporate formalities; (3) nonpayment of dividends; (4) insolvency of debtor corporation at time of transaction in question; (5) siphoning of funds by dominant shareholder; (6) nonfunctioning of other officers and directors; (7) absence of corporate records; and (7) existence of corporation as merely facade for individual dealings.
Document Preview: LABOR AND EMPLOYMENT - Benefit Plans. Issue of whether ERISA plan was top hat plan could not be resolved on motion to dismiss.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: In re England Motor Co.
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, N.D. Mississippi.
Headnote: Under Mississippi law, courts will not pierce the veil of a corporate entity unless the party seeking to treat the entities as a single enterprise demonstrates: (1) some frustration of expectations regarding the party to whom he looked for performance, (2) the flagrant disregard of corporate formalities by the principals of the corporation, and (3) some indication of fraud or other equivalent malfeasance by the corporate principals.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Claims. Substantive consolidation of parent company's case with those of its subsidiaries did not create setoff mutuality.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: Spagnola v. Chubb Corp.
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: To establish that relationship between shareholder and corporation is such that the corporation was not operated as a separate legal entity, as required to properly plead alter-ego liability under Minnesota or Indiana law, plaintiffs may rely upon several significant factors, including (1) insufficient capitalization for purposes of corporate undertaking, (2) failure to observe corporate formalities, (3) nonpayment of dividends, (4) insolvency of debtor corporation at the time of the transaction in question, (5) siphoning of funds by the dominant shareholder, (6) nonfunctioning of other officers and directors, (7) absence of corporate records, and (8) the existence of the corporation as a mere facade for individual dealings.
Document Preview: INSURANCE - Class Actions. Insureds could not fairly or adequately represent putative class, barring class certification in breach of contract action.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: F.T.C. v. Bronson Partners, LLC
Court: United States District Court, D. Connecticut.
Headnote: Alter ego status is demonstrated under Texas law, by the total dealings of corporation and individual, including degree to which corporate formalities are practiced and extent that corporate and individual property are maintained separately, the amount of financial interest, ownership and control the individual maintains over the corporation, and whether the corporation has been used for personal purposes.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW - Advertising. Restitution of $1.9 million and permanent injunction were proper remedies for false advertising.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: Walz v. Martinez
Court: Court of Appeals of Texas, San Antonio.
Headnote: An alter ego relationship may be shown from the total dealings of the corporation and the individual; this showing may include evidence of the degree to which corporate formalities have been followed and corporate and individual property have been kept separately, the amount of financial interest, ownership and control the individual maintains over the corporation, and whether the corporation has been used for personal purposes.
Document Preview: LITIGATION - Jurisdiction. Children of decedent did not purposefully avail selves of activities within Texas to extent supporting exercise of personal jurisdiction.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: In re BH S & B Holdings LLC
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: Simply going out of business, even if caused by malfeasance, is not enough to support piercing of the corporate veil.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Business Relationships. Unsecured creditors committee failed to establish that piercing debtor's corporate veil was warranted.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: In re Callahan
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, D. Massachusetts, Eastern Division.
Headnote: Twelve factors considered by Massachusetts courts in deciding whether to pierce corporate veil are: (1) whether there is common ownership; (2) whether there is pervasive control; (3) any confused intermingling of business activity, assets or management; (4) thin capitalization; (5) nonobservance of corporate formalities; (6) absence of corporate records; (7) no payment of dividends; (8) insolvency at the time of the litigated transaction; (9) any siphoning away of corporate assets by dominant shareholders; (10) nonfunctioning officers and directors; (11) use of corporation for transactions of dominant shareholders; and (12) use of corporation in promoting fraud.
Document Preview: TAXATION - Liens. Tax lien did not attach to property titled solely in name of taxpayer's wife.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: McCallum Family L.L.C. v. Winger
Court: Colorado Court of Appeals, Div. VII.
Headnote: Courts consider a variety of factors in determining a corporation's status as an alter ego of a person or entity, as one part of the three-prong test for determining whether it is appropriate to pierce the corporate veil, including the factors of whether (1) the corporation is operated as a distinct business entity; (2) funds and assets are commingled; (3) adequate corporate records are maintained; (4) the nature and form of the entity's ownership and control facilitate misuse by an insider; (5) the business is thinly capitalized; (6) the corporation is used as a "mere shell"; (7) legal formalities are disregarded; and (8) corporate funds or assets are used for noncorporate purposes.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. The burden of proof in an action to pierce the corporate veil is by a preponderance of the evidence.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: U.S. v. Stephens
Court: United States District Court, D. Montana, Billings Division.
Headnote: In determining whether a corporation is the alter ego of an individual, courts should consider the following factors: (1) whether the individual is in a position of control or authority over the entity; (2) whether the individual controls the entity's actions without need to consult others; (3) whether the individual uses the entity to shield himself from personal liability; (4) whether the individual uses the business entity for his or her own financial benefit; (5) whether the individual mingles his own affairs in the affairs of the business entity; and (6) whether the individual uses the business entity to assume his own debts, or the debts of another, or whether the individual uses his own funds to pay the business entity's debts.
Document Preview: TAXATION - Collection. United States could reach assets of taxpayer's corporations to recover unpaid tax assessments for personal income tax.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: Longhi v. Mazzoni
Court: Court of Appeals of Indiana.
Headnote: To decide whether a plaintiff has met its burden to pierce a corporate veil, courts consider whether the plaintiff has presented evidence showing: (1) undercapitalization; (2) absence of corporate records; (3) fraudulent representation by corporation shareholders or directors; (4) use of the corporation to promote fraud, injustice or illegal activities; (5) payment by the corporation of individual obligations; (6) commingling of assets and affairs; (7) failure to observe required corporate formalities; or (8) other shareholder acts or conduct ignoring, controlling, or manipulating the corporate form.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Piercing corporate veil and treble damages were warranted where manager of development company used down payment on home as investment capital.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: Longhi v. Mazzoni
Court: Court of Appeals of Indiana.
Headnote: The common factors that courts consider in piercing the corporate veil is not necessarily an exhaustive list, and all factors need not be shown to support a decision to pierce the corporate veil.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Piercing corporate veil and treble damages were warranted where manager of development company used down payment on home as investment capital.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: U.S. v. Toler
Court: United States District Court, S.D. Ohio, Eastern Division.
Headnote: Under Ohio law, courts may consider a number of nonexclusive factors in deciding whether to disregard corporate fiction under the alter ego theory, including: (1) grossly inadequate capitalization, (2) failure to observe corporate formalities, (3) insolvency of the debtor corporation at the time the debt is incurred, (4) shareholders holding themselves out as personally liable for certain corporate obligations, (5) diversion of funds or other property of the company property for personal use, (6) absence of corporate records, and (7) the fact that the corporation was a mere facade for the operations of the dominant shareholders.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Alter-ego doctrine was satisfied under Ohio law, as would support piercing corporate veil to satisfy tax lien.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: In re Hecker
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, D. Minnesota.
Headnote: In traditional veil-piercing cases, Minnesota courts apply a two-prong test, with the first prong focusing on the shareholder's relationship to the corporation and the second examining whether piercing the corporate veil is necessary to avoid injustice or fundamental unfairness.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Bankruptcy Estate. Debtor could not reverse-pierce corporate veil to claim Minnesota homestead exemption in property owned by LLC.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: In re Hecker
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, D. Minnesota.
Headnote: Under Minnesota law, factors that are significant to the inquiry under the first prong of the test for corporate veil-piercing, which focuses on the shareholder's relationship to the corporation, include whether there is insufficient capitalization for purposes of corporate undertaking, a failure to observe corporate formalities, nonpayment of dividends, insolvency of debtor corporation at time of transaction in question, siphoning of funds by dominant shareholder, nonfunctioning of other officers and directors, absence of corporate records, and existence of the corporation as merely a facade for individual dealings.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Bankruptcy Estate. Debtor could not reverse-pierce corporate veil to claim Minnesota homestead exemption in property owned by LLC.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: In re Saba Enterprises, Inc.
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: Eight factors, although not all-inclusive, are generally considered in the alter ego analysis for corporate veil-piercing claim under Colorado law: (1) failure to operate the subsidiary as a distinct business entity, (2) commingling of funds and assets, (3) maintenance of inadequate corporate records, (4) facilitation of insider misuse by the nature and form of the entity's ownership and control, (5) inadequate capitalization, (6) use of the entity as a mere shell, (7) disregard of legal formalities by the parent/shareholder, and (8) use of corporate funds or assets for non-corporate purposes.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Avoidance. Chapter 7 trustee satisfied fraud pleading rule in asserting actual fraudulent transfer claims.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: In re SMTC Mfg. of Texas
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, W.D. Texas, Austin Division.
Headnote: Under Texas law, alter ego claim is established based upon total dealings of corporation and individual, including degree to which corporate formalities have been followed and corporate and individual property have been kept separate, amount of financial interest, ownership and control that individual maintains over corporation, and whether corporation has been used for personal purposes.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Avoidance. Even obligation on absolute and unconditional guarantee may be discounted for fraudulent transfer avoidance purposes.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: In re SMTC Mfg. of Texas
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, W.D. Texas, Austin Division.
Headnote: Under Texas law, resolution of alter ego issues must be based on consideration of totality of the circumstances; there is no litmus test.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Avoidance. Even obligation on absolute and unconditional guarantee may be discounted for fraudulent transfer avoidance purposes.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: Laborers' Pension Fund v. Lay-Com, Inc.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Seventh Circuit.
Headnote: Under Illinois law, in the veil-piercing analysis a laundry list of factors is considered to determine whether there is a unity of interest between two corporations or between a corporation and a controlling shareholder or other dominant personality, but the focus is on whether the corporations have respected corporate formalities, that is, respected their separateness from each other, or whether one was a sham acting at the whim of the other.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Piercing corporate veil was warranted to recover unpaid contributions to union-administered pension and welfare funds.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: Laborers' Pension Fund v. Lay-Com, Inc.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Seventh Circuit.
Headnote: Under Illinois law, sham corporations as would warrant piercing their corporate veil can be mere figments, little more than corporate names held up like picket signs by an individual who is individually responsible for the putative corporation's actions.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Piercing corporate veil was warranted to recover unpaid contributions to union-administered pension and welfare funds.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: In re Sewell
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, E.D. Texas, Sherman Division.
