Headnote: Under Texas law, alter ego status is shown from the total dealings of the entity and the individual, including the degree to which corporate and individual property have been kept separately, the amount of financial interest, ownership, and control the individual maintains over the corporation, and whether the corporation has been used for personal purposes.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Discharge. Purported assignee of judgments lacked standing to bring nondischargeability action.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: U.S. v. Bigalk
Court: United States District Court, D. Minnesota.
Headnote: Under Minnesota law, the determination of whether an entity is the alter ego of an individual entails a two-step analysis: first, courts consider the relationship between the individual and the entity, focusing on such factors as the failure to observe corporate formalities, nonpayment of dividends, siphoning of funds by the individual, absence of records for the entity, and the existence of the entity as merely a facade for the individual, and second, courts consider the relationship between the entity and the party that seeks to disregard it, disregarding the entity only if it has operated in a fraudulent or unjust manner toward that party.
Document Preview: TORTS - Fraud. Transfer of farm to business trust was fraudulent conveyance under Minnesota law.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: Boudreau v. Gentile
Court: United States District Court, N.D. Illinois, Eastern Division.
Headnote: When determining whether there is such unity of interest and ownership to justify piercing the corporate veil court considers whether there is: (1) inadequate capitalization; (2) failure to issue stock; (3) failure to observe corporate formalities; (4) nonpayment of dividends; (5) insolvency of the debtor corporation; (6) nonfunctioning of the other officers or directors; (7) absence of corporate records; (8) commingling of funds; (9) diversion of assets from the corporation by or to a stockholder or other person or entity to the detriment of creditors; (10) failure to maintain arm's-length relationships among related entities; and (11) whether, in fact, the corporation is a mere facade for the operation of the dominant stockholders.
Document Preview: LABOR AND EMPLOYMENT - Benefit Plans. Companies constituted single enterprise were alter egos of shell company liable for unpaid contributions to union pension fund.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: GMAC, LLC v. Hillquist
Court: United States District Court, N.D. Illinois, Western Division.
Headnote: In evaluating the unity of interest and ownership between a corporation and an individual, as an element under Illinois law for determining whether to pierce the corporate veil, courts consider the following factors: (1) inadequate capitalization; (2) failure to issue stock; (3) failure to observe corporate formalities; (4) nonpayment of dividends; (5) insolvency of the debtor corporation; (6) nonfunctioning of the other officers or directors; (7) absence of corporate records; (8) commingling of funds; (9) diversion of assets from the corporation by or to a shareholder; (10) failure to maintain arm's length relationships among related entities; and (11) whether the corporation is a mere facade for the operation of the dominant shareholders.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Successor Liability. Sole proprietor was not liable for successor corporation's debts under theory of successor liability.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: In re Tyson
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: Under American law, courts disregard the corporate form when presented with evidence of its abuse, which may include concealment of true facts, improper motives, lack of adequate capitalization, improper recordkeeping, or evidence that the corporate form has been used as a facade by a third party, such as a dominant shareholder.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Business Relationships. Bankruptcy court would pierce veil of shell corporation involved in international distribution of debtor's boxing match.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: Wilson v. Davis
Court: Court of Appeals of Texas, Houston (1st Dist.).
Headnote: Alter ego, as basis for disregarding corporate fiction, is shown from the total dealings of the corporation and the individual, including the degree to which corporate formalities have been followed and corporate and individual property have been kept separately, the amount of financial interest, ownership and control the individual maintains over the corporation, and whether the corporation has been used for personal purposes.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Fact issue barred summary judgment for closely held corporation on alter ego theory of liability for fatal accident.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: East Hampton Union Free School Dist. v. Sandpebble Builders, Inc.
Court: Supreme Court, Appellate Division, Second Department, New York.
Headnote: Factors to be considered in determining whether corporation's owner has abused the privilege of doing business in the corporate form so as to permit "piercing the corporate veil" and impose personal liability on owner for corporation's obligations include whether there was a failure to adhere to corporate formalities, inadequate capitalization, commingling of assets, and use of corporate funds for personal use.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. School district failed to allege that corporation owner's conduct gave rise to liability under theory of piercing corporate veil.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: RaceRedi Motorsports, LLC v. Dart Machinery, Ltd.
Court: United States District Court, D. Maryland.
Headnote: Although there appears to be no universal rule as to the specific criteria that courts will consider in determining whether to apply the alter-ego doctrine, some of the factors commonly considered, when dealing with a single corporation, are (1) whether the corporation is inadequately capitalized, fails to observe corporate formalities, fails to issue stock or pay dividends, or operates without a profit, (2) whether there is commingling of corporate and personal assets, (3) whether there are non-functioning officers or directors, (4) whether the corporation is insolvent at the time of the transaction, and (5) the absence of corporate records.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW - Trade Secrets. Manufacturer sufficiently stated a claim of misappropriation of trade secrets under Maryland law.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: Siematic Mobelwerke GmbH & Co. KG v. Siematic Corp.
Court: United States District Court, E.D. Pennsylvania.
Headnote: Factors to be considered in piercing the corporate veil under Pennsylvania law include: (1) gross undercapitalization, (2) failure to observe corporate formalities, (3) substantial mingling of corporate and personal affairs, and (4) using the corporate form to perpetrate a fraud.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW - Contracts. Agreement between manufacturer and its distributor did not require the distributor to pay freight and installation charges.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: Siematic Mobelwerke GmbH & Co. KG v. Siematic Corp.
Court: United States District Court, E.D. Pennsylvania.
Headnote: The factors used to determine whether to pierce the corporate veil under Pennsylvania law are not exhaustive, nor is every element required for a finding of liability; however, the situation must present an element of injustice or fundamental unfairness.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW - Contracts. Agreement between manufacturer and its distributor did not require the distributor to pay freight and installation charges.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: L.D.G., Inc. v. Brown
Court: Supreme Court of Alaska.
Headnote: Under "mere instrument" test for piercing corporate veil, court asks whether (1) the shareholder sought to be charged owns all or most of the stock of corporation; (2) shareholder has subscribed to all of the capital stock of corporation or otherwise caused its incorporation; (3) corporation has grossly inadequate capital; (4) shareholder uses property of corporation as his own; (5) directors or executives of corporation act independently in interest of corporation or simply take their orders from shareholder in the latter's interest; and (6) formal legal requirements of corporation are observed; it is not necessary for all six factors to be satisfied, but they help fact-finder to decide whether evidence favors piercing veil.
Document Preview: TORTS - Dram Shop. Evidence regarding intoxicated bar patron's role in decedent's death was inadmissible at trial on damages in dram shop action.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: McWilliams Ballard, Inc. v. Broadway Management Co., Inc.
Court: United States District Court, District of Columbia.
Headnote: Under District of Columbia law, factors for determining when to pierce the corporate veil include: (1) whether corporate formalities have been disregarded, (2) whether corporate funds and assets have been extensively intermingled with personal assets, (3) inadequate initial capitalization, and (4) fraudulent use of the corporation to protect personal business from the claims of creditors.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. A developer stated a claim under District of Columbia law to pierce corporate veil of marketer of units in new development.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: In re Coleman
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, S.D. Mississippi.
Headnote: For the agency exception to the separate taxable entity doctrine to apply, the presence of the following three factors is required: (1) written agency agreement at the time the assets are required by the corporate agent, (2) activities by both the principal and the agent consistent with the agreement, and (3) representation of the agency arrangement to all third parties dealing with the asset.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Taxes. Double taxation did not warrant disallowance of the IRS' proof of claim for taxes arising from debtor's dividend income.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: In re 201 Forest Street LLC
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, D. Massachusetts, Central Division.
Headnote: First Circuit considers 12 factors when determining whether to pierce the corporate veil: (1) common ownership, (2) pervasive control, (3) confused intermingling of business activity, assets, or management, (4) thin capitalization, (5) nonobservance of corporate formalities, (6) absence of corporate records, (7) no payment of dividends, (8) insolvency at the time of the litigated transaction, (9) siphoning away of corporate assets by the dominant shareholders, (10) nonfunctioning of officers and directors, (11) use of the corporation for transactions of the dominant shareholders, and (12) use of the corporation in promoting fraud.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Claims. Lender's claim would be equitably subordinated based on the inequitable conduct of its principal.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: Smith v. Simmons
Court: United States District Court, E.D. California.
Headnote: Under California law, when assessing whether there is requisite "unity of interest" to warrant application of alter ego doctrine, court should consider: inadequate capitalization, commingling of funds and other assets, holding out by one entity that it is liable for other's debts, identical equitable ownership, use of same offices and employees, use of one as mere conduit for other's affairs, disregard of corporate formalities, lack of segregation of corporate records, and identical directors and officers.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW - Guaranty. Buyer corporation's vice president did not personally guarantee its obligations under asset purchase agreement.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: Gass v. Anna Hosp. Corp.
Court: Appellate Court of Illinois, Fifth District.
Headnote: In determining whether the "unity of interest and ownership" prong of piercing-the-corporate-veil test is met, a court generally will not rest its decision on a single factor, but will examine many factors, including: (1) inadequate capitalization, (2) failure to issue stock, (3) failure to observe corporate formalities, (4) nonpayment of dividends, (5) insolvency of the debtor corporation, (6) nonfunctioning of the other officers or directors, (7) absence of corporate records, (8) commingling of funds, (9) diversion of assets from the corporation by or to a stockholder or other person or entity to the detriment of creditors, (10) failure to maintain arm's-length relationships among related entities, and (11) whether, in fact, corporation is mere facade for operation of dominant stockholders.
Document Preview: HEALTH - Venue. Personal representative of patient's estate failed to join hospital's parent corporation in good faith.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: In re Yellowstone Mountain Club, LLC
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, D. Montana.
Headnote: In determining whether shareholder is alter-ego with an entity under Montana law, the following factors are considered along with the other evidence and circumstances of each individual case: whether the shareholder owns all or most of the corporation's stock, is a director and/or president of the corporation, makes all the corporate decisions without consulting the other directors or officers, and admits to third parties that the shareholder and the corporation are one and the same, whether the shareholder's personal funds are commingled with the corporation's funds, whether the shareholder's personal credit and corporation's credit are used interchangeably to obtain personal and corporate loans, whether the shareholder and corporation engage in the same type of business, and whether the shareholder and corporation have the same address which is the address of shareholder's personal residence.
Document Preview: LITIGATION - Evidence. Counsel who represented debtors before they filed bankruptcy did not violate attorney-client privilege by serving on creditors' committee

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: Equity Trust Co. Custodian ex rel. Eisenmenger IRA v. Cole
Court: Court of Appeals of Minnesota.
Headnote: Several factors are relevant to the inquiry of whether a corporate veil may be pierced under an alter ego theory, including: insufficient capitalization for purposes of corporate undertaking, failure to observe corporate formalities, nonpayment of dividends, insolvency of debtor corporation at time of transaction in question, siphoning of funds by dominant shareholder, nonfunctioning of other officers and directors, absence of corporate records, and existence of corporation as merely facade for individual dealings.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Corporate veil of entities involved in real estate fraud could be pierced under alter-ego theory.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: Equity Trust Co. Custodian ex rel. Eisenmenger IRA v. Cole
Court: Court of Appeals of Minnesota.
Headnote: Whether a party holds an ownership interest in a corporate entity is not dispositive to the determination of whether to pierce the corporate veil; veil piercing is an equitable remedy, and courts are to consider reality and not form in determining a party's involvement in a corporate enterprise.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Corporate veil of entities involved in real estate fraud could be pierced under alter-ego theory.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: Peyton Place, Condominium Associates, Inc. v. Guastella
Court: Court of Appeal of Louisiana, Fifth Circuit.
Headnote: Factors that courts consider when determining whether to apply the alter ego doctrine to piece the corporate veil include but are not limited to the following: (1) commingling of corporate and shareholder funds, (2) failure to follow statutory formalities for incorporating and transacting corporate affairs, (3) undercapitalization, (4) failure to provide separate bank accounts and bookkeeping records, and (5) failure to hold regular shareholder and director meetings.
Document Preview: REAL PROPERTY - Attorney Fees. Court did not abuse it discretion in assessing attorney fees to unit owner on condominium association's principal demand against owner.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: Sheffield Services Co. v. Trowbridge
Court: Colorado Court of Appeals, Div. IV.
Headnote: Courts consider various factors in identifying a unity of interest in ownership so as to disregard the corporate fiction and treat the corporation and shareholder as alter egos, including whether: (1) the corporation is operated as a distinct business entity; (2) assets and funds are commingled; (3) adequate corporate records are maintained; (4) the nature and form of the entity's ownership and control facilitate misuse by an insider; (5) the business is thinly capitalized; (6) the corporation is used as a mere shell; (7) shareholders disregard legal formalities; and (8) corporate funds or assets are used for noncorporate purposes.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Limited Liability Companies. Doctrine of piercing the corporate veil extended to manager of LLC who was not a member.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: Parks v. Anderson
Court: United States District Court, D. Kansas.
Headnote: In deciding whether to disregard the corporate entity, Kansas courts consider eight factors: (1) undercapitalization of one-man corporation; (2) failure to observe corporate formalities; (3) nonpayment of dividends; (4) siphoning of corporate funds by dominant stockholder; (5) nonfunctioning of other officers or directors; (6) absence of corporate records; (7) use of corporation as facade for operations of dominant stockholder or stockholders; and (8) use of corporate entity in promoting injustice or fraud.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Bankruptcy Estate. Paydown of residential mortgage debt triggered statutory cap on debtor's state homestead exemption.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: In re The Heritage Organization, L.L.C.
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, N.D. Texas, Dallas Division.
Headnote: Among factors considered by Delaware courts when deciding whether first prong of two-pronged veil piercing test is satisfied, i.e., whether corporation and its dominant interest holder operated as single economic entity, are: (1) whether corporation was adequately capitalized; (2) whether it was solvent; (3) whether dividends were paid, corporate records kept, officers and directors functioned properly, and other corporate formalities were observed; (4) whether dominant interest holder siphoned corporate funds; and (5) whether, in general, the corporation simply functioned as facade for dominant interest holder.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Avoidance. LLC's membership distributions were actually fraudulent to creditors under Texas law.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: In re The Heritage Organization, L.L.C.
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, N.D. Texas, Dallas Division.
Headnote: Factors considered by Tennessee courts in deciding whether to pierce corporate veil are: (1) whether there was failure to collect paid in capital; (2) whether corporation was grossly undercapitalized; (3) nonissuance of stock certificates; (4) sole ownership of stock by one individual; (5) use of same office or business location; (6) employment of same employees or attorneys; (7) use of corporation as instrumentality or business conduit for individual or another corporation; (8) diversion of corporate assets by or to a stockholder or other entity to detriment of creditors, or manipulation of assets and liabilities in another; (9) use of corporation as subterfuge in illegal transactions; (10) formation and use of corporation to transfer to it existing liability of another person or entity; and (11) failure to maintain arms-length relationships among related entities; however, it is not necessary that all of these factors weigh in plaintiff's favor in order to justify piercing the corporate veil.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Avoidance. LLC's membership distributions were actually fraudulent to creditors under Texas law.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: In re The Heritage Organization, L.L.C.
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, N.D. Texas, Dallas Division.
Headnote: Under Texas law, alter ego doctrine applies when there is such unity between corporation and individual that separateness of corporation has ceased and holding only the corporation liable will result in injustice; it is established from the total dealings of corporation and individual, including degree to which corporate formalities have been followed and corporate and individual property have been kept separate, amount of financial interest, ownership and control the individual maintains over corporation, and whether corporation has been used for personal purposes.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Avoidance. LLC's membership distributions were actually fraudulent to creditors under Texas law.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: Hamilton Beach Brands, Inc. v. Metric and Inch Tools, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, C.D. California.
Headnote: When determining the applicability of the alter ego doctrine in California, a court can consider numerous factors, including inadequate capitalization, commingling of funds and other assets of the two entities, the holding out by one entity that it is liable for the debts of the other, identical equitable ownership in the two entities, use of the same offices and employees, use of one as a mere conduit for the affairs of the other, disregard of corporate formalities, lack of segregation of corporate records, and identical directors and officers.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Older corporation was not alter ego of younger corporation.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: Hamilton Beach Brands, Inc. v. Metric and Inch Tools, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, C.D. California.
Headnote: When determining the applicability of the alter ego doctrine in California, no single factor is determinative, and instead a court must examine all the circumstances to determine whether to apply the doctrine.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Older corporation was not alter ego of younger corporation.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: Nichols v. Tseng Hsiang Lin
Court: Court of Appeals of Texas, Dallas.
Headnote: The types of evidence a court will consider as proof of an alter ego relationship between corporation and an individual include: (1) the payment of alleged corporate debts with personal checks or other commingling of funds, (2) representations that the individual will financially back the corporation, (3) the diversion of company profits to the individual for his personal use, (4) inadequate capitalization, and (5) other failure to keep corporate and personal assets separate.
Document Preview: LITIGATION - Jurisdiction. Fiduciary shield doctrine protected foreign citizen from trial court's exercise of general personal jurisdiction over him.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: Nichols v. Tseng Hsiang Lin
Court: Court of Appeals of Texas, Dallas.
Headnote: An individual's standing as an officer, director, or majority shareholder of an entity alone is insufficient to support a finding of alter ego.
Document Preview: LITIGATION - Jurisdiction. Fiduciary shield doctrine protected foreign citizen from trial court's exercise of general personal jurisdiction over him.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: Cement-Lock v. Gas Technology Institute
Court: United States District Court, N.D. Illinois, Eastern Division.
Headnote: Illinois courts look to four factors in considering whether to disregard a corporation's identity: (1) the failure to maintain adequate corporate records or to comply with corporate formalities, (2) the commingling of funds or assets, (3) undercapitalization, and (4) one corporation treating the assets of another corporation as its own.
Document Preview: TORTS - Damages. New business rule barred admission of expert's current-day valuation of company's intellectual property.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: American Medical Systems, Inc. v. Biolitec, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, D. Massachusetts.
Headnote: Litigants who insist that the corporate veil must be brushed aside must first prove lack of corporate independence, fraudulent intent, and manifest injustice; the test is conjunctive and thus the parent-subsidiary relationship is an improper basis for the exercise of personal jurisdiction in the absence of any one of the elements.
Document Preview: PATENTS - Jurisdiction. Service of process on corporation in Germany under Hague Service Convention was not defective for lack of request form.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: Ramirez v. STi Prepaid LLC
Court: United States District Court, D. New Jersey.
Headnote: Under New Jersey law, relevant factors in determining whether corporate veil should be pierced include: gross undercapitalization, failure to observe corporate formalities, non-payment of dividends, the insolvency of the debtor corporation at the time, siphoning of the funds of the corporation by the dominant stockholder, non-functioning of other officers or directors, absence of corporate records, and the fact that the corporation is merely a façade for the operations of the dominant stockholder or stockholders.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Allegations were insufficient to pierce corporate veil and hold company liable under New Jersey Consumer Fraud Act.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: Mr. Cinnamon of Kansas, Inc. v. Hall
Court: Court of Appeals of Kansas.
Headnote: Court should consider the following factors in determining whether it is justified to disregard the corporate entity, pursuant to alter ego doctrine: (1) undercapitalization of a one-man corporation, (2) failure to observe corporate formalities, (3) nonpayment of dividends, (4) siphoning of corporate funds by the dominant stockholder, (5) nonfunctioning of other officers or directors, (6) absence of corporate records, (7) the use of the corporation as a facade for operations of the dominant stockholder or stockholders, and (8) the use of the corporate entity in promoting injustice or fraud.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW - Jurisdiction. Court could not exercise personal jurisdiction over nonresident corporate officer of buyer of cigarettes from seller in state.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: In re Chocolate Confectionary Antitrust Litigation
Court: United States District Court, M.D. Pennsylvania.
Headnote: Courts evaluate alter egos in the veil-piercing context by reference to factors such as undercapitalization of the subsidiary, failure to observe corporate formalities, nonpayment of dividends, insolvency of the debtor corporation, siphoning of funds from the debtor corporation by the dominant stockholder, nonfunctioning of officers and directors, absence of corporate records, and whether the corporation is merely a facade for the operations of the dominant stockholder; these factors also affect the alter ego jurisdictional analysis but do not preclude consideration of other indicia of corporate control.
Document Preview: ANTITRUST - Jurisdiction. Plaintiffs failed to establish prima facie showing of purposeful availment jurisdiction over foreign chocolate manufacturers.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: In re LMcD, LLC
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, M.D. Pennsylvania.
Headnote: Under Pennsylvania law, factors for court to consider in deciding whether to pierce corporate veil are: any undercapitalization, failure to adhere to corporate formalities, substantial intermingling of corporate and personal affairs, and use of corporate form to perpetuate fraud.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Limited Liability Companies. Veil could not be pierced based on possible undercapitalization of LLC or mere confusion of identities.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: State Capital Title & Abstract Co. v. Pappas Business Services, LLC
Court: United States District Court, D. New Jersey.
Headnote: In determining whether a unity of interest and ownership exists, as element under New Jersey law for piercing the corporate veil, six non-binding factors may be considered: (1) gross undercapitalization; (2) failure to observe corporate formalities and non-payment of dividends; (3) the insolvency of the debtor corporation at the time; (4) siphoning of funds of the corporation by the dominant stockholder; (5) non-functioning of other officers or directors and absence of corporate records; and (6) the fact that the corporation is merely a facade for the operations of the dominant stockholder or stockholders.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW - Contracts. Economic loss doctrine barred claim of contractor's breach of duty of loyalty.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: Van Doren v. Coe Press Equipment Corp.
Court: United States District Court, E.D. Pennsylvania.
Headnote: Under Pennsylvania law, in deciding whether to pierce corporate veil, court should consider undercapitalization, failure to adhere to corporate formalities, substantial intermingling of corporate and personal affairs, and use of corporate form to perpetrate fraud.
Document Preview: PRODUCTS LIABILITY - Persons Liable. Workers' Compensation Act's exclusivity provision did not bar worker's products liability action against his employer.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: Christian v. Smith
Court: Supreme Court of Nebraska.
Headnote: Some of the relevant factors in determining whether to disregard the corporate entity, or pierce the corporate veil, on the basis of fraud are (1) grossly inadequate capitalization, (2) insolvency of the debtor corporation at the time the debt is incurred, (3) diversion by the shareholder or shareholders of corporate funds or assets to their own or other improper uses, and (4) the fact that the corporation is a mere facade for the personal dealings of the shareholder and that the operations of the corporation are carried on by the shareholder in disregard of the corporate entity.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW - Contracts. Oral agreement came within leading object exception to statute of frauds requirement that agreement to pay debt of another be in writing.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: Christian v. Smith
Court: Supreme Court of Nebraska.
Headnote: A corporation is "insolvent," for the purposes of determining whether to disregard the corporate entity, or pierce the corporate veil, on the basis of fraud, if it is unable to pay its debts as they become due in the usual course of its business, or if it has an excess of liabilities of the corporation over its assets at a fair valuation.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW - Contracts. Oral agreement came within leading object exception to statute of frauds requirement that agreement to pay debt of another be in writing.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: AHA Sales, Inc. v. Creative Bath Products, Inc.
Court: Supreme Court, Appellate Division, Second Department, New York.
Headnote: Factors to be considered by a court in determining whether to pierce the corporate veil include failure to adhere to corporate formalities, inadequate capitalization, commingling of assets, use of corporate funds for personal use, use of common office space, address, and telephone numbers of corporate entities, and the amount of business discretion displayed by the allegedly dominated corporation.
Document Preview: LABOR AND EMPLOYMENT - Hours and Wages. Sales representative stated cause of action against manufacturer under Labor Law statute regulating payment of commissions.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: Wachovia Securities, LLC v. Jahelka
Court: United States District Court, N.D. Illinois, Eastern Division.
Headnote: Eleven factors that Illinois courts consider in deciding whether unity of interest and ownership between individual and corporation is such that the corporate fiction should be disregarded are: (1) fact that corporation was inadequately capitalized; (2) its failure to issue stock; (3) its failure to observe corporate formalities; (4) its nonpayment of dividends; (5) insolvency of corporation; (6) non-functioning of its other officers or directors; (7) absence of corporate records; (8) commingling of funds; (9) diversion of assets from corporation by or to shareholder; (10) failure to maintain arm's length relationships among related entities; and (11) whether corporation is mere facade for operation of dominant shareholders.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Corporate veil could be pierced to hold shareholders personally liable for margin debt.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: Wachovia Securities, LLC v. Jahelka
Court: United States District Court, N.D. Illinois, Eastern Division.
Headnote: Under Illinois law, no one factor is determinative on whether unity of interest and ownership between individual and corporation is such that corporate fiction should be disregarded; rather, court's task is to decide whether pertinent factors, taken as a whole, demonstrate that corporation is actually the alter ego of individual,.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Corporate veil could be pierced to hold shareholders personally liable for margin debt.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: Wachovia Securities, LLC v. Jahelka
Court: United States District Court, N.D. Illinois, Eastern Division.
Headnote: South Dakota courts consider six factors in deciding whether to pierce corporate veil: (1) fact that corporation is undercapitalized; (2) its failure to observe corporate formalities; (3) absence of corporate records; (4) payment by corporation of individual obligations; (5) fraudulent misrepresentation(s) by corporate directors; and (6) use of corporation to promote fraud, injustice or illegality.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Corporate veil could be pierced to hold shareholders personally liable for margin debt.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: Cantrell v. Putnam County Sheriff's Dep't
Court: Court of Appeals of Indiana.
Headnote: Factors considered in the determination of piercing the corporate veil include: (1) undercapitalization; (2) absence of corporate records; (3) fraudulent representation by corporation shareholders or directors; (4) use of the corporation to promote fraud, injustice, or illegal activities; (5) payment by the corporation of individual obligations; (6) commingling of assets and affairs; (7) failure to observe required corporate formalities; or (8) other shareholder acts or conduct ignoring, controlling, or manipulating the corporate form.
Document Preview: CRIMINAL JUSTICE - Forfeitures. Vehicle owned by corporation was subject to forfeiture after corporation's sole shareholder was arrested with drugs in vehicle.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: In re Oko
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, E.D. New York.
Headnote: Among factors tending to show domination and control of corporation by its shareholders, such as may permit piercing of corporate veil under New York law, are: (1) absence of corporate formalities, such as election of directors, issuance of stock and maintenance of corporate records; (2) inadequate capitalization; (3) use of corporate funds for personal rather than corporate purpose; and (4) payment or guarantee of debts of corporation by owners or by another related corporation.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Avoidance. Corporate veil could be pierced to hold shareholder personally liable for judgment on fraudulent transfer claim.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: Trevino v. Merscorp, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, D. Delaware.
Headnote: Under Delaware law, in determining whether to pierce corporate veil, court may consider: (1) undercapitalization; (2) failure to observe corporate formalities; (3) nonpayment of dividends; (4) insolvency of debtor corporation at time; (5) siphoning of corporation's funds by dominant stockholder; (6) absence of corporate records; and (7) fact that corporation is merely facade for operations of dominant stockholder or stockholders.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Mortgagors could not pierce corporate veil to hold banks liable for mortgagee's alleged overcharges.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: Crutcher-Tufts Resources, Inc. v. Tufts
Court: Court of Appeal of Louisiana, Fourth Circuit.
Headnote: Factors for evaluating an alter ego claim in a corporate setting are: (1) commingling of corporate and shareholder funds, (2) failure to follow statutory formalities required for the transaction of corporate affairs, (3) undercapitalization, (4) failure to provide separate bank accounts and bookkeeping records, and (5) failure to hold regular shareholder or director meetings.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Shareholders. Plaintiff had no cause of action against shareholder based on alter ego theory of liability.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: Coughlin Const. Co., Inc. v. Nu-Tec Industries, Inc.
Court: Supreme Court of North Dakota.
Headnote: Factors considered significant in determining whether to pierce the corporate veil include insufficient capitalization for purposes of the corporate undertaking, failure to observe corporate formalities, nonpayment of dividends, insolvency of corporation at time of transaction in question, siphoning of funds by dominant shareholder, nonfunctioning of other officers and directors, absence of corporate records, and existence of corporation as merely a facade for individual dealings.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Piercing of subcontractor's corporate veil was warranted.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: Freeland v. Enodis Corp.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Seventh Circuit.
Headnote: To prevail on an alter ego/veil piercing claim under Indiana law, plaintiff must adduce evidence showing (1) undercapitalization, (2) absence of corporate records, (3) fraudulent representation by corporation's shareholders or directors, (4) use of corporation to promote fraud, injustice, or illegal activities, (5) payment by corporation of individual obligations, (6) commingling of assets or affairs, (7) failure to observe required formalities, or (8) other shareholder acts or conduct ignoring, controlling, or manipulating the corporate form.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Avoidance. Finding, in avoidance action, that corporate debtor made transfers with actual fraudulent intent was not clearly erroneous.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: Alli v. U.S.
Court: United States Court of Federal Claims.
Headnote: In order to pierce the corporate veil under Michigan law, three elements are required: (1) the corporate entity must be a mere instrumentality of another entity or individual; (2) the corporate entity must be used to commit a fraud or wrong; and (3) there must have been an unjust loss or injury to the party seeking to pierce the veil.
Document Preview: REAL PROPERTY - Subsidized Housing. Termination of HAP contracts was justified by failure to provide decent, safe and sanitary housing.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: Alli v. U.S.
Court: United States Court of Federal Claims.
Headnote: In considering whether a corporation is a mere instrumentality of another entity or individual under Michigan law pertaining to piercing the corporate veil, courts may examine, inter alia, the adequacy of the corporation's capitalization, the commingling of funds, the diversion of corporate assets for personal use, a failure to comply with the formalities of corporate organization, and domination and control over the corporation by another person or entity.
Document Preview: REAL PROPERTY - Subsidized Housing. Termination of HAP contracts was justified by failure to provide decent, safe and sanitary housing.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: In re Freier
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, D. Minnesota.
Headnote: Under Minnesota law, significant to the assessment of the relationship between a shareholder and a corporation, for purposes of determining whether to pierce the corporate veil, are: insufficiency of capitalization for purposes of corporate undertaking, failure to observe corporate formalities, insolvency of debtor corporation at time of transactions in question, siphoning of funds by the sole shareholder, absence of corporate records, and the existence of the corporation as merely a facade for individual dealings.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Discharge. Debt arising from debtor's failure to pay concrete supplier fell within fiduciary fraud discharge exception.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: In re Restaurant Development Group, Inc.
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, N.D. Illinois, Eastern Division.
Headnote: In determining whether plaintiff has met "unity of interest and ownership" prong of test for piercing corporate veil, Illinois court generally will not rest its decision on single factor, but will look at totality of circumstances, including whether corporation: (1) is inadequately capitalized; (2) failed to issue stock; (3) failed to observe corporate formalities; (4) failed to pay dividends; (5) is insolvent; (6) had non-functioning officers or directors; (7) lacked corporate records; (8) commingled funds; (9) diverted assets from itself to stockholder or to other person or entity to detriment of corporate creditors; (10) failed to maintain arms-length relationships with related entities; and (11) is, in fact, a mere facade for operation of dominant stockholders.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Pleading. Trustee stated successor liability claim against corporate entity to which debtor's assets were transferred.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: In re Martin
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, D. New Hampshire.
Headnote: Under New Hampshire law, in determining whether to pierce corporate veil on ground that shareholder used corporate form to promote injustice or fraud, court should consider whether shareholder substantially depleted corporate assets, and whether shareholder used corporation to further his own private business rather than that of corporation.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Corporation's majority shareholder did not use corporate entity to promote injustice or fraud.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: Sudden Service, Inc. v. Brockman Forklifts, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, E.D. Michigan, Southern Division.
Headnote: In deciding whether to pierce the corporate veil, a court may consider a nonexhaustive list of specific factors, including undercapitalization of the corporation, the maintenance of separate books, the separation of corporate and individual finances, the use of the corporation to support fraud or illegality, the honoring of corporate formalities, and whether the corporation is a sham.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW - Fraudulent Transfers. Contributions by president and sole shareholder of corporation were loans rather than fraudulent transfers.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: Judson Atkinson Candies, Inc. v. Latini-Hohberger Dhimantec
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Seventh Circuit.
Headnote: Illinois courts consider the following factors when determining whether there is sufficient "unity of interest" to justify disregarding the corporate form: (1) inadequate capitalization; (2) failure to issue stock; (3) failure to observe corporate formalities; (4) nonpayment of dividends; (5) insolvency of the debtor corporation; (6) nonfunctioning of the other officers or directors; (7) absence of corporate records; (8) commingling of funds; (9) diversion of assets from the corporation by or to a stockholder or other person or entity to the detriment of creditors; (10) failure to maintain arm's-length relationships among related entities; and (11) whether, in fact, the corporation is a mere facade for the operation of the dominant stockholders.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Judgment creditor failed to demonstrate that debtor was alter ego of parent company, as required to pierce corporate veil.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: Michigan Elec. Employees Pension Fund v. Encompass Elec. & Data, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, W.D. Michigan, Southern Division.
Headnote: Veil piercing and alter ego concepts are separate and distinct; in general, efforts to "pierce the corporate veil" ask court to hold one entity vicariously liable for another's debts, whereas contention that one entity is the other's "alter ego" asserts that they are the same entity and liability then is not vicarious but direct.
Document Preview: LABOR AND EMPLOYMENT - Collective Bargaining. Electrical contractor whose president signed letters of assent was bound by CBAs expressly incorporated by reference therein.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: Estate of Raleigh v. Mitchell
Court: District of Columbia Court of Appeals.
Headnote: In determining whether a corporation is the alter ego of its shareholders, a court will consider various factors, such as: (1) whether corporate formalities have been disregarded; (2) whether corporate funds and assets have been extensively intermingled with personal assets; (3) inadequate initial capitalization; and (4) fraudulent use of the corporation to protect personal business from the claims of creditors.
Document Preview: REAL PROPERTY - Parties. Estate of corporation's sole shareholder did not have standing to bring quiet title action on property owned by corporation.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: Cemen Tech, Inc. v. Three D Industries, L.L.C.
Court: Supreme Court of Iowa.
Headnote: The burden is on the party seeking to pierce the corporate veil to show the exceptional circumstances required, and factors that would support such a finding include: (1) the corporation is undercapitalized, (2) it lacks separate books, (3) its finances are not kept separate from individual finances, or individual obligations are paid by the corporation, (4) the corporation is used to promote fraud or illegality, (5) corporate formalities are not followed, and (6) the corporation is a mere sham.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW - Unfair Practices. Trial court erred in refusing to allow plaintiff to raise theory of reverse palming off.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: Saft America, Inc. v. Plainview Batteries, Inc.
Court: Court of Appeals of North Carolina.
Headnote: Factors to consider in determining whether to pierce the corporate veil include: (1) inadequate capitalization; (2) non-compliance with corporate formalities; (3) complete domination and control of the corporation so that it has no independent identity; and (4) excessive fragmentation of a single enterprise into separate corporations.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Allegations in complaint stated basis for claim of piercing corporate veil to establish personal jurisdiction.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: Galvan v. Caviness Packing Co., Inc.
Court: United States District Court, N.D. Texas, Amarillo Division.
Headnote: Factors to be considered in determining whether a corporation is the alter ego of an individual include the degree to which corporate formalities have been followed and corporate and individual property have been kept separately, amount of financial interest, ownership and control the individual or parent maintains over corporation, and whether corporation has been used for personal or parental purposes.
Document Preview: LABOR AND EMPLOYMENT - Discrimination. Several plaintiffs in representative action could not maintain retaliation claims against their employer.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: Rolls-Royce Corp. v. Heros, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, N.D. Texas, Dallas Division.
Headnote: Under Texas law, alter ego liability is shown from total dealings of corporation and individual, including: (1) degree to which corporate formalities have been followed and corporate and individual property have been kept separately; (2) amount of financial interest, ownership and control individual maintains over corporation; and (3) whether corporation has been used for personal purposes.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW - Judgment. Res judicata was inapplicable to aircraft engine manufacturer's RICO claims.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: Pamperin v. Streamline Mfg., Inc.
Court: Court of Appeals of Tennessee. Western Section, at Nashville.
Headnote: Generally, no one factor is conclusive in determining whether to pierce the corporate veil to impose liability against a related entity; rather, courts will rely upon a combination of factors in deciding the issue.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Hot tub buyer established that it was necessary to pierce corporate veil to reach shareholder of insolvent corporation.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: Scarff Bros., Inc. v. Bischer Farms, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, E.D. Michigan, Northern Division.
Headnote: Under Michigan law, generally, alter ego liability means that an individual who abuses the corporate form to conduct personal business may face liability because a court can then pierce the corporate veil.
Document Preview: AGRICULTURE - Animals. Course of dealing created implied contract between cattle broker and feedlot owners.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: Scarff Bros., Inc. v. Bischer Farms, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, E.D. Michigan, Northern Division.
Headnote: Under Michigan law, factors to consider in determining whether abuse of the corporate form warranting piercing of the corporate veil occurred include the following: (1) the absence of corporate formalities; (2) commingling personal and corporate funds; (3) siphoning corporate funds to a dominant stockholder; and (4) operation of the corporation as a mere facade for the personal operations of a stockholder.
Document Preview: AGRICULTURE - Animals. Course of dealing created implied contract between cattle broker and feedlot owners.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: Trustees of the Graphic Communications Intern. Union Upper Midwest Local 1M Health and Welfare Plan v. Bjorkedal
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Eighth Circuit.
Headnote: Under Minnesota law, in determining whether the corporation is the alter ego or a mere instrumentality of the shareholder, as required to pierce the corporate veil, a number of factors must exist before a shareholder will be held liable for the obligations of a corporation: (1) insufficient capitalization, (2) failure to observe corporate formalities, (3) nonpayment of dividends, (4) insolvency of debtor corporation, (5) siphoning of funds, (6) nonfunctioning of officers and directors, (7) absence of corporate records, or (8) existence of corporation as a mere facade for individual dealings.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Partnerships. Rental partnership was not alter ego of printing company, as to make it liable for company's contractual obligations.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: In re Polo Builders, Inc.
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, N.D. Illinois, Eastern Division.
Headnote: Among factors that Illinois courts may assess in deciding, for purpose of veil-piercing claim, whether there is such unity of interest and ownership that separate personalities of corporation and individual no longer exist are: whether corporation is inadequately capitalized; any failure to issue stock or to observe corporate formalities; nonpayment of dividends;, whether corporation is insolvent; non-functioning of corporate officers and directors;, absence of corporate records; commingling of funds or assets; and treatment by an individual of assets of corporation as his own.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Bankruptcy Estate. LLC's veil could not be pierced to hold its members liable for LLC's breach of contract to purchase estate property.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: Ivanov v. Sunset Pools Management Inc.
Court: United States District Court, District of Columbia.
Headnote: Under District of Columbia law, to determine whether a corporation and shareholder have abused the corporate form, courts weigh several factors, including whether they have commingled funds, staff, and property, whether a single shareholder dominates the corporation, whether the corporation is adequately capitalized, and, especially, whether the corporate form has been used to effectuate a fraud.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Natural person was not alter ego of alleged malfeasant corporation on basis that person was part-owner of corporation.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: Wachovia Securities, LLC v. Neuhauser
Court: United States District Court, N.D. Illinois, Eastern Division.
Headnote: To determine whether, under Illinois law, unity of interest and ownership between individual and corporation is such that corporate fiction should be disregarded, courts consider following factors: (1) inadequate capitalization, (2) failure to issue stock, (3) failure to observe corporate formalities, (4) nonpayment of dividends, (5) insolvency of corporation, (6) non-functioning of officers or directors, (7) absence of corporate records, (8) commingling of funds, (9) diversion of assets from corporation by or to shareholder, (10) failure to maintain arm's length relationships among related entities, and (11) whether corporation is mere facade for operation of dominant shareholders; court's task is to decide whether these factors, taken as a whole, demonstrate that corporation is actually alter ego of individual, and no one factor is determinative.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW - Fraudulent Transfers. Factual issues precluded summary judgment for debtor and transferees on constructive fraudulent transfer claim.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: Wachovia Securities, LLC v. Neuhauser
Court: United States District Court, N.D. Illinois, Eastern Division.
Headnote: To satisfy fraud or injustice aspect of inquiry into whether piercing of the corporate veil is warranted, party requesting veil-piercing must point to more than the mere prospect of an unsatisfied judgment, and instead must show that some wrong beyond a creditor's inability to collect will result if veil is not pierced, such as the individuals sought to be held liable being unjustly enriched or unfairly avoiding liability after draining corporate assets.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW - Fraudulent Transfers. Factual issues precluded summary judgment for debtor and transferees on constructive fraudulent transfer claim.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: In re Storer
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, D. Montana.
Headnote: Factors which are relevant under Montana law in deciding whether corporation is alter ego of individual include, but are not limited to, the following: (1) whether individual is in position of control or authority over corporation; (2) whether individual controls corporation's actions without need to consult others; (3) whether individual uses corporation to shield himself from personal liability; (4) whether individual uses corporation for his own financial benefit; (5) whether individual mingles his own affairs in the affairs of corporation; and (6) whether individual uses corporate entity to assume his own debts, or debts of another, or whether individual uses his own funds to pay entity's debts.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Discharge. Any breach of contract did not rise to level of fraud, for dischargeability purposes.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: Millennium Const., LLC v. Loupolover
Court: Supreme Court, Appellate Division, Second Department, New York.
Headnote: Factors to be considered by a court in determining whether to pierce the corporate veil include failure to adhere to corporate formalities, inadequate capitalization, commingling of assets, and use of corporate funds for personal use.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Corporate veil would not be pierced so as to hold its president personally liable for alleged breach of contract.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: In re Ma
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, N.D. Ohio, Eastern Division.
Headnote: To determine whether corporation is alter ego of individual, Ohio courts consider these factors: (1) grossly inadequate capitalization; (2) failure to observe corporate formalities; (3) insolvency of corporation when debt is incurred; (4) a shareholder's holding himself out as personally liable for corporate obligations; (5) diversion of corporate funds or property for personal use; (6) absence of corporate records; and (7) use of corporation as mere facade for operations of dominant shareholder; however, these factors are neither exclusive nor exhaustive.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Discharge. Debtor's misconduct as principal of mortgage broker was in nature of willful and malicious injury.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: In re JNS Aviation, LLC
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, N.D. Texas, Amarillo Division.
Headnote: Under Texas law, in determining the applicability of the "alter ego" strand of corporate disregard or veil-piercing, the court looks to the total dealings between the corporation and the individual, including the degree to which corporate formalities have been maintained, whether corporate and individual assets have been kept separately, the financial interests, ownership, and control the individual maintains over the corporation, and whether the corporation has been used for personal purposes.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Business Relationships. Creditor could pierce debtor-LLC's veil so as to hold nondebtor owners liable for default judgment.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: Sparks v. Booth
Court: Court of Appeals of Texas, Dallas.
Headnote: As proof of alter ego, a court considering piercing the corporate veil may consider: (1) the payment of alleged corporate debts with personal checks or other commingling of funds, (2) representations that the individual will financially back the corporation, (3) the diversion of company profits to the individual for his personal use, (4) inadequate capitalization, and (5) other failure to keep corporate and personal assets separate. V.T.C.A., Business Organizations Code § 21.223(a)(2).
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW - Contracts. Expert's testimony was legally sufficient to support award of damages for defects in home.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: Sparks v. Booth
Court: Court of Appeals of Texas, Dallas.
Headnote: An individual's standing as an officer, director, or majority shareholder of an entity alone is insufficient to support a finding of alter ego necessary to pierce the corporate veil. V.T.C.A., Business Organizations Code § 21.223(a)(2).
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW - Contracts. Expert's testimony was legally sufficient to support award of damages for defects in home.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: Country Village Homes, Inc. v. Patterson
Court: Court of Appeals of Texas, Houston (1st Dist.).
Headnote: Evidence relevant to prove an Alter Ego theory to disregard the corporate fiction includes: (1) payment of alleged corporate debts with personal checks or other commingling of funds; (2) representations that the individual will financially back the corporation; (3) diversion of company profits for the individual's personal use; (4) inadequate capitalization; and (5) other failures to keep corporate and personal assets separate.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Error in failing to instruct actual fraud was an element of Single Business Enterprise theory was not preserved for appeal.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: Country Village Homes, Inc. v. Patterson
Court: Court of Appeals of Texas, Houston (1st Dist.).
Headnote: A showing that an individual is an officer, director, or majority shareholder is insufficient to support a finding of Alter Ego to disregard the corporate fiction.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Error in failing to instruct actual fraud was an element of Single Business Enterprise theory was not preserved for appeal.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: HOK Sport, Inc. v. FC Des Moines, L.C.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Eighth Circuit.
Headnote: Under Iowa law, the corporate form can be disregarded through piercing of the corporate veil if (1) the corporation is undercapitalized, (2) without separate books, (3) its finances are not kept separate from individual finances, and individual obligations are paid by the corporation, (4) the corporation is used to promote fraud or illegality, (5) corporate formalities are not followed, or (6) the corporation is merely a sham; a party seeking to pierce the corporate veil need not prove all six factors, but it must prove at least one of the factors.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Non-profit Entities. Person who was nonprofit's president and only officer and board member was liable for nonprofit's debts as alter ego.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: Hoyt Properties, Inc. v. Production Resource Group, L.L.C.
Court: Supreme Court of Minnesota.
Headnote: Factors relevant to the inquiry regarding whether to pierce the corporate veil under the alter ego theory include insufficient capitalization for purposes of corporate undertaking, failure to observe corporate formalities, nonpayment of dividends, insolvency of debtor corporation at time of transaction in question, siphoning of funds by dominant shareholder, nonfunctioning of other officers and directors, absence of corporate records, and existence of corporation as mere facade for individual dealings.
Document Preview: TORTS - Fraud. Attorney's representations regarding veil-piercing were actionable as fraudulent misrepresentations.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: Four Seasons Mfg., Inc. v. 1001 Coliseum, LLC
Court: Court of Appeals of Indiana.
Headnote: In deciding whether the party seeking to pierce the corporate veil has met its burden, Indiana courts consider whether the party has presented evidence showing: (1) undercapitalization; (2) absence of corporate records; (3) fraudulent representation by corporation shareholders or directors; (4) use of the corporation to promote fraud, injustice, or illegal activities; (5) payment by the corporation of individual obligations; (6) commingling of assets and affairs; (7) failure to observe required corporate formalities; or (8) other shareholder acts or conduct ignoring, controlling, or manipulating the corporate form.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Limited Liability Companies. Piercing of corporate veil of LLC was warranted.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: State ex rel. Cooper v. Ridgeway Brands Mfg., LLC
Court: Court of Appeals of North Carolina.
Headnote: Factors to consider in determining whether to pierce the corporate veil include: (1) inadequate capitalization; (2) non-compliance with corporate formalities; (3) complete domination and control of the corporation so that it has no independent identity; and (4) excessive fragmentation of a single enterprise into separate corporations.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Allegations against cigarette manufacturer's owner stated claim for piercing the corporate veil.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: Mid-South Mgt. Co. Inc. v. Sherwood Development Corp.
Court: Court of Appeals of South Carolina.
Headnote: There is a two-prong test to determine whether a corporate veil should be pierced: the first part of the test requires an eight-factor analysis and looks to observance of the corporate formalities by the dominant shareholders, and the second part requires that there be an element of injustice or fundamental unfairness if the acts of the corporation be not regarded as the acts of the individuals.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Partnership failed to prove sufficient number of Sturkie factors to justify piercing corporate veil.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: Mid-South Mgt. Co. Inc. v. Sherwood Development Corp.
Court: Court of Appeals of South Carolina.
Headnote: In determining whether the corporate formalities were observed under the first prong of the Sturkie piercing-the-corporate-veil test, courts consider eight factors: (1) whether the corporation was grossly undercapitalized; (2) failure to observe corporate formalities; (3) non-payment of dividends; (4) insolvency of the debtor corporation at the time; (5) siphoning of funds of the corporation by the dominant stockholder; (6) non-functioning of other officers or directors; (7) absence of corporate records; and (8) the fact that the corporation was merely a façade for the operations of the dominant stockholder.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Partnership failed to prove sufficient number of Sturkie factors to justify piercing corporate veil.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: Mid-South Mgt. Co. Inc. v. Sherwood Development Corp.
Court: Court of Appeals of South Carolina.
Headnote: The conclusion to disregard the corporate entity must involve a number of the eight applicable factors, but need not involve them all.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Partnership failed to prove sufficient number of Sturkie factors to justify piercing corporate veil.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: Mid-South Mgt. Co. Inc. v. Sherwood Development Corp.
Court: Court of Appeals of South Carolina.
Headnote: The burden of proving the fundamental unfairness prong of the Sturkie piercing-the-corporate-veil test requires the plaintiff to establish that (1) the defendant was aware of the plaintiff's claim against the corporation, and (2) thereafter, the defendant acted in a self-serving manner with regard to the property of the corporation and in disregard of the plaintiff's claim in the property.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Partnership failed to prove sufficient number of Sturkie factors to justify piercing corporate veil.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: Albright v. Attorney's Title Ins. Fund
Court: United States District Court, D. Utah, Central Division.
Headnote: In order to pierce the corporate veil the plaintiff must satisfy a two-part test: (1) the plaintiff must show that there was such unity of interest and lack of respect given to the separate identity of the corporation by its shareholders that the personalities and assets of the corporation and the individual are indistinct, and (2) the plaintiff must show that adherence to the corporate fiction would sanction a fraud, promote injustice, or lead to an evasion of legal obligations.
