Document Preview: TORTS - RICO. Company executive vice president's actions attempting to cover up fraud did not cause fraud as to support private RICO claim.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: In re B.L. Jennings, Inc.
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, M.D. Florida, Jacksonville Division.
Headnote: Manipulation of assets to detriment of creditors supports a finding of inequitable result, such as will permit a piercing of corporate veil under California law.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Avoidance. Transfer of unencumbered property for no consideration after debtor was named as tort defendant was fraudulent transfer.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: In re B.L. Jennings, Inc.
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, M.D. Florida, Jacksonville Division.
Headnote: While determination of alter ego liability is at its core an equitable one, which must be made on case-by-case basis under California law, there are various factors that courts consider, such as commingling of funds and other assets of the two entities, use of one as mere shell or conduit for affairs of the other, treatment by individual of entity's assets as his own, and failure to segregate funds of individual and entity.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Avoidance. Transfer of unencumbered property for no consideration after debtor was named as tort defendant was fraudulent transfer.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: Trossman v. Philipsborn
Court: Appellate Court of Illinois, First District, Sixth Division.
Headnote: A court may reverse pierce the corporate veil when: (1) an insider owns all, or substantially all, of the stock; (2) the insider treats the property as his own; and (3) no shareholder or creditor would be adversely affected.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Partnerships. Partner was not equitably estopped from changing his reasons for not paying pro rata share of loan under guaranty.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: Wechsler v. Macke Intern. Trade, Inc.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Federal Circuit.
Headnote: Bad faith in one form or another must be shown before the court may disregard the fiction of separate corporate existence, under California law.
Document Preview: PATENTS - Damages. Award of lost profit damages to patent owner was not supported by substantial evidence.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: S.E.C. v. Resource Development Intern., LLC
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Fifth Circuit.
Headnote: Under Texas law, whether corporation and individual are "alter egos" is shown from their total dealings, including degree to which corporate formalities have been followed and corporate and individual property has been kept separately, amount of financial interest, ownership and control that individual maintains over corporation, and whether corporation has been used for personal purposes.
Document Preview: SECURITIES REGULATION - Judgment. Transfer by corporation operated as Ponzi scheme was actually and constructively fraudulent to creditors.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: Comcast of IL X v. Multi-Vision Electronics, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, D. Nebraska.
Headnote: Some of the factors that are relevant in determining whether to disregard a corporate entity on the basis of fraud are: (1) grossly inadequate capitalization, (2) insolvency of the debtor corporation at the time the debt is incurred, (3) diversion by the shareholder or shareholders of corporate funds or assets to their own or other improper uses, and (4) the fact that the corporation is a mere facade for the personal dealings of the shareholder and that the operations of the corporation are carried on by the shareholder in disregard of the corporate entity.
Document Preview: LITIGATION - Judgment. Trust set up by judgment debtor was void and therefore did not protect assets from judgment creditor's claims.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: Town of Haynesville, Inc. v. Entergy Corp.
Court: Court of Appeal of Louisiana, Second Circuit.
Headnote: An alter ego analysis for piercing the corporate veil involves the consideration of five factors: (1) commingling of corporate and shareholder funds, (2) failure to follow statutory formalities for incorporating and transacting corporate affairs, (3) undercapitalization, (4) failure to maintain separate bank accounts and bookkeeping records and, (5) failure to hold regular shareholder and director meetings.
Document Preview: ENERGY AND UTILITIES - Electricity. Town could not raise a utility's franchise fee based on acts of affiliated utilities.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: In re Jamuna Real Estate LLC
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, E.D. Pennsylvania.
Headnote: Under Pennsylvania law, in determining whether to pierce corporate veil, court should consider: (1) insufficient capitalization; (2) intermingling of funds; (3) non-functioning officers and directors; (4) absence of corporate formalities; (5) failure to pay dividends; (6) outward representation of sole proprietorship as opposed to incorporation.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Professionals. Doctrine of in pari delicto did not bar Chapter 7 trustees from asserting RICO claims against debtor corporations' principals

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: Certain Underwriters at Lloyd's, London, Subscribing to Policy Number 501/NB03ACMD v. Nance
Court: United States District Court, D. New Mexico.
Headnote: Under New Mexico law, factors in "improper purpose" criterion for piercing corporate veil include undercapitalization, sham formalities or formation, or fraudulent manipulation or mismanagement resulting in losses.
Document Preview: INSURANCE - Liability. Alter ego doctrine could not be used against innocent third-party insurer.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: Seghers v. El Bizri
Court: United States District Court, N.D. Texas, Dallas Division.
Headnote: Under Texas law, when making the determination as to whether the corporate veil should be pierced, the court is to consider the totality of the circumstances, including the degree to which corporate formalities have been followed and corporate and individual property have been kept separately, the amount of financial interest, ownership and control the individual maintains over the corporation, and whether the corporation has been used for personal purposes.
Document Preview: LITIGATION - Jurisdiction. Court had personal jurisdiction over corporation based on reverse piercing of corporate veil.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: In re First Assured Warranty Corp.
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, D. Colorado.
Headnote: Among factors that Hawai'i courts may consider in deciding whether to disregard corporate fiction on alter ego theory are: (1) commingling of funds and other assets, failure to segregate funds of the separate entities, and unauthorized diversion of corporate funds or assets to other than corporate uses; (2) treatment by individual of assets of corporation as his own; (3) failure to obtain authority to issue stock or to subscribe to or issue the same; (4) holding out by individual that he is personally liable for debts of corporation; (5) identical equitable ownership in the two entities; (6) entities' use of same office or business location; (7) failure to adequately capitalize entities; and (8) disregard for corporate formalities.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Case Administration. Bankruptcy case did not have to be dismissed on McCarran-Ferguson Act grounds.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: In re First Assured Warranty Corp.
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, D. Colorado.
Headnote: In deciding whether to disregard corporate fiction and treat corporation and its shareholder as alter egos, Colorado courts consider several factors, including: (1) whether corporation is operated as a distinct business entity; (2) whether funds and assets are commingled; (3) whether adequate corporate records are maintained; (4) whether nature and form of entity's ownership and control facilitate a misuse by insider; (5) whether business is thinly capitalized; (6) whether corporation is used as mere shell; (7) whether shareholders disregard legal formalities; and (8) whether corporate funds or assets are used for noncorporate purposes.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Case Administration. Bankruptcy case did not have to be dismissed on McCarran-Ferguson Act grounds.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: In re Doctors Hosp. of Hyde Park, Inc.
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, N.D. Illinois, Eastern Division.
Headnote: Under Illinois law, in determining whether entity was mere instrumentality of another, for purposes of alter ego theory, court should consider: (1) inadequate capitalization; (2) failure to issue stock; (3) failure to observe corporate formalities; (4) nonpayment of dividends; (5) debtor corporation's insolvency; (6) nonfunctioning of other officers or directors; (7) absence of corporate records; (8) commingling of funds; (9) diversion of assets from corporation by or to shareholder; (10) failure to maintain arm's length relationships among related entities; and (11) whether corporation is mere facade for operation of dominant shareholders.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Avoidance. Debtor-hospital operator was insolvent at time it made rent payments.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: Petrich v. MCY Music World, Inc.
Court: Appellate Court of Illinois, First District, Fourth Division.
Headnote: Delaware law requires an element of fraud to pierce the corporate veil; factors showing fraud include undercapitalization, lack of solvency, proper payment of dividends, observance of corporate formalities, and improper shareholder activity.
Document Preview: TORTS - Public Amusements and Entertainment. Concertgoer could not bring class action after missing portion of concert due to traffic and parking problems.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: Cappuccitti v. Gulf Indus. Products, Inc.
Court: Court of Appeals of Texas, Houston (1st Dist.).
Headnote: To determine whether an alter ego relationship exists in either a piercing the corporate veil or a reverse-piercing situation, courts look to the total dealings of the corporation and the individual, including the degree to which corporate and individual property have been kept separate, the amount of financial interest, ownership, and control the individual maintains over the corporation, and whether the corporation has been used for personal purposes.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Texas court had personal jurisdiction over a nonresident defendant company owner and parent company under alter ego doctrine.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: Cappuccitti v. Gulf Indus. Products, Inc.
Court: Court of Appeals of Texas, Houston (1st Dist.).
Headnote: An individual's standing as an officer, director, or majority shareholder of an entity alone is not enough to support a finding of alter ego sufficient to pierce the corporate veil.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Texas court had personal jurisdiction over a nonresident defendant company owner and parent company under alter ego doctrine.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: Scott v. American Tobacco Co., Inc.
Court: Court of Appeal of Louisiana, Fourth Circuit.
Headnote: There are several non-inclusive factors a court may use to determine whether to apply the alter ego doctrine: (1) commingling of corporate and shareholder funds, (2) failure to follow statutory formalities for incorporating and transacting corporate affairs, (3) undercapitalization, (4) failure to provide separate bank accounts and bookkeeping records, and (5) failure to hold regular shareholder and director meetings.
Document Preview: TORTS - Damages. Smoking cessation program was limited to medically necessary costs of cessation treatment.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: Lee v. Hasson
Court: Court of Appeals of Texas, Houston (14th Dist.).
Headnote: A corporate entity can be disregarded and its shareholders held liable if the corporation is the mere alter ego of its owner as shown from the total dealings of the corporation and the individual, including the degree to which corporate formalities have been followed and corporate and individual property have been kept separately, the amount of financial interest, ownership and control the individual maintains over the corporation, and whether the corporation has been used for personal purposes.
Document Preview: FAMILY LAW - Settlements. Financial advisor breached fiduciary duty to wealthy friend and thus fee agreement on property settlement was void.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: Pottschmidt v. Klosterman
Court: Court of Appeals of Ohio, Ninth District, Medina County.
Headnote: Some of the factors used to determine if alter-ego doctrine has been met for purposes of piercing the corporate veil include (1) whether corporate formalities were observed, (2) whether corporate records were kept, (3) whether corporate funds were commingled with personal funds, and (4) whether corporate property was used for a personal purpose.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Alter-ego doctrine was satisfied for purposes of piercing corporate veil.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: Dictoguard, Inc. v. Lopeo
Court: Court of Appeal of Louisiana, Fifth Circuit.
Headnote: To pierce the corporate veil or find that a corporation is an alter ego of an individual, the courts traditionally look to five factors that, when considered with the totality of the evidence, indicate that the individual and the corporation were not actually separate entities: (1) commingling of corporate and shareholder funds; (2) failure to follow statutory formalities required for incorporation and for the transaction of corporate affairs; (3) undercapitalization; (4) failure to provide separate bank accounts and bookkeeping records; and, (5) failure to hold regular shareholder or director meetings.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW - Arbitration. Trial court exceeded its authority by awarding damages beyond arbitrator's award.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: In re Derivium Capital, LLC
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, D. South Carolina.
Headnote: Although mere fact that a single individual has substantial ownership of all the stock of a corporation is not by itself a sufficient ground to disregard the corporate form under South Carolina law, the corporate form may be disregarded if such ownership is combined with other factors, such as gross undercapitalization, failure to observe corporate formalities, non-payment of dividends, insolvency of the corporation, siphoning of funds of the corporation by the dominant stockholder, non-functioning of other officers or directors, absence of corporate records, and the fact that the corporation is merely a facade for the operations of the dominant stockholder or stockholders; decision to disregard corporate form must involve a number of these factors, and plaintiff must also demonstrate an element of injustice or fundamental unfairness.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Avoidance. Trustee's actual and constructive fraudulent transfer claims under South Carolina law did not satisfy fraud pleading rule.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: In re Kilroy
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, S.D. Texas, Houston Division.
Headnote: Under Delaware law, numerous factors are important to alter ego analysis, including: whether corporation was adequately capitalized; whether it was solvent; whether dividends were paid, corporate records kept, officers and directors functioned properly, and other corporate formalities were observed; whether dominant shareholder siphoned off corporate funds; and whether, in general, corporation simply functioned as facade for dominant shareholder.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Discharge. Debtor was barred by prior judgment on alter ego claim from disputing that false statements should be attributed to him.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: In re Kilroy
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, S.D. Texas, Houston Division.
Headnote: While, under Delaware law, numerous factors are important to alter ego analysis, no single factor can justify decision to disregard the corporate entity.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Discharge. Debtor was barred by prior judgment on alter ego claim from disputing that false statements should be attributed to him.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: Stanley v. Mississippi State Pilots of Gulfport, Inc.
Court: Supreme Court of Mississippi.
Headnote: Piercing the corporate veil to allow for personal liability of corporate officers arises from officers' diversion of corporate assets.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Successor Liability. Successor corporation was liable for predecessor corporation's debt to judgment creditor after fraudulent conveyance.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: In re Lupo
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, N.D. Ohio, Eastern Division.
Headnote: To determine whether corporation is alter ego of its shareholder(s), as first prerequisite under Ohio law for piercing corporate veil, courts consider such factors as: (1) grossly inadequate capitalization, (2) failure to observe corporate formalities, (3) insolvency of corporation at time debt is incurred, (4) whether shareholders hold themselves personally liable for certain corporate obligations, (5) diversion of funds or other corporate property for personal use, (6) absence of corporate records, and (7) fact that corporation was mere façade for operations of dominant shareholder(s); however, based on equitable nature of veil piercing, no list of factors can be exclusive or exhaustive.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Discharge. Fraudulent scheme was in nature of willful and malicious injury to defrauded party.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: In re Teknek, LLC
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, N.D. Illinois, Eastern Division.
Headnote: In deciding whether the requisite unity of interest exists between individual and corporation, as first prerequisite for piercing corporate veil under Illinois law, courts consider the following criteria: (1) whether there was failure to maintain adequate corporate records or to comply with corporate formalities; (2) whether there was commingling of funds or assets; (3) whether corporation was undercapitalized; and (4) whether one corporation treated assets of another corporation as its own.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Jurisdiction. Debtor-LLC's contacts could be counted as contacts of its members in order to establish personal jurisdiction.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: d'Elia v. Rice Development, Inc.
Court: Court of Appeals of Utah.
Headnote: Significant factors courts consider under the "formalities requirement" prong of the alter ego doctrine are: (1) undercapitalization of a one-man corporation, (2) failure to observe corporate formalities, (3) nonpayment of dividends, (4) siphoning of corporate funds by the dominant stockholder, (5) nonfunctioning of other officers or directors, (6) absence of corporate records, (7) the use of the corporation as a facade for operations of the dominant stockholder or stockholders, and (8) the use of the corporate entity in promoting injustice or fraud.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Limited Liability Companies. The owner of a limited liability company was personally liable for tortious acts of the company in which he participated.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: Troutwine Estates Development Co., LLC v. Comsub Design and Engineering, Inc.
Court: Court of Appeals of Indiana.
Headnote: To meet its burden when trying to impose personal liability on a shareholder for acts of a corporation, a plaintiff may present evidence showing: (1) undercapitalization; (2) absence of corporate records; (3) fraudulent representation by corporate shareholders or directors; (4) use of the corporation to promote fraud, injustice, or illegal activities; (5) payment by the corporation of individual obligations; (6) commingling of assets and affairs; or (8) other shareholder acts or conduct ignoring, controlling, or manipulating the corporate form.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Limited Liability Companies. LLC members could be personally liable for judgment provided analysis used to determine corporate officer liability applied.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: Camofi Master LDC v. College Partnership, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: Under New York law, in determining whether corporation acted as alter ego of another corporation, court should consider: (1) absence of formalities and paraphernalia that are part and parcel of corporate existence; (2) inadequate capitalization; (3) whether funds are put in and taken out of corporation for personal rather than corporate purposes; (4) overlap in ownership, officers, directors, and personnel; (5) common office space, address and telephone numbers of corporate entities; (6) amount of business discretion displayed by allegedly dominated corporation; (7) whether related corporations deal with dominated corporation at arms length; (8) whether corporations are treated as independent profit centers; (9) payment or guarantee of debts of dominated corporation by other corporations in group; and (10) whether corporation in question had property that was used by other corporations as if it were its own.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW - Commercial Paper. Financial advisor's purported fraudulent inducement could not serve as defense in action to collect sums due under notes.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: Laborers' Pension Fund v. Lay-Com, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, N.D. Illinois, Eastern Division.
Headnote: Under Illinois law, factors in "unity of interest" prong of test for piercing corporate veil include inadequate capitalization, failure to issue stock, failure to observe corporate formalities, nonpayment of dividends, insolvency of debtor corporation, nonfunctioning of other officers or directors, absence of corporate records, commingling of funds, diversion of assets from corporation by or to stockholder or other person or entity to detriment of creditors, and failure to maintain arm's length relationships among related entities.
Document Preview: LABOR AND EMPLOYMENT - Collective Bargaining. Company was successor to dissolved entity, and bound by its union agreements, given identity of successor's operations.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: SteriFx, Inc. v. Roden
Court: Court of Appeal of Louisiana, Second Circuit.
Headnote: To pierce the corporate veil or find that a corporation is an alter ego of an individual, the courts traditionally look to five factors that, when considered with the totality of the evidence, indicate that the individual and the corporation were not actually separate entities: (1) commingling of corporate and shareholder funds; (2) failure to follow statutory formalities required for incorporation and for the transaction of corporate affairs; (3) undercapitalization; (4) failure to provide separate bank accounts and bookkeeping records; and (5) failure to hold regular shareholder or director meetings.
Document Preview: LITIGATION - Jurisdiction. Nonresident directors lacked sufficient personal contacts with Louisiana to subject them to personal jurisdiction.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: Sofi Classic S.A. de C.V. v. Hurowitz
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: Court's considerations in determining whether to pierce corporate veil under Massachusetts law include: (1) common ownership; (2) pervasive control; (3) confused intermingling of business activity assets or management; (4) thin capitalization; (5) non-observance of corporate formalities; (6) absence of corporate records; (7) no payments of dividends; (8) insolvency at time of litigated transaction; (9) siphoning away of corporate assets by dominant shareholders; (10) non-functioning of officers and directors; (11) use of corporation for transactions of dominant shareholders; and (12) use of corporation in promoting fraud.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Mexican garment manufacturer stated claim for piercing corporate veil against officers of import company.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: Sofi Classic S.A. de C.V. v. Hurowitz
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: Court's considerations in determining whether to pierce corporate veil under South Carolina law include: (1) whether corporation was grossly undercapitalized; (2) failure to observe corporate formalities; (3) non-payment of dividends; (4) insolvency of debtor corporation; (5) siphoning of funds of corporation by dominant stockholder; (6) non-functioning of other officers or directors; (7) absence of corporate records; and (8) whether corporation was merely facade for operations of dominant stockholder.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Mexican garment manufacturer stated claim for piercing corporate veil against officers of import company.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: In re Phillips
Court: Supreme Court of Colorado, En Banc.
Headnote: In establishing whether such unity of interest exists as to disregard the corporate fiction and treat the corporation and shareholder as alter egos, courts consider a variety of factors, including whether (1) the corporation is operated as a distinct business entity, (2) funds and assets are commingled, (3) adequate corporate records are maintained, (4) the nature and form of the entity's ownership and control facilitate misuse by an insider, (5) the business is thinly capitalized, (6) the corporation is used as a "mere shell," (7) shareholders disregard legal formalities, and (8) corporate funds or assets are used for noncorporate purposes.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Colorado Supreme Court rules that Colorado law permits outside reverse piercing of corporate veil.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: In re Phillips
Court: Supreme Court of Colorado, En Banc.
Headnote: A court may reverse pierce the corporate veil and obtain the assets of a corporation for the obligations of a controlling shareholder or other corporate insider only upon a clear showing that (1) the controlling insider and the corporation are alter egos of each other, (2) justice requires recognizing the substance of the relationship over the form because the corporate fiction is utilized to perpetuate a fraud or defeat a rightful claim, and (3) an equitable result is achieved by piercing.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Colorado Supreme Court rules that Colorado law permits outside reverse piercing of corporate veil.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: In re Verestar, Inc.
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: Factors establishing that the entities acted as a single economic unit for purposes of claim for alter ego liability under Delaware law include whether the corporation was adequately capitalized for the corporate undertaking; whether the corporation was solvent; whether dividends were paid, corporate records kept, officers and directors functioned properly, and other corporate formalities were observed; whether the dominant shareholder siphoned corporate funds; and whether, in general, the corporation simply functioned as a facade for the dominant shareholder; some combination of factors is required, and an overall element of injustice or unfairness must always be present.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Avoidance. Committee stated claims for constructive fraudulent transfers, but not actual fraudulent transfers.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: Western Reserve Life Assur. Co. of Ohio v. Bratton
Court: United States District Court, N.D. Iowa, Cedar Rapids Division.
Headnote: On a claim under Iowa law for piercing the corporate veil, a court should consider whether: (1) the corporation is undercapitalized; (2) it lacks separate books; (3) its finances are not kept separate from individual finances, or individual obligations are paid by the corporation; (4) the corporation is used to promote fraud or illegality; (5) corporate formalities are not followed; and (6) the corporation is a mere sham.
Document Preview: INSURANCE - Agents and Brokers. Verbal agreement had not been integrated and merged into subsequent written agreement.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: Bollore S.A. v. Import Warehouse, Inc.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Fifth Circuit.
Headnote: To determine whether the alter ego doctrine applies under Texas law, a court considers the total dealings of the corporation and the individual, including the degree to which corporate formalities have been followed and corporate and individual property have been kept separately, the amount of financial interest, ownership and control the individual maintains over the corporation, and whether the corporation has been used for personal purposes.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW - Debt Collection. Texas turnover statute could not be used to find that a store owned by judgment debtor's mother was debtor's alter ego.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: Television Events & Marketing, Inc. v. AMCON Distributing, Co.
Court: United States District Court, D. Hawai'i.
Headnote: Factors considered in evaluating a claim for alter ego liability under Hawaii law include: 1) commingling or failing to separate funds; 2) the failure to adequately capitalize a corporation; 3) the total absence of corporate assets, and undercapitalization; 4) the use of a corporation as a mere shell, instrumentality or conduit for a single venture or the business of an individual or another corporation; 5) the concealment and misrepresentation of the identity of the responsible ownership, management and financial interest; 6) the disregard of legal formalities and the failure to maintain arm's length relationships among the related entities; 7) the formation and use of a corporation to transfer to it the existing liability of another person or entity; 8) whether the subsidiary has no business or assets except those conveyed to it by the parent; and 9) the parent's financing of the subsidiary.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW - Licenses. Genuine issues of material fact existed as to whether best efforts provisions of license agreements were breached.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: Network Enterprises, Inc. v. APBA Offshore Productions, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: Under New York law, because disregarding corporate separateness as an equitable remedy is one that differs with the circumstances of each case, no single factor or even combination of factors is dispositive; the general principle followed by the courts has been that liability is imposed when doing so would achieve an equitable result.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW - Contracts. Type II preliminary agreement bound parties to negotiate in good faith terms necessary to telecast a boat racing season.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: Jacobs Vehicle Systems, Inc. v. Pacific Diesel Brake Co.
Court: United States District Court, D. Connecticut.
Headnote: Under Connecticut law, party seeking to pierce corporate veil under instrumentality theory must show: (1) control, not mere majority or complete stock control, but complete domination, not only of finances but of policy and business practice in respect to transaction attacked so that corporate entity as to this transaction had at time no separate mind, will or existence of its own; (2) that such control was used by defendant to commit fraud or wrong, to perpetrate violation of statutory or other positive legal duty, or dishonest or unjust act in contravention of plaintiff's legal rights; and (3) that aforesaid control and breach of duty proximately caused injury or unjust loss complained of.
Document Preview: PATENTS - Transportation. Parent did not so dominate manufacturer as to warrant piercing corporate veil in connection with patent infringement claim.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: Berry v. Lee
Court: United States District Court, N.D. Texas, Dallas Division.
Headnote: Under Texas law, factors weighing in favor of fusing corporations and/or individuals for jurisdictional purposes include: common business names, business departments, offices, directors or officers, employees, stock ownership, financing, accounting, and payment of wages by one corporation to another corporation's employees and the rendering of services by employees of one corporation on behalf of another corporation.
Document Preview: LITIGATION - Jurisdiction. Chinese corporation and other corporate entities were a single business enterprise for jurisdictional purposes.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: East Market Street Square, Inc. v. Tycorp Pizza IV, Inc.
Court: Court of Appeals of North Carolina.
Headnote: Factors in determining the level of control a corporate or individual defendant exercises over a corporation, for purposes of determining whether to pierce the corporate veil, are: (1) inadequate capitalization; (2) non-compliance with corporate formalities; (3) complete domination and control of corporation so that it has no independent identity; and (4) excessive fragmentation of single enterprise into separate corporations.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Piercing of corporate veil of commercial tenant was warranted.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: Platten v. HG Bermuda Exempted Ltd.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, First Circuit.
Headnote: Under Massachusetts law, when undertaking an inquiry into the actual nature of the corporate interrelationship to evaluate whether the corporate form should be disregarded, a court considers: (1) common ownership; (2) pervasive control; (3) confused intermingling of business assets; (4) thin capitalization; (5) nonobservance of corporate formalities; (6) absence of corporate records; (7) no payment of dividends; (8) insolvency at the time of the litigated transaction; (9) siphoning away of corporation's funds by dominant shareholder; (10) nonfunctioning of officers and directors; (11) use of the corporation for transactions of the dominant shareholders; and (12) use of the corporation in promoting fraud.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW - Motion Practice. District court did not abuse its discretion by denying plaintiffs leave to file supplemental affidavit.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: Dishon v. Ponthie
Court: Court of Appeal of Louisiana, Third Circuit.
Headnote: Five factors are considered by courts in deciding whether a corporation is the alter ego of a shareholder: (1) commingling of corporate and shareholder funds, (2) failure to follow statutory formalities for the incorporating and transacting of corporate affairs, (3) undercapitalization, (4) failure to maintain separate bank accounts and bookkeeping records, and (5) failure to hold regular shareholder and director meetings.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Single-business-entity exception applied to first corporation.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: Fontana v. TLD Builders, Inc.
Court: Appellate Court of Illinois, Second District.
Headnote: In determining whether the unity of interest and ownership prong of the piercing-the-corporate-veil test is met, a court generally will not rest its decision on a single factor, but will examine many factors, including: (1) inadequate capitalization; (2) failure to issue stock; (3) failure to observe corporate formalities; (4) nonpayment of dividends; (5) insolvency of the debtor corporation; (6) nonfunctioning of the other officers or directors; (7) absence of corporate records; (8) commingling of funds; (9) diversion of assets from the corporation by or to a stockholder or other person or entity to the detriment of creditors; (10) failure to maintain arm's-length relationships among related entities; and (11) whether, in fact, the corporation is a mere facade for the operation of the dominant stockholders.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Piercing of the corporate veil of construction company to hold president liable was warranted.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: Hoffmann v. Dandurand
Court: Court of Appeals of Texas, Dallas.
Headnote: Individual's standing as officer, director, or majority shareholder of entity alone is insufficient to support finding of alter ego, as would permit trial court to disregard corporate fiction that corporation is separate legal entity that insulates its owners or shareholders from personal liability. V.A.T.S. Bus.Corp.Act, art. 2.21(A)(3).
Document Preview: LITIGATION - Jurisdiction. Trial court did not have special jurisdiction over nonresident chief executive officer of corporation.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: In re Adler, Coleman Clearing Corp.
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: Among the considerations relevant to determining whether an individual so controls a corporate entity as to warrant piercing the corporate veil, under New York law, are: (1) the absence of the formalities and paraphernalia that are part and parcel of the corporate existence, i.e., issuance of stock, election of directors, keeping of corporate records and the like, (2) whether funds are put in and taken out of the corporation for personal rather than corporate purposes, (3) overlap in ownership, officers, directors, and personnel, (4) common office space, address, and telephone numbers of corporate entities, (5) the amount of business discretion displayed by the allegedly dominated corporation, and (6) whether the corporation in question had property that was used by related corporations as if it were their own.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Individual had sufficient control over companies to warrant piercing the corporate veil.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: Mobius Management Systems, Inc. v. West Physician Search, L.L.C.
Court: Missouri Court of Appeals, Eastern District, Division Two.
Headnote: It is not necessary to show actual fraud to justify piercing of corporate veil; in some situations, the corporate veil may be pierced when a corporation is undercapitalized, or when its assets are stripped to avoid creditors.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Corporation was undercapitalized shell company, operated as such with intent to avoid legal obligations.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: Brant v. Krilich
Court: Court of Appeals of Indiana.
Headnote: In deciding whether a plaintiff has met the burden to pierce the corporate veil, the court considers whether the plaintiff has presented evidence showing: (1) undercapitalization, (2) absence of corporate records, (3) fraudulent representation by corporate shareholders or directors, (4) use of the corporation to promote fraud, injustice, or illegal activities, (5) payment by the corporation of individual obligations, (6) commingling of assets and affairs, (7) failure to observe required corporate formalities, or (8) other shareholder acts or conduct ignoring, controlling, or manipulating the corporate form.
Document Preview: LITIGATION - Attachment and Garnishment. Failure to provide notice of hearing to a garnishee rendered subsequent garnishment invalid.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: New York State Teamsters Conference Pension and Retirement Fund v. Express Services, Inc.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Second Circuit.
Headnote: Inquiry into company's alter ego status focuses on commonality of (1) management, (2) business purpose, (3) operations, (4) equipment, (5) customers, and (6) supervision and ownership.
Document Preview: LABOR AND EMPLOYMENT - Benefit Plans. Determinations of employer status per se under Multiemployer Pension Plan Amendments Act are for the court.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: In re Lindell
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, D. Minnesota.
Headnote: To determine whether shareholder can be liable for corporate obligations on veil-piercing theory under Minnesota law, courts first consider shareholder's actions with regard to corporation based on factors such as shareholder's failure to observe corporate formalities, absence of corporate records, and whether corporation is merely facade for individual dealings, and then decide whether veil-piercing is necessary in order to prevent injustice or fundamental unfairness.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Avoidance. Debtors did not receive reasonably equivalent value for promissory note.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: JSC Foreign Economic Association Technostroyexport v. International Development and Trade Services, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: In determining whether requirement for piercing of corporate veil, under New York law, that owners exercise complete dominion over corporation with respect to transaction attacked, courts are to consider (1) absence of formalities and paraphernalia that are part and parcel of corporate existence, such as issuance of stock, election of directors, and keeping of corporate records, (2) inadequate capitalization, (3) whether funds are put in and taken out of corporation for personal rather than corporate purposes, (4) overlap in ownership, officers, directors, and personnel, (5) common office space, address and telephone numbers of corporate entities, (6) the amount of business discretion displayed by allegedly dominated corporation, (7) whether the related corporations deal with the dominated corporation at arms length, (8) whether the corporations are treated as independent profit centers, (9) payment or guarantee of debts of dominated corporation by other corporations in group, and (10) whether dominated corporation in question had property that was used by other of the corporations as if it were its own.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Corporate veil would be pierced in breach of contract case.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: Davlyn Mfg. Co., Inc. v. H&M Auto Parts, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, E.D. Pennsylvania.
Headnote: In determining whether an individual or corporation is an alter ego or successor of a corporation, the court should consider the nature of the corporate entities' ownership and control, including commonality of stockholders or officers, common use of employees, business locations, or sales systems, common marketing or trademarking; similarity of core business lines, and commingling of funds and assets; court should also consider the sufficiency of consideration paid for the transfer of the predecessor's assets or product line, as well as any other indicia of fraudulent intent in the creation of the second entity.
Document Preview: LITIGATION - Jurisdiction. Court lacked personal jurisdiction over defendants in patent infringement action.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: Lily Transp. Corp. v. Royal Institutional Services, Inc.
Court: Appeals Court of Massachusetts, Norfolk.
Headnote: Factors to be considered, under Pennsylvania law, as basis for piercing the corporate veil are undercapitalization, failure to adhere to corporate formalities, substantial intermingling of corporate and personal affairs, and use of the corporate form to perpetrate a fraud.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Failure to disclose contractor was dealing with LLC rather than corporation did not warrant piercing of LLC.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: In re Parmalat Securities Litigation
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: A firm may be liable under New York law for the acts of a wrongdoer if the wrongdoer is the other's alter ego; whether a wrongdoer is a defendant's alter ego is a fact specific matter that turns on such factors as the failure to adhere to corporate formalities, undercapitalization, intermingling of funds, overlap in ownership, staff and directorship, common use of office space, the degree of discretion shown by the wrongdoer, whether the dealings between the entities are at arms length, and whether the corporations are treated as independent profit centers.
Document Preview: SECURITIES REGULATION - Fraud. Global accounting firm was subject to liability for alleged securities fraud committed by Italian member firm.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: Action Mfg. Co., Inc. v. Simon Wrecking Co.
Court: United States District Court, E.D. Pennsylvania.
Headnote: Alter ego test for piercing the corporate veil looks to following factors: gross undercapitalization, failure to observe corporate formalities, nonpayment of dividends, insolvency of debtor corporation, siphoning of funds from the debtor corporation by the dominant stockholder, nonfunctioning of officers and directors, absence of corporate records, and whether the corporation is merely a facade for the operations of the dominant stockholder.
Document Preview: ENVIRONMENTAL LAW - Jurisdiction. Forum contacts of holding company's subsidiary could not be imputed to holding company for personal jurisdiction purposes.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: International Union, United Auto., Aerospace and Agr. Implement Workers of America v. Aguirre
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Sixth Circuit.
Headnote: Factors to be considered in determining whether to pierce corporate veil include under-capitalization of corporation, maintenance of separate books, separation of corporate and individual finances, use of corporation to support fraud or illegality, honoring of corporate formalities, and whether corporation is merely a sham.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Evidence did not warrant piercing of corporate veil.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: Dickens v. Alliance Analytical Laboratories, LLC
Court: Court of Appeals of Washington, Division 3, Special Panel.
Headnote: To pierce the corporate veil, two separate, essential factors must be established; first, the corporate form must be intentionally used to violate or evade a duty and, second, the fact finder must establish that disregarding the corporate veil is necessary and required to prevent an unjustified loss to the injured party.
Document Preview: LABOR AND EMPLOYMENT - Hours and Wages. Issue of fact existed as to whether individual was personally liable as agent for unpaid wages, through corporate piercing.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: Maroun v. Wyreless Systems, Inc.
Court: Supreme Court of Idaho, Boise, February 2005 Term.
Headnote: Merely being a director or officer of a corporation is not sufficient to pierce the corporate veil.
Document Preview: TORTS - Fraud. Employer's representations were not actionable as fraud.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: Boles v. National Development Co., Inc.
Court: Court of Appeals of Tennessee.
Headnote: Some factors to consider in determining whether to pierce the corporate veil are whether the corporation was grossly undercapitalized; the nonissuance of stock certificates; the sole ownership of stock by one individual; the use of the corporation as an instrumentality or business conduit for an individual or another corporation; the diversion of corporate assets by or to a stockholder or other entity to the detriment of creditors; the use of the corporation as a subterfuge in illegal transactions; the formation and use of the corporation to transfer to it the existing liability of another person or entity; and the failure to maintain arms length relationships among entities.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Principal of corporate developer that breach contract to build lake in recreational development was alter ego of developer.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: Boles v. National Development Co., Inc.
Court: Court of Appeals of Tennessee.
Headnote: No one factor is conclusive in determining whether or not to disregard a corporate entity; rather, courts should rely upon a combination of factors in deciding such an issue.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Principal of corporate developer that breach contract to build lake in recreational development was alter ego of developer.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: Boles v. National Development Co., Inc.
Court: Court of Appeals of Tennessee.
Headnote: It is not necessary that all of the Allen factors weigh in a plaintiff's favor in order to justify the piercing of the corporate veil.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Principal of corporate developer that breach contract to build lake in recreational development was alter ego of developer.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: Manning v. United Medical Corp. of New Orleans
Court: Court of Appeal of Louisiana, Fourth Circuit.
Headnote: When determining whether to apply the "alter ego doctrine," under which third parties may bring suits against shareholders, thereby piercing the corporate veil, courts should consider the following factors, which include but are not limited to: (1) commingling of corporate and shareholder funds; (2) failure to follow statutory formalities for incorporating and transacting corporate affairs; (3) undercapitalization; (4) failure to provide separate bank accounts and bookkeeping records; and (5) failure to hold regular shareholder and director meetings.
Document Preview: HEALTH - Malpractice. Hospital shareholders and directors owed no personal duty towards child who suffered brain injury during birth.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: Meshel v. Ohev Sholom Talmud Torah
Court: District of Columbia Court of Appeals.
Headnote: Although no single factor is dispositive in determining whether the two necessary elements for piercing the corporate veil under an alter ego theory have been proved, which elements are the existence of a unity of ownership and interest and the use of the corporate form to perpetuate fraud or wrong, courts are required to consider a range of factors, including whether corporate formalities have been observed, whether there has been any commingling of corporate and shareholder funds, staff, and property, whether a single shareholder dominates the corporation, whether the corporation is adequately capitalized, and, especially, whether the corporate form has been used to effectuate a fraud.
Document Preview: CIVIL RIGHTS - Religion. First Amendment did not divest court of jurisdiction in congregation members' action to compel arbitration before a Beth Din.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: Williams v. Security Nat. Bank of Sioux City, Iowa
Court: United States District Court, N.D. Iowa, Western Division.
Headnote: Under Iowa law, factors that would support piercing corporate veil include: (1) corporation is undercapitalized; (2) it lacks separate books; (3) its finances are not kept separate from individual finances, or individual obligations are paid by corporation; (4) corporation is used to promote fraud or illegality; (5) corporate formalities are not followed; and (6) corporation is mere sham.
Document Preview: ESTATE PLANNING AND PROBATE - Trusts. Accountant's testimony regarding whether trust tax returns were properly completed was admissible.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: Hambleton Bros. Lumber Co. v. Balkin Enterprises, Inc.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Ninth Circuit.
Headnote: Under Oregon law, a shareholder's "improper conduct" in the exercise of control over a corporation, as would support piercing the corporate veil to impose corporate liability on the shareholder, can include gross undercapitalization, milking or draining of corporate funds, misrepresentation, commingling of funds, holding out, and the failure to observe corporate formalities.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Shareholders. Shareholder was not personally liable for dissolved corporation's alleged breach of contract.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: Escobedo v. BHM Health Associates, Inc.
Court: Supreme Court of Indiana.
Headnote: Factors to be considered when determining whether to pierce the corporate veil include: (1) undercapitalization, (2) absence of corporate records, (3) fraudulent representation by corporation shareholders or directors, (4) use of the corporation to promote fraud, injustice, or illegal activities, (5) payment by the corporation of individual obligations, (6) commingling of assets and affairs, (7) failure to observe required corporate formalities, or (8) other shareholder acts or conduct ignoring, controlling, or manipulating the corporate form. West's A.I.C. 23-1-26-3(b).
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Piercing the corporate veil to impose liability on shareholders unpaid wages was not warranted.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: In re Giampietro
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, D. Nevada.
Headnote: Under the test set forth in the Nevada Supreme Court's McCleary Cattle Co. decision and subsequently codified in essence, there are three requirements for ignoring the separate existence of a corporation pursuant to the alter ego doctrine: (1) the corporation must be influenced and governed by the person asserted to be its alter ego, (2) there must be such unity of interest and ownership that one is inseparable from the other, and (3) the facts must be such that adherence to the fiction of separate entity would, under the circumstances, sanction a fraud or promote injustice. West's NRSA 78.747.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Parties. Plaintiff was not a creditor of debtor and so lacked standing to file § 727(a)(3) complaint.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: Rondout Valley Central School Dist. v. Coneco Corp.
Court: United States District Court, N.D. New York.
Headnote: Under Massachusetts law, inability of corporation to answer to its debts is never alone a sufficient basis to pierce corporate veil.
Document Preview: EDUCATION - Property and Contracts. Contractor's actual performance was admission of obligation to perform.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: Rondout Valley Central School Dist. v. Coneco Corp.
Court: United States District Court, N.D. New York.
Headnote: Twelve factors that Massachusetts courts consider in deciding whether pierce corporate veil are: (1) common ownership; (2) pervasive control; (3) confused intermingling of business activity and assets, (4) thin capitalization; (5) nonobservance of corporate formalities; (6) absence of corporate records; (7) nonpayment of dividends; (8) insolvency at time of litigated transaction; (9) siphoning away of corporate assets by dominant shareholders; (10) non-functioning of officers and directors; (11) use of corporation for transactions of dominant shareholders; and (12) use of corporation in promoting fraud.
Document Preview: EDUCATION - Property and Contracts. Contractor's actual performance was admission of obligation to perform.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: Rondout Valley Central School Dist. v. Coneco Corp.
Court: United States District Court, N.D. New York.
Headnote: Twelve factors that Massachusetts courts consider in determining whether to pierce corporate veil are not of equal importance, and veil-piercing analysis is not simple matter of counting factors; rather, factors should be used in balancing test to decide whether the over-all corporate structure and operation mislead.
Document Preview: EDUCATION - Property and Contracts. Contractor's actual performance was admission of obligation to perform.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: Lisanti v. Dixon
Court: Court of Appeals of Texas, Dallas.
Headnote: An alter ego relationship may be shown from the total dealings of the corporation and the individual, including evidence of the degree to which corporate formalities have been followed and corporate and individual property have been kept separately, the amount of financial interest, ownership, and control the individual maintains over the corporation, and whether the corporation has been used for personal purposes.
Document Preview: LABOR AND EMPLOYMENT - Wrongful Discharge. Employee showed she was fired for refusing to commit insurance fraud.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: University Medical Associates of Medical University of S.C. v. UnumProvident Corp.
Court: United States District Court, D. South Carolina, Charleston Division.
Headnote: Under South Carolina law, in analyzing claim to pierce corporate veil, court should consider: (1) whether corporation was grossly undercapitalized; (2) its failure to observe corporate formalities; (3) non-payment of dividends; (4) insolvency of debtor corporation at time; (5) siphoning of funds of corporation by dominant stockholder; (6) non-functioning of other officers or directors; (7) absence of corporate records; and (8) whether corporation was merely facade for operations of dominant stockholder.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Plaintiffs sufficiently articulated their intent to pierce corporate veil.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: Cass v. Stephens
Court: Court of Appeals of Texas, El Paso.
Headnote: A showing that a corporation is the alter ego of an individual may include evidence of the degree to which corporate formalities have been followed and corporate and individual property have been kept separately, the amount of financial interest, ownership and control the individual maintains over the corporation, and whether the corporation has been used for personal purposes.
Document Preview: ENERGY AND UTILITIES - Damages. Award of $7.5 million in punitive damages for General's widow in action against well operator was excessive.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: U.S. v. JG-24, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, D. Puerto Rico.
Headnote: Under Puerto Rico law, in making determination as to whether to disregard corporate entity, court should consider: undercapitalization, nonpayment of dividends, nonfunctioning officers and directors, failure to observe corporate formalities, absence of corporate records, commingling of funds, and use of corporate funds for non-corporate uses.
Document Preview: ENVIRONMENTAL LAW - CERCLA. Owner of fiberglass product manufacturer was personally liable under CERCLA for response costs.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: Morris v. Powell
Court: Court of Appeals of Texas, San Antonio.
Headnote: Alter ego may be shown from the total dealings of the corporation and the individual, including the degree to which corporate formalities have been followed and corporate and individual property have been kept separately, the amount of financial interest, ownership and control the individual maintains over the corporation, and whether the corporation has been used for personal purposes.
Document Preview: AGRICULTURE - Jurisdiction. Veterinarian had sufficient minimum contacts with Texas so as to support specific personal jurisdiction.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: Morris v. Powell
Court: Court of Appeals of Texas, San Antonio.
Headnote: As proof of alter ego, a court may consider: (1) the payment of alleged corporate debts with personal checks or other commingling of funds, (2) representations that the individual will financially back the corporation, (3) the diversion of company profits to the individual for his personal use, (4) inadequate capitalization, and (5) other failure to keep corporate and personal assets separate.
Document Preview: AGRICULTURE - Jurisdiction. Veterinarian had sufficient minimum contacts with Texas so as to support specific personal jurisdiction.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: Morris v. Powell
Court: Court of Appeals of Texas, San Antonio.
Headnote: An individual's standing as an officer, director, or majority shareholder of an entity alone is insufficient to support a finding of alter ego.
Document Preview: AGRICULTURE - Jurisdiction. Veterinarian had sufficient minimum contacts with Texas so as to support specific personal jurisdiction.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: Signal Peak Enterprises of Texas, Inc. v. Bettina Investments, Inc.
Court: Court of Appeals of Texas, Dallas.
Headnote: Alter ego is shown from the total dealings of the corporation and the individual, including the degree to which corporate and individual property have been kept separately, the amount of financial interest, ownership and control the individual maintains over the corporation, and whether the corporation has been used for personal purposes.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: Taylor v. Clark
Court: Missouri Court of Appeals, Southern District.
Headnote: The existence of a corporate entity will be disregarded when the corporation is operated while undercapitalized or if its assets are stripped to avoid the demands of creditors.

Title: Sunbelt Environmental Services, Inc. v. Rieder's Jiffy Market, Inc.
Court: Missouri Court of Appeals, Southern District, Division Two.
Headnote: The existence of a corporate entity will be disregarded when the corporation is operated while undercapitalized or if its assets are stripped to avoid the demands of creditors.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: Cambridge Electronics Corp. v. MGA Electronics, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, C.D. California.
Headnote: Among the factors to be considered in applying alter ego doctrine are commingling of funds and other assets of corporate and alleged alter ego, the holding out by one entity that it is liable for the debts of the other, identical equitable ownership in the two entities, use of the same offices and employees, and use of one as a mere shell or conduit for the affairs of the other.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW - Fraudulent Transfers. Payment made by corporation to shareholder's father was not fraudulent transfer.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: In re Ticketplanet.com
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: Factors in deciding whether entities acted as single economic unit, as required to support "alter ego" claim under Delaware law, include: whether corporation was adequately capitalized for corporate undertaking; whether corporation was solvent; whether dividends were paid, corporate records kept, officers and directors functioned properly, and other corporate formalities were observed; whether the dominant shareholder siphoned corporate funds; and whether, in general, corporation simply functioned as facade for dominant shareholder.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW - Secured Transactions. Problems with post-default foreclosure sale did not cause it to be a conversion.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: In re Devos, Inc.
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, W.D. Pennsylvania.
Headnote: When determining whether facts of particular case warrant piercing of corporate veil based on alter ego theory, court should consider whether corporation is grossly undercapitalized for its purposes, whether there was any failure to observe corporate formalities, non-payment of dividends, insolvency of debtor-corporation at the time, siphoning funds of corporation by dominant officers or directors, or absence of corporate records, and whether corporation is merely facade for operations of dominant stockholder or stockholders.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Leases and Contracts. Lessee did not abandon equipment left in leased premises.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: Hunting v. Elders
Court: Court of Appeals of South Carolina.
Headnote: The Sturkie factors for piercing the corporate veil which have less importance include the failure to observe corporate formalities, nonfunctioning of other officers or other directors, the absence of corporate records and the nonpayment of dividends.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Dominant shareholder was responsible for judgment against corporation under alter ego theory.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: Ziegler v. Inabata of America, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, D. Colorado.
Headnote: In determining whether to pierce corporate veil under Colorado law, court may consider (1) whether corporation is operated as separate entity, (2) commingling of funds and other assets, (3) failure to maintain adequate corporate records, (4) nature of corporation's ownership and control, (5) absence of corporate assets and undercapitalization, (6) use of corporation as mere shell, (7) disregard of legal formalities, and (8) diversion of corporation's funds or assets to noncorporate uses.
Document Preview: LABOR AND EMPLOYMENT - Wrongful Discharge. Claim for wrongful termination was not barred by after-acquired evidence doctrine.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: Advanced Telephone Systems, Inc. v. Com-Net Professional Mobile Radio, LLC
Court: Superior Court of Pennsylvania.
Headnote: In context of alter-ego/corporate piercing claims, factors to be considered in disregarding the corporate form are: undercapitalization, failure to adhere to corporate formalities, substantial intermingling of corporate and personal affairs, and use of the corporate form to perpetuate a fraud.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. There is no right to jury trial for alter-ego claim seeking piercing of corporate veil of LLC.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: Flynn v. Thibodeaux Masonry, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, District of Columbia.
Headnote: In first prong of analysis of whether piercing the corporate veil is warranted, a court determines whether there is a unity of interest and ownership such that separate personalities of corporation and individual no longer exist by looking at several factors, including: (1) the nature of the corporate ownership and control; (2) whether the corporation has maintained minutes or adequate corporate records; (3) whether the corporation has maintained corporate formalities necessary for issuance or subscription to stock, such as an independent board of directors' formal approval of the stock issue; (4) whether there is a commingling of funds and other assets of the corporation; (5) whether there is a diversion of the corporation's funds or assets to non-corporate uses such as the personal uses of the corporation's shareholders; and (6) whether the corporation and its individual shareholders use the same office or business location.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Shareholder was personally liable for corporation's ERISA liability upon corporate veil-piercing.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: Flynn v. Thibodeaux Masonry, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, District of Columbia.
