Headnote: In determination of whether there is a unity of interest and ownership such that the separate personalities of a corporation and an individual no longer exist, it is not necessary that all of the relevant factors be present to justify piercing the corporate veil.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Shareholder was personally liable for corporation's ERISA liability upon corporate veil-piercing.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: Exter Shipping Ltd. v. Kilakos
Court: United States District Court, N.D. Georgia, Atlanta Division.
Headnote: No uniform standard exists under federal common law for determining when a corporation is the alter ego of its owners; each case must be decided based upon the totality of the circumstances, considering factors including (1) commingling of corporate and personal finances, (2) failure to hold director/shareholder meetings or maintain corporate records, (3) non-functioning of other officers/directors, and (4) whether failure to disregard the corporate fiction would be unjust or fundamentally unfair to an injured party.
Document Preview: LITIGATION - Jurisdiction. Court lacked personal jurisdiction over Greek owners of time charterer.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: Carone v. Retamco Operating, Inc.
Court: Court of Appeals of Texas, San Antonio.
Headnote: Alter ego is shown from the total dealings of the corporation and the individual, including the degree to which corporate formalities have been followed and corporate and individual property have been kept separately, the amount of financial interest, ownership and control the individual maintains over the corporation, and whether the corporation has been used for personal purposes.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Letters and documents did not show that defendant was corporation's alter ego.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: Carone v. Retamco Operating, Inc.
Court: Court of Appeals of Texas, San Antonio.
Headnote: The types of evidence that a court will consider as proof of alter ego include: (1) the payment of alleged corporate debts with personal checks or other commingling of funds, (2) representations that the individual will financially back the corporation, (3) the diversion of company profits to the individual for his personal use, (4) inadequate capitalization, and (5) other failure to keep corporate and personal assets separate.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Letters and documents did not show that defendant was corporation's alter ego.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: Richmond v. Indalex Inc.
Court: United States District Court, M.D. North Carolina.
Headnote: Under North Carolina law, factors that may be relevant in determining whether corporation is so dominated by its shareholders that there is sufficient control to satisfy first element of mere instrumentality rule and support piercing corporate veil are (1) inadequate capitalization, (2) failure to comply with corporate formalities, (3) complete domination and control of the corporation so that it has no independent entity, (4) excessive fragmentation of single enterprise into separate corporations, (5) non-payment of dividends, (6) insolvency, (7) siphoning of funds by the dominant shareholder, (8) non-functioning of other officers or directors, and (9) absence of corporate records.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Parent companies' alleged control of an employer would not permit piercing corporate veil for employee's injury.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: JSC Foreign Economic Ass'n Technostroyexport v. International Development and Trade Services, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: Under New York law, courts consider several factors when determining whether to pierce the corporate veil, including: (1) absence of formalities and paraphernalia that are part and parcel of the corporate existence, i.e., issuance of stock, election of directors, keeping of corporate records and the like; (2) inadequate capitalization; (3) whether funds are put in and taken out of corporation for personal rather than corporate purposes; (4) overlap in ownership, officers, directors, and personnel; (5) common office space, address and telephone numbers of corporate entities; (6) amount of business discretion displayed by the allegedly dominated corporation; (7) whether related corporations deal with dominated corporation at arms length; (8) whether corporations are treated as independent profit centers; (9) payment or guarantee of debts of dominated corporation by other corporations in group; and (10) whether corporation in question had property that was used by other of the corporations as if it were its own.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Likelihood of success on corporate veil-piercing claim supported propriety of attachment order.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: Wechsler v. Macke Intern. Trade Inc.
Court: United States District Court, C.D. California, Western Division.
Headnote: Under California law, factors to be considered in determining whether alter ego doctrine applies include commingling of funds and other assets, individual holding himself out as liable for debts of corporation, ownership and control of corporation by individual, inadequate capitalization, disregard of corporate formalities, and lack of segregation of corporate records.
Document Preview: PATENTS - Personal Liability. Sole shareholder was not personally liable for company's patent infringement.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: South Alabama Pigs, LLC v. Farmer Feeders, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, M.D. Alabama, Northern Division.
Headnote: Under Alabama law, corporate veil may be pierced where a corporation is set up as a subterfuge, where shareholders do not observe the corporate form, where the legal requirements of corporate law are not complied with, where the corporation maintains no corporate records, where the corporation maintains no corporate bank account, where the corporation has no employees, where corporate and personal funds are intermingled and corporate funds are used for personal purposes, or where an individual drains funds from the corporation.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW - Arbitration. Arbitration clause did not amount to agreement not to arbitrate.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: Harte-Hanks Direct Marketing/Baltimore, Inc. v. Varilease Technology Finance Group, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, D. Maryland.
Headnote: Maryland courts will pierce the corporate veil only where necessary to prevent fraud or to enforce a paramount equity; among the factors to be considered in determining whether the corporate veil must be pierced to enforce a paramount equity are gross undercapitalization of the corporation, a dominant shareholder's siphoning of corporate funds, the absence of corporate records, or other indicators that the corporation is merely a facade for the shareholder's operations.
Document Preview: LITIGATION - Jurisdiction. Status as owner of defendant companies was not sufficient to confer personal jurisdiction over nonresident.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: International Financial Services Corp. v. Chromas Technologies Canada, Inc.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Seventh Circuit.
Headnote: Under Illinois law, determining whether there is such a unity of interest and ownership that the separate personalities of the corporation and the individual no longer exist and that piercing the corporate veil is thus warranted is essentially a question of fact that depends on whether there was inadequate capitalization, a failure to observe corporate formalities, commingling of funds, an absence of corporate records, and other factors, but the balance of the veil-piercing analysis, namely, deciding whether adhering to the fiction of a separate corporate existence would promote injustice or inequity, is the type of equitable determination that a jury is not to decide.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Piercing of corporate veil was equitable doctrine in Illinois, so issue was not one for the jury.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: University Medical Associates of Medical University of South Carolina v. UnumProvident Corp.
Court: United States District Court, D. South Carolina, Charleston Division.
Headnote: Under South Carolina law, in analyzing claim to pierce corporate veil, court should consider: (1) whether corporation was grossly undercapitalized; (2) its failure to observe corporate formalities; (3) non-payment of dividends; (4) insolvency of debtor corporation at time; (5) siphoning of funds of corporation by dominant stockholder; (6) non-functioning of other officers or directors; (7) absence of corporate records; and (8) whether corporation was merely facade for operations of dominant stockholder.
Document Preview: INSURANCE - Bad Faith and Unfair Practices. Fact that insurer had paid all amounts due under policy did not bar insured's bad faith claim.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: JSC Foreign Economic Ass'n Technostroyexport v. International Development and Trade Services, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: Courts will consider following factors when determining whether to pierce corporate veil under New York law: (1) absence of formalities and paraphernalia that are part and parcel of corporate existence; (2) inadequate capitalization; (3) whether funds are put in and taken out of corporation for personal rather than corporate purposes; (4) overlap in ownership, officers, directors, and personnel; (5) common office space, address and telephone numbers of corporate entities; (6) amount of business discretion displayed by allegedly dominated corporation; (7) whether related corporations deal with dominated corporation at arms length; (8) whether corporations are treated as independent profit centers; (9) payment or guarantee of debts of dominated corporation by other corporations in group; and (10) whether corporation in question had property that was used by other corporation as if it were its own.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Russian metal seller properly stated veil-piercing claim against corporate purchasers.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: Matheson v. Virgin Islands Community Bank, Corp.
Court: District Court of the Virgin Islands, Division of St. Croix, Appellate Division.
Headnote: In deciding when court should pierce the corporate veil, Third Circuit considers factors of (1) whether corporation suffers from gross undercapitalization,(2) failure to observe corporate formalities, (3) non-payment of dividends, (4) insolvency of debtor corporation, (5) siphoning of funds from debtor corporation from dominant stockholder, (6) nonfunctioning of officers, (7) absence of corporate records, and (8) whether corporation is merely facade for operation of dominant stockholder.
Document Preview: LABOR AND EMPLOYMENT - Wrongful Discharge. Virgin Islands bank officer's wrongful discharge cause of action accrued before statutory amendment.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: Hildreth v. Tidewater Equipment Co., Inc
Court: Court of Appeals of Maryland.
Headnote: For purposes of application of alter ego doctrine, some of the factors commonly considered when dealing with a single corporation are: (1) whether the corporation is inadequately capitalized, fails to observe corporate formalities, fails to issue stock or pay dividends, or operates without a profit; (2) whether there is commingling of corporate and personal assets; (3) whether there are non-functioning officers or directors; (4) whether the corporation is insolvent at the time of the transaction; and (5) the absence of corporate records.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Principal of unregistered foreign corporation was not personally liable for corporate debt.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: F.G. Bruschweiler (Antiques) Ltd. v. GBA Great British Antiques, L.L.C.
Court: Court of Appeal of Louisiana, Fifth Circuit.
Headnote: Factors that courts consider when determining whether to apply the alter ego doctrine include but are not limited to the following: 1) commingling of corporate and shareholder funds; 2) failure to follow statutory formalities for incorporating and transacting corporate affairs; 3) undercapitalization; 4) failure to provide separate bank accounts and bookkeeping records; and 5) failure to hold regular shareholder and director meetings.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Limited Liability Companies. Members of LLC that disregarded some corporate formalities were not liable for debt of LLC.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: Escobedo v. BHM Health Associates, Inc.
Court: Court of Appeals of Indiana.
Headnote: To decide whether plaintiff has met the burden of piercing the corporate veil, a court considers whether the plaintiff has presented evidence showing: (1) undercapitalization, (2) absence of corporate records, (3) fraudulent representation by corporation shareholders or directors, (4) use of the corporation to promote fraud, injustice, or illegal activities, (5) payment by the corporation of individual obligations, (6) commingling of assets and affairs, (7) failure to observe required corporate formalities, or (8) other shareholder acts or conduct ignoring, controlling, or manipulating the corporate form.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Actions of corporation's owners warranted piercing the corporate veil.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: Cosgrove Distributors, Inc. v. Haff
Court: Appellate Court of Illinois, Third District.
Headnote: Courts look at a number of factors to determine whether to pierce the veil, including inadequate capitalization, failure to issue stock, failure to observe corporate formalities, nonpayment of dividends, insolvency of the debtor corporation, nonfunctioning of the other officers or directors, absence of corporate records, commingling of funds, diversion of assets from the corporation by or to a shareholder, failure to maintain arm's-length relationships among related entities, and whether the corporation is a mere facade for the operation of the dominant shareholders.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Shareholders were not equitably estopped from asserting corporate status.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: Roofers Local 149 Security Trust Fund v. Duane Smelser Roofing Co.
Court: United States District Court, E.D. Michigan, Southern Division.
Headnote: No one factor is dispositive in determining whether corporate form should be disregarded, pursuant to alter ego doctrine, in a particular case.
Document Preview: LABOR AND EMPLOYMENT - Benefit Plans. Fact issues precluded summary judgment on multiemployer benefit funds' contribution claim under ERISA.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: InterGen N.V. v. Grina
Court: United States Court of Appeals, First Circuit.
Headnote: In determining whether corporate form may be disregarded, courts consider (1) whether entities in question have ignored independence of their separate operations, (2) whether defendant employed multiplicity of entities as part of artifice or scheme to defraud, and (3) whether holding corporate form inviolate would lead to substantial injustice or inequity.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW - Arbitration. Plaintiff was not judicially estopped from asserting that it was not bound by arbitration clause.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: InterGen N.V. v. Grina
Court: United States Court of Appeals, First Circuit.
Headnote: Independent operations prong of test for determining if corporate form may be disregarded looks at such things as (1) whether corporation is operated as separate entity, (2) commingling of funds and other assets, (3) failure to maintain adequate records or minutes, (4) nature of corporation's ownership and control, (5) absence of corporate assets and undercapitalization, (6) use of corporation as mere shell, instrumentality, or conduit of individual or another corporation, (7) disregard of legal formalities and failure to maintain arms-length relationship among related entities, and (8) diversion of corporation's funds or assets to noncorporate uses.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW - Arbitration. Plaintiff was not judicially estopped from asserting that it was not bound by arbitration clause.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: State ex rel. Graeber v. Marion County Landfill, Inc.
Court: Supreme Court of Kansas.
Headnote: District court should consider the following elements before reaching the decision to pierce the corporate veil: (1) undercapitalization of a one-man corporation; (2) failure to observe corporate formalities; (3) nonpayment of dividends; (4) siphoning of corporate funds by the dominant stockholder; (5) nonfunctioning of other officers or directors; (6) absence of corporate records; (7) the use of the corporation as a facade for operations of the dominant stockholder or stockholders; and (8) the use of the corporate entity in promoting injustice or fraud.
Document Preview: ENVIRONMENTAL LAW - Solid Waste. County was liable as guarantor for closure and postclosure operations of private landfill.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: Peschel Family Trust v. Colonna
Court: Supreme Court of Montana.
Headnote: Factors to be considered in determining whether shareholder is alter ego of corporation, for purpose of determining whether to pierce corporate veil and hold shareholder personally liable, include whether shareholder owns all or most of corporation's stock, whether shareholder makes all corporate decisions without consulting other directors or officers, whether shareholder's personal funds are commingled with corporation's funds, where shareholder's personal business records are kept separate from corporation's business records, and whether shareholder admits to third parties that shareholder and corporation are one in same.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Substantial evidence supported decision to pierce corporate veil and hold sole shareholder personally liable for breach of lease.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: Dominguez v. Payne
Court: Court of Appeals of Texas, Corpus Christi–Edinburg.
Headnote: Alter ego is shown from the total dealings of a corporation and an individual, including the degree to which corporate and individual property have been kept separately, the amount of financial interest, ownership, and control that the individual maintains over the corporation, and whether the corporation has been used for personal purposes.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Fact issues existed regarding whether shareholder was alter ego of corporate developer.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: Estate of Lisle v. C.I.R.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Fifth Circuit.
Headnote: Question of whether corporation is alter ego of individual is ultimately determined by examining totality of circumstances, including amount of financial interest individual has in corporation, ownership and control that individual maintains over corporation, and whether corporation has been used for personal purposes.
Document Preview: TAXATION - Income. Income was attributed to taxpayer.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: Goldstein v. Mortenson
Court: Court of Appeals of Texas, Austin.
Headnote: An alter-ego relationship, as basis to pierce corporate veil, may be shown from the total dealings of the corporation and the individual and may include evidence of the degree to which corporate formalities have been followed and corporate and individual property have been kept separately, the amount of financial interest, ownership and control the individual maintains over the corporation, and whether the corporation has been used for personal purposes.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW - Damages. An exemplary damage award exceeded the legal maximum award.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: In re Xyan.Com, Inc.
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, E.D. Pennsylvania.
Headnote: The factors to consider in determining whether the corporate veil can be pierced under Pennsylvania law include the following: (1) a failure to observe corporate formalities; (2) non-payment of corporate dividends; (3) insolvency of the debtor corporation at the time of a significant action or transaction; (4) siphoning of corporate funds by the dominant shareholder; (5) non-functioning of the other officers or directors of the corporation; (6) lack or absence of corporate records; (7) establishment that the corporation is merely a sham for the operations of the dominant stockholder; and (8) undercapitalization of the corporation.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Creditors' committee stated fraud claim under theory of reverse piercing of the corporate veil.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: Miner v. Fashion Enterprises, Inc.
Court: Appellate Court of Illinois, First District, Second Division.
Headnote: To determine whether a unity of interests exists to the extent that the corporate veil should be pierced, courts will look to a number of factors, including whether there is inadequate capitalization, failure to observe corporate formalities, insolvency of the debtor corporation, and absence of corporate records.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Judgment creditor may file a new action to pierce the corporate veil of a judgment debtor.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: In re Transcolor Corp.
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, D. Maryland.
Headnote: Under Maryland law, factors used in analyzing whether a paramount equity should be enforced and the corporate veil pierced include, inter alia, whether the corporation was grossly undercapitalized, the dominant stockholder's siphoning of corporate funds, the absence of corporate records, and the corporation's status as a facade for the stockholders' operations.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Business Relationships. Insider of debtor-corporation was liable for fraud.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: Trustees of Nat. Elevator Industry Pension, Health Benefit and Educational Funds v. Lutyk
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Third Circuit.
Headnote: Under federal alter ego doctrine, factors in determining whether to pierce corporate veil include: (1) gross undercapitalization; (2) failure to observe corporate formalities; (3) nonpayment of dividends; (4) insolvency of debtor corporation; (5) siphoning of funds from debtor corporation by dominant stockholder; (6) nonfunctioning of officers and directors; (7) absence of corporate records; and (8) whether corporation is merely facade for operations of dominant stockholder.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Sole shareholder of bankrupt employer was personally liable for employer's failure to make benefit plan contributions.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: Schlueter v. Carey
Court: Court of Appeals of Texas, Fort Worth.
Headnote: An "alter ego" relationship may be shown from the total dealings of the corporation and the individual, such as evidence of the degree to which corporate and individual property have been kept separate; the amount of financial interest, ownership, and control the individual has maintained over the corporation; and whether the corporation has been used for personal purposes.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Shareholder was liable as corporation's alter ego for injury caused to customer by corporation.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: John T. Callahan & Sons, Inc. v. Dykeman Elec. Co., Inc.
Court: United States District Court, D. Massachusetts.
Headnote: In Massachusetts, the relevant factors a court considers when determining whether to set aside the corporate form are: (1) common ownership; (2) pervasive control; (3) confused intermingling of business assets; (4) thin capitalization; (5) nonobservance of corporate formalities; (6) absence of corporate records; (7) no payment of dividends; (8) insolvency at the time of the litigated transaction; (9) siphoning away of corporation's funds by dominant shareholder; (10) nonfunctioning of officers and directors; (11) use of the corporation for transactions of the dominant shareholders; and (12) use of the corporation in promoting fraud.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Successor Liability. Creditor failed to show that new corporation was liable on mere continuation theory of successor liability.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: Oceanics Schools, Inc. v. Barbour
Court: Court of Appeals of Tennessee.
Headnote: Generally, no one factor is conclusive in determining whether to disregard a corporate entity; rather, the courts typically rely upon a combination of factors in deciding such an issue.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Action to pierce judgment debtor's corporate veil was timely.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: Oceanics Schools, Inc. v. Barbour
Court: Court of Appeals of Tennessee.
Headnote: It is not necessary that all of the Federal Deposit Ins. Corp. v. Allen factors weigh in a plaintiff's favor, in order to justify the piercing of the corporate veil.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Action to pierce judgment debtor's corporate veil was timely.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: Firstar Bank, N.A. v. Faul Chevrolet, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, N.D. Illinois, Eastern Division.
Headnote: In order to find that defendants have unity of interest sufficient to warrant piercing of corporate veil under Illinois law, court should consider: (1) whether corporation has failed to maintain adequate corporate records or to comply with corporate formalities; (2) whether other defendants have commingled corporation's funds or assets; (3) whether corporation was undercapitalized; and (4) whether other defendants have treated assets of corporation as their own.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Automobile dealership's creditor was not entitled to pierce corporate veil.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: S.E.C. v. Hickey
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Ninth Circuit.
Headnote: Under California law, individual's complete lack of ownership of real estate brokerage, which was wholly owned by individual's mother, precluded finding that brokerage was individual's alter ego.
Document Preview: SECURITIES REGULATION - Fraud. Court could freeze assets of nonparty controlled by SEC fraud defendant, to enforce disgorgement.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: Leonard v. McMorris
Court: Supreme Court of Colorado, En Banc.
Headnote: The court considers a variety of factors to determine whether the corporate form should be disregarded by piercing the corporate veil, including: (1) whether the corporation is operated as a separate entity; (2) commingling of funds and other assets; (3) failure to maintain adequate corporate records; (4) the nature of the corporation's ownership and control; (5) absence of corporate assets and undercapitalization; (6) use of the corporation as a mere shell; (7) disregard of legal formalities; and (8) diversion of the corporation's funds or assets to noncorporate uses.
Document Preview: LABOR AND EMPLOYMENT - Hours and Wages. Wage Claim Act does not make corporate officers personally liable for unpaid wages.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: Amoco Production Co. v. Texaco, Inc.
Court: Court of Appeal of Louisiana, Third Circuit.
Headnote: Five factors are considered by courts when determining whether to apply the "alter ego" doctrine, for purposes of piercing the corporate veil: (1) commingling of corporate and shareholder funds; (2) failure to follow statutory formalities for incorporating and transacting corporate affairs; (3) undercapitalization; (4) failure to maintain separate bank accounts and bookkeeping records; and (5) failure to hold regular shareholder and director meetings.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Corporate parent was liable to gas production company for subsidiary's breach of mineral subleases.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: Teamsters Health and Welfare Fund of Philadelphia and Vicinity v. World Transp., Inc.
Court: United States District Court, E.D. Pennsylvania.
Headnote: In determining whether to pierce the corporate veil and impose alter ego liability upon dominant shareholder, the district court considers: (1) gross undercapitalization, (2) failure to observe corporate formalities, (3) non-payment of dividends, (4) insolvency of the debtor corporation, (5) siphoning of funds by the dominant shareholder, (6) non-functioning of other officers and directors, (7) absence of corporate records, and (8) whether the corporation is a mere facade for the operations of dominant shareholder.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Imposition of alter ego liability upon shareholder of corporation was not warranted.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: Teamsters Health and Welfare Fund of Philadelphia and Vicinity v. World Transp., Inc.
Court: United States District Court, E.D. Pennsylvania.
Headnote: Corporation's repayment of legitimate shareholder loans by itself does not constitute siphoning and is insufficient itself to warrant piercing the corporate veil, and imposing alter ego liability upon dominant shareholders for corporate debts, even if the transaction may constitute fraud; however, the repayment of loans from shareholders or other diversion of corporate assets at a time when the company's finances are troubled may strongly indicate siphoning.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Imposition of alter ego liability upon shareholder of corporation was not warranted.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: U.S. v. Union Corp.
Court: United States District Court, E.D. Pennsylvania.
Headnote: Third Circuit alter ego test for piercing the corporate veil requires that a court consider the following factors: 1) gross undercapitalization, 2) failure to observe corporate formalities, 3) nonpayment of dividends, 4) insolvency of debtor corporation, 5) siphoning of funds from the debtor corporation by the dominant stockholder, 6) non-functioning of officers and directors, 7) absence of corporate records, and 8) whether the corporation is merely a facade for the operations of the dominant stockholder.
Document Preview: ENVIRONMENTAL LAW - CERCLA. Past and current owners of contaminated site were responsible parties under CERCLA.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: Imperial Trading Co., Inc. v. Uter
Court: Court of Appeal of Louisiana, First Circuit.
Headnote: Some factors to consider in determining whether to apply alter-ego doctrine to pierce corporate veil include commingling of corporate and shareholder funds, failing to follow statutory formalities for incorporating and transacting corporate affairs, undercapitalization, failing to maintain separate bank accounts and bookkeeping records, and failing to hold regular shareholder and director meetings.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Limited Liability Companies. Trial court properly refused to pierce veils of limited liability companies.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: Acree v. McMahan
Court: Court of Appeals of Georgia.
Headnote: Sole owner's use and control of corporation to promote owner's ends is not a factor in determining whether to pierce corporate veil.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Shareholders. Issue of whether shareholder breached buyout agreement by failing to make payments was for jury.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: Sunset Aviation, Inc. v. DHS Aviation, Inc.
Court: Court of Appeal, First District, Division 5, California.
Headnote: Unity of ownership and interest was present, warranting imposition of alter ego liability, where sole shareholder was also president and only officer of corporation, corporation owned no assets, it did not have an address separate from shareholder's personal residence or office at another company, corporate records were sparse, funds in corporate bank account were occasionally used for shareholder's personal expenditures, and capitalization was inadequate.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Alter ego liability was properly imposed, given undercapitalization of corporation and other factors.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: Sunset Aviation, Inc. v. DHS Aviation, Inc.
Court: Court of Appeal, First District, Division 5, California.
Headnote: Sole shareholder's conduct constituted the kind of bad faith that would make it inequitable for him to hide behind corporate veil, warranting imposition of alter ego liability, where he undercapitalized corporation, he conditioned his loans to corporation on his being the senior secured creditor, thereby subordinating claims of any other creditor to his claims, and he entered stipulated judgment in breach of contract action brought against corporation knowing that there were no funds to satisfy the judgment.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Alter ego liability was properly imposed, given undercapitalization of corporation and other factors.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: Field v. Jennison
Court: Supreme Court of Iowa.
Headnote: The factors to be considered in an attempt to pierce the corporate veil are whether: (1) the corporation is undercapitalized, (2) the corporation lacks separate books, (3) its finances are not kept separate from individual finances, or individual obligations are paid by the corporation, (4) the corporation is used to promote fraud or illegality, (5) corporate formalities are not followed, or (6) the corporation is a mere sham.
Document Preview: LABOR AND EMPLOYMENT - Contracts. Corporate officer who signed employment contract acted behalf of corporation, not in his own right.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: Turner v. Turner
Court: Court of Special Appeals of Maryland.
Headnote: The factors to determine whether a paramount equity should be enforced include, inter alia, whether the corporation was grossly undercapitalized, the dominant stockholder's siphoning of corporate funds, the absence of corporate records, and the corporation's status as a facade for the stockholders' operations.
Document Preview: FAMILY LAW - Spousal Support. Trial court abused its discretion by awarding wife only $2,000 a month in indefinite alimony.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: Nerox Power Systems, Inc. v. M-B Contracting Co., Inc.
Court: Supreme Court of Alaska.
Headnote: There are six factors for determining if a corporation is a "mere instrumentality" of one of its shareholders: (1) whether the shareholder owns all or most of the stock, (2) whether the shareholder subscribed to all of the capital stock or caused the incorporation, (3) whether the corporation is "grossly" undercapitalized, (4) whether the shareholder uses the property of the corporation for his or her own benefit, (5) whether the directors of the corporation act independently of the shareholder, and (6) whether the formal legal requirements of the corporation are observed.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW - Liens. Deeds of trust were equitably subordinated to liens of third-party creditors.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: Hardy v. Brock
Court: Supreme Court of Mississippi.
Headnote: In order to pierce the corporate shield, a plaintiff must prove the following: (1) some frustration of contractual expectations regarding the party to whom he looked for performance; (2) flagrant disregard of corporate formalities by the defendant corporation and its principals; (3) a demonstration of fraud or other equivalent misfeasance on part of corporate shareholder.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Officer could not be held individually liable for alleged misfeasance on part of corporation.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: Community Care Centers, Inc. v. Hamilton
Court: Court of Appeals of Indiana.
Headnote: In deciding whether a party seeking to pierce the corporate veil has met its burden, courts consider whether the party has presented evidence showing: (1) undercapitalization,(2) absence of corporate records, (3) fraudulent representation by corporation shareholders or directors, (4) use of the corporation to promote fraud, injustice, or illegal activities, (5) payment by the corporation of individual obligations, (6) commingling of assets and affairs, (7) failure to observe required corporate formalities, or (8) other shareholder acts or conduct ignoring, controlling, or manipulating the corporate form.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Evidence that corporation transferred its operations informally did not require piercing of corporate veil.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: Interfaith Community Organization v. Honeywell Intern., Inc.
Court: United States District Court, D. New Jersey.
Headnote: Factors for considering whether to pierce corporate veil are: (1) gross undercapitalization; (2) failure to observe corporate formalities; (3) nonpayment of dividends; (4) insolvency of debtor corporation; (5) siphoning of funds from the debtor corporation by the dominant stockholder; (6) nonfunctioning of officers and directors; (7) absence of corporate funds; and (8) whether the corporation is merely a facade for the operations of the dominant stockholder.
Document Preview: ENVIRONMENTAL LAW - CERCLA. Factors weighted against piercing veil to make parent corporation liable for CERCLA cleanup costs.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: Howell v. Hilton Hotels Corp.
Court: Court of Appeals of Texas, Houston (1st Dist.).
Headnote: Alter ego, as a basis for piercing corporate veil, is shown from the total dealings of the corporation and the individual, including the degree to which corporate and individual property have been kept separately, the amount of financial interest, ownership and control the individual maintains over the corporation, and whether the corporation has been used for personal purposes.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Partnerships. Funds paid to alleged partner as profits were not partnership property.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: In re Woolum
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, M.D. Florida, Jacksonville Division.
Headnote: Under Florida law, in deciding whether to disregard corporate entity, courts consider such factors as utilization of corporate assets for payment of personal obligations or investments; failure to maintain either the legal or factual existence of corporate entity; and the general treatment of corporation as sham.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Bankruptcy Estate. Property was not included in estate on constructive trust theory.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: Oliver v. Pinnacle Homes, Inc.
Court: Court of Appeals of Indiana.
Headnote: To decide whether a plaintiff has met the burden necessary to pierce the corporate veil, courts consider whether the plaintiff has presented evidence showing: (1) undercapitalization, (2) absence of corporate records, (3) fraudulent representation by corporation shareholders or directors, (4) use of the corporation to promote fraud, injustice or illegal activities, (5) payment by the corporation of individual obligations, (6) commingling of assets and affairs, (7) failure to observe required corporate formalities, or (8) other shareholder acts or conduct ignoring, controlling, or manipulating the corporate form.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Manufacturer of modular home was not alter ego of builder for purposes of debt liability.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: Albee v. Krasnoff
Court: Court of Appeals of Georgia.
Headnote: Absent some intentional conduct on the part of the individual shareholder to misuse or abuse the corporate form, we will not pierce the corporate veil to hold that individual shareholder liable for the obligations of the corporation.
Document Preview: TORTS - Fraud. Promises by investment firm president did not create confidential relationship with clients.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: Pinebrook Properties, Ltd. v. Brookhaven Lake Property Owners Ass'n
Court: Court of Appeals of Texas, Texarkana.
Headnote: Alter ego is shown from the total dealings of the corporation and the individual, including the degree to which corporate and individual property have been kept separately, the amount of financial interest, ownership and control the individual maintains over the corporation, and whether the corporation has been used for personal purposes.
Document Preview: REAL PROPERTY - Covenants and Restrictions. Landowner could regulate use of land despite restrictive covenant.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: Fairfield Development, Inc. v. Georgetown Woods Sr. Apartments Ltd. Partnership
Court: Court of Appeals of Indiana.
Headnote: In deciding whether the plaintiff has met the burden of piercing the corporate veil, the trial court may consider evidence of the following factors: (1) undercapitalization; (2) absence of corporate records; (3) fraudulent representation by corporation shareholders or directors; (4) use of the corporation to promote fraud, injustice or illegal activities; (5) payment by the corporation of individual obligations; (6) commingling of assets and affairs; (7) failure to observe required corporate formalities; or (8) other shareholder acts or conduct ignoring, controlling, or manipulating the corporate form.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Construction corporation was alter ego of family.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: Fairfield Development, Inc. v. Georgetown Woods Sr. Apartments Ltd. Partnership
Court: Court of Appeals of Indiana.
Headnote: List of factors that a trial court may consider in determining whether to pierce the corporate veil is not necessarily exhaustive, and all factors need not be shown to support a decision to pierce the corporate veil.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Construction corporation was alter ego of family.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: Virtualmagic Asia, Inc. v. Fil-Cartoons, Inc.
Court: Court of Appeal, Fourth District, Division 1, California.
Headnote: Under the alter ego doctrine, the courts consider numerous factors, including inadequate capitalization, commingling of funds and other assets of the two entities, the holding out by one entity that it is liable for the debts of the other, identical equitable ownership in the two entities, use of the same offices and employees, use of one as a mere conduit for the affairs of the other, disregard of corporate formalities, lack of segregation of corporate records, and identical directors and officers.
Document Preview: INTELLECTUAL PROPERTY - Jurisdiction. California had specific jurisdiction over nonresident film animation provider.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: Virtualmagic Asia, Inc. v. Fil-Cartoons, Inc.
Court: Court of Appeal, Fourth District, Division 1, California.
Headnote: No single factor is determinative, and instead a court must examine all the circumstances to determine whether to apply the alter ego doctrine to a corporation's shareholders.
Document Preview: INTELLECTUAL PROPERTY - Jurisdiction. California had specific jurisdiction over nonresident film animation provider.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: Wallace v. Ramon
Court: Court of Appeals of Texas, San Antonio.
Headnote: The corporate fiction is properly disregarded: (1) when the fiction is used as a means of perpetrating fraud; (2) where a corporation is organized and operated as a mere tool or business conduit of another corporation; (3) where the corporate fiction is resorted to as a means of evading an existing legal obligation; (4) where the corporate fiction is employed to achieve or perpetrate monopoly; (5) where the corporate fiction is used to circumvent a statute; and (6) where the corporate fiction is relied upon as a protection of crime or to justify wrong.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW - Contracts. Evidence was sufficient to establish breach of contract in post-answer default judgment.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: Hinkle v. Adams
Court: Court of Appeals of Texas, Texarkana.
Headnote: Alter ego is shown from the total dealings of the corporation and the individual, including the degree to which corporate and individual property have been kept separately, the amount of financial interest, ownership and control the individual maintains over the corporation, and whether the corporation has been used for personal purposes.
Document Preview: HEALTH - Malpractice. Evidence was insufficient to show that physician/shareholder was alter ego of corporate medical center.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: Medlock v. Medlock
Court: Supreme Court of Nebraska.
Headnote: Among the factors which are relevant in determining to disregard the corporate entity are diversion by the shareholder or shareholders of corporate funds or assets to their own or improper uses and the fact that the corporation is a mere facade for the personal dealings of the shareholder and that the operations of the corporation are carried on by the shareholder in disregard of the corporate entity.
Document Preview: FAMILY LAW - Marital Property. Nonprofit religious corporation was former husband's alter ego.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: Medlock v. Medlock
Court: Supreme Court of Nebraska.
Headnote: Legal ownership, while relevant, is not a dispositive factor and does not preclude the finding of alter ego when control of the corporation is otherwise established.
Document Preview: FAMILY LAW - Marital Property. Nonprofit religious corporation was former husband's alter ego.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: In re World Vision Entertainment, Inc.
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, M.D. Florida, Orlando Division.
Headnote: When determining if a corporate veil should be pierced, Tennessee courts examine factors such as the sole ownership or domination of the corporation by one individual, the use of the same office or business location, the employment of the same employees, the use of the corporation as an instrumentality or business conduit for an individual or another corporation, and the diversion of corporate assets by or to a stockholder or another entity.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Avoidance. Commission payments to brokers under investment program were fraudulent and would be avoided.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: Alomang v. Freeport-McMoran, Inc.
Court: Court of Appeal of Louisiana, Fourth Circuit.
Headnote: The following circumstances must be proven to merit the finding that one corporation is the alter ego of another: (1) commingling of corporate and shareholder funds; (2) failure to follow statutory formalities required for incorporation and for the transaction of corporate affairs; (3) undercapitalization; (4) failure to provide separate bank accounts and bookkeeping records; and (5) failure to hold regular shareholder or director meetings. (Per Gorbaty, J., with one judge concurring.)
Document Preview: LITIGATION - Pleading. Foreign nationals failed to plead facts sufficient to pierce corporate veil of parent corporation.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: Yankee Microwave, Inc. v. Petricca Communications Systems, Inc.
Court: Appeals Court of Massachusetts, Berkshire.
Headnote: The relevant factors in applying the doctrine of corporate disregard are: (1) common ownership; (2) pervasive control; (3) confused intermingling of business assets; (4) thin capitalization; (5) nonobservance of corporate formalities; (6) absence of corporate records; (7) no payment of dividends; (8) insolvency at the time of the litigated transaction; (9) siphoning away of corporation's funds by dominant shareholder; (10) nonfunctioning of officers and directors; (11) use of the corporation for transactions of the dominant shareholders; and (12) use of the corporation in promoting fraud.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Insolvent corporation's repayment of advances made by related corporation was not a fraudulent conveyance.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: Cherry Creek Card & Party Shop, Inc. v. Hallmark Marketing Corp.
Court: United States District Court, D. Colorado.
Headnote: Corporate veil may be pierced if: (1) there is such unity of interest and lack of respect given to separate identity of the corporation by its shareholders that personalities and assets of corporation and individuals are indistinct, and (2) adherence to corporate fiction would sanction fraud, promote injustice, or lead to evasion of legal obligations.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW - Arbitration. Non-signatory was not equitably estopped from asserting it was not bound by arbitration clause.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: Cherry Creek Card & Party Shop, Inc. v. Hallmark Marketing Corp.
Court: United States District Court, D. Colorado.
Headnote: Factors considered in determining whether corporation and its stockholders have maintained their separate identities include: (1) whether corporation is operated as separate entity; (2) commingling of funds and other assets; (3) failure to maintain adequate corporate records or minutes; (4) nature of corporation's ownership and control; (5) absence of corporate assets and undercapitalization; (6) use of corporation as mere shell, instrumentality or conduit of individual or another corporation; (7) disregard of legal formalities and failure to maintain arms-length relationship among related entities; and (8) diversion of corporation's funds or assets to noncorporate uses.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW - Arbitration. Non-signatory was not equitably estopped from asserting it was not bound by arbitration clause.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: Fuller v. American Recreational Vehicles
Court: Court of Appeal of Louisiana, Third Circuit.
Headnote: If the foreign corporation is not viable and the individual officers are using it as a shield to conduct their personal activities, a court may be compelled to pierce the corporate veil and permit assertion of personal jurisdiction over the officers.
Document Preview: LITIGATION - Jurisdiction. Nonresident officers of foreign corporation did not have personal contacts with forum state.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: Shanghai Automation Instrument Co., Ltd. v. Kuei
Court: United States District Court, N.D. California.
Headnote: Under California law, factors to consider in determining whether there is unity of interest, warranting piercing of corporate veil, include: inadequate capitalization; commingling of funds and other assets; treating assets of corporation as one's own; unauthorized diversion of corporate assets to non-corporate uses; holding out as personally liable for corporate debts; having sole ownership of all stock in corporation by individual or members of family; contracting with another with intent to avoid performance by using corporation as shield against personal liability; using corporation as mere shell for single venture or business of individual or another corporation; concealing personal business activities; failing to maintain adequate corporate records; disregarding legal formalities; use of same office or business location; and use of corporate entity to procure labor, services or merchandise for another person or entity.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Joint Ventures. Default judgment was entered against fewer than all defendants.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: Comey v. C.I.R.
Court: United States Tax Court.
Headnote: Corporate form may be disregarded, where corporation's purpose is not equivalent of business activity and corporation carries on no business activity.
Document Preview: TAXATION - Income. Taxpayers were liable for tax on stock holdings purportedly transferred to sham corporation.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: Comey v. C.I.R.
Court: United States Tax Court.
Headnote: Corporation that originally had a business purpose or that once engaged in business activity may be disregarded, if corporation subsequently becomes inactive and no longer has a business purpose.
Document Preview: TAXATION - Income. Taxpayers were liable for tax on stock holdings purportedly transferred to sham corporation.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: Stauffacher v. Lone Star Mud, Inc.
Court: Court of Appeals of Texas, Texarkana.
Headnote: To determine whether an alter ego relationship exists, the courts look at the totality of the dealings and relationships between the corporation and the individual; this may include evidence of the degree to which corporate formalities have been followed, whether corporate and individual property have been kept separate, amount of financial interest, ownership, and control the individual maintains over the corporation, and whether the corporation has been used for personal purposes.
Document Preview: LITIGATION - Jurisdiction. For jurisdiction purposes, evidence supported finding that nonresident was alter ego of corporation that operated oil well in forum state.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: Pereira v. Cogan
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: In deciding whether corporation was mere facade, as factor bearing on their alter ego analysis, Delaware courts examine not just the transactions complained of, but potentially many others as well.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Appeals. Court would not certify standing issue for immediate appeal.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: Government of Virgin Islands, Bureau of Internal Revenue v. Lansdale
Court: District Court of the Virgin Islands, Division of St. Croix.
Headnote: Factors to be considered, under Delaware law, in determining whether to pierce corporate veil include whether the dominant shareholders siphoned corporate funds, whether the corporation is a facade for the dominant shareholders, whether a corporation was adequately capitalized and solvent, and whether corporate formalities were followed, including payment of dividends and upkeep of corporate records.
Document Preview: LITIGATION - Jurisdiction. Corporations' acts and omissions could be attributed to owners to satisfy Virgin Islands' long-arm statute.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: Government of Virgin Islands, Bureau of Internal Revenue v. Lansdale
Court: District Court of the Virgin Islands, Division of St. Croix.
Headnote: Some factors relevant to piercing the corporate veil under California law include commingling funds and other assets, unauthorized diversion of corporate funds or assets to other than corporate uses, treatment by individual of corporation's assets as his own, holding out by individual that he is personally liable for corporation's debts, identical equitable ownership in two entities, identification of equitable owners, directors and officers thereof with domination and control of two entities, sole ownership of all of stock in corporation by one individual or members of family, failure to adequately capitalize corporation, total absence of corporate assets and undercapitalization, use of corporation as mere shell, instrumentality or conduit for single venture or business of individual, disregard of legal formalities and failure to maintain arm's length relationships among related entities, diversion of assets from corporation by or to stockholder or other person or entity to detriment of creditors, or manipulation of assets and liabilities between entities so as to concentrate assets in one and liabilities in another, or use of corporation as subterfuge of illegal transactions, and formation and use of corporation to transfer to it existing liability of another person or entity.
Document Preview: LITIGATION - Jurisdiction. Corporations' acts and omissions could be attributed to owners to satisfy Virgin Islands' long-arm statute.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: Shoemaker v. Giacalone
Court: Court of Appeal of Louisiana, Second Circuit.
Headnote: To pierce the corporate veil, or find that a corporation is an alter ego of an individual, courts traditionally look to five factors that, when considered with the totality of the evidence, indicate that the individual and the corporation were not actually separate entities: (1) commingling of corporate and shareholder funds, (2) failure to follow statutory formalities required for incorporation and for the transaction of corporate affairs, (3) undercapitalization, (4) failure to provide separate bank accounts and bookkeeping records, and, (5) failure to hold regular shareholder or director meetings. LSA-R.S. 12:93, subd. B.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Patron injured in brawl did not establish that tavern corporation was sole shareholder's alter ego.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: Middle Tennessee News Co., Inc. v. Charnel of Cincinnati, Inc.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Seventh Circuit.
Headnote: For purposes of determining whether piercing the corporate veil is appropriate under Indiana law, plaintiffs must show that corporate form was so ignored, controlled or manipulated that it was merely instrumentality of another, and that misuse of corporate form would constitute fraud or promote injustice, pursuant to eight-factor test requiring court to balance evidence of (1) undercapitalization, (2) absence of corporate records, (3) fraudulent representation by corporation shareholders or directors, (4) use of corporation to promote fraud, injustice or illegal activities, (5) payment by corporation of individual obligations, (6) commingling of assets and affairs, (7) failure to observe required corporate formalities, and (8) other shareholder acts or conduct ignoring, controlling or manipulating corporate form.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Debtor Protections. Judgment did not violate bankruptcy automatic stay.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: Trustees of Nat. Elevator Industry Pension v. Lutyk
Court: United States District Court, E.D. Pennsylvania.
Headnote: In determining whether to pierce corporate veil and impose personal liability on shareholder, District Court considers, inter alia, whether corporation is grossly undercapitalized for its purposes, failure to observe corporate formalities, nonpayment of dividends, insolvency of debtor corporation at the time, siphoning of funds of the corporation by dominant stockholder, nonfunctioning of other officers or directors, absent corporate record, fact that the corporation is merely a facade for operations of dominant stockholder or stockholders, and whether situation presents element of injustice or fundamental unfairness.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Sole shareholder was liable for unpaid contributions to ERISA plans.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: Trustees of Nat. Elevator Industry Pension v. Lutyk
Court: United States District Court, E.D. Pennsylvania.
Headnote: Repayment of legitimate shareholder loans by itself does not constitute siphoning of funds from corporation and is insufficient to pierce corporate veil under alter ego theory, even if transaction may constitute fraud, but repayment of loans from shareholders or other diversion of corporate assets at time when company's finances are troubled may strongly indicate siphoning.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Sole shareholder was liable for unpaid contributions to ERISA plans.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: Trustees of Nat. Elevator Industry Pension v. Lutyk
Court: United States District Court, E.D. Pennsylvania.
Headnote: When determining if corporation is merely facade for operations of dominant stockholder or stockholders, as would support piercing corporate veil under alter ego theory, one factor is whether shareholder owns title to necessary assets, indicating intent to protect such assets from business misfortunes.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Sole shareholder was liable for unpaid contributions to ERISA plans.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: Fiumetto v. Garrett Enterprises, Inc.
Court: Appellate Court of Illinois, Second District.
Headnote: Several factors are relevant in determining whether a sufficient unity of interest exists between a corporation and an individual to warrant piercing the corporate veil, including: (1) inadequate capitalization; (2) failure to issue stock; (3) failure to observe corporate formalities; (4) nonpayment of dividends; (5) insolvency of the debtor corporation at the time; (6) nonfunctioning of other officers or directors; (7) absence of corporate records; and (8) whether the corporation is a mere facade for the operation of dominant stockholders.
Document Preview: LABOR AND EMPLOYMENT - Unemployment Compensation. Private right of action for retaliatory discharge for claiming unemployment compensation could be implied.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: Fiumetto v. Garrett Enterprises, Inc.
Court: Appellate Court of Illinois, Second District.
Headnote: Generally, the decision to disregard the corporate entity will not rest upon a single factor regarding unity of interest between a corporation and an individual.
Document Preview: LABOR AND EMPLOYMENT - Unemployment Compensation. Private right of action for retaliatory discharge for claiming unemployment compensation could be implied.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: Pearson v. Component Technology Corp.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Third Circuit.
Headnote: Under the alter ego test for determining whether a corporate veil should be pierced, a court must look to the factors of gross undercapitalization, failure to observe corporate formalities, nonpayment of dividends, insolvency of the debtor corporation, siphoning of funds from the debtor corporation by the dominant stockholder, nonfunctioning of officers and directors, absence of corporate records, and whether the corporation is merely a facade for the operations of the dominant stockholder.
Document Preview: LABOR AND EMPLOYMENT - Layoffs. Secured creditor was not liable under WARN for employer's unnoticed plant closure.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: Nichols v. Pabtex, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, E.D. Texas, Beaumont Division.
Headnote: Texas courts use a heavily fact specific, multifactor test in determining alter ego status; in applying these factors, courts are concerned with the reality and not form, with how the corporation operated and the individual defendant's relationship to that corporation.
Document Preview: LABOR AND EMPLOYMENT - Workers' Compensation. Employee, who already received worker's compensation benefits, was not precluded from recovering under FELA.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: Mallard Automotive Group, Ltd. v. LeClair Management Corp.
Court: United States District Court, D. Nevada.
Headnote: In determining whether there was sufficient unity of interest between individual and corporation to render corporation liable for debts and obligations of individual under reverse piercing theory under Nevada law, court should consider: (1) commingling of funds: (2) undercapitalization; (3) unauthorized diversion of funds; (4) treatment of corporate assets as individual's own; and (5) failure to observe corporate formalities.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Fact issues remained as to whether government could hold corporation liable for individual's taxes.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: Soerries v. Dancause
Court: Court of Appeals of Georgia.
Headnote: Because the cardinal rule of corporate law is that a corporation possesses a legal existence separate and apart from that of its officers and shareholders, the mere operation of corporate business does not render one personally liable for corporate acts.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Evidence was sufficient to support verdict piercing corporate veil in dramshop case.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: Carter Enterprises, Inc. v. Ashland Specialty Co., Inc.
Court: United States District Court, S.D. West Virginia.
Headnote: Piercing the corporate veil to hold corporation's owner responsible for corporation's liabilities involves examination of relationship between corporation and its owner and of degree to which corporation observes, vel non, formalities required of it by state; if court finds that a blurring of line between corporation and its owner exists and that equity demands it, court will conclude that what appears to be two separate entities existing in parallel is, for certain purposes, a single entity.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Claims. Debtor-corporation was liable, on successor liability theory, for debts of sole proprietorship.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: D.S.I. v. Natare Corp.
Court: Court of Appeals of Indiana.
Headnote: In determining whether to pierce the corporate veil, the Court of Appeals will examine several factors, including the following: (1) undercapitalization; (2) absence of corporate records; (3) fraudulent representations by corporate shareholders or directors; (4) use of the corporation to promote fraud, injustice or illegal activities; (5) payment by the corporation of individual obligations; (6) commingling of assets and affairs; (7) failure to observe required corporate formalities; or (8) other shareholder acts or conduct ignoring, controlling, or manipulating the corporate form.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Swimming pool business's corporate veil was pierced to hold owner liable for frivolous suit sanctions.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: Victory Lake Marine, Inc. v. Velduis
Court: Court of Appeals of Nebraska.
Headnote: Among the factors which are relevant in determining to disregard the corporate entity on the basis of fraud are: (1) grossly inadequate capitalization; (2) insolvency of the debtor corporation at the time the debt is incurred; (3) diversion by the shareholder or shareholders of corporate funds or assets to their own or other improper uses; and (4) the fact that the corporation is a mere facade for the personal dealings of the shareholder and that the operations of the corporation are carried on by the shareholder in disregard of the corporate entity.
