Document Preview: REAL PROPERTY - Landlord and Tenant. Fact issues regarding corporate tenant precluded summary judgment against officers personally.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: Rio Grande Valley Gas Co. v. City of Edinburg
Court: Court of Appeals of Texas, Corpus Christi-Edinburg.
Headnote: Prospect that a claimant will not be able to collect a judgment unless the corporate form is disregarded is part of the justification for doctrines such as alter ego and single business enterprise; that does not mean, however, that a claimant may not pursue theories for piercing the corporate veil at the same time that basic liability issues are litigated.
Document Preview: ENERGY AND UTILITIES - Oil and Gas. Liability for franchisee's conduct extended throughout natural gas suppliers' corporate family.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: In re Paques, Inc.
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, E.D. Pennsylvania.
Headnote: Factors which weigh in favor of piercing corporate veil include the following: failure to observe corporate formalities; non-payment of dividends; the insolvency of corporation; siphoning off of funds of corporation by dominant shareholder; non-functioning officers or directors; absence of corporate records; and fact that corporation is merely facade for operations of dominant shareholder. or stockholders.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Jurisdiction. Court could exercise personal jurisdiction over debtor's foreign corporate parent.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: Attorney General v. M.C.K., Inc.
Court: Supreme Judicial Court of Massachusetts, Suffolk.
Headnote: The relevant factors in determining whether corporate entity may be disregarded are (1) common ownership; (2) pervasive control; (3) confused intermingling of business assets; (4) thin capitalization; (5) nonobservance of corporate formalities; (6) absence of corporate records; (7) no payment of dividends; (8) insolvency at the time of the litigated transaction; (9) siphoning away of corporation's funds by dominant shareholder; (10) nonfunctioning of officers and directors; (11) use of the corporation for transactions of the dominant shareholders; and (12) use of the corporation in promoting fraud.
Document Preview: HEALTH - Residential Facilities. Sale of nursing home could include real property owned by related entity.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: Dews v. Ratterree
Court: Court of Appeals of Georgia.
Headnote: Because the cardinal rule of corporate law is that a corporation possesses a legal existence separate and apart from that of its officers and shareholders, the mere operation of corporate business does not render one personally liable for corporate acts, and in determining whether to pierce the corporate veil, sole ownership of a corporation by one person or another corporation is not a factor, and neither is the fact that the sole owner uses and controls it to promote his ends, but instead there must be some evidence of abuse of the corporate form, and the plaintiff must show that the defendant disregarded the separate entities by commingling on an interchangeable or joint basis or confusing the otherwise separate properties records or control.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Question of whether corporate veil of garage door company should be pierced in tort action was for jury.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: Hamilton v. AAI Ventures, L.L.C.
Court: Court of Appeal of Louisiana, First Circuit.
Headnote: Failure of shareholder to conduct business on a corporate footing, such that court can pierce corporate veil, can occur if shareholder disregarded corporate formalities to such an extent that shareholder and corporation became indistinguishable, or such unity existed that separate individualities ceased and corporation was operated as "alter ego" of shareholder; indicia of such disregard include commingling of corporate and shareholder funds, failing to follow statutory formalities for incorporating and transacting corporate affairs, undercapitalization, failing to maintain separate bank accounts and bookkeeping records, and failing to hold regular shareholder and director meetings.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Evidence supported trial court's piercing of corporate veil.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: LFC Marketing Group, Inc. v. Loomis
Court: Supreme Court of Nevada.
Headnote: Essence of alter ego doctrine, which allows piercing of the corporate shield, is to do justice whenever it appears that the protections provided by the corporate form are being abused.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Alter ego doctrine permitted reaching corporate assets to satisfy judgment against controlling individual.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: LFC Marketing Group, Inc. v. Loomis
Court: Supreme Court of Nevada.
Headnote: Following factors, though not conclusive, may indicate the existence of an alter ego relationship: (1) commingling of funds; (2) undercapitalization; (3) unauthorized diversion of funds; (4) treatment of corporate assets as the individual's own; and (5) failure to observe corporate formalities.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Alter ego doctrine permitted reaching corporate assets to satisfy judgment against controlling individual.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: LFC Marketing Group, Inc. v. Loomis
Court: Supreme Court of Nevada.
Headnote: Absence of corporate ownership by individual debtor does not automatically preclude application of reverse piercing; circumstances of each case and interests of justice control.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Alter ego doctrine permitted reaching corporate assets to satisfy judgment against controlling individual.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: Sonora Diamond Corp. v. Superior Court
Court: Court of Appeal, Fifth District, California.
Headnote: Among factors to be considered in applying alter ego doctrine are commingling of funds and other assets of the two entities, the holding out by one entity that it is liable for the debts of the other, identical equitable ownership in the two entities, use of the same offices and employees, use of one as a mere shell or conduit for the affairs of the other, inadequate capitalization, disregard of corporate formalities, lack of segregation of corporate records, and identical directors and officers.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Jurisdiction. Canadian parent corporation of Nevada subsidiary was not subject to personal jurisdiction.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: Hayes v. Collins
Court: Court of Appeals of Georgia.
Headnote: Sole ownership of a corporation by one person is not a factor in determining whether the corporate arrangement was a sham, so as to justify piercing the corporate veil, and neither is the fact that the sole owner uses and controls it to promote her ends.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Sole shareholder could not be held liable for corporate debt despite her adulterous affair with lender.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: Godwin Realty Associates v. CATV Enterprises, Inc.
Court: Supreme Court, Appellate Division, First Department, New York.
Headnote: The stripping of corporate assets by shareholders to render the corporation judgment proof constitutes a fraud or wrong justifying piercing the corporate veil.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Evidence supported piercing of the corporate veil.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: Eastern Minerals & Chemicals Co. v. Mahan
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Third Circuit.
Headnote: Factors considered under Pennsylvania law with respect to the alter ego theory for piercing the corporate veil include, but are not limited to, the following: failure to observe corporate formalities, non-payment of dividends, insolvency of debtor corporation, siphoning the funds from corporation by dominant shareholders, non-functioning of other officers and directors, absence of corporate records, whether the corporation is a mere facade for the operations of a common shareholder or shareholders, and gross undercapitalization.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Judgment. Claim preclusion did not bar creditor's claim against debtor's sole shareholder.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: In re Computer Engineering Associates, Inc.
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, D. Massachusetts.
Headnote: Factors that New York courts consider in deciding whether to pierce corporate veil are as follows: (1) whether corporate formalities were observed; (2) whether capitalization was adequate; (3) whether funds were put in and taken out of corporation for personal rather than corporate purposes; (4) whether there is overlap in ownership, officers, directors and personnel; (5) whether corporate entities share common office space, address and telephone numbers; (6) amount of business discretion displayed by the allegedly dominated corporation; (7) whether the alleged dominator deals with dominated corporation at arms length; (8) whether corporation is treated as independent profit center; (9) whether others pay or guarantee debts of dominated corporation; and (10) whether corporation in question had property that was used by the alleged dominator as if it were his/her own.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Avoidance. Joint deposit arrangement was not absolute transfer of debtor-contractor's interest in payments.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: In re Computer Engineering Associates, Inc.
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, D. Massachusetts.
Headnote: Among factors that Massachusetts courts consider in deciding whether to pierce corporate veil are whether corporation (1) failed to enjoy sufficient capitalization to support corporate undertaking; (2) failed to observe corporate formalities; (3) failed to pay dividends; (4) was insolvent at time of relevant transaction; (5) diverted corporate funds to dominant shareholders; (6) had nonfunctioning corporate directors and officers other than the shareholders; (7) failed to maintain corporate records; or (8) was used for transactions of dominant shareholders and/or for fraudulent scheme.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Avoidance. Joint deposit arrangement was not absolute transfer of debtor-contractor's interest in payments.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: Aluminum Chemicals (Bolivia), Inc. v. Bechtel Corp.
Court: Court of Appeals of Texas, Texarkana.
Headnote: Alter ego, as a basis for disregarding the corporate fiction, is shown from the total dealings of the corporation and the individual, including the degree to which corporate and individual property have been kept separately, the amount of financial interest, ownership and control the individual maintains over the corporation, and whether the corporation has been used for personal purposes.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Concepts of alter ego and joint enterprise are not different ways of describing same legal issue.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: Backuswalcott v. Common Ground Community HDFC, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: To determine whether a corporation is the alter ego of another, a variety of factors are examined, including: the sharing of a common office, staff, and ownership, the intermingling of funds, the treatment of the corporations as one, not separate, profit centers, the absence of formalities and paraphernalia of corporate existence, and any inadequate capitalization.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW - Debt Collection. Not-for-profit corporation fell within FDCPA's affiliate exemption.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: United Food & Commercial Workers Union v. Fleming Foods East, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, D. New Jersey.
Headnote: When determining whether facts of particular case warrant piercing of corporate veil based on alter ego theory, court should consider whether corporation is grossly undercapitalized for its purposes, failure to observe corporate formalities, non-payment of dividends, insolvency of debtor corporation at time, siphoning funds of corporation by dominant officers or directors, absence of corporate records, and fact that corporation is merely facade for operations of dominant stockholder or stockholders.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Wholesale food distributor was alter ego of retail store in determining its ERISA liability.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: Williams v. Vanaria
Court: Massachusetts Appellate Division, District Court Department, Northern District.
Headnote: Determination to disregard corporate form of a closely-held corporation must be based on the following factors: (1) common ownership, (2) pervasive control, (3) confused intermingling of business activity, assets or management, (4) thin capitalization, (5) non-observance of corporate formalities, (6) absence of corporate records, (7) no payment of dividends, (8) insolvency at time of litigated transaction, (9) siphoning away of corporate assets by dominant shareholders, (10) nonfunctioning of officers and directors, (11) use of corporation for transactions of dominant shareholders, and (12) use of corporation in promoting fraud.-Williams v. Vanaria.
Document Preview: This is an action against a corporate employer and individual officers of the corporation to recover payment allegedly due under the plaintiff's employment agreement for expenses he incurred. The record indicates that individual defendants Steven and Robert Vanaria were officers and directors of defendant Vanaria Contracting Co., Inc. (Vanaria), a Massachusetts corporation primarily engaged in the construction business of commercial site excavation. At some point in the mid 1980's, plaintiff Robert Williams became employed by Vanaria as a truck driver. He received an hourly wage, plus gasoline and other expenses for a truck that he drove for the company and between his home and Vanaria job sites. The plaintiff's wages and expense reimbursements were at all times paid by Vanaria corporate checks drawn on Vanaria corporate accounts. The plaintiff was listed as an employee on Vanaria's books, and the required taxes, insurance and other payroll deductions were taken by...

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: Hale Propeller, L.L.C. v. Ryan Marine Prod. Pty., Ltd.
Court: United States District Court, D. Connecticut.
Headnote: Factors to consider in determining whether corporation is dominated, for purpose of veil-piercing inquiry, include: (1) absence of corporate formalities; (2) inadequate capitalization; (3)whether funds are put in and taken out of corporation for personal rather than corporate purposes; (4) overlapping ownership, officers, directors, personnel; (5) common office space, address, phones; (6) amount of business discretion by allegedly dominated corporation; (7) whether corporations dealt with each other at arm's length; (8) whether corporations are treated as independent profit centers; (9) payment or guarantee of debts of dominated corporation; (10) whether dominated corporation had property that was used by other as if it were its own; and (11) post-tort activity conducted to strip corporation of assets in anticipation of impending legal liability.
Document Preview: LITIGATION - Jurisdiction. Veil was pierced, subjecting corporate principal to personal jurisdiction.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: In re AVN Corp.
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, W.D. Tennessee, Western Division.
Headnote: Requirements for piercing the corporate veil under Nevada law are as follows: (1) corporation must be influenced and governed by the person asserted to be its alter ego, (2) there must be such unity of interest and ownership that one is inseparable from the other, and (3) the facts must be such that adherence to the fiction of separate entity would, under the circumstances, sanction a fraud or promote injustice.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Claims. Interests of fairness required court to give claimant chance to amend claim.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: In re SunSport, Inc.
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, E.D. Virginia, Richmond Division.
Headnote: Under Virginia law, there is no single rule or criterion which is to be applied to determine whether piercing the corporate veil is justified.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Business Relationships. Successor liability would be imposed on company that acquired Chapter 7 debtor's assets prepetition.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: In re SunSport, Inc.
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, E.D. Virginia, Richmond Division.
Headnote: To show, under Virginia law, that corporate entity was the alter ego, alias, stooge, or dummy of the individual sought to be charged personally, plaintiff may offer evidence that defendant has exercised undue domination and control over the corporation, such that the separate personalities of the corporation and individual no longer exist and to adhere to that separateness would work an injustice; relevant to this inquiry is evidence of whether defendant observed corporate formalities, kept corporate records, whether there were other officers and directors, and whether personal assets were commingled with corporate assets.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Business Relationships. Successor liability would be imposed on company that acquired Chapter 7 debtor's assets prepetition.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: In re Marriage of Ballstaedt
Court: Supreme Court of Iowa.
Headnote: Factors which would support piercing the corporate veil include: (1) undercapitalization of the corporation; (2) lack of separate books for the corporation; (3) corporate finances are not kept separate from individual finances, or individual obligations are paid by the corporation; (4) the corporation is used to promote fraud or illegality; (5) corporate formalities are not followed; and (6) the corporation is a mere sham.
Document Preview: FAMILY LAW - Child Support. Payments from purchaser of husband's business to him personally were subject to income withholding.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: Brevet Intern., Inc. v. Great Plains Luggage Co.
Court: Supreme Court of South Dakota.
Headnote: Factors to consider when determining whether equity demands piercing the corporate veil include (1) undercapitalization, (2) failure to observe corporate formalities, (3) absence of corporate records, (4) payment by the corporation of individual obligations, (5) fraudulent misrepresentation by corporate directors, and (6) use of the corporation to promote fraud, injustice, or illegality; first four factors may be grouped in "separate corporate identity" prong, while final two may be grouped in "fraud or inequitable consequences" prong.
Document Preview: TORTS - Fraud. Fact issues precluded summary judgment on consulting firm's fraud claim.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: Autrey v. 22 Texas Services Inc.
Court: United States District Court, S.D. Texas, Galveston Division.
Headnote: Under Pennsylvania law, factors to be considered in determining whether to disregard the corporate form to hold corporate principals liable for wrongdoing include, but are not limited to, undercapitalization, failure to adhere to corporate formalities, substantial intermingling of corporate and personal affairs, and use of the corporate form to commit a fraud.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Triable issues regarding capitalization precluded summary judgment against corporate principals.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: In re RBGSC Inv. Corp.
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, E.D. Pennsylvania, Philadelphia Division.
Headnote: Under Pennsylvania law, corporate veil can be pierced only when the person in control of corporation uses his/her control of corporation solely to further his/her personal interests.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Leases and Contracts. Debtor's rejection of executory contract terminated its obligations thereunder.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: In re RBGSC Inv. Corp.
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, E.D. Pennsylvania, Philadelphia Division.
Headnote: Factors for court to consider in determining whether corporate veil can be pierced, each of which must be proven by preponderance of evidence, include: (1) a failure to observe corporate formalities; (2) non-payment of corporate dividends; (3) insolvency of debtor corporation at time of significant action or transaction; (4) siphoning off of corporate funds by dominant shareholder; (5) non-functioning of other officers or directors of corporation; (6) lack or absence of corporate records; (7) establishment that corporation is merely a sham for the operations of dominant stockholder(s); and (8) undercapitalization of corporation.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Leases and Contracts. Debtor's rejection of executory contract terminated its obligations thereunder.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: Pearson v. Component Technology Corp.
Court: United States District Court, W.D. Pennsylvania.
Headnote: Factors to be considered for piercing the corporate veil under alter ego theory include: (1) gross undercapitalization; (2) failure to observe corporate formalities; (3) failure to pay dividends; (4) insolvency of debtor corporation; (5) siphoning funds by dominant stockholder; (6) nonfunctioning officers or directors; (7) absence of corporate records; (8) intermingling of funds; (9) fact that subservient corporation is merely facade for operations of dominant stockholder; and (10) finding of fraud or fundamental unfairness.
Document Preview: LABOR AND EMPLOYMENT - Layoffs. Secured creditor was not liable for failing to inform debtor's employees of plant closure.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: Pearson v. Component Technology Corp.
Court: United States District Court, W.D. Pennsylvania.
Headnote: No single criterion is dispositive as to whether a corporate veil should be pierced, and list of ten factors to consider when undertaking such analysis is not exhaustive.
Document Preview: LABOR AND EMPLOYMENT - Layoffs. Secured creditor was not liable for failing to inform debtor's employees of plant closure.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: De Castro v. Sanifill, Inc.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, First Circuit.
Headnote: In determining whether to disregard the corporate form, courts normally conduct a highly fact-specific inquiry, including, inter alia, consideration of: the extent to which a subsidiary may have disregarded corporate formalities; the degree of control exercised by the parent over the day-to-day operations of the subsidiary; overlap in ownership, officers, directors, and personnel; and whether the subsidiary was adequately capitalized, and adequacy of capital is determined within the context of the relevant corporate purposes and activities.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Parent and Subsidiary. Piercing corporate veil not warranted.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: Lewis v. Central Oklahoma Medical Group, Inc.
Court: Court of Civil Appeals of Oklahoma, Division No. 1.
Headnote: In determining whether one corporation is simply the instrumentality of another corporation and should be treated as one corporation for the purpose of tort law, court considers whether: (1) the parent corporation owns most or all of the stock, (2) the corporations have common officers or directors, (3) the parent provides financing to the subsidiary, (4) the dominant corporation subscribes to all the other's stock, (5) the subordinate corporation is under capitalized, (6) the parent pays the salaries, expenses or losses of the subsidiary, (7) a great deal of business is with parent corporation or assets of the former were conveyed to the other corporation, (8) the parent refers to the subsidiary as a division or department, (9) the subsidiary follows directions from the parent's officers or directors, (10) legal formalities for keeping the entities separate are observed.
Document Preview: HEALTH - Malpractice. Fact questions precluded summary judgment for health maintenance organization (HMO) and its parent.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: Sign of the Surf, Inc. v. Commissioner of Revenue
Court: Appeals Court of Massachusetts, Suffolk.
Headnote: Personal financial problems of a corporate officer cannot be treated legally as reasonable cause for invading corporate assets needed to pay the corporation's creditors.
Document Preview: TAXATION - Collection. Restaurant was not entitled to abatement of penalties for delinquent payment of meals tax.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: Pointer (U.S.A.), Inc. v. H & D Foods Corp.
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: In determining whether to pierce corporation veil, under Massachusetts law, courts are to consider whether there was (1) majority ownership and pervasive control of the affairs of the corporation, (2) thin capitalization, (3) nonobservance of corporate formalities or absence of corporate records, (4) no payment of dividends, (5) nonfunctioning of officers and directors, (6) insolvency of the corporation at the time of the litigated transaction, (7) siphoning of corporate funds or intermingling of corporate and personal funds by the dominant shareholder(s), (8) use of the corporation for transactions of the dominant shareholder(s), and (9) use of the corporation in promoting fraud.
Document Preview: Provider of credit to corporation engaged in importation of seafood sued sole shareholder, seeking to pierce corporate veil after corporation became insolvent and went out of business. Parties cross moved for summary judgment. The District Court, Griesa, J., held that: (1) provider's knowledge that corporation was short of capital precluded veil piercing, and (2) shareholder did not misuse corporate form by temporarily taking money from corporation to finance real estate venture of another corporation. Summary judgment for shareholder.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: U.S. v. Scherping
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Eighth Circuit.
Headnote: Under Minnesota law, determination of whether an entity is the alter ego of an individual entails two-step analysis: first, court considers the relationship between the individual and the entity, focusing on such factors as the failure to observe corporate formalities, nonpayment of dividends, siphoning of funds by the individual, absence of records for the entity, and the existence of the entity as merely a facade for the individual, and, second, court considers the relationship between the entity and the party that seeks to disregard it, disregarding entity only if it has operated in a fraudulent or unjust manner toward that party.
Document Preview: Government brought collection action against individuals and two business trusts, seeking foreclosure of its tax liens upon defendants' real property. The United States District Court for the District of Minnesota, Paul A. Magnuson, Chief Judge, granted summary judgment for government, and defendants appealed. The Court of Appeals, McMillian, Circuit Judge, held that: (1) action was not barred by statute of limitations; (2) reverse piercing of corporate veil was warranted to hold trusts liable for individuals' tax liabilities; and (3) individuals' transfers of property to trusts were fraudulent conveyances. Affirmed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: U.S. v. Scherping
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Eighth Circuit.
Headnote: Under Minnesota law, disregard of the corporate entity requires not only that a number of factors be present, such as failure to observe corporate formalities, nonpayment of dividends, siphoning of funds by the individual, absence of records for the entity, and the existence of the entity as merely a facade for the individual, but also that there be an element of injustice or fundamental unfairness.
Document Preview: Government brought collection action against individuals and two business trusts, seeking foreclosure of its tax liens upon defendants' real property. The United States District Court for the District of Minnesota, Paul A. Magnuson, Chief Judge, granted summary judgment for government, and defendants appealed. The Court of Appeals, McMillian, Circuit Judge, held that: (1) action was not barred by statute of limitations; (2) reverse piercing of corporate veil was warranted to hold trusts liable for individuals' tax liabilities; and (3) individuals' transfers of property to trusts were fraudulent conveyances. Affirmed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: House v. 22 Texas Services, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, S.D. Texas, Galveston Division.
Headnote: Factors to be considered in disregarding the corporate form under Pennsylvania law include undercapitalization, failure to adhere to corporate formalities, substantial intermingling of corporate and personal affairs, and use of the corporate form to commit a fraud.
Document Preview: Estate and survivor of Texas nursing home resident whose death allegedly resulted from negligence of nursing home staff and administration brought wrongful death action against Texas limited partnership that owned nursing home, nursing home's non-resident manager, non-resident corporation that was manager's general partner, and various non-resident individuals who were officers and/or limited partners in entities in question. Defendants moved to dismiss for lack of personal jurisdiction. The District Court, Kent, J., held that: (1) court had specific personal jurisdiction over entities in question; (2) court could pierce corporate veils to attribute corporations' contacts with Texas to their shareholding officers; (3) limited partners' involvement with nursing home operations in Texas were sufficient to warrant exercise of personal jurisdiction; but (4) non-share-holding corporate officers were entitled to protection under fiduciary shield doctrine. Motions granted in part and...

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: 66, Inc. v. Crestwood Commons Redevelopment Corp.
Court: Supreme Court of Missouri, En Banc.
Headnote: Conduct other than fraud that may justify piercing the corporate veil includes the violation of statutory duties and undercapitalization.
Document Preview: REAL PROPERTY - Eminent Domain. Owners of uncapitalized redevelopment corporation were liable for damages to landowner when condemnation was abandoned.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: Raber v. Osprey Alaska, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, M.D. Florida, Tampa Division.
Headnote: Under Florida law, piercing of corporate veil is warranted where plaintiff pleads that a corporation is the instrumentality of the defendant and that the defendant engaged in improper conduct by failing to observe corporate formalities, by commingling funds of the corporation with funds of other corporations and with personal funds, by using the assets of the corporation for his own personal use, by failing to adequately capitalize the corporation, and by using the corporate form to avoid liability.
Document Preview: Purchasers of corporation sued sellers for breach of contract and fraud. Seller moved to dismiss for failure to state claim. The District Court, Kovachevich, Chief Judge, held that: (1) purchaser stated claim despite lack of contractual privity with seller; (2) averment that conditions precedent had been satisfied was not required in complaint; and (3) complaint stated fraud claim with sufficient particularity. Motion denied.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: In re Erdman
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, D. North Dakota.
Headnote: In order to pierce corporate veil under North Dakota law, party must establish a confluence of several factors in a specific eight-factor list, as well an element of injustice, inequity or fundamental unfairness if corporate veil is not pierced; eight factors which support corporate veil piercing are as follows: (1) that corporation is insufficiently capitalized for purpose of the corporate undertaking; (2) that there has been a failure to observe corporate formalities; (3) nonpayment of dividends; (4) insolvency of debtor corporation at time of transaction in question; (5) siphoning of funds by the dominant shareholder; (6) nonfunctioning of other officers and directors; (7) absence of corporate records; and (8) existence of corporation merely as facade for individual dealings.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Corporate veil could be pierced to hold debtors personally liable on nondischargeable loan.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: GAVCO, Inc. v. Chem-Trend Inc.
Court: United States District Court, W.D. North Carolina, Charlotte Division.
Headnote: Under North Carolina law, factors considered in applying "domination and control"' test, in order to determine whether corporation is mere instrumentality, include: (1) whether corporation was grossly undercapitalized for purposes of corporate undertaking; (2) failure to observe corporate formalities; (3) non-payment of dividends; (4) insolvency of debtor corporation at time; (5) siphoning of funds of corporation by dominant stockholder; (6) non-functioning of other officers or directors; (7) absence of corporate records; and (8) fact that corporation is merely a facade for operations of dominant stockholder or stockholders.
Document Preview: Independent sales representative sued manufacturer for unpaid sales commissions following termination of parties' contract. Manufacturer counterclaimed for, inter alia, breach of contract, unfair trade practices, and conspiracy. Representative moved for summary judgment. The District Court, Horn, United States Chief Magistrate Judge, held that: (1) depositions taken in related lawsuit to which representative was not a party were inadmissible; (2) contract required payment of earned commissions regardless of representative's outside activities; (3) issue of fact existed as to whether outside activities constituted termination by malfeasance under North Carolina sales commission statute; (4) issue of fact existed as to whether corporation was representative's alter ego; and (5) issue of fact existed as to whether outside activities constituted breach. Motion granted in part.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: Securities Investor Protection Corp. v. Stratton Oakmont, Inc.
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: Factors considered in the Second Circuit to determine whether disregarding corporate separateness is an appropriate remedy are as follows: (1) absence of formalities and paraphernalia that are part and parcel of corporate existence, such as issuance of stock, election of directors, and keeping of corporate records and the like, (2) inadequate capitalization, (3) whether funds are put in and taken out of corporation for personal rather than corporate purposes, (4) overlap in ownership, officers, directors, and personnel, (5) common office space, address, and telephone numbers of corporate entities, (6) amount of business discretion displayed by allegedly dominated corporation, (7) whether the related corporations deal with dominated corporation at arms length, (8) whether corporations are treated as independent profit centers, (9) payment or guarantee of debts of dominated corporation by other corporations in the group, and (10) whether corporation in question had property that was used by other of the corporations as if it were its own.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Business Relationships. SIPA trustee's reverse veil-piercing theory survived dismissal motions.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: Castillo v. M.E.K. Const., Inc.
Court: Court of Appeals of Mississippi.
Headnote: To pierce the veil of a corporation, the party seeking to impose liability on the corporation's shareholders must demonstrate: (1) some frustration of contractual expectations regarding the party to whom he looked for performance; (2) the flagrant disregard of corporate formalities by the defendant corporation and its principals; (3) a demonstration of fraud or other equivalent misfeasance on the part of the corporate shareholder.
Document Preview: LABOR AND EMPLOYMENT - Workers' Compensation. General contractor and subcontractor were entitled to immunity under exclusive remedy provision of workers' compensation statute.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: Residential Warranty Corp. v. Bancroft Homes Greenspring Valley, Inc.
Court: Court of Special Appeals of Maryland.
Headnote: The factors used in analyzing whether a paramount equity should be enforced, so as to warrant piercing the corporate veil, include, inter alia, whether the corporation was grossly undercapitalized, the dominant stockholder's siphoning of corporate funds, the absence of corporate records, and the corporation's status as a facade for the stockholders' operations.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Mere speculation regarding fraud was insufficient to pierce corporate veil.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: Cadle v. Graubart
Court: Court of Appeals of Texas, Beaumont.
Headnote: As basis for disregarding corporate fiction, alter ego is shown from the total dealings of the corporation and the individual, including the degree to which corporate formalities have been followed and corporate and individual property have been kept separately, the amount of financial interest, ownership and control the individual maintains over the corporation, and whether the corporation has been used for personal purposes
Document Preview: LITIGATION - Jurisdiction. Trial court did not have personal jurisdiction over nonresident individual defendant.

Title: Hall v. Timmons
Court: Court of Appeals of Texas, Beaumont.
Headnote: Alter ego, as basis for disregarding corporate fiction, is shown from the total dealings of the corporation and the individual, including the degree to which corporate and individual property have been kept separately, the amount of financial interest, ownership and control the individual maintains over the corporation, and whether the corporation has been used for personal purposes.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Incomplete instruction on alter ego probably caused rendition of improper judgment.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: Real Colors, Inc. v. Patel
Court: United States District Court, N.D. Illinois, Eastern Division.
Headnote: In determining whether unity of interest and ownership exists between corporation and its shareholders, so as to allow for piercing of corporate veil under Illinois law, factors to be considered, with none determinative, include (1) inadequate capitalization, (2) failure to issue stock, (3) failure to observe corporate formalities, (4) non-payment of dividends, (5) insolvency of the debtor corporation at the time, (6) non-functioning of other officers or directors, (7) absence of corporate records, and (8) whether the corporation is a mere facade for the operation of dominant stockholders.
Document Preview: Buyer of dyes sued seller, alleging breach of contract and tortious interference with buyer's contract with its customer. Seller counterclaimed, seeking payment of amounts due under contract. Parties made summary judgment motions. The District Court, Keys, United States Magistrate Judge, held that: (1) failure to file statements of facts deemed undisputed, pursuant to local rule, in connection with earlier motions in present case did not preclude ability to bring counterclaim in present case; (2) seller did not breach any exclusive dealing agreement by selling dyes directly to buyer's customer; (3) seller did not tortiously interfere with contract between buyer and its customer; (4) buyer was required to pay for dyes delivered and accepted before any conduct alleged to constitute interference with contract began; (5) there was fact question, precluding summary judgment, as to whether seller agreed to reduce price on one shipment by $1,000; and (6) corporate veil of buyer would not...

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: Com. v. Vienna Health Products, Inc.
Court: Commonwealth Court of Pennsylvania.
Headnote: Factors which may justify disregarding the corporate form and holding the shareholders liable for corporate debts include intermingling of personal and corporate affairs, undercapitalization, failure to adhere to corporate formalities, or using the corporate form to perpetrate a fraud.
Document Preview: CRIMINAL JUSTICE - Double Jeopardy. Commonwealth could not recover corporation's unpaid fines from shareholder who was convicted of same crimes.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: Bob's Beverage, Inc. v. ACME, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, N.D. Ohio, Eastern Division.
Headnote: Avoiding personal liability is a proper purpose, which does not support disregarding corporate form under Ohio law, for forming a corporation.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: BioCore, Inc. v. Khosrowshahi
Court: United States District Court, D. Kansas.
Headnote: Under Kansas law, factors considered significant in justifying a disregard of the corporate entity are (1) undercapitalization of a one-man corporation, (2) failure to observe corporate formalities, (3) nonpayment of dividends, (4) siphoning of corporate funds by the dominant stockholder, (5) nonfunctioning of other officers or directors, (6) absence of corporate records, (7) use of the corporation as a facade for operations of the dominant stockholder or stockholders, and (8) use of the corporate entity in promoting injustice or fraud.
Document Preview: Corporation producing medical chemicals, with its principal office in Kansas, sued former officer in federal district court for the Southern District of New York, alleging various tort and contract claims. Following transfer to federal district court in Kansas, former officer counterclaimed. Summary judgment motions were made. The District Court, Vratil, J., held that: (1) Kansas statute governing suit against shareholders following unsatisfied judgment against corporation did not apply to suit seeking piercing of corporate veil; (2) there was personal jurisdiction over Kansas citizen, who was chief executive officer of employer, under New York long-arm statute, as required for court to have jurisdiction over suit commenced in federal court in New York and transferred to federal court in Kansas; (3) exercise of personal jurisdiction was consistent with due process; (4) fact question whether corporations amenable to personal jurisdiction in New York were alter ego of another Kansas...

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: In re Maxx Race Cards, Inc.
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, W.D. North Carolina, Charlotte Division.
Headnote: North Carolina courts consider numerous factors in determining whether third party exercises sufficient control over corporation to pierce corporate veil, including: inadequate capitalization; non-compliance with corporate formalities; complete domination and control; any excessive fragmentation, non-payment of dividends, insolvency of debtor corporation, siphoning of funds by dominant shareholder, non-functioning of other officers or directors, and absence of corporate records.

Title: Johnson v. Exclusive Properties Unlimited
Court: Supreme Judicial Court of Maine.
Headnote: To determine whether a shareholder has abused the privilege of a separate corporate identity under the first prong of the veil piercing doctrine, courts weigh the following 12 factors: (1) common ownership; (2) pervasive control; (3) confused intermingling of business activity, assets, or management; (4) thin capitalization; (5) nonobservance of corporate formalities; (6) absence of corporate records; (7) no payment of dividends; (8) insolvency at the time of the litigated transaction; (9) siphoning away of corporate assets by the dominant shareholders; (10) nonfunctioning of officers and directors; (11) use of the corporation for transactions of the dominant shareholders; and (12) use of the corporation in promoting fraud.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Corporate veil piercing doctrine did not require a finding of fraud or illegality.

Title: Johnson v. Exclusive Properties Unlimited
Court: Supreme Judicial Court of Maine.
Headnote: Twelve factors to consider when determining whether a shareholder has abused the privilege of a separate corporate identity under the first prong of the veil piercing doctrine apply whether the defendant is a corporate shareholder or individual shareholder, although some factors may seem better suited to one inquiry than the other.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Corporate veil piercing doctrine did not require a finding of fraud or illegality.

Both third claimant and bank appealed.  The Court of Appeals, Diana Gribbon Motz, Circuit Judge, held that: (1) charterer and...

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: In re Lahiri
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, E.D. Pennsylvania.
Headnote: Factors to consider in deciding whether corporate veil should be pierced, or whether one corporation is the alter ego of another, include: ignoring corporate formalities; gross undercapitalization; lack of corporate records; non-functioning officers and directors; non-arms-length transactions; and day-to-day control sufficient to deprive alter ego of its corporate identity.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: Lippe v. Bairnco Corp.
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: Under New York law, corporate veil can be pierced where there has been, among other things, a failure to adhere to corporate formalities, inadequate capitalization, a use of corporate funds for personal purpose, an overlap in ownership and directorship, or common use of office space and equipment.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Avoidance. Affiliates were not liable for participating in fraudulent transfers.

Title: Riedel v. Steger Material Handling Co., Inc.
