Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: In re Blatstein
Court: United States District Court, E.D. Pennsylvania.
Headnote: In deciding whether to pierce corporate veil under Pennsylvania law, court should consider the following factors: whether corporation is grossly undercapitalized for its intended purpose; whether corporate formalities were followed; whether dividends were paid; whether corporation is insolvent; whether the dominant shareholder has siphoned funds; whether there exist other officers; and whether corporation is mere facade for the operations of dominant shareholder.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Claims. Court caps landlord's rent claim based on date premises were re-leased.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: People v. V & M Industries, Inc.
Court: Appellate Court of Illinois, Fifth District.
Headnote: In determining whether to disregard a corporate entity, a court should consider the following variables, with no single factor being determinative: (1) inadequate capitalization; (2) the failure to issue stock; (3) the failure to observe corporate formalities; (4) the payment of dividends; (5) the insolvency of the debtor corporation at the time; (6) the nonfunctioning of other corporate officers or directors; (7) the absence of corporate records; and (8) whether the corporation is a mere facade for the operation of dominant stockholders.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Evidence supported piercing of corporate veil as to corporate polluter.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: George Hyman Const. Co. v. Gateman
Court: United States District Court, D. Massachusetts.
Headnote: A business can have a legitimate purpose, for purposes of piercing corporate veil under Massachusetts law, even if it is not designed to make dividend payments or profit distributions.
Document Preview: General contractor brought action against demolition subcontractor, which did not pay its vendors, and subcontractor's shareholders. Shareholders filed counterclaim for unfair and deceptive trade practices. The District Court, Saris, J., held that: (1) shareholders could not be held liable for corporate debts by virtue of piercing the corporate veil; (2) general contractor failed to state claim for fraud; (3) shareholders' conduct in transferring money from subcontractor to related corporation was not an unfair and deceptive business practice; and (4) general contractor's suit was not baseless, so as to constitute an unfair and deceptive trade practice. So ordered.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: George Hyman Const. Co. v. Gateman
Court: United States District Court, D. Massachusetts.
Headnote: For purposes of piercing corporate veil under Massachusetts law, siphoning of corporate assets should not be confused with drawing salaries and receiving certain benefits.
Document Preview: General contractor brought action against demolition subcontractor, which did not pay its vendors, and subcontractor's shareholders. Shareholders filed counterclaim for unfair and deceptive trade practices. The District Court, Saris, J., held that: (1) shareholders could not be held liable for corporate debts by virtue of piercing the corporate veil; (2) general contractor failed to state claim for fraud; (3) shareholders' conduct in transferring money from subcontractor to related corporation was not an unfair and deceptive business practice; and (4) general contractor's suit was not baseless, so as to constitute an unfair and deceptive trade practice. So ordered.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: George Hyman Const. Co. v. Gateman
Court: United States District Court, D. Massachusetts.
Headnote: When determining whether to pierce corporate veil under Massachusetts law, the relevant factors are weighed, not counted.
Document Preview: General contractor brought action against demolition subcontractor, which did not pay its vendors, and subcontractor's shareholders. Shareholders filed counterclaim for unfair and deceptive trade practices. The District Court, Saris, J., held that: (1) shareholders could not be held liable for corporate debts by virtue of piercing the corporate veil; (2) general contractor failed to state claim for fraud; (3) shareholders' conduct in transferring money from subcontractor to related corporation was not an unfair and deceptive business practice; and (4) general contractor's suit was not baseless, so as to constitute an unfair and deceptive trade practice. So ordered.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: Lorenz v. Beltio, Ltd.
Court: Supreme Court of Nevada.
Headnote: Some factors to be considered when determining if a unity exists in an alter ego analysis include, but are not limited to, commingling of funds, undercapitalization, unauthorized diversion of funds, treatment of corporate assets as the individual's own, and failure to observe corporate formalities; however, no one of these factors alone is determinative to apply the alter ego doctrine.
Document Preview: Landlords brought action against tenant for a declaratory judgment that lease for motel property was terminated and seeking damages for waste committed on property. After corporation to which tenant purportedly assigned lease filed bankruptcy and bankruptcy court lifted automatic stay, the Second Judicial District Court, Washoe County, Brent T. Adams, J., entered judgment in favor of landlords, but refused to pierce corporate veil to hold its shareholders personally liable. On cross-appeals, the Supreme Court held that: (1) evidence was sufficient to support finding that landlords' re-entry of leased motel premises terminated lease; (2) tenant's assignment of lease to corporation was effective prior to landlords' termination of lease; (3) assignment did not eliminate effectiveness of landlords' termination of lease, rendering corporation a holdover-tenant liable for damages; (4) district court's order did not violate automatic stay in corporation's...

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: Falcon Associates, Inc. v. Cox
Court: Appellate Court of Illinois, Fifth District.
Headnote: In determining whether to disregard a corporate entity, a court should consider a number of variables, with no single factor being determinative; such variables include: (1) inadequate capitalization, (2) the failure to issue stock, (3) the failure to observe corporate formalities, (4) the payment of dividends, (5) the insolvency of the debtor corporation at the time, (6) the nonfunctioning of other corporate officers or directors, (7) the absence of corporate records, and (8) whether the corporation is a mere facade for the operation of dominant stockholders.
Document Preview: REAL PROPERTY - Vendor and Purchaser. Homebuilder-vendor was potentially liable under Consumer Fraud and Deceptive Business Practices Act to purchasers of home even absent intent to deceive.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: Liberty Mut. Ins. Co. v. Leroy Holding Co., Inc.
Court: United States District Court, N.D. New York.
Headnote: Factors used under New York law to determine whether party against whom corporate veil is sought to be pierced exercised complete domination over corporation include: (1) absence of corporate formality in dominated company; (2) inadequate capitalization; (3) whether funds are put in or taken out of corporation for other than corporate purposes; (4) overlap in ownership, officers, directors, and personnel; (5) common office space, addresses and telephone numbers; (6) amount of business discretion dominated company possesses; (7) whether corporations deal at arms length; (8) whether corporations are treated as independent profit centers; (9) payment or guarantee of debts of dominated corporation; and (10) whether dominated corporation's property was used by other as if it were its own.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Attorney Fees. No award of attorney fees against creditor for automatic stay violation.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: Browning-Ferris Industries of Illinois, Inc. v. Ter Maat
Court: United States District Court, N.D. Illinois, Western Division.
Headnote: Under Illinois law, in determining whether to disregard a corporate entity, court considers a number of factors, including: (1) inadequate capitalization; (2) failure to issue stock; (3) failure to observe corporate formalities; (4) nonpayment of dividends; (5) insolvency of the debtor corporation at the time; (6) nonfunctioning of other officers or directors; (7) absence of corporate records; (8) whether the corporation is a mere facade for the operation of dominant stockholders; and (9) whether dominant individuals commingled corporate funds with personal funds or preferred themselves as creditors.
Document Preview: Former landfill operator brought action against subsequent corporate landfill operator, subsequent corporate transporter, and officer of subsequent operator and transporter under Comprehensive Environmental Response, Compensation and Liability Act (CERCLA) and Declaratory Judgment Act, seeking monetary damages for past and future costs incurred to respond to environmental contamination at landfill. The District Court, Reinhard, J., held that: (1) transporter was directly liable as operator; (2) officer was not individually liable under CERCLA as operator, pursuant to state veil-piercing theory; (3) affidavit of former operator's employee concerning type of waste hauled to landfill was admissible as nonhearsay admission by party opponent; (4) oversight costs of Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) and Illinois Environmental Protection Agency (IEPA) were recoverable under CERCLA; (5) subsequent operator, transporter, and site owners were responsible for costs of emergency removal...

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: Huard v. Shreveport Pirates, Inc.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Fifth Circuit.
Headnote: In determining whether to apply alter ego doctrine under Louisiana law, totality of circumstances must be considered; however, factors usually considered relevant in evaluating adherence to corporate formalities are: (1) commingling of corporate and shareholder funds; (2) failure to follow statutory formalities for incorporating and transacting corporate affairs; (3) undercapitalization; (4) failure to provide separate bank accounts and bookkeeping records; and (5) failure to hold regular shareholder and director meetings.
Document Preview: Former vice president and head coach for football team brought suits against team and its sole owner arising out of their termination.  Actions were consolidated.  The United States District Court for the Western District of Louisiana, Donald E. Walter, J., refused to impose personal liability on owner, and plaintiffs appealed.  The Court of Appeals, Dennis, Circuit Judge, held that: (1) there was insufficient evidence of fraud to pierce corporate veil on that basis, and (2) there was insufficient evidence of disregard of corporate formalities to support piercing of corporate veil on that basis. Affirmed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: Miranda v. Smyrna Building Corp.
Court: Civil Court, City of New York, Richmond County.
Headnote: Factors necessary to determine domination and control, for purposes of piercing the corporate veil, included, but not limited to, the absence of formalities which are part of the corporate existence, inadequate capitalization, absence of assets, liabilities, or income, personal use of corporate funds, shuttling personal funds in and out of the corporation, the perpetration of fraud by means of the corporate vehicle, and the existence of post-tort activity conducted to strip the corporation of assets in anticipation of impending legal liability.
Document Preview: REAL PROPERTY - Vendor and Purchaser. Vendor breached its contract with purchasers by failing to provide tax abatements.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: In re Cassis
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, N.D. Iowa.
Headnote: Corporation's existence is presumed to be separate, but can be disregarded if: (1) corporation is undercapitalized, (2) without separate books, (3) its finances are not kept separate from individual finances, and individual obligations are paid by corporation, (4) corporation is used to promote fraud or illegality, (5) corporate formalities are not followed, or (6) corporation is merely a sham.
Document Preview: Discharge - Alleged fraudulent transfer ofcorporate property supported neither denial of Chapter 7 debtor-individuals' discharge nor avoidance of the transfer.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: Pirelli Armstrong Tire Corp. v. Titan Tire Corp.
Court: United States District Court, C.D. Illinois.
Headnote: In determining whether to pierce corporate veil, Illinois courts consider: (1) inadequate capitalization; (2) failure to observe corporate formalities; (3) commingling of funds; (4) absence of corporate records; and (5) failure to maintain arm's-length relationships among related entities.
Document Preview: Tire manufacturer brought action against buyer of its plant and buyer's parent company alleging violations of federal trademark laws and Illinois Uniform Deceptive Trade Practices Act, deceptive trade practices, unfair competition, and breach of asset purchase and intellectual property agreements. On parties' cross-motions for summary judgment, the District Court, Richard Mills, J., held that: (1) piercing of corporate veil was not warranted; (2) trademarks were valid; (3) manufacturer's claims were not barred by doctrines of estoppel or laches; (4) defendant infringed and diluted manufacturer's trademarks; (5) defendant unlawfully passed off its tires as those of manufacturer; and (6) defendant breached asset purchase and intellectual property agreements. Judgment for tire manufacturer against competitor.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: Hiller Cranberry Products, Inc. v. Koplovsky Foods, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, D. Massachusetts.
Headnote: In determining whether to pierce the corporate veil, Massachusetts courts consider twelve factors: (1) common ownership; (2) pervasive control; (3) confused intermingling of business activity, assets or management; (4) insufficient capitalization for purposes of the corporate undertaking; (5) nonobservance of corporate formalities; (6) nonpayment of dividends; (7) insolvency of corporation at the time of the transaction; (8) siphoning of corporate funds by the dominant shareholders; (9) nonfunctioning of officers and directors other than the shareholders; (10) absence of corporate records; (11) use of the corporation for transactions of the dominant shareholders; and (12) use of the corporation in promoting fraud.
Document Preview: Cranberry supplier, who had not received payment, brought action against buyer, buyer's controlling shareholder, and company to which buyer had delivered the cranberries, asserting claims under the Perishable Agricultural Commodities Act (PACA), for misrepresentation, and for violations of the Massachusetts Fraudulent Conveyance Act and the Massachusetts Unfair Trade Practices Act.  The District Court, Harrington, J., held that: (1) supplier was not entitled to PACA trust protection; (2) alter-ego theory did not apply, so as to impose liability for debt on either shareholder or transferee company; (3) shareholder was not liable for any misrepresentation; and (4) shareholder's transfers of property were not fraudulent conveyances. So ordered.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: Jean Anderson Hierarchy of Agents v. Allstate Life Ins. Co.
Court: United States District Court, E.D. Pennsylvania.
Headnote: Relevant factors to consider in deciding whether the corporate "veil" should be pierced include: a failure to observe corporate formalities; nonpayment of dividends; the insolvency of corporation; a siphoning of corporate funds by the dominant stockholder; the nonfunctioning of other officers or directors; a lack of corporate records; the fact that the corporation is merely a facade for the operations of dominant stockholder or stockholders; and the gross corporate undercapitalization.
Document Preview: Former executive sales director of insurance company brought action challenging company's alleged discriminatory conduct regarding the payment of commissions and earned persistency bonuses.  On motion to dismiss for failure to state claim, the District Court, Joyner, J., held that: (1) allegations in former sales director's complaint were not sufficient to state claim against insurance company's sister or parent corporations or against the parent's corporate parent; (2) allegations were sufficient to state claim against insurer under the Fair Labor Standards Act/Equal Pay Act and under Title VII; and (3) allegations were not sufficient to state a claim under Pennsylvania law for the intentional infliction of emotional distress or for punitive damages. So ordered.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: Chemtall, Inc. v. Citi-Chem, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, S.D. Georgia, Savannah Division.
Headnote: Sole shareholder status is insufficient in itself to allow for piercing of corporate veil, under Georgia law; there must be evidence of abuse of corporate form.
Document Preview: Supplier of goods sued corporation which was buyer, and its principal, seeking payment.  Supplier moved to strike principal's answer.  The District Court, Edenfield, J., held that: (1) court had jurisdiction over principal; (2) corporate veil would be pierced to impose liability of corporation on principal; (3) claim of misappropriation of corporate assets did not belong to bankruptcy estate, and could be pursued by supplier against principal during pendency of corporation's bankruptcy; and (4) conduct of principal warranted striking of answer. Motion to strike granted.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: Saint Joseph Hosp. v. Berks County Board of Assessment Appeals
Court: Commonwealth Court of Pennsylvania.
Headnote: Corporate form may be disregarded in situations where there is gross undercapitalization, failure to adhere to corporate formalities, substantial intermingling of personal and corporate affairs, and the use of the corporate form to perpetrate a fraud.
Document Preview: TAXATION - Real Property. Hospital was purely public charity entitled to exemption from real estate taxes.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: Middleton v. Parish of Jefferson
Court: Court of Appeal of Louisiana, Fifth Circuit.
Headnote: Shareholder status is not the only element used in determining if veil piercing is appropriate; courts also consider other factors including, but not limited to: (1) commingling of corporate and shareholder funds; (2) failure to follow statutory formalities for incorporating and transacting corporate affairs; (3) undercapitalization; (4) failure to provide separate bank accounts and booking records; and (5) failure to hold regular shareholder and director meetings.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. President and corporation were the same party for purposes of res judicata.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: Keams v. Tempe Technical Institute, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, D. Arizona.
Headnote: Under Arizona law, while corporate status is not lightly disregarded, courts will pierce corporate veil and impose personal liability if business is conducted on personal rather than corporate basis, and if business was established without adequate financial basis.
Document Preview: Former students at for-profit vocational school sued school, its owner, its officers, and issuer and purchaser of student loans in Superior Court of Maricopa, alleging common law fraud, consumer fraud, and state racketeering in connection with school's failure to provide education, housing, and job placement assistance.  Upon removal of action to federal court, individual defendants, issuer, and purchaser moved for summary judgment.  The District Court, Silver, J., held that: (1) bank's processing of applications for student loans did not constitute ratification of school's allegedly fraudulent actions; (2) bank had no special relationship with students as required for finding that bank owed students duty of care in its processing of applications; (3) under Arizona law, as predicted by district court, bank had no independent legal duty to disclose to students any knowledge it might have had with respect to school's financial irregularities;...

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: In re Circle Land and Cattle Corp.
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, D. Kansas.
Headnote: Under Kansas law, courts look to eight factors in deciding whether shareholder has so dominated a corporation that corporate veil should be pierced: (1) undercapitalization of what is a one-man corporation; (2) failure to observe corporate formalities; (3) nonpayment of dividends; (4) siphoning of corporate funds by dominant shareholder; (5) nonfunctioning of other officers or directors; (6) absence of corporate records; (7) use of corporation as facade for operation of dominant shareholder or shareholders; and (8) use of corporate entity in promoting injustice or fraud.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Case Administration. Veil-piercing factors alleged by creditor did not warrant substantive consolidation of Chapter 11 debtor with alleged corporate alter ego.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: Fleming Companies, Inc. v. Rich
Court: United States District Court, E.D. Missouri, Eastern Division.
Headnote: To justify piercing corporate veil on "instrumentality" theory, plaintiff must show: (1) not mere majority or complete stock control, but complete domination, not only of finances, but of policy and business practice with respect to transaction attacked such that the corporate entity, as to this transaction, had at time no separate mind, will or existence of its own; (2) use of such control by defendant to commit fraud or wrong, to perpetrate violation of statutory or other positive legal duty, or dishonest and unjust act in contravention of plaintiff's legal rights; and (3) that aforesaid control and breach of duty proximately caused injury or unjust loss complained of.
Document Preview: Judgment creditors brought action for creditor's bill to enforce judgments previously entered against corporate entities by having certain conveyances voided as fraudulent and by piercing corporate veil.  The District Court, Limbaugh, J., held that: (1) passage of the Missouri Uniform Fraudulent Transfer Act (MoUFTA) was not meant to extinguish long-standing equitable remedy of creditor's bill, as remedy available to creditor to set aside transfer by debtor on ground of fraud; (2) grocery store's rental payments to parents of its director and sole shareholder, pursuant to renewal of alleged lease on which no rent had ever been paid, were made with actual intent to hinder, delay, or defraud creditors; (3) transaction by which insolvent grocery store pledged certificate of deposit as substitute collateral to obtain release of certificate of deposit belonging to its director's parents was likewise void as fraudulent conveyance; and (4) corporate veil could be...

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: Fleming Companies, Inc. v. Rich
Court: United States District Court, E.D. Missouri, Eastern Division.
Headnote: To determine whether corporate veil should be pierced under Missouri law, courts consider various indicators, including whether the corporation operated without sufficient funds to meet its obligations, transfer by debtor corporation of its property to second corporation when both are controlled by same person, and/or the manipulation or stripping of assets to avoid demands of creditors.
Document Preview: Judgment creditors brought action for creditor's bill to enforce judgments previously entered against corporate entities by having certain conveyances voided as fraudulent and by piercing corporate veil.  The District Court, Limbaugh, J., held that: (1) passage of the Missouri Uniform Fraudulent Transfer Act (MoUFTA) was not meant to extinguish long-standing equitable remedy of creditor's bill, as remedy available to creditor to set aside transfer by debtor on ground of fraud; (2) grocery store's rental payments to parents of its director and sole shareholder, pursuant to renewal of alleged lease on which no rent had ever been paid, were made with actual intent to hinder, delay, or defraud creditors; (3) transaction by which insolvent grocery store pledged certificate of deposit as substitute collateral to obtain release of certificate of deposit belonging to its director's parents was likewise void as fraudulent conveyance; and (4) corporate veil could be...

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: In re Main, Inc.
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, E.D. Pennsylvania.
Headnote: Under Pennsylvania law, factors to consider in determining whether corporate veil can be pierced include: (1) failure to observe corporate formalities; (2) nonpayment of corporate dividends; (3) insolvency of corporation at time of significant action or transaction; (4) siphoning of corporate funds by dominant shareholder; (5) nonfunctioning of other officers or directors of corporation; (6) lack or absence of corporate records; (7) fact that corporation is merely a sham for operations of dominant stockholder(s); and (8) fact that corporation is undercapitalized.
Document Preview: Business Organizations. Corporate veil could not be pierced, so as to bring debtor-corporations' assets into bankruptcy estate of individual Chapter 7 debtor.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: American Fuel Corp. v. Utah Energy Development Co., Inc.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Second Circuit.
Headnote: In identifying "dominated" corporation whose veil may be pierced under New York law, court considers whether corporate formalities are observed, whether capitalization is adequate, whether funds are put in and taken out of corporation for personal rather than corporate purposes, whether there is overlap in ownership, officers, directors, and personnel, whether corporate entities share common office space, address, and telephone numbers, amount of business discretion displayed by allegedly dominated corporation, whether alleged dominator deals with dominated corporation at arms length, whether corporation is treated as independent profit center, whether others pay or guarantee debts of dominated corporation, and whether corporation in question had property that was used by alleged dominator as if it were dominator's own.
Document Preview: After corporation and its president brought action alleging that defendant breached its employment contract with president and its separate contract with corporation, defendant moved to compel arbitration pursuant to arbitration clause in president's employment contract.  The United States District Court for the Southern District of New York, Sonia Sotomayor, J., 1996 WL 396131, granted motion.  Corporation appealed.  The Court of Appeals, Winter, Chief Judge, held that corporation was not bound by arbitration clause. Reversed and vacated.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: Genetic Implant Systems, Inc. v. Core-Vent Corp.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Federal Circuit.
Headnote: Under Washington law, court may disregard corporate form only if principal personally participates in alleged wrongful conduct or approves conduct.
Document Preview: Manufacturer of dental implants brought action against competitor and competitor's president, requesting declaratory judgment of noninfringement and invalidity of competitor's patent.  The United States District Court for the Western District of Washington, Thomas S. Zilly, J., dismissed for lack of personal jurisdiction, and manufacturer appealed.  The Court of Appeals, Lourie, Circuit Judge, held that: (1) competitor had sufficient contacts with state to support personal jurisdiction; (2) exercise of jurisdiction over competitor was reasonable; but (3) district court lacked jurisdiction over president. Affirmed in part and reversed in part.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: Ditty v. CheckRite, Ltd., Inc.
Court: United States District Court, D. Utah, Central Division.
Headnote: Under Utah law, factors to consider whether to pierce corporate veil under alter ego doctrine include undercapitalization of close corporation, failure to observe corporate formalities, siphoning of corporate funds by dominant shareholder, nonfunctioning of other officers or directors and use of corporation as facade for operations of dominant shareholder.
Document Preview: Makers of dishonored checks brought action against collection agency, agency's law firm and attorney in firm alleging violations of Fair Debt Collection Practices Act (FDCPA) and Fair Credit Reporting Act (FCRA).  Both parties moved for summary judgment.  The District Court, Campbell, J., held that: (1) dishonored check was debt for purposes of FDCPA; (2) firm collected fee from makers which violated dishonored instruments statute and FDCPA; (3) firm's letter complied with validation notice requirement under FDCPA; (4) firm violated FDCPA by using deceptive collection practices; (5) issues of material fact precluded summary judgment; (6) firm was not consumer reporting agency for purposes of FCRA; (7) agency was liable as principal for illegal collection activities of its agent-law firm; (8) attorney was debt collector and was personally liable under FDCPA; (9) injunctive relief was not available to makers; and (10) FDCPA did not apply to checks issued in connection...

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: Ost-West-Handel Bruno Bischoff GmbH v. Project Asia Line, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, E.D. Virginia, Norfolk Division. .
Headnote: Generally, corporation's distinct identity should be upheld unless there are specific, unusual circumstances that call for court to look behind or beyond the corporate structure, and it is burden of party challenging corporate identity to establish such circumstances by clear and convincing evidence.
Document Preview: Vessel owner filed complaint against charterer of another vessel in personam, and against the other vessel in rem, seeking to attach the vessel and its bunkers, based on claim that charterer had failed to pay amounts owing pursuant to charter party involving its vessel. Bank filed intervening complaint seeking to foreclose and assert first preferred Liberian ship mortgage on vessel. Third claimant filed claim for amounts owing on time charter involving third vessel. After arrested vessel was sold, bench trial was conducted to resolve respective priorities among claimants. The District Court, MacKenzie, Senior District Judge, held that: (1) evidence that attorney retained to organize corporation which was registered owner of arrested vessel and to facilitate sale of vessel billed work to charterer which managed vessel, and that chief financial officer of charterer had brief tenure as president of registered owner, was insufficient to find that charterer and...

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: Trans-World Intern., Inc. v. Smith-Hemion Productions, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, C.D. California.
Headnote: Alter ego analysis under Delaware law must start with examination of factors which reveal how corporation operates and particular defendant's relationship to that operation; factors include whether corporation was adequately capitalized, whether corporation was solvent, whether dividends were paid, corporate records kept, officers and directors functioned properly, and other corporate formalities were observed, whether dominant shareholder siphoned corporate funds, and whether, in general, corporation simply functioned as facade for dominant shareholder.
Document Preview: Production company sued musical performers in family group and performers' corporation, alleging promissory estoppel, fraud, and alter ego claims arising out of cancelled televised performance.  After mistrial, plaintiff dismissed fraud claim and parties submitted claims to court based on record created during trial.  The District Court, Laughlin E. Waters, Senior District Judge, held that: (1) production company failed to establish promissory estoppel claim against performer who stated intent to appear on show; (2) dismissal of fraud claim did not preclude alter ego claims; and (3) performers were not alter egos of corporation. So ordered.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: Garcia v. Coffman
Court: Court of Appeals of New Mexico.
Headnote: Requirements for piercing corporate veil are instrumentality or domination; improper purpose, and proximate cause.
Document Preview: Patient sued chiropractor and his corporation, alleging scheme to provide excessive services and charge excessive fees.  The District Court, Bernalillo County, Susan M. Conway, D.J., awarded nominal damages and punitive damages for fraudulent misrepresentation and breach of fiduciary duty, and awarded attorney fees.  Appeal was taken.  The Court of Appeals, Flores, J., held that: (1) patient could pierce corporate veil and recover directly from chiropractor; (2) patient could not recover for both breach of fiduciary duty and fraudulent misrepresentation; (3) punitive damages were recoverable; and (4) attorney fees were recoverable. Affirmed in part; reversed ion part. Hartz, C.J., concurred specially and filed opinion.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: Haywood v. Louisiana Sugar Cane Products
Court: Court of Appeal of Louisiana, Third Circuit.
Headnote: Generally, grounds for piercing corporate veil under the alter ego doctrine include, but are not limited to: (1) corporation's failure to follow statutory corporate formalities, including conducting regular shareholder and directors meeting; (2) commingling of shareholders' assets with those of corporation; (3) failure to maintain separate bank accounts and records; and (4) undercapitalization of corporation such that it would not have sufficient funds necessary to do business or meet reasonably expected risks.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Corporate Veil. Incorporated, nonprofit cooperative marketing association was not alter ego of its member sugar mill cooperatives, and cooperatives could not be held liable for personal injuries sustained by worker on association's property.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: Barton v. Moore
Court: Supreme Court of Minnesota.
Headnote: In deciding whether shareholder can be liable for corporate obligations on veil-piercing theory, court employs two-pronged test that focuses first on shareholder's relationship to corporation and then on whether veil piercing is necessary to avoid injustice or fundamental unfairness.
Document Preview: Lenders brought suit to recover from corporation and corporate shareholders, on alter ego and direct liability theory, for alleged breach of loan agreement, and defendants moved to dismiss for failure to state claim on which relief could be granted.  The District Court, Allan R. Markert, J., granted defendants' motion, and plaintiffs appealed.  The Court of Appeals, Kalitowski, J., 1996 WL 33099, reversed, and defendants appealed.  The Supreme Court, Gardebring, J., held that: (1) allegations in lenders' complaint were sufficient to state veil-piercing claim, and (2) statute specifically limiting the interest rate of loans for business or agricultural purposes provided exclusive remedy for business borrowers who obtained loans found to be usurious under statute. Judgment of Court of Appeals, affirmed; case remanded.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: Barton v. Moore
Court: Supreme Court of Minnesota.
Headnote: Factors that court considers in deciding whether relationship between shareholder and corporation is such as to permit piercing of corporate veil include whether there is insufficient capitalization for purposes of corporate undertaking, failure to observe corporate formalities, nonpayment of dividends, insolvency of debtor corporation at time of transaction in question, siphoning of funds by dominant shareholder, nonfunctioning of other officers and directors, absence of corporate records, and existence of corporation as mere facade for individual dealings.
Document Preview: Lenders brought suit to recover from corporation and corporate shareholders, on alter ego and direct liability theory, for alleged breach of loan agreement, and defendants moved to dismiss for failure to state claim on which relief could be granted.  The District Court, Allan R. Markert, J., granted defendants' motion, and plaintiffs appealed.  The Court of Appeals, Kalitowski, J., 1996 WL 33099, reversed, and defendants appealed.  The Supreme Court, Gardebring, J., held that: (1) allegations in lenders' complaint were sufficient to state veil-piercing claim, and (2) statute specifically limiting the interest rate of loans for business or agricultural purposes provided exclusive remedy for business borrowers who obtained loans found to be usurious under statute. Judgment of Court of Appeals, affirmed; case remanded.

Title: Weaver v. Kellogg
Court: United States District Court, S.D. Texas, Houston Division.
Headnote: Under Delaware law, in deciding whether corporate veil should be pierced, court may look to the following factors: whether corporation was adequately capitalized and solvent; whether corporate formalities were followed, including payment of dividends and upkeep of corporate records; whether dominant shareholders siphoned corporate funds; and whether corporation is mere facade for dominant shareholders.
Document Preview: Avoidance. Promissory note transactions, pursuant to which Chapter 11 debtor's shareholders executed replacement notes, were transfers, for fraudulent transfer purposes.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: Barnco Intern., Inc. v. Arkla, Inc.
Court: Court of Appeal of Louisiana, Second Circuit.
Headnote: Indicia of disregard of corporate formalities, which warrants pierce of corporate veil, include undercapitalization, commingling of corporate and shareholder funds, failing to follow statutory formalities for incorporating and transacting corporate affairs, failing to maintain separate bank accounts and bookkeeping records, and failing to hold regular shareholder and director meetings. (Per Hightower, J., with one Judge concurring in result and one Judge concurring in part and dissenting in part.)

Title: Birbara v. Locke
Court: United States Court of Appeals, First Circuit.
Headnote: In determining whether to pierce corporate veil, under Massachusetts law, courts may consider factors including insufficient capitalization, nonobservance of corporate formalities, failure to pay dividends, insolvency at time of litigated transaction, siphoning off corporate funds, absence of functioning officers besides dominant shareholders, absence of corporate records, use of corporation to advance interests of dominant shareholders, and use of corporation in promoting fraud.
Document Preview: Investors in subsidiary corporation brought suit against subsidiary, its parent and officers and directors of each, alleging breach of contract by subsidiary and asserting corporate veil piercing claim.  The United States District Court for the District of Massachusetts, Nathaniel M. Gorton, J., entered judgment on jury verdict against all defendants, and appeal was taken. The Court of Appeals, Lynch, Circuit Judge, held that requirements for piercing of corporate veil had not been satisfied. Reversed; jury verdict vacated.

Title: Bridgestone/Firestone, Inc. v. Recovery Credit Services, Inc.

The Court of Appeals, Winter, Circuit Judge, held that: (1) corporate veil could be pierced, to attribute liability of corporations to principal; (2) damages could be based upon rate of nonpayment taken from most recent year, and applying it to prior years, as defendants' own destruction of records for earlier years precluded more accurate damages estimates; (3) creditor failed to establish that principal had committed fraud when promising to honor contractual commitments; (4) contract provision calling for award of attorney fees when indemnification was involved, was not...

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: National Soffit & Escutcheons, Inc. v. Superior Systems, Inc.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Seventh Circuit.
Headnote: In determining whether corporate veil should be pierced, under Indiana law, court should consider whether there is evidence of (1) undercapitalization, (2) absence of corporate records, (3) fraudulent representation by corporation's shareholders or directors, (4) using corporation to promote fraud, injustice, or illegal activities, (5) payment by corporation of individual obligation, (6) commingling of assets or affairs, (7) failure to observe required formalities, or (8) other shareholder acts or conduct ignoring, controlling or manipulating corporate form.
Document Preview: Suit was brought against second corporation, to enforce state court judgment obtained against first corporation.  The United States District Court for the Northern District of Indiana, Robert L. Miller, Jr., J., granted summary judgment for second corporation and appeal was taken.  The Court of Appeals, Bauer, Circuit Judge, held that: (1) second corporation was not alter ego of first corporation, so as to allow for piercing of corporate veil, even though corporations had some officers in common and were in same line of business, and (2) second corporation was not successor of first corporation. Affirmed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: Broussard v. Meineke Discount Muffler Shops, Inc.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: Forum Ins. Co. v. Texarkoma Transp. Co.

Headnote: Corporate veil can be pierced where there has been, inter alia, failure to adhere to corporate formalities, inadequate capitalization, use of corporate funds for personal purpose, overlap in ownership and directorship, or common use of office space and equipment.

Title: Wilson v. Friedberg
Court: Court of Appeals of South Carolina.
Headnote: First prong of two-prong test for piercing corporate veil looks to observance of corporate formalities by dominant shareholder and consists of following factors: whether corporation was grossly undercapitalized; failure to observe corporate formalities; nonpayment of dividends; insolvency of corporation at time; siphoning of corporate funds by dominant stockholder; nonfunctioning of other officers or directors; absence of corporate records; and fact that corporation was merely facade for operations of dominant stockholder.

Title: Hart v. Steel Products, Inc.

Title: Knoll v. Butler

Title: Gonzales County Water Supply Corp. v. Jarzombek
Court: Court of Appeals of Texas, Corpus Christi-Edinburg.
Headnote: Courts will disregard corporate fiction and hold shareholders, officers and directors individually liable, even though corporate formalities have been observed and corporate and individual property have been kept separate, when corporate form has been used as part of basically unfair device to achieve inequitable result; specifically, where corporation or corporate fiction is used as means of perpetrating fraud; is organized and operated as mere tool or business conduit of another corporation; is resorted to as means of evading existing legal obligation; is employed to achieve or perpetrate monopoly; is used to circumvent statute; and is relied upon as protection of crime or to justify wrong.
Document Preview: Corporate Veil. Incorporated individual's purportedly inconsistent statements about organization of his drilling business did not warrant disregard of corporate form in breach of contract action.

Title: Sansone v. Moseley

Title: Ontel Products, Inc. v. Project Strategies Corp.

Title: Humphreys v. Medical Towers, Ltd.
Court: United States District Court, S.D. Texas.
Headnote: Under Texas law, alter ego status is shown by total dealings of corporation and individual, including degree to which corporate formalities have been followed and corporate and individual property have been kept separately, amount of financial interest, ownership and control the individual maintains over the corporation, and whether the corporation has been used for personal purposes.
Document Preview: Former building manager brought suit against employer, a limited partnership which owned the building, its general partner, and the president and sole shareholder of general partner.  Plaintiff asserted claims for intentional infliction of emotional distress, violations of Title VII and the Texas Commission on Human Rights Act (TCHRA) including sexual harassment, sex discrimination, and retaliation.  On defendants' motion for summary judgment, the District Court, Crone, United States Magistrate Judge, held that: (1) plaintiff failed to adduce facts sufficient to find extreme and outrageous conduct and severe emotional distress, as elements of intentional infliction of emotional distress claim under Texas law; (2) summary judgment was precluded on hostile work environment sexual harassment claim; (3) plaintiff's allegations were inadequate to raise fact issue concerning quid pro quo sexual harassment; (4) summary judgment was precluded on...

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: Beck v. Equine Estates Development Co.
Court: Court of Appeals of Iowa.
Headnote: A corporation's existence may be disregarded so as to make shareholders personally liable for corporate obligations if: the corporation is undercapitalized, it is without separate books, its finances are not kept separate from individual finances, individual obligations are paid by the corporation, the corporation is used to promote fraud or illegality, corporate formalities are not followed, or the corporation is merely a sham, and continued corporate activity by shareholders following administrative dissolution may also result in personal liability. I.C.A. § 490.622.
Document Preview: Purchasers of real estate sued vendor corporation, its two shareholders, and the assignee of corporation's interest in the land to recover prior payments on contract after vendor was unable to convey deed.  The District Court for Warren County, James W. Brown, J., entered judgment in favor of purchasers.  Defendants appealed.  The Court of Appeals, Huitink, J., held that: (1) there was not sufficient evidence to justify piercing vendor's corporate veil so as to hold officers personally liable for purchasers' damages, but (2) assignee of vendor's interest in real estate was liable for purchasers' damages. Affirmed in part, reversed in part.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: Alberto v. Diversified Group, Inc.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Fifth Circuit.
Headnote: Under Delaware law, numerous factors are pertinent to alter ego analysis, but no single factor can justify decision to disregard corporate entity.
Document Preview: Corporate Veil. Homeowners could not pierce corporate veil on developer or alter ego theory to hold parent liable for developer's debts.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: Pel-Star Energy, Inc. v. U.S. Dept. of Energy
Court: United States District Court, W.D. Louisiana, Shreveport Division. .
Headnote: Under Louisiana law, some factors considered by courts in determining propriety of piercing the corporate veil include, but are not limited to, commingling of corporate and shareholder funds, failure to follow statutory formalities for incorporating and transacting corporate affairs, undercapitalization, failure to provide separate bank accounts and bookkeeping records, and failure to hold regular shareholder and director meetings.
Document Preview: Corporate crude oil reseller and partial owner of reseller brought action seeking judicial review of Federal Energy Regulatory Commission (FERC) order finding owner personally liable, through piercing the corporate veil, for $4,663,852.89 in crude oil overcharges by reseller plus interest under crude oil antilayering regulations.  The District Court, Stagg, J., held that: (1) it would review order de novo, rather than under substantial evidence test; (2) Commission had jurisdiction to impose personal liability on owner for crude oil overcharges, despite fact that Commission was not Article III court; (3) federal law, rather than state law, governed its determination of propriety of Commission's decision to pierce the corporate veil; and (4) piercing of the corporate veil was improper. Reversed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: Muroll Gesellschaft M.B.H. v. Tennessee Tape, Inc.
Court: Court of Appeals of Tennessee, Middle Section, at Nashville.
Headnote: Conditions under which corporate entity will be disregarded vary according to circumstances present in the case, and matter is particularly within the province of trial court.
Document Preview: Corporate Veil. Fraudulent transaction between corporations owned by one shareholder justified piercing corporate veil.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: Muroll Gesellschaft M.B.H. v. Tennessee Tape, Inc.
Court: Court of Appeals of Tennessee, Middle Section, at Nashville.
Headnote: Each case involving disregard of the corporate entity must rest upon its special facts; generally, no one factor is conclusive in decision whether to disregard corporate entity.
Document Preview: Corporate Veil. Fraudulent transaction between corporations owned by one shareholder justified piercing corporate veil.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: Elgin Sweeper Co. v. Melson Inc.
Court: United States District Court, N.D. New York.
Headnote: Initially, some proof of fraud, whether actual or intended, must be offered before court can pierce the corporate veil, and the next step in determining appropriateness of piercing corporate veil is to analyze the following factors: ownership of stock, commonality of directors and officers, financial relationships between entities, and independence of subsidiary's directors or executives.
Document Preview: Action was brought against Canadian bank and former officers, directors or shareholders of certain related corporations, alleging fraudulent conveyance, breach of contract and breach of fiduciary duty under New York law, arising out of bank loan and series of intercompany transfers and defaulted obligations. On motion of defendants to dismiss or for summary judgment, the District Court, Scullin, J., held that: (1) application of Canadian law would not divest court of subject matter jurisdiction; (2) application of foreign country's law by itself would not constitute grounds for dismissal under doctrine of forum non conveniens; (3) no difference was shown between Ontario and New York law with respect to fraudulent conveyance claims, and thus New York law would be applied as the choice of law; (4) failure of plaintiff to obtain permission to proceed with action from Ontario court that adjudicated bankruptcy of debtor corporation, as...

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: Wolf v. Walt
Court: Supreme Court of Nebraska.
Headnote: Some of the relevant factors in determining whether to disregard corporate entity on basis of fraud are (1) grossly inadequate capitalization, (2) insolvency of debtor corporation at time debt is incurred, (3) diversion by shareholder or shareholders of corporate funds or assets to their own or other improper uses, and (4) fact that corporation is mere facade for personal dealings with shareholder and that operations of corporation are carried on by shareholder in disregard of corporate entity.
Document Preview: Lessor of cattle brought suit against sole shareholder of lessee, seeking recovery under theories of conversion, constructive fraud, breach of contract and bailment.  Claims were either dismissed by trial court or found against lessor by jury, and the District Court, Cuming County, Robert B. Ensz, J., entered judgment for lessee.  Appeal was taken.  The Supreme Court, Lanphier, J., held that: (1) corporate veil would not be pierced; (2) shareholder had not converted cattle; and (3) shareholder had not committed constructive fraud. Affirmed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: In re Hoffman Associates, Inc.
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, D. South Carolina.
Headnote: Under Fourth Circuit's DeWitt test, element of injustice or fundamental unfairness must exist before corporate veil may be pierced, and court's conclusion to disregard the corporate entity may not rest on single factor but, rather, must involve number of such factors, which include: whether corporation was grossly undercapitalized; whether there was failure to observe corporate formalities; whether there was nonpayment of dividends, insolvency of the debtor corporation, siphoning of corporation's funds by dominant stockholder, nonfunctioning of other officers or directors, or absence of corporate records; and whether corporation was merely facade for operations of the dominant stockholder.
Document Preview: Business Relationships. Chapter 7 trustee could pierce the debtor's corporate veil and hold controlling officer liable for all amounts due creditors of the debtor.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: Pine Tree Associates v. Doctors' Associates, Inc.
Court: Court of Appeal of Louisiana, First Circuit.
Headnote: With respect to concept of piercing corporate veil to reach alter ego, factors courts consider when determining whether to apply alter ego doctrine include, but are not limited to: comingling of corporate and shareholder funds; failure to follow statutory formalities for incorporating and transacting corporate affairs; under-capitalization; failure to provide separate bank accounts and bookkeeping records; and failure to hold regular shareholder and director meetings.
Document Preview: Piercing Veil. Allegation of fraud not required in contract suit for piercing of corporate veil.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: Markham v. Fay
Court: United States District Court, D. Massachusetts.
Headnote: Under Massachusetts law, 12 factors which should be considered in deciding whether to penetrate corporate form are: common ownership; pervasive control; confused intermingling of business assets, or management; thin capitalization; nonobservance of corporate formalities; absence of corporate records; no payment of dividends; insolvency at time of litigated transaction; siphoning away of corporate assets by dominant shareholder; nonfunctioning of officers and directors; use of corporation for transactions of dominant shareholder; and use of corporation in promoting fraud.
Document Preview: Trustee in bankruptcy filed interpleader action with regard to proceeds from sale of nursing homes held in name of debtor and mortgaged by corporation and trusts, after United States asserted interest in proceeds as holder of judgment based upon responsible person liability against president of corporation and settlor of trusts for nursing homes' unpaid withholding taxes.  The District Court, Collings, United States Magistrate Judge, held that: (1) memorandum of decision on summary judgment was law of case as to timeliness of government's claims and as to which law applied; (2) under Massachusetts law, corporation and trusts were not alter egos of president of corporation and settlor of trust, for purposes of veil piercing; (3) Internal Revenue Service (IRS), as creditor of settlor of trusts, was entitled as matter of law to such portion of interpled fund as represented proceeds from sale of nursing homes, as assets of trusts; and (4) declaration...

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: Scully Signal Co. v. Joyal
Court: United States District Court, D. Rhode Island.
Headnote: Under Massachusetts, Rhode Island, or New York law, it would be unjust and inequitable to recognize defendant corporation as separate and distinct corporate entity, and corporate veil would be pierced, where two individuals who served as incorporators of corporation and then as secretary and treasurer, and president, issued to themselves at incorporation an undetermined number of shares of common stock without any initial capital investment by either party, corporation did not receive any capital contributions from any source upon incorporating, corporation did not hold board of directors or shareholders meetings, official minutes were not kept, secretary-treasurer regularly paid disbursements and expenses incurred on behalf of corporation out of accounts held in the name of another corporate entity in which he possessed an interest, and corporation was incorporated for purpose of promoting fraud by infringing proprietary technology and trade secrets embodied in computerized fuel management software system.
Document Preview: Owner of computerized fuel management system sued incorporators and officers of entity formed to copy proprietary system, and sued developers of both systems, for misappropriation of trade secrets, breach of contract, intentional interference with contract, unfair competition, and deceptive trade practices and unjust enrichment.  Incorporators moved to dismiss based on lack of in personam jurisdiction and failure to state claim, and developers moved for partial summary judgment.  The District Court, Pettine, Senior District Judge, accepted report and recommendation of Lovegreen, United States Magistrate Judge, who recommended that: (1) owner be allowed to pierce corporate veil of defendant corporation; (2) personal jurisdiction existed over individual defendants who conceded jurisdiction over shell corporation; (3) incorporators were not entitled to summary judgment on intentional interference with contract claim; (4) defendants were...

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: In re Black
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, E.D. Texas, Sherman Division.
Headnote: Under Texas law, in order to warrant piercing of corporate veil, courts generally require evidence that corporate entity amounts to fraud, promotes injustice, or is relied on to justify wrong, that corporation was inadequately capitalized, that individual controls or manages entity in such manner that it becomes his alter ego, or that corporate formalities were not adhered to by corporation.
Document Preview: CORPORATIONS. Chapter 7 debtor president of Chapter 11 debtor in possession, was not personally liable for DIP's breach of fiduciary duty and willful malicious acts in using proceeds from sale of secured inventory to pay other expenses while under duty to remit proceeds to secured creditor.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: F.D.I.C. v. Hinch
Court: United States District Court, N.D. Oklahoma.
Headnote: Under Oklahoma law, corporation may be deemed to be mere instrumentality of individual if corporation is undercapitalized, without separate books, its finances are not kept separate from individual finances, individual obligations are paid by corporation or vice versa, corporate formalities are not followed, or corporation is merely a sham.
Document Preview: Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation (FDIC), in its corporate capacity, filed fraudulent transfer action seeking to set aside certain trusts and partnerships as shams in order to collect on judgments acquired from failed bank.  On defendants' motions to dismiss and for summary judgment, the District Court, Kern, J., held that: (1) fraudulent transfer provisions of Omnibus Crime Control Act of 1990 did not apply retroactively; (2) that FDIC acquired judgments from failed bank by means of bridge bank did not preclude FDIC's standing to pursue those judgments in fraudulent transfer action; (3) Oklahoma law did not require that judgment debtor be stockholder of corporation to justify reverse piercing of corporate veil; and (4) issues of fact precluded summary judgment in favor of FDIC or judgment debtor. Motions granted in part; denied in part.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: In re Mass
Court: United States District Court, M.D. Pennsylvania.
Headnote: Under Pennsylvania law, factors that are to be considered to determine whether corporate veil should be pierced under alter ego theory include: failure to observe corporate formalities; nonpayment of dividends; insolvency of corporation; siphoning of corporate funds by dominant shareholders; nonfunctioning of other officers or directors; absence of corporate records; and gross undercapitalization of corporation.
Document Preview: VEIL PIERCING. reverse piercing of corporate veil was appropriate, to make assets of debtor-shareholders' wholly owned corporation available for payment of creditors.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: In re Nutri/System of Florida Associates
Court: United States District Court, E.D. Pennsylvania.
Headnote: Factors to consider when deciding whether to pierce corporate veil include gross undercapitalization, failure to observe corporate formalities, nonpayment of dividends, insolvency, siphoning of corporate funds by dominant shareholders, nonfunctioning of other officers or directors, absence of corporate records, and fact that corporation is mere facade for operations of dominant shareholders.
Document Preview: LEASES AND EXECUTORY CONTRACTS. landlords could not recover administrative rents from purchasers of Chapter 11 debtor.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: Valley Mechanical Contractors, Inc. v. Gonzales
Court: Court of Appeals of Texas, Corpus Christi-Edinburg.
Headnote: Corporation's status as alter ego of individual may be established, for purposes of piercing corporate veil, based on total dealings of corporation and individual, including degree to which corporate formalities have been followed and corporate and individual property have been kept separate, amount of financial interest, ownership and control that individual maintains over corporation, and extent to which corporation has been used for personal purposes.
Document Preview: Veil Piercing. Corporation was mere alter ego of judgment debtor, whose bank accounts could be garnished.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: Michigan State Painters Ins. Fund v. Ron Simmons Painting, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, E.D. Michigan, Southern Division.
Headnote: Factors to be considered in determining whether corporate veil can be pierced include undercapitalization of corporation, maintenance of separate books, separation of corporate and individual finances, use of corporation to support fraud or illegality, honoring of corporate formalities, and whether corporation is merely a sham.
Document Preview: Employee benefit plans and labor union brought action under Employee Retirement Income Security Act (ERISA) against two painting contractors and their owners.  On motions for summary judgment by plans, union, first contractor, and first contractor's owner, the District Court, Gadola, J., held that: (1) fact issues existed as to whether contractors were joint employer, and (2) fact issues existed as to whether corporate veil of first contractor could be pierced so as to make its owner personally liable for contributions. Motions denied.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: National Automotive Trading Corp. of China v. Pioneer Trading Co., Inc.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Eighth Circuit.
Headnote: Factors tending to establish abuse of corporate privilege, as would warrant piercing corporate veil, include: corporation is undercapitalized, corporation lacked separate books, corporation's finances are not kept separate from individual finances or individual obligations are paid by corporation, corporation is used primarily to promote fraud or illegality, corporate formalities are not followed, and corporation is a mere sham.
Document Preview: In action against corporate and individual defendants, the United States District Court for the Southern District of Iowa, Harold D. Vietor, J., refused to pierce corporate veils to impose liability on individual defendants, and plaintiff appealed.  The Court of Appeals held that jury instruction accurately and fairly stated law governing piercing corporate veil. Affirmed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1043 In general >
Title: In re Rymsbran Continental Corp.
Court: United States District Court, E.D. New York.
Headnote: Under New York law, existence of overlapping staff and directors is only one factor to consider in determining whether a party has acted as alter ego for another.
Document Preview: RELIEF FROM DEFAULT. denial of lessors' motion for relief from default, on debtor-lessee's claim for $500,000 in damages, constituted abuse of discretion.
